Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Midson v. Meeting House Lane Medical Practice, P.C.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: The corporate veil will be pierced to achieve equity, even absent fraud, when a corporation has been so dominated by an individual or another corporation and its separate entity so ignored that it primarily transacts the dominator's business instead of its own and can be called the other's alter ego.
Document Preview: HEALTH  Malpractice. Physician who became patient's attending physician after diagnosis and beginning treatment was not liable for medical malpractice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Midson v. Meeting House Lane Medical Practice, P.C.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, generally considered are such factors as whether there is an overlap in ownership, officers, directors and personnel, inadequate capitalization, a commingling of assets, or an absence of separate paraphernalia that are part of the corporate form, such that one of the corporations is a mere instrumentality, agent and alter ego of the other.
Document Preview: HEALTH  Malpractice. Physician who became patient's attending physician after diagnosis and beginning treatment was not liable for medical malpractice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: First v. Rolling Plains Implement Company, Incorporated
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporations are distinct legal entities, and generally one corporation will not be held responsible for acts of another.
Document Preview: TORTS  Limitations. General evidence was not sufficient to show that actual fraud or constructive fraud claims were barred by statute of limitations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Haymount Urgent Care PC v. GoFund Advance, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In Connecticut, under first element of instrumentality rule for piercing corporate veil, by determining whether requisite level of control has been exercised, following factors are considered: (1) absence of corporate formalities, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes, (4) overlapping ownership, officers, directors, personnel, (5) common office space, address, phones, (6) amount of business discretion by allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether corporations dealt with each other at arm's length, (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) payment or guarantee of debts of dominated corporation, and (10) whether corporation had property that was used by other corporation as if it were its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Joint and several liability was justified under alter ego theory for breach of merchant cash advance agreements.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Wells Fargo Bank, N.A. v. Stewart Homes, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, courts consider various factors in assessing whether the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, including: inadequate capitalization, commingling of funds and other assets of the two entities, the holding out by one entity that it is liable for the debts of the other, identical equitable ownership in the two entities, use of the same offices and employees, use of one as a mere conduit for the affairs of the other, disregard of corporate formalities, lack of segregation of corporate records and identical directors and officers.
Document Preview: FINANCE AND BANKING  Attachment and Garnishment. Bank demonstrated probable validity of fraudulent transfer claim under California law, as required to issue writ of attachment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Caston v. F. Hoffmann-La Roche, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Alter ego relationship is shown where (1) two entities are so closely intertwined that their personalities blend, i.e., there is unity of interest, and (2) failure to disregard their separate identities would result in fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: HEALTH  Drugs. Federal law preempted state law claims against generic drug suppliers for failure to warn and misrepresentation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Caston v. F. Hoffmann-La Roche, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Factors that support a "unity of interest" between two entities, as required for the entities to be in an alter ego relationship, are inadequate capitalization of one entity, commingling funds, assets, and records, moving assets to one entity and liabilities to another, eschewing corporate formalities and arm's length negotiations, having common equity owners, officers, and directors, and sharing office space and employees.
Document Preview: HEALTH  Drugs. Federal law preempted state law claims against generic drug suppliers for failure to warn and misrepresentation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Pentacon BV v. Vanderhaegen
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, to assert alter-ego liability, a plaintiff must show that: (1) one entity exercised complete domination of another entity with respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in the plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Alleged sale of start-up after no sale period, which was planned during such period, did not violate no sale clause of share redemption agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Pentacon BV v. Vanderhaegen
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: New York courts consider the following factors to decide whether one entity exercised complete domination over another with respect to a transaction, as an element of alter-ego liability: (1) the absence of the formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the entity for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers; (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by the dominated entity; (7) whether the related entities deal with the dominated entity at arms length; (8) whether the entities are treated as independent profit centers; (9) the payment or guarantee of debts of the dominated entity by other entities in the group; and (10) whether the entity in question had property that was used by the other entity as if it were its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Alleged sale of start-up after no sale period, which was planned during such period, did not violate no sale clause of share redemption agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Bhatia v. Silvergate Bank
Court: United States District Court, S.D. California.
Headnote: To satisfy the test for showing one corporate entity is the alter ego of another, a plaintiff must make out a prima facie case (1) that there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the two entities no longer exist and (2) that failure to disregard their separate identities would result in fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: E-COMMERCE  Fraud. Cryptocurrency exchange customers adequately alleged exchange's bank had actual knowledge of exchange's fraud, as element of aiding and abetting.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Bhatia v. Silvergate Bank
Court: United States District Court, S.D. California.
Headnote: In assessing whether a plaintiff has made a prima facie showing that two entities have such unity of interest and ownership that their separate personalities no longer exist, as the first prong of the alter ego test, courts consider nine factors: (1) the commingling of funds and other assets of the entities, (2) the holding out by one entity that it is liable for the debts of the other, (3) identical equitable ownership of the entities, (4) use of the same offices and employees, (5) use of one as a mere shell or conduit for the affairs of the other, (6) inadequate capitalization, (7) disregard of corporate formalities, (8) lack of segregation of corporate records, and (9) identical directors and officers.
Document Preview: E-COMMERCE  Fraud. Cryptocurrency exchange customers adequately alleged exchange's bank had actual knowledge of exchange's fraud, as element of aiding and abetting.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Bhatia v. Silvergate Bank
Court: United States District Court, S.D. California.
Headnote: For purposes of assessing whether a plaintiff has made a prima facie showing that a failure to disregard the separate identities of a corporation and another organization would result in fraud or injustice, as the second prong of the test for whether one entity is the alter ego of the other, the alter ego doctrine is not limited to intentional fraud, nor does it require bad faith; so long as there is a unity of interest and ownership, courts will ignore the corporate form and attribute wrongful or inequitable conduct to the organization controlling the corporation.
Document Preview: E-COMMERCE  Fraud. Cryptocurrency exchange customers adequately alleged exchange's bank had actual knowledge of exchange's fraud, as element of aiding and abetting.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Bhatia v. Silvergate Bank
Court: United States District Court, S.D. California.
Headnote: A court may consider the same variety of factors in making determinations on both prongs of the test for whether one entity is the alter ego of another.
Document Preview: E-COMMERCE  Fraud. Cryptocurrency exchange customers adequately alleged exchange's bank had actual knowledge of exchange's fraud, as element of aiding and abetting.

Title: Franks v. Coopersurgical, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Rhode Island.
Headnote: Under Rhode Island law, piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that the two corporate entities are de facto nonexistent.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY  Preemption. Patient's products liability claim on theory of design defect was preempted by Medical Device Amendments of Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: SonicSolutions Algae Control, LLC v. Diversified Power International, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, courts consider the following factors in determining whether to disregard a corporation's separate legal identity: (1) whether there was a failure to collect paid in capital; (2) whether the corporation was grossly undercapitalized; (3) the non-issuance of stock certificates; (4) the sole ownership of stock by one individual; (5) the use of the same office or business location; (6) the employment of the same employees or attorneys; (7) the use of the corporation as an instrumentality or business conduit for an individual or another corporation; (8) the diversion of corporate assets by or to a stockholder or other entity to the detriment of creditors, or the manipulation of assets and liabilities in another; (9) the use of the corporation as a subterfuge in illegal transactions; (10) the formation and use of the corporation to transfer to it the existing liability of another person or entity; and (11) the failure to maintain arms length relationships among related entities.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Implied Contracts. Genuine issues of material fact existed as to whether implied-in-fact contract existed between distributor and manufacturer under Massachusetts law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Cortlandt Street Recovery Corp. v. Bonderman
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: In considering domination by owner of a corporation to pierce the corporate veil, courts consider factors such as disregard of corporate formalities, inadequate capitalization, intermingling of funds, overlap in ownership, officers, directors and personnel, common office space or telephone numbers, degree of discretion demonstrated by alleged dominated corporation, whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers, and payment or guarantee of corporation's debts by dominating entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. There was no evidence that corporate entities involved in recapitalization of judgment debtors were their alter egos to pierce the corporate veil.

Title: In re HVI Cat Canyon, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, C.D. California, NORTHERN DIVISION.
Headnote: To satisfy the alter ego test under federal or California law, a plaintiff must make out a prima facie case (1) that there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the two entities no longer exist and (2) that failure to disregard their separate identities would result in fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Stays. Stay of alter ego claims until trustee obtained judgment against corporate defendants and they failed to satisfy such judgment was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Elpers Bros. Construction & Supply, Inc. v. Smith
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Where trial court granted partial summary judgment for homeowners' association (HOA) on homeowners' negligence and breach of contract claims against it arising from inadequate drainage system installed on their property, and only remaining allegations against HOA were that it was an "alter ego" of other parties named in suit, dismissal of HOA as a named party in the suit was warranted; alter ego theory was not an independent cause of action, and remedy of piercing the corporate veil would be futile absent any independent claims.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Dismissal of action against homeowners' association (HOA) was warranted when only remaining claim was that HOA was alter ego of another party.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Elpers Bros. Construction & Supply, Inc. v. Smith
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: The corporate alter ego doctrine is a device by which a plaintiff attempts to demonstrate that two corporations are so closely connected that the plaintiff should be able to sue one for the actions of the other.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Dismissal of action against homeowners' association (HOA) was warranted when only remaining claim was that HOA was alter ego of another party.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Citibank, N.A. v. Aralpa Holdings Limited Partnership
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, factors to consider in determining whether an individual exercises complete domination over a corporation for that individual to be considered the alter ego of corporation to pierce the corporate veil include (1) the absence of the formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence, i.e., issuance of stock, election of directors, keeping of corporate records and the like, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, addresses, and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the related corporations deal with the dominated corporation at arm's length, (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) the payment or guarantee of debts of the dominated corporation by other corporations in the group, and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Guarantor exercised domination over LLCs such that they had become a mere instrumentality of him, as required to reverse-pierce their corporate veils.

Headnote: Where one corporate entity serves as the "alter ego" of another, courts may pierce the corporate veil to impose liability on the corporate entity that would generally not be liable.

Title: Doheny v. International Business Machines, Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Courts consider the following factors to determine whether to pierce the corporate veil under New York law: (1) whether corporate formalities are observed, (2) whether the capitalization is adequate, (3) intermingling of funds, (4) whether there is overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) whether the corporate entities share common office space, address and telephone numbers, (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the alleged dominator deals with the dominated corporation at arm's length, (8) whether the corporation is treated as independent profit center, (9) whether others pay or guarantee debts of the dominated corporation, and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by the alleged dominator as if it were the dominator's own.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Discrimination. Former employee alleged that employer would not have laid her off but for her age, as required to state disparate-treatment claim under ADEA.

Title: Hunter v. Rhino Shield
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth District, Franklin County.
Headnote: Even if a corporation merely has a similar name as another corporation, or if its address is next door to another similar sounding corporation, but if neither corporation has any ownership interest in the other, that does not mean the corporate veils of the two can be pierced such that one can be held liable for the conduct of the other.

Title: Coast-to-Coast Produce, LLC v. Lakeside Produce USA, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, to show that one entity is the mere instrumentality of another entity, courts look to these factors: (1) whether the corporation is undercapitalized, (2) whether separate books are kept, (3) whether there are separate finances for the corporation, (4) whether the corporation is used for fraud or illegality, (5) whether corporate formalities have been followed, and (6) whether the corporation is a sham; however, the existence of one of these factors, alone, is not necessarily dispositive, nor are the listed factors exhaustive.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Abstention. Abstention for foreign bankruptcy cases did not apply to produce distributors' action to enforce rights under Perishable Agricultural Commodities Act.

Title: Brummett v. Bailey
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.

Title: Lifetouch National School Studios Inc. v. Oklahoma School Pictures, LLC
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 4.
Headnote: Oklahoma law requires a two-step analysis to hold one corporation liable for the debts of another under a theory of alter ego liability; first, the party seeking to impose alter ego liability must satisfy the instrumentality analysis with evidence addressing the nine factors for determining if one corporation may be held liable for the acts of another; second, party seeking to disregard the separate legal existence of one corporation must show that doing so is necessary to circumvent fraud, protect the rights of third persons, and accomplish justice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Triable issues of fact existed as to whether LLC created judgment debtor as an instrumentality to wrongfully obtain clients and business.

Title: Tabchouri v. Hard Eight Restaurant Company, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: In determining whether an individual or another corporation constitutes an alter ego of a corporation, so as to support piercing the corporate veil, a reviewing court must look for overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, inadequate capitalization, a commingling of assets, or an absence of separate paraphernalia that are part of the corporate form, such that one of the corporations is a mere instrumentality, agent, and alter ego of the other.
Document Preview: TORTS  Dram Shop. Piercing corporate veil to hold owners of LLC restaurant operator liable for violation of Dram Shop Act was unwarranted, absent fraud or wrongdoing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: McGee v. Johnson & Johnson
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Pennsylvania does not allow recovery unless party seeking to pierce corporate veil on alter-ego theory establishes that controlling corporation wholly ignored separate status of controlled corporation and so dominated and controlled its affairs that its separate existence was mere sham.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY  Defects. Negligence claim under Pennsylvania law for failure to warn of manufacturing defects in breast implants was preempted by Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: McGee v. Johnson & Johnson
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Pennsylvania requires a threshold showing that the controlled corporation acted robot- or puppet-like in mechanical response to the controller's tugs on its strings or pressure on its buttons in order for a plaintiff to seek recovery on alter-ego theory of liability.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY  Defects. Negligence claim under Pennsylvania law for failure to warn of manufacturing defects in breast implants was preempted by Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: 138-77 Queens Blvd LLC v. Silver
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: In order to assess whether a corporation has been sufficiently dominated to warrant piercing the corporate veil under New York law, courts consider the following factors, which are neither exhaustive nor universally relevant: (1) the absence of the formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence, such as, issuance of stock, election of directors, and keeping of corporate record, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the related corporations deal with the dominated corporation at arms length, (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) the payment or guarantee of debts of the dominated corporation by other corporations in the group, and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Landlord plausibly alleged that father of personal guarantor of its commercial tenant exercised complete control and domination over tenant as required to pierce corporate veil as to father.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Stephens v. Mike's Transport, Inc.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 2.
Headnote: Corporations are distinct legal entities, and generally one corporation will not be held responsible for the acts of another.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Trucking business was alter ego of judgment debtors and thus liable for judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Stephens v. Mike's Transport, Inc.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 2.
Headnote: One corporation may be held liable for the acts of another under the theory of alter ego liability if (1) the separate existence is a design or scheme to perpetrate a fraud, or (2) one corporation is merely an instrumentality or agent of the other; in other words, it must appear that one corporation is merely a dummy or a sham.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Trucking business was alter ego of judgment debtors and thus liable for judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Stephens v. Mike's Transport, Inc.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 2.
Headnote: Factors relevant to determination of whether to pierce corporate veil to liability as the instrumentality or agent of another include: (1) whether dominant corporation owns or subscribes to all subservient corporation's stock, (2) whether dominant and subservient corporations have common directors and officers, (3) whether dominant corporation provides financing to subservient corporation, (4) whether subservient corporation is grossly undercapitalized, (5) whether dominant corporation pays salaries, expenses or losses of subservient corporation, (6) whether most of subservient corporation's business is with dominant corporation or subservient corporation's assets were conveyed from dominant corporation, (7) whether dominant corporation refers to subservient corporation as division or department, (8) whether subservient corporation's officers or directors follow dominant corporation's directions, and (9) whether corporations observe legal formalities for keeping entities separate.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Trucking business was alter ego of judgment debtors and thus liable for judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Hacker v. Fabe
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 8, California.
Headnote: Factors for the trial court to consider when deciding whether to ignore corporate entity under the alter ego doctrine include the commingling of funds and assets of the two entities, identical equitable ownership in the two entities, use of the same offices and employees, disregard of corporate formalities, identical directors and officers, and use of one as a mere shell or conduit for the affairs of the other.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Substantial evidence supported amending original judgment to add debtor's former manager as an alter ego judgment debtor due to his control of debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Franklin Capital Funding, LLC v. Austin Business Finance, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, to show that one entity is the mere instrumentality of another entity, for purposes of piercing the corporate veil, courts look to the following factors: (1) whether the corporation is undercapitalized, (2) whether separate books are kept, (3) whether there are separate finances for the corporation, (4) whether the corporation is used for fraud or illegality, (5) whether corporate formalities have been followed, and (6) whether the corporation is a sham.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Assignee of automobile dealer's factoring debt plausibly stated claim for breach of assignment agreement against assignor and its alleged alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Franklin Capital Funding, LLC v. Austin Business Finance, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, existence of one of the factors for showing that entity is the mere instrumentality of another entity, for purposes of piercing the corporate veil is not necessarily dispositive, nor are the factors exhaustive.

Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil between corporation and shell entity in order to reach the shell entity, plaintiffs must show that entity dominated corporation and used that domination to commit a fraud or other wrong against plaintiffs.

Title: Attarian v. Sagard Capital Partners, L.P.
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, court may pierce the corporate veil between corporation and a shell entity, in order to reach the shell entity, only if the shell entity was established for no other purpose than as a vehicle for fraud.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Hours and Wages. Former employees' action against corporate employer's beneficial shareholder to recover unpaid wages was premature.

Title: Washington v. Jay Street Development Corp.

Headnote: To establish that two entities are alter egos of each other, one must demonstrate that one of the entities controls the other or that the two operate as a single integrated entity.

Title: Concepts NREC, LLC v. Qiu
Court: United States District Court, D. Vermont.
Headnote: In assessing whether an entity functions as an alter ego of another entity, the district court considers the following factors: (1) disregard of corporate formalities, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) intermingling of funds, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) the degree of business discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the dealings between the entities are at arm's length, (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between the entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Jurisdiction. Corporation was the alter ego of Chinese company, as would support exercising personal jurisdiction over company to enforce discovery subpoenas.

Title: Concepts NREC, LLC v. Qiu
Court: United States District Court, D. Vermont.
Headnote: In determining whether companies have adhered to corporate formalities, for purposes of assessing whether an entity functions as an alter ego of another entity, the district court considers actions such as inadequate record keeping, lack of corporate kits, and failure to comply with governmental requirements such as taxes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Jurisdiction. Corporation was the alter ego of Chinese company, as would support exercising personal jurisdiction over company to enforce discovery subpoenas.

Title: Concepts NREC, LLC v. Qiu
Court: United States District Court, D. Vermont.
Headnote: For purposes of assessing whether companies have adhered to corporate formalities when determining whether an entity functions as an alter ego of another entity, advertising and marketing materials are intended to be read by the consuming public and generally such content is not sufficient to pierce the corporate veil; therefore, the general rule is that advertising and marketing materials do not trump the reality of documents evidencing adherence to corporate formalities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Jurisdiction. Corporation was the alter ego of Chinese company, as would support exercising personal jurisdiction over company to enforce discovery subpoenas.

Title: Concepts NREC, LLC v. Qiu
Court: United States District Court, D. Vermont.
Headnote: Although marketing materials generally are insufficient to demonstrate a lack of formal separation between corporate entities, for purposes of assessing whether an entity functions as an alter ego of another entity, the district court in the end must achieve an equitable result.

Title: AHBP LLC v. Lynd Company
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Texas, San Antonio Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, parties are not jointly liable for a corporation's obligations merely because they were part of a single business enterprise, that is, merely because of centralized control, mutual purposes, and shared finances; rather, disregarding the corporate structure involves two considerations: (1) the relationship between the two entities and (2) whether the entities' use of limited liability was illegitimate.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Exclusive licensee adequately alleged that licensor was founding company's alter ego so that corporate veil could be pierced for contract claims.

Title: Thornton v. Dutch Naturals Processing, LLC

Headnote: Under Kentucky law, unjust situations warranting veil-piercing may arise when a parent corporation causes a subsidiary's liability and then renders the subsidiary unable to pay the liability or when an intentional scheme to squirrel assets into a liability-free corporation while heaping liabilities upon an asset-free corporation would be successful.

Title: Arçelik, A.Ş. v. E.I. Du Pont de Nemours and Company
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Under the agency theory of liability under Delaware law, one corporation, completely independent of a second corporation, may assume the role of the second corporation's agent in the course of one or more specific transactions; that is, not only must an arrangement exist between the two corporations so that one acts on behalf of the other and within usual agency principles, but the arrangement must be relevant to the plaintiff's claim of wrongdoing.
Document Preview: TORTS  Negligence. Manufacturer failed to establish that company produced defective resin, as required for negligent manufacture claim under direct manufacture theory.

Title: Lopez v. Escamilla

Headnote: Factors to consider in determining whether to lift corporate veil, pursuant to alter ego doctrine, include commingling of funds and assets, identical equitable ownership, use of same offices and employees, disregard of corporate formalities, identical directors and officers, and who is treating assets of corporation as his own.

Title: Philip Morris USA, Inc. v. Rintoul

Headnote: Courts will look through the screen of corporate entity to the individuals who compose it in cases in which the corporation was a mere device or sham to accomplish some ulterior purpose, or a mere instrumentality or agent of another corporation or individual owning all or most of its stock, or where the purpose is to evade some statute or to accomplish some fraud or illegal purpose.

Title: Butler Motors, Inc. v. Benosky

Title: Clarke v. Service Employees International Union
Court: Supreme Court of Nevada.
Headnote: Generally, the commingling of funds, shared operations, shared headquarters, shared bank accounts, or failure to observe corporate formalities shows unity of interest or ownership, as necessary to establish alter ego liability of corporation.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Unions. There was no unity of interest and ownership between union that had employed employee and another union, as necessary to impose alter ego liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Mohegan Lake Motors, Inc. v. Maoli
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: New York courts consider ten factors to decide whether requisite domination is present to pierce corporate veil: absence of typical corporate formalities and paraphernalia; inadequate capitalization; whether funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal purposes; overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; common office space, address, and telephone numbers; amount of business discretion displayed dominated corporation; whether related corporations deal with dominated corporation at arms length; whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers; payment or guarantee of debts of dominated corporation by other corporations in group; and whether corporation in question had property that was used by other corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Fact issue as to whether it was appropriate to pierce corporate veil of car dealership's buyer LLC precluded summary judgment on seller LLC's claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Ford v. Carnival Corporation
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: To disregard corporate separateness in admiralty requires showing that controlling corporate entity exercises total domination of subservient corporation, to extent that subservient corporation manifests no separate corporate interests of its own.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW  Cruise Ships. Passengers were required to show cruise line had actual or constructive knowledge of condition that created COVID-19 risk in negligence claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Ford v. Carnival Corporation
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Federal common law allows piercing of the corporate veil where a corporation uses its alter ego to perpetrate a fraud or where it so dominates and disregards its alter ego's corporate form that the alter ego was actually carrying on the controlling corporation's business instead of its own.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW  Cruise Ships. Passengers were required to show cruise line had actual or constructive knowledge of condition that created COVID-19 risk in negligence claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Chung v. Carnival Corporation
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: To disregard corporate separateness in admiralty under the alter ego doctrine requires a showing that the controlling corporate entity exercises total domination of the subservient corporation, to the extent that the subservient corporation manifests no separate corporate interests of its own.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW  Cruise Ships. Passengers sufficiently alleged that ship's owner knew or should have known that COVID-19 posed a threat based on an outbreak aboard the ship.

Headnote: Federal common law allows piercing of the corporate veil where a corporation uses its alter ego to perpetrate a fraud or where it so dominates and disregards its alter ego's corporate form that the alter ego was actually carrying on the controlling corporation's business instead of its own.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW  Cruise Ships. Passengers sufficiently alleged that ship's owner knew or should have known that COVID-19 posed a threat based on an outbreak aboard the ship.

Title: Mortimer v. McCool
Court: Supreme Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: The notion of affiliate corporations depends upon the premise that they are siblings-of common parentage, and the prospect of wrongdoing in that scenario, for the purposes of determining whether to disregard the corporate entities under a theory of enterprise liability depends upon the actions (or omissions) of the common owner to exploit limited liability while failing to observe the separation between the corporations; thus, enterprise liability requires that the affiliates that the enterprise comprises have common owners and/or an administrative nexus above the sister corporations, and without that nexus, piercing the veil to reach a sister corporation cannot be just.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Enterprise liability doctrine did not apply to permit judgment creditor to pierce veil of judgment debtor LLC's affiliated corporate entity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Blackwell v. Superior Safe Rooms LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: While no one talismanic fact will justify with impunity piercing the corporate veil, a careful review of the entire relationship between various corporate entities, their directors and officers may reveal that such an equitable action is warranted.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment debtor's corporate form was so ignored, controlled, or manipulated that it was merely the instrumentality of garnishee defendants.

Headnote: A subset of piercing the corporate veil to hold one corporation liable for the actions of another is the corporate alter ego doctrine.

Headnote: The "corporate alter ego doctrine" is a device by which a plaintiff tries to show that two corporations are so closely connected that the plaintiff should be able to sue one for the actions of the other.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment debtor's corporate form was so ignored, controlled, or manipulated that it was merely the instrumentality of garnishee defendants.

Title: Blackwell v. Superior Safe Rooms LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: The purpose of the corporate alter ego doctrine is to avoid the inequity that results when one corporation uses another corporation as a shield from liability.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment debtor's corporate form was so ignored, controlled, or manipulated that it was merely the instrumentality of garnishee defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Blackwell v. Superior Safe Rooms LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: When a plaintiff seeks to pierce the corporate veil using the corporate alter ego doctrine, the court considers additional factors, including whether: (1) similar corporate names were used; (2) the corporations shared common principal corporate officers, directors, and employees; (3) the business purposes of the corporations were similar; and (4) the corporations were located in the same offices and used the same telephone numbers and business cards.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment debtor's corporate form was so ignored, controlled, or manipulated that it was merely the instrumentality of garnishee defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Blackwell v. Superior Safe Rooms LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Factors indicating that a corporation is the alter ego of another may include the intermingling of business transactions, functions, property, employees, funds, records, and corporate names in dealing with the public.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment debtor's corporate form was so ignored, controlled, or manipulated that it was merely the instrumentality of garnishee defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Blackwell v. Superior Safe Rooms LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Where the record indicates that the businesses of the corporations at issue were conducted in such a manner that innocent third parties had no way of knowing with which corporation they were dealing, it may be appropriate to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment debtor's corporate form was so ignored, controlled, or manipulated that it was merely the instrumentality of garnishee defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: MGF Healthcare Partners, Inc. v. Blue Ridge Healthcare Birmingham, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Alabama law, a party seeking to pierce the corporate veil of one entity to reach a second must show: (1) complete control and domination of the subservient corporation by the dominant party such that the subservient corporation had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) misuse of that control by the dominant party, and (3) that the misuse proximately caused the harm complained of.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Healthcare contractor could not prevail against company for breach of contract and other claims under the alter ego theory of corporate veil piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Cork v. CC-Palo Alto, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California, San Jose Division.
Headnote: Among the factors to be considered in applying California's alter-ego doctrine, under which the courts will ignore the corporate entity and deem the corporation's acts to be those of the persons or organizations actually controlling the corporation, are commingling of funds and other assets of the two entities, the holding out by one entity that it is liable for the debts of the other, identical equitable ownership in the two entities, use of the same offices and employees, and use of one as a mere shell or conduit for the affairs of the other.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Retirement community residents alleged they had property interest in entrance fees, as required to state claim for financial elder abuse.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Liberty Highrise Pvt. Ltd. v. Praxis Energy Agents DMCC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors that weigh in favor of a finding that two entities are alter egos include overlap in staff, officers, and directors, absence of arms-length dealing, blurred lines of corporate control, and intermingled financial transactions.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW  Jurisdiction. Maritime vessel operator made prima facie showing of personal jurisdiction over Dubai company and Singapore company sufficient to defeat motion to dismiss.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: G & E Construction, LLC v. Rubicon Construction, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Sole ownership of a corporation by one person or another corporation is not a factor, and neither is the fact that the sole owner uses and controls it to promote his ends, when considering whether to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil was unwarranted to permit general contractor's principal to have been held personally liable by subcontractor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Shetel Industries LLC v. Adin Dental Implant Systems, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, determining that veil-piercing is appropriate to hold shareholder or officer personally liable for corporate acts is a fact specific inquiry, and courts consider many factors, including: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of funds; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) the degree of discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the dealings between the entities are at arms [sic] length; (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of the corporations debts by the dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between the entities.
Document Preview: E-COMMERCE  Internet. Distributor of dental implants and its director and president were not liable under Anticybersquatting Consumer Protection Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re AuditHead, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. South Carolina.
Headnote: Alter ego claim under South Carolina law requires a showing that the retention of separate corporate personalities would promote fraud, wrong or injustice, or would contravene public policy.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Case Administration. Substantive consolidation could not be applied in order to bring assets of alleged non-debtor successor into debtor-LLC's estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re AuditHead, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. South Carolina.
Headnote: To prove an alter ego relationship between corporate entities under North Carolina law, plaintiff must establish three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control but complete domination, not only over finances, but over policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked, so that corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; and (2) that such control was used by defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) that aforesaid control and breach of duty proximately caused the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Case Administration. Substantive consolidation could not be applied in order to bring assets of alleged non-debtor successor into debtor-LLC's estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Butler America, LLC v. Aviation Assurance Company, LLC
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 6, California.
Headnote: Factors for the court to consider in considering alter ego liability include identical equitable ownership, comingling of funds, use of the same offices, disregard of formalities, and use of one entity as a mere shell for the affairs of another.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Judgment. Substantial evidence established that debtor's owner and related entities were its alter egos, warranting amendment of judgment to add them as debtors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Royal Alice Properties, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, legal fiction of a distinct corporate entity may be disregarded in order to hold another entity liable for the debts of corporation, when corporation is so organized and controlled as to make it merely an instrumentality or adjunct of another corporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Common ownership and commingling of funds supported single business enterprise claim against debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Moss v. Associated Underwriters, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Nebraska.
Headnote: "Horizontal veil piercing" occurs when a limited liability entity is considered to be the alter ego of another limited liability entity with the same owner.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence warranted piercing corporate veil of insurance corporation to hold corporation's sole shareholder liable for unpaid judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Moss v. Associated Underwriters, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Nebraska.
Headnote: Under the concept of horizontal veil piercing, a creditor with a claim against one of the limited liability entities seeks to disregard corporate separateness between the entities to reach assets belonging to both.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence warranted piercing corporate veil of insurance corporation to hold corporation's sole shareholder liable for unpaid judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Carter v. City of Montgomery
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Alabama, Northern Division.
Headnote: To pierce the veil under Alabama law between two corporations based on excessive control, a plaintiff must show: (1) complete control and domination; (2) misuse of that control; and (3) proximate cause.
Document Preview: CIVIL RIGHTS  Due Process. Issue of fact existed whether city knew and was deliberately indifferent to company requesting probation revocation despite no willful failure to pay fines.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Roche v. Hyde
Court: Court of Appeal, First District, Division 4, California.
Headnote: As is the case with alter ego analysis, to impute knowledge to a corporate successor, it is not necessary that the plaintiff prove actual fraud; it is enough if the recognition of the two entities as separate would result in an injustice.
Document Preview: TORTS  Malicious Prosecution. Fraud or perjury exception to interim adverse judgment rule must apply to discovery misconduct that deprives a summary judgment movant of a fair hearing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Prime Bank v. Vitano, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: In a situation involving multiple business entities, the actions of one can have legal consequences on the other if there was such a unity of interest and ownership that there is effectively no independence between the two.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Limitations. Cause of action against corporation that had guaranteed debtor's loan accrued, and limitation period began to run, when debtor defaulted on loan.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: KR Enterprises, Inc. v. Zerteck, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Indiana, South Bend Division.
Headnote: Under Indiana law, to overcome the presumption that distinct corporations are separate for liability purposes, a plaintiff must show that one corporation dominated another to the extent that one of three circumstances existed; the first is that the subordinate was the mere instrumentality of the dominant corporation, the second is that the dominant corporation employed the subordinate to perpetrate a fraud, and the third has to do with the under-capitalization of the subordinate corporate entity.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Secured Transactions. Assignee of creditor's security interest in accounts receivable was subject to account debtors' claims and defenses against assignor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: KR Enterprises, Inc. v. Zerteck, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Indiana, South Bend Division.
Headnote: Under Indiana law, in order for the corporate form to be ignored for purposes of shifting liability from one corporation to another, the plaintiff must demonstrate that the business relationship of the corporations was the proximate cause of the injury sustained.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Secured Transactions. Assignee of creditor's security interest in accounts receivable was subject to account debtors' claims and defenses against assignor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Pridy v. Piedmont Natural Gas Company, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Tennessee, Nashville Division.
Headnote: The test for determining whether two companies are alter egos is whether the two enterprises have substantially identical management, business, purpose, operation, equipment, customers, supervision and ownership.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Benefit Plans. Employees' ERISA claim fell within scope of claims that were subject to grievance procedures set forth in CBAs.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: WAG SPV I, LLC v. Fortune Global Shipping & Logistics, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Several factors courts look to in determining whether a defendant is an alter ego of another under federal common law on piercing the corporate veil-none of which is dispositive-include (1) disregard of corporate formalities, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) intermingling of funds, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address, and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) the degree of business discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the dealings between the entities are at arm's length, (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between the entities.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Attachment and Garnishment. New York rule that restraining notice or turnover order served on New York bank branch has no impact on assets in other branches applies domestically.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Apple Inc. v. Allan & Associates Limited
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California, San Jose Division.
Headnote: To determine whether there is a sufficient unity of interest and ownership to support alter ego liability under California law, courts consider factors like: commingling of funds, failure to maintain minutes or adequate corporate records, identification of the equitable owners with the domination and control of the two entities, the use of the same office or business locations, the identical equitable ownership of the two entities, the use of a corporation as a mere shell, instrumentality or conduit for a single venture or the business of an individual, and failure to adequately capitalize a corporation.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Limitations. Discovery rule did not apply to toll limitations period for seller's contract claim against company overseeing electronics-waste recycling program.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Jass v. CherryRoad Technologies, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Hawai‘i.
Headnote: To pursue an alter ego theory in Hawai'i, a plaintiff must allege sufficient facts showing that: (1) a corporation is not only influenced and governed by a second corporation, but that there is such a unity of interest that the individuality, or separateness, of the two corporations has ceased; and (2) an adherence to the fiction of the separate existence of the corporation would, under the particular circumstances, sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Whistleblowing. Former high-ranking corporate executive stated a claim under Hawaii Whistleblower Protection Act (HWPA) against employer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Angell v. Santefort Family Holdings LLC
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Third District.
Headnote: The doctrine of piercing the corporate veil allows courts to pierce the veil of limited liability where the corporation is merely the alter ego or business conduit of another person or entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Owner of mobile home park and owner of mobile home were subject to the doctrine of piercing the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Angell v. Santefort Family Holdings LLC
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Third District.
Headnote: A party seeking to pierce the corporate veil will be successful where (1) there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporations no longer exist and (2) circumstances exist so that adherence to the fiction of a separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or promote inequitable consequences.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Owner of mobile home park and owner of mobile home were subject to the doctrine of piercing the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Theodore v. Uber Technologies, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Where corporations are formed, or availed of, to carry out the objectives and purposes of the corporations or persons controlling them, agency principles may dictate that the controlling person(s) and the entity not be regarded as separate.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Arbitration. Terms and conditions on online account creation page were not conspicuous enough to communicate terms of any agreement between customer and company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Alexander v. Community Hospital of Long Beach
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: To determine whether a sufficient unity of interest and ownership exists between two entities in applying the alter ego doctrine, the court considers commingling of assets, identical ownership, use of the same offices and employees, disregard of corporate formalities, identical directors and officers, and use of one as a mere shell or conduit for the affairs of the other.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Wrongful Discharge. Substantial evidence did not support hospital's liability to nurses for negligent supervision of director alleged to have created hostile work environment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Constellation-F, LLC v. World Trading 23, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 8, California.
Headnote: The fact that one company does business as another does not, without more, support an alter ego finding.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Landlord and Tenant. Holdover rent provision increasing base rent by 150% if tenant remained after lease expired was not an unenforceable penalty.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Clark Rigging & Rental Corp. v. Liberty Mutual Insurance Company
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: When a corporation has been so dominated by an individual or another corporation and its separate entity so ignored that it primarily transacts the dominator's business instead of its own and can be called the other's alter ego, the corporate form may be disregarded to achieve an equitable result.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Plaintiff sufficiently alleged that limited liability company's alleged alter ego was in fact its alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: General Fidelity Insurance Company v. WFT, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: To determine whether to pierce the corporate veil based on one corporation's complete control of another, courts consider four primary factors with regard to the controlled corporation: (1) inadequate capitalization; (2) lack of compliance with corporate formalities; (3) complete domination and control of the corporation such that it has no independent identity; and (4) excessive fragmentation.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Insurance company was winding up when it transferred assets to second company, as necessary for transfer of assets to constitute constructive fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: General Fidelity Insurance Company v. WFT, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: For purposes of determining whether to pierce the corporate veil based on one corporation's complete control of another, a plaintiff's showing of constructive fraud or fraudulent transfer is sufficient to satisfy the requirements that the controlling company used its control to commit wrong and that the control caused the injury or loss plaintiff complained of.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Insurance company was winding up when it transferred assets to second company, as necessary for transfer of assets to constitute constructive fraud.

Title: Hipps v. Biglari Holdings, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: The purpose of the corporate alter ego doctrine is to avoid the inequity that results when one corporation uses another corporation as a shield from liability.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Shareholders. Sole remedy for shareholders' merger-related claims of breach of fiduciary duty and unjust enrichment was to sell shares on open market.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Hipps v. Biglari Holdings, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: When a plaintiff seeks to pierce the corporate veil using the corporate alter ego doctrine, courts consider additional factors, including whether: (1) similar corporate names were used; (2) the corporations shared common principal corporate officers, directors, and employees; (3) the business purposes of the corporations were similar; and (4) the corporations were located in the same offices and used the same telephone numbers and business cards.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Shareholders. Sole remedy for shareholders' merger-related claims of breach of fiduciary duty and unjust enrichment was to sell shares on open market.
