Title: Hipps v. Biglari Holdings, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Factors indicating that a corporation is the alter ego of another may include the intermingling of business transactions, functions, property, employees, funds, records, and corporate names in dealing with the public.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Shareholders. Sole remedy for shareholders' merger-related claims of breach of fiduciary duty and unjust enrichment was to sell shares on open market.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Fliss
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, before separate corporate identity of one corporation will be disregarded and it will treated as alter ego of another, it must generally be shown that first corporation is so controlled and its affairs so conducted that it is mere instrumentality of another, and it must further appear that observance of the fiction of separate corporate existence would, under the circumstances, sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Claim was unenforceable pursuant to state law merger doctrine.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Mou v. SSC San Jose Operating Company LP
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California, San Jose Division.
Headnote: To invoke the "alter ego doctrine" under California law, plaintiff must allege: (1) that there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the two corporations no longer exist, and (2) that if the acts are treated as those of only one of the corporations, an inequitable result will follow.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST  Pleading. Former nursing home resident failed to state claim for violation of California's UCL, predicated on alleged violations of various California and federal statutes and regulations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Mou v. SSC San Jose Operating Company LP
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California, San Jose Division.
Headnote: Among the factors to be considered in applying California "alter ego doctrine" are: (1) comingling of funds and other assets of the two entities, (2) holding out by one entity that it is liable for the debts of the other, (3) identical equitable ownership in the two entities, (4) use of the same offices and employees, and (5) use of one as a mere shell or conduit for the affairs of the other.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST  Pleading. Former nursing home resident failed to state claim for violation of California's UCL, predicated on alleged violations of various California and federal statutes and regulations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: TrueNorth Companies, L.C. v. TruNorth Warranty Plans of North America, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Iowa, Cedar Rapids Division.
Headnote: Under Iowa law, a corporate entity is the alter ego of another if (1) the other entity influences and governs the subject entity; (2) a unity of interest and ownership exists such that the two entities cannot be separated; and (3) giving effect to the fictional separation between the two entities would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Jurisdiction. Corporation formed by alleged infringer's founder was not the alter ego of alleged infringer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Gaubert Oil Company, Inc. v. Bayou Fuel Marine and Hardware Supplies, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporations are separate entities; however, the legal fiction of a distinct corporate entity may be disregarded when a corporation is so organized and controlled as to make it merely an instrumentality of another corporation.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Fraudulent Transfers. Promissory note holder could bring revocatory action seeking to annul note maker's sale of movables against maker's lenders.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: AKH Company, Inc. v. Universal Underwriters Insurance Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: In deciding whether there is a unity of interest necessary for imposing liability as corporation's alter ego, courts consider the following factors: inadequate capitalization, commingling of funds and other assets of the two entities, the holding out by one entity that it is liable for the debts of the other, identical equitable ownership in the two entities, use of the same offices and employees, use of one as a mere conduit for the affairs of the other, disregard of corporate formalities, lack of segregation of corporate records, and identical directors and officers.
Document Preview: INSURANCE  Duty to Defend. Cost-sharing agreement for defense costs in consolidated suits against and by insured did not breach duty to defend.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Access Realty Group, Inc. v. Kane
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Sixth Division.
Headnote: Determining whether a separate corporate entity exists generally applies to a veil-piercing fact scenario.

Headnote: The corporate form may be disregarded where one corporation is so organized and controlled and its affairs so conducted that it is a mere instrumentality or adjunct of another corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Crosskey Architects, LLC v. Poko Partners, LLC
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil under the identity rule, the plaintiff must show that there was such a unity of interest and ownership that the independence of the corporations had in effect ceased or had never begun, an adherence to the fiction of separate identity would serve only to defeat justice and equity by permitting the economic entity to escape liability arising out of an operation conducted by one corporation for the benefit of the whole enterprise.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Factual findings supported use of identity rule as basis for piercing corporate veil of real estate development entity.

Headnote: When a corporation is so manipulated by an individual or another corporate entity as to become a mere puppet or tool for the manipulator, justice may require the courts to disregard the corporate fiction and impose liability on the real actor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Takeda Pharmaceuticals U.S.A., Inc. v. Spireas
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under the alter ego theory of piercing the corporate veil under Pennsylvania law, a party must establish that the controlling corporation wholly ignored the separate status of the controlled corporation and so dominated and controlled its affairs that its separate existence was a mere sham; said another way, the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must show that the corporation acted robot-like or puppet-like in mechanical response to the controller's tugs on its strings or pressure on its buttons.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Breach of contract claim premised on principal's own conduct did not require piercing corporate veil of licensing company to permit recovery.

Title: Planned Parenthood Federation of America, Inc. v. Center for Medical Progress
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: When assessing whether there is a unity of interest for the purposes of alter ego liability under California law, courts consider whether there is evidence of commingling of funds or other assets, the holding out by one entity that it is liable for the debts of the other, identical equitable ownership of the entities, use of the same offices and employees, use of one as a mere shell or conduit for the affairs of the other, inadequate capitalization, disregard of corporate formalities, and identical directors and officers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Russell Barnett Ford of Tullahoma, Inc. v. H & S Bakery, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Tennessee, Winchester Division.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, mere dominance of a corporation by another corporation or its shareholders is insufficient to justify piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Bakery business was not a party to contract for sale of commercial vehicles, and thus, could not be held liable for breach of that contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Russell Barnett Ford of Tullahoma, Inc. v. H & S Bakery, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Tennessee, Winchester Division.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, when considering whether to pierce the corporate veil, courts will consider whether the corporation was used to commit fraud or wrongdoing, but must also consider the following factors: (1) whether there was a failure to collect paid in capital, (2) whether the corporation was grossly undercapitalized, (3) the non-issuance of stock certificates, (4) the sole ownership of stock by one individual, (5) the use of the same office or business location, (6) the employment of the same employees or attorneys, (7) the use of the corporation as an instrumentality or business conduit for an individual or another corporation, (8) the diversion of corporate assets by or to a stockholder or other entity to the detriment of creditors, or the manipulation of assets and liabilities in another, (9) the use of the corporation as a subterfuge in illegal transactions, (10) the formation and use of the corporation to transfer to it the existing liability of another person or entity, and (11) the failure to maintain arms length relationships among related entities; not every factor needs to be met, nor will any single factor be dispositive in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Bakery business was not a party to contract for sale of commercial vehicles, and thus, could not be held liable for breach of that contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Blast Fitness Group, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, it is appropriate to depart from general principle of corporate separateness in two situations: (1) when there is active and direct participation by representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in the activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of this intercorporate relationship, or (2) when there is a confused intermingling of the activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of separate nature of corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about manner and capacity in which various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Chapter 7 trustee stated plausible claim for veil piercing and/or alter ego determination against affiliated entities under Massachusetts law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Blast Fitness Group, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, in imposing liability upon one or more of a group of closely identified corporations, a court need not consider with nicety which of them ought to be held liable for the act of one corporation for which the plaintiff deserves payment.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Chapter 7 trustee stated plausible claim for veil piercing and/or alter ego determination against affiliated entities under Massachusetts law.

Title: In re Blast Fitness Group, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, it is appropriate to depart from general principle of corporate separateness in two situations: (1) when there is active and direct participation by representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in the activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of this intercorporate relationship, or (2) when there is a confused intermingling of the activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of separate nature of corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about manner and capacity in which various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Trustee stated plausible strong-arm claim to avoid transfer of right to acquire real estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Blast Fitness Group, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, it is appropriate to depart from the general principle of corporate separateness in two situations: (1) when there is active and direct participation by representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in the activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of this intercorporate relationship, or (2) when there is a confused intermingling of the activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of separate nature of corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about manner and capacity in which various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Hebert v. Vantage Travel Service, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, disregard of corporate separateness is permitted when two factors are met: (1) when there is active and direct participation by the representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in the activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of the intercorporate relationship, or (2) when there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of the separate nature of the corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about the manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Class Actions. Class certification was warranted with respect to proposed class of passengers on malfunctioning tour boat.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Trustees of Operating Engineers Local 324 Pension Fund v. Bourdow Contracting, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: The "alter-ego doctrine" is an equitable doctrine that allows courts to treat two companies as the same entity when necessary to prevent either of them from manipulating its corporate form to evade its labor obligations.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Benefit Plans. LLC was corporation's alter ego for purposes of union pension fund's ERISA action to recover from LLC corporation's withdrawal liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Trustees of Operating Engineers Local 324 Pension Fund v. Bourdow Contracting, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: The test for determining whether two companies are alter egos looks to see whether the two companies have substantially identical management, business purpose, operation, equipment, customers, supervision, and ownership, as well as an employer's intent to evade its labor obligations.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Benefit Plans. LLC was corporation's alter ego for purposes of union pension fund's ERISA action to recover from LLC corporation's withdrawal liability.

Title: Trustees of Operating Engineers Local 324 Pension Fund v. Bourdow Contracting, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: The business purpose factor for determining whether two companies are alter egos looks to overlap in the type of work performed.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Benefit Plans. LLC was corporation's alter ego for purposes of union pension fund's ERISA action to recover from LLC corporation's withdrawal liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Trustees of Operating Engineers Local 324 Pension Fund v. Bourdow Contracting, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: The operations factor for determining whether two companies are alter egos looks to continuity of work force, that is, whether the new company attracted employees of its own or employed a number of former employees of the older company, and to continuity of work space.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Benefit Plans. LLC was corporation's alter ego for purposes of union pension fund's ERISA action to recover from LLC corporation's withdrawal liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Trustees of Operating Engineers Local 324 Pension Fund v. Bourdow Contracting, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: The equipment factor for determining whether two companies are alter egos looks to whether the new company acquired any of the older company's equipment, and if so, whether the acquisition was an arm's-length transaction.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Benefit Plans. LLC was corporation's alter ego for purposes of union pension fund's ERISA action to recover from LLC corporation's withdrawal liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Trustees of Operating Engineers Local 324 Pension Fund v. Bourdow Contracting, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: The court looks to overlap in customer base and customers, as a factor for determining whether two companies are alter egos.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: d'Amico Dry d.a.c. v. Nikka Finance, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: Corporate entity is liable for the acts of separate, related entity only under extraordinary circumstances; it is only in such extraordinary circumstances where courts find alter ego liability and then pierce the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: d'Amico Dry d.a.c. v. Nikka Finance, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: Decision by one corporation to act as a guarantor or another's debt, without any apparent consideration, thereby putting its assets at risk, weighs in favor of alter ego finding, because it suggests that the first corporation treats the second as its own.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Gipson Mechanical Contractors, Inc. v. U.A. Local 572 of the United Association of the Journeyman and Apprentices of the Plumbing and Pipefitters Industry of the United States and Canada (AFL-CIO)
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Tennessee, Nashville Division.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, factors to be considered in determining whether an alter ego relationship exists include: (1) whether there was a failure to collect paid in capital; (2) whether corporation was grossly undercapitalized; (3) nonissuance of stock certificates; (4) sole ownership of stock by one individual; (5) use of same office or business location; (6) employment of same employees or attorneys; (7) use of corporation as an instrumentality or business conduit for an individual or another corporation; (8) diversion of corporate assets by or to a stockholder or other entity to the detriment of creditors, or manipulation of assets and liabilities in another; (9) use of corporation as a subterfuge in illegal transactions; (10) formation and use of corporation to transfer to it existing liability of another person or entity; and (11) failure to maintain arms' length relationships among related entities.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: D'Amico Dry D.A.C. v. Primera Maritime (Hellas) Limited
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors relevant to determining whether one entity is the alter ego of another, as required to pierce the corporate veil, include: (1) the absence of the formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence, i.e., issuance of stock, election of directors, keeping of corporate records and the like; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the related corporations deal with the dominated corporation at arm's length; (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) the payment or guarantee of debts of the dominated corporation by other corporations in the group; and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Successor Liability. Ship management company was liable as a successor-in-interest for judgment incurred by predecessor in English court.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: A.O.A. v. Rennert
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Missouri law, when one corporation dominates and controls another to the point where formal corporate separateness is no longer followed, the subordinate corporation becomes the "alter ego" of the parent.
Document Preview: TORTS  Negligence. Allegations that Peruvian children were injured by refinery's pollution were sufficient to state plausible claims of negligence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: A.O.A. v. Rennert
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under New York law, determinations of veil piercing are fact specific and courts may consider several factors, including the disregard of corporate formalities; inadequate capitalization; intermingling of funds; overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; and payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity.
Document Preview: TORTS  Negligence. Allegations that Peruvian children were injured by refinery's pollution were sufficient to state plausible claims of negligence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: A.O.A. v. Rennert
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Missouri law, a principal-agent relationship between two corporate entities is established when there is such domination and control that the controlled corporation has no separate mind, will or existence of its own and is but a business conduit for its principal.
Document Preview: TORTS  Negligence. Allegations that Peruvian children were injured by refinery's pollution were sufficient to state plausible claims of negligence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Lloyd's Syndicate 457 v. American Global Maritime Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, a court may disregard the legal fiction of a distinct corporate entity when a corporation is so organized and controlled as to make it merely an instrumentality or adjunct of another corporation or, in other words, when one corporation is wholly under the control of another.
Document Preview: TORTS  Negligence. Maritime warranty surveyor owed duty to insurers of all-risk commercial liability insurance policy to use reasonable care and competence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Lloyd's Syndicate 457 v. American Global Maritime Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, a court considers the totality of the circumstances to determine whether one corporation controls another, including stock ownership, common directors or officers, unified administrative control, directors and officers of one corporation who act independently of corporate interests, asset commingling, undercapitalization, one corporation that causes another to be incorporated, one corporation pays salaries or other expenses of another corporation, one corporation receives business only through an affiliated corporation, one corporation uses the property of another as its own, failure to follow corporate formalities, common employees, one corporation's employees render services on behalf of another corporation, common offices, centralized accounting, undocumented transfers of funds between corporations, unclear allocation of profits and losses between corporations, and excessive fragmentation of a single enterprise.
Document Preview: TORTS  Negligence. Maritime warranty surveyor owed duty to insurers of all-risk commercial liability insurance policy to use reasonable care and competence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Atempa v. Pedrazzani
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: Ordinarily, a corporation is regarded as a legal entity separate and distinct from its stockholders, officers and directors; under the alter ego doctrine, however, where a corporation is used by an individual or individuals, or by another corporation, to perpetrate fraud, circumvent a statute, or accomplish some other wrongful or inequitable purpose, a court may disregard the corporate entity and treat the corporation's acts as if they were done by the persons actually controlling the corporation.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Hours and Wages. Corporate employer's owner, president, secretary, and director was subject to civil penalties for employer's failure to pay appropriate wage.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Packaged Seafood Products Antitrust Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. California.
Headnote: A court may disregard the corporate form in order to hold one corporation liable for the debts of another affiliated corporation when the latter is so organized and controlled, and its affairs are so conducted, as to make it merely an instrumentality, agency, conduit, or adjunct of another corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Jurisdiction. Seafood producer was alter ego of holding company, thus general jurisdiction over producer could be imputed to holding company in antitrust case.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Thomas Industries, Inc. v. City of Bristol
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: The factors considered under federal law to determine whether an entity is the alter ego of another include: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of funds; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) the degree of business discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the dealings between the entities are at arms-length; (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity; and (10) intermingling of property between the entities.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Interpleader. City's liens did not have priority over the previously perfected liens of United States or state Department of Labor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Thomas Industries, Inc. v. City of Bristol
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, a party seeking to hold another party liable as an alter ego under the identity test must establish that there was such a unity of interest and ownership that the independence of the corporations had in effect ceased or had never begun.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Interpleader. City's liens did not have priority over the previously perfected liens of United States or state Department of Labor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Thomas Industries, Inc. v. City of Bristol
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under the identity test, in order to determine whether an entity is the alter ego of another entity under Connecticut law, courts look at factors including overlapping ownership, officers, directors, personnel and common office space, address, and phones.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Interpleader. City's liens did not have priority over the previously perfected liens of United States or state Department of Labor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Daimler AG v. A-Z Wheels LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. California.
Headnote: Under the alter ego doctrine in California, where a corporation is used by an individual or individuals, or by another corporation, to perpetrate fraud, circumvent a statute, or accomplish some other wrongful or inequitable purpose, a court may disregard the corporate entity and treat the corporation's acts as if they were done by the persons actually controlling the corporation. Cal. Civ. Code § 3528.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS  Name or Likeness. Internet automobile wheel and rim sellers infringed on trademarks and patents.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Britax Child Safety, Inc. v. Nuna International B.V.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: The question of whether an alter ego relationship exists should be examined in terms of the legal interrelationship of the entities, the authority to control and the actual exercise of control, the administrative chains of command and organizational structure, the performance of functions, and the public's perception.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Jurisdiction. Dutch manufacturer did not have sufficient contacts with Pennsylvania.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Pertuis v. Front Roe Restaurants, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of South Carolina.
Headnote: Disregarding the corporate structure involves two considerations: one is the relationship between two entities; the other consideration is whether the entities' use of limited liability was illegitimate.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Under single business enterprise theory, corporations may be liable for each other's obligations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: CBF Industria de Gusa S/A v. AMCI Holdings, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Courts consider a variety of factors in assessing the control element, including (1) intermingling of personal and corporate funds and siphoning of corporate funds by a principal; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities and keep proper books and records; (3) failure to pay dividends; (4) inadequate capitalization; (5) insolvency; (6) perpetuation of fraud by shareholders in maintaining the corporate form; (7) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (8) common office space, address, and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (9) the degree of discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation, (10) whether the dealings between the entities are at arms length, (11) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, and (12) payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Arbitration. Companies and individuals interrelated with buyer of pig iron were not deprived of full and fair opportunity to be heard.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Neopart Transit, LLC v. CBM N.A. Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: The question of whether an alter ego relationship exists should be examined in terms of the legal interrelationship of the entities, the authority to control and the actual exercise of control, the administrative chains of command and organizational structure, the performance of functions, and the public's perception.
Document Preview: TORTS  Tortious Interference. Distributor did not state claim against former employee of its predecessor for tortious interference with prospective contractual relations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Neopart Transit, LLC v. CBM N.A. Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Courts consider ten discrete factors to decide whether one entity is the alter ego of another: (1) ownership of all or most of the stock of the related corporation; (2) common officers and directors; (3) common marketing image; (4) common use of a trademark or logo; (5) common use of employees; (6) integrated sales system; (7) interchange of managerial and supervisory personnel; (8) performance by the related corporation of business functions which the principal corporation would normally conduct through its own agent or departments; (9) acting of the related corporation as marketing arm of the principal corporation, or as an exclusive distributor; and (10) receipt by the officers of the related corporation of instruction from the principal corporation.
Document Preview: TORTS  Tortious Interference. Distributor did not state claim against former employee of its predecessor for tortious interference with prospective contractual relations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: U.S. KingKing, LLC v. Precision Energy Services, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Disregarding the corporate structure involves two considerations: (1) the relationship between the entities, and (2) whether the entities' use of limited liability was illegitimate.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Factual issues as to if member of oil equipment supplier's customer, a limited-liability company, was customer's alter ego precluded summary judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: U.S. KingKing, LLC v. Precision Energy Services, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: In determining whether the company and the owner of the company are alter egos, as partially required to pierce the corporate veil, courts assess the relationship between the entities using such factors as: (1) whether the entities shared a common business name, common offices, common employees, or centralized accounting, (2) whether one entity paid the wages of the other entity's employees, (3) whether one entity's employees rendered services on behalf of the other entity, (4) whether one entity made undocumented transfers of funds to the other entity, and (5) whether the allocation of profits and losses between the entities is unclear. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Factual issues as to if member of oil equipment supplier's customer, a limited-liability company, was customer's alter ego precluded summary judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Boroditskiy v. European Specialties LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, determining whether veil-piercing is appropriate is a fact specific inquiry, and court considers (1) disregard of corporate formalities, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) intermingling of funds, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) the degree of discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the dealings between the entities are at arms length, (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between the entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Corporation was not alter ego of LLC, despite shared members, telephone number, and office space.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Gowen v. Helly Nahmad Gallery, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York.
Headnote: In determining whether a corporation was completely dominated by another, such that court can pierce the corporate veil, court may consider factors such as the disregard of corporate formalities; inadequate capitalization; intermingling of funds; overlap in ownership, officers, directors and personnel; common office space or telephone numbers; the degree of discretion demonstrated by the alleged dominated corporation; whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; and the payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity, but no one factor is dispositive.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Replevin. New York was not inconvenient forum for replevin action seeking return of painting taken by Nazis during occupation of Paris.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Belair Care Center, Inc. v. Cool Insuring Agency, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Corporate veil will be pierced and liability imposed when either (1) there is complete domination of a corporation by an individual or another corporation with respect to the transaction being attacked that resulted in a fraud or wrong against the complaining party, or (2) a corporation has been so dominated by an individual or another corporation and its separate entity so ignored that it primarily transacts the dominator's business instead of its own and can be called the other's alter ego.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Pleading. Former members of group self-insured trust (GSIT) should have been allowed to add false advertising claims to complaint against insurance brokers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Trisvan v. Heyman
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: A party seeking to pierce the corporate veil under New York law and hold another entity or individual liable on a claim against a corporation must show: (1) the alleged alter ego exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue; and (2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: HEALTH  Drugs. Pharmaceutical manufacturer had duty to warn physicians, but not patients, of potential side-effects of medication.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Sky Cable, LLC v. DIRECTV, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: If legally separate entities fail to follow corporate formalities when doing business with one another, this failure may raise an inference that the entities are one and the same; additionally, piercing an entity's veil under the alter ego theory is particularly appropriate when a single individual or entity completely dominates and controls another entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Outsider reverse piercing of LLC veil was available under Delaware law when LLC was alter ego of its sole member, as predicted by federal court.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: United States v. Dental Dreams, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. New Mexico.
Headnote: Under New Mexico law, a plaintiff seeking to impose liability pursuant to alter ego doctrine must show that recognition of the separate corporate existence of the two corporations would sanction fraud or other improper purposes.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT  False Claims. Fact issues remained whether employer's reason for terminating employee was pretextual, precluding summary judgment on FCA claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Shantou Real Lingerie Manufacturing Co., Ltd. v. Native Group International, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, factors to consider in determining whether an individual exercises complete domination over a corporation include: (1) the absence of the formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence, i.e., issuance of stock, election of directors, keeping of corporate records and the like, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the related corporations deal with the dominated corporation at arm's length, (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) the payment or guarantee of debts of the dominated corporation by other corporations in the group, and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate debtor's principal dominated and controlled corporation, such that piercing the corporate veil was appropriate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Advanced Contracting Solutions, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Hallmarks of the alter ego doctrine include whether the two enterprises have substantially identical management, business purpose, operation, equipment, customers, supervision, and ownership, but not all of these factors need to be present in order to establish that two entities are alter egos, and no single factor is dispositive.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Debtor was no longer the alter ego of unionized concrete contractor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Advanced Contracting Solutions, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To determine whether alter ego entities had successfully separated or disentangled, court would apply the traditional alter ego standard, with the recognition that another court's prior decision on the entities' alter ego status at that earlier date was entitled to res judicata effect and that the other court's findings could not be challenged in the current proceeding, and with emphasis placed on what had changed compared to the facts relied upon in the earlier decision.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Debtor was no longer the alter ego of unionized concrete contractor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Holder v. Fraser Shipyards, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: Whether multiple corporate entities should be deemed one depends on a totality of the circumstances and is characterized overall by an absence of an arm's length relationship found among unintegrated companies.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW  Workers Compensation. Consideration of whether employment contractor or shipyard had control over worker leaned in favor of worker's status as shipyard's borrowed employee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: A.L. Dougherty Real Estate Management Company, LLC v. Su Chin Tsai
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, FIRST DIVISION.
Headnote: A court may disregard a corporate entity and pierce the veil of limited liability where the corporation is merely the alter ego or business conduit of another person or entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Court properly declined to evaluate corporate veil piercing claim under principles applicable to breach of contract claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: A.L. Dougherty Real Estate Management Company, LLC v. Su Chin Tsai
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, FIRST DIVISION.
Headnote: The "alter ego doctrine," which permits a court to disregard a corporate entity and pierce the veil of limited liability, fastens liability on the individual or entity that uses a corporation merely as an instrumentality to conduct that person's or entity's business.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Court properly declined to evaluate corporate veil piercing claim under principles applicable to breach of contract claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Builders Group & Development Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Under Puerto Rico law, corporation is alter ego or business conduit of its stockholders when there is such unity of interest and ownership that the personalities of the corporation and the stockholders, whether natural or artificial persons, are intermingled and, as a result, the corporation actually is not a separate and independent entity.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Fact issues precluded summary judgment on turnover claims asserted on alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Comprehensive Power, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts, Central Division.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, claim may be brought against alter ego of corporation when there is active and direct participation by representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of the intercorporate relationship, or when there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of the separate nature of the corporate entities or serious ambiguity about the manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Trustee stated plausible basis for imputing intent, for fraudulent transfer avoidance purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Meinert Plumbing v. Warner Industries, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth District, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: In test for whether piercing the corporate veil is allowed, evidence of total control of one corporation by another corporation must be of a nature and a degree that renders the two corporations fundamentally indistinguishable.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Dealers were not entitled to pierce corporate veil in suits against manufacturing corporation and its parent corporations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Turman v. Superior Court of Orange County
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Among the factors to be considered in applying the alter ego doctrine to disregard corporate identity are (1) commingling of funds and other assets, (2) the holding out by one entity that it is liable for the debts of the other, (3) identical equitable ownership in the two entities, (4) use of the same offices and employees, (5) use of one entity as a mere shell or conduit for the affairs of the other, (6) inadequate capitalization, (7) disregard of corporate formalities, (8) lack of segregation of corporate records, and (9) identical directors and officers; no one characteristic governs, but the courts must look at all the circumstances to determine whether the doctrine should be applied.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Hours and Wages. Trial court employed improper tests when determining alter ego and joint employer issues.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: GBB Properties Two, LLC v. Stirling Properties, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: The legal fiction of a distinct corporate entity may be disregarded when a corporation is so organized and controlled as to make it merely an instrumentality or adjunct of another corporation.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Contractors and Developers. Landowner's complaint stated claim against developer, a corporation, under a single-business-entity theory of piercing the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: GBB Properties Two, LLC v. Stirling Properties, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: If one corporation is wholly under the control of another, the fact that it is a separate entity does not relieve the latter from liability.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Contractors and Developers. Landowner's complaint stated claim against developer, a corporation, under a single-business-entity theory of piercing the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Chapco, Inc. v. Woodway USA, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, there are two circumstances which would permit the court to pass the liability of one business entity to another: the instrumentality rule, in which one entity is merely an instrumentality of the other; and the identity rule, in which the two entities have such a unity of interest and ownership that their independence from each other had ceased or never begun.
Document Preview: PATENTS  Consumer Goods. Alleged infringer's treadmill products infringed on patentee's patent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Chapco, Inc. v. Woodway USA, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, under the identity rule for piercing the corporate veil, if the plaintiff can show that there was such a unity of interest and ownership that the independence of the corporations had in effect ceased or had never begun, an adherence to the fiction of separate identity would serve only to defeat justice.
Document Preview: PATENTS  Consumer Goods. Alleged infringer's treadmill products infringed on patentee's patent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Moore v. Navillus Tile, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: The hallmarks of the alter ego doctrine include whether the two enterprises have substantially identical management, business purpose, operation, equipment, customers, supervision, and ownership, but not all of these factors need to be present in order to establish that two entities are alter egos, and no single factor is dispositive.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Benefit Plans. Subcontractor was alter ego of employer, and thus was obligated to make contributions to multi-employer benefit funds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Moore v. Navillus Tile, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Although the alter ego doctrine is primarily applied in situations involving successor companies, when the successor is merely a disguised continuance of the old employer, it also applies to situations when the companies are parallel companies; accordingly, two companies can be found to be alter egos when both companies exist simultaneously.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Benefit Plans. Subcontractor was alter ego of employer, and thus was obligated to make contributions to multi-employer benefit funds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Cedillo
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Examples of complete domination, such as may support piercing the corporate veil, include the following: (1) absence of corporate formalities and of paraphernalia that are part and parcel of corporate existence; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) fact that funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors and personnel; (5) common office space, address, and telephone numbers; (6) amount of business discretion displayed by allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether related corporations deal with the dominated corporation at arm's length; (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of debts of the dominated corporation by other corporations in the group, and (10) that the corporation in question had property that was used by other corporations as if it were their own.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Immigrant debtor's English-illiteracy bears on whether financial statement was submitted fraudulently.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Landmark Legacy, LP v. Runkle
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: The corporate alter ego doctrine is a device by which a plaintiff tries to show that two corporations are so closely connected that the plaintiff should be able to sue one for the actions of the other.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Sanctions. General partner and limited partnership's negligence claim against financial planner was groundless, thus warranting attorney fee award as sanction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Landmark Legacy, LP v. Runkle
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: The purpose of the corporate alter ego doctrine is to avoid the inequity that results when one corporation uses another corporation as a shield from liability.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Sanctions. General partner and limited partnership's negligence claim against financial planner was groundless, thus warranting attorney fee award as sanction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Landmark Legacy, LP v. Runkle
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: When a plaintiff seeks to pierce the corporate veil using the corporate alter ego doctrine, the court considers such factors as whether: (1) similar corporate names were used; (2) the corporations shared common principal corporate officers, directors, and employees; (3) the business purpose of the corporations were similar; and (4) the corporations were located in the same offices and used the same telephone numbers and business cards.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Sanctions. General partner and limited partnership's negligence claim against financial planner was groundless, thus warranting attorney fee award as sanction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Landmark Legacy, LP v. Runkle
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Factors indicating that a corporation is the alter ego of another may include the intermingling of business transactions, functions, property, employees, funds, records, and corporate names in dealing with the public.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Sanctions. General partner and limited partnership's negligence claim against financial planner was groundless, thus warranting attorney fee award as sanction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Neff v. Brady
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: The separate identity of corporations will be observed by the courts, even in instances where one may dominate or control the other, or may even treat it as a mere department, instrumentality or agency of the other.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Pleading. Shareholders failed to sufficiently plead claim for liability against corporation's senior vice president and general counsel under Swiss law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: 21st Century Financial Services, LLC v. Manchester Financial Bank
Court: United States District Court, S.D. California.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining alter ego liability, under California law, include inadequate capitalization, commingling of funds and other assets of the two entities, the holding out by one entity that it is liable for the debts of the other, identical equitable ownership in the two entities, use of the same offices and employees, use of one as a mere conduit for the affairs of the other, disregard of corporate formalities, lack of segregation of corporate records, and identical directors and officers.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Partnerships. General partner of limited partnership that funded bank's pre-formation expenses was not alter ego of bank.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: 21st Century Financial Services, LLC v. Manchester Financial Bank
Court: United States District Court, S.D. California.
Headnote: Common legal or equitable ownership is an important component of the unity of interest required to support alter ego liability under California law.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Partnerships. General partner of limited partnership that funded bank's pre-formation expenses was not alter ego of bank.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: LiquidX Inc. v. Brooklawn Capital, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York veil-piercing law, successor to corporation that conducted online exchange for accounts receivable exercised complete domination and control over predecessor, as would support finding it was alter ego for purposes of compelling successor's participation in arbitration between predecessor and creditor, given that the two entities were virtually indistinguishable; although predecessor hired a wind-down consultant to oversee transition and although it retained a single employee in successor's new office, successor was new company in name only as it continued to operate predecessor's business in a seamless transition after company was rebranded, and successor took over responsibility for financing and defending predecessor's outstanding legal disputes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Successor was indistinguishable from predecessor company, as would support compelling it to participate in arbitration with predecessor's creditor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: LiquidX Inc. v. Brooklawn Capital, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York veil-piercing law, successor to corporation that conducted online exchange for accounts receivable structured and executed a corporate transfer of predecessor in order to perpetrate a wrong, as would support finding it was alter ego for purposes of compelling successor's participation in arbitration between predecessor and creditor, where successor had structured a foreclosure that would allow it to acquire predecessor's business free and clear of its creditors, leaving predecessor's creditors with nothing but a shell company to litigate against.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Successor was indistinguishable from predecessor company, as would support compelling it to participate in arbitration with predecessor's creditor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Nicks v. Koch Meat Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, when determining whether a unity of interest and ownership exists to justify disregarding separate corporate identities, court looks to the following factors: (1) inadequate capitalization; (2) failing to issue stock; (3) failing to observe corporate formalities; (4) failing to pay dividends; (5) corporate insolvency; (6) nonfunctioning corporate officers; (7) missing corporate records; (8) commingling funds; (9) diverting assets to an owner or other entity to creditor detriment; (10) failing to maintain an arm's-length relationship among related entities; and (11) whether the corporation is a mere facade for a dominant owner.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. FLSA complaint sufficiently alleged employer's alter ego liability for wage and hour violations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Conde v. Sensa
Court: United States District Court, S.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, nonexclusive factors that can be used to support the unity of interest requirement for imposing alter ego liability include commingling of funds, failure to maintain minutes or adequate corporate records, identification of the equitable owners with the domination and control of the two entities, the use of the same office or business locations, the identical equitable ownership of the two entities, the use of a corporation as a mere shell, instrumentality or conduit for a single venture or the business of an individual, and the failure to adequately capitalize a corporation.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Pleading. A plaintiff may not rely on unsubstantiated state-court allegations to defeat a motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Khoobehi Properties, LLC v. Baronne Development No. 2, L.L.C.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporations are separate entities; however, the legal fiction of a distinct corporate entity may be disregarded when a corporation is so organized and controlled as to make it merely an instrumentality of another corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Seller of membership interest in LLC relinquished its right to an accounting from LLC when it sold its interest.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Khoobehi Properties, LLC v. Baronne Development No. 2, L.L.C.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: If one corporation is wholly under the control of another, the fact that it is a separate entity does not relieve the latter from liability.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Seller of membership interest in LLC relinquished its right to an accounting from LLC when it sold its interest.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Landress v. Tier One Solar LLC
Court: United States District Court, M.D. North Carolina.
Headnote: Under North Carolina's instrumentality rule, corporation will be held liable for torts of another corporation over which it exercises actual control, operating it as mere instrumentality or tool.
Document Preview: TORTS  Parties. Company's former CFO was indispensable party in investor's action against company, its parent, and other executives.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Medici v. Lifespan Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, the standard for piercing the corporate veil is a demanding one, and corporations are presumed to be separate and distinct entities notwithstanding relationships between them.
Document Preview: HEALTH  Discipline. Scientist had to exhaust his administrative remedies before Department of Health and Human Services' Office of Research Integrity before bringing suit challenging termination for research misconduct.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Medici v. Lifespan Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: There are two scenarios in which the corporate form may be disregarded under Massachusetts law: (1) the first is when there is active and direct participation by the representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in the activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of the inter-corporate relationship, and (2) the second is when there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of the separate nature of the corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about the manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: HEALTH  Discipline. Scientist had to exhaust his administrative remedies before Department of Health and Human Services' Office of Research Integrity before bringing suit challenging termination for research misconduct.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Ryan Racing, LLC v. Gentilozzi
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: To show that one entity is the mere instrumentality of another, as required to pierce the corporate veil under Michigan law, courts look to these factors: (1) whether the corporation is undercapitalized; (2) whether separate books are kept; (3) whether there are separate finances for the corporation; (4) whether the corporation is used for fraud or illegality; (5) whether corporate formalities have been followed; and (6) whether the corporation is a sham.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment debtor was undercapitalized, weighing in favor of piercing corporate veil to permit judgment creditor to collect judgment from judgment debtor's owner.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Ryan Racing, LLC v. Gentilozzi
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: In determining whether one entity is the mere instrumentality of another, as required to pierce the corporate veil under Michigan law, courts consider the commingling of funds and the extent to which the shareholder controlled the decisions of the entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment debtor was undercapitalized, weighing in favor of piercing corporate veil to permit judgment creditor to collect judgment from judgment debtor's owner.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Lieberman v. Corporacion Experienca Unica, S.A.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Transfers of funds between corporations that were memorialized in companies' records, rather than undocumented, undercut alter ego theory of liability on claim to pierce the corporate veil under Pennsylvania law.
