Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Gust, Inc. v. AlphaCap Ventures, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under California law, factors suggesting an alter ego relationship include: (1) commingling of funds and other assets and failure to segregate funds of the separate entities; (2) the treatment by an individual of the assets of the corporation as his own; (3) the disregard of legal formalities and the failure to maintain arm's length relationships among related entities; and (4) the diversion of assets from a corporation by or to a stockholder or other person or entity, to the detriment of creditors, or the manipulation of assets between entities so as to concentrate the assets in one and the liabilities in another.
Document Preview: PATENTS  Computers and Electronics. Computer-implemented method claims were directed to patent-ineligible abstract idea of managing information used to facilitate crowdfunding.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Olivieri Const. Corp. v. WN Weaver Street, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: A corporate veil will be pierced to achieve equity, even absent fraud, when a corporation has been so dominated by an individual or another corporation and its separate entity so ignored that it primarily transacts the dominator's business instead of its own and can be called the other's alter ego.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Subcontractor alleged that shareholder engaged in acts amounting to abuse of corporate form, as required to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Commodity Exchange, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, court considers a number of indicia in order to determine whether one entity dominated another such that the corporate form should be disregarded, including: (1) the failure to observe corporate formality; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of personal and corporate funds; (4) the sharing of common office space, address, and telephone numbers; (5) an overlap of ownership, directors, officers or personnel; and (6) use of the corporation as a means to perpetrate the wrongful act against plaintiff.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST  Conspiracy. Complaint sufficiently alleged gold price-fixing conspiracy against banks who participated in daily gold auctions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Smith v. Hi–Speed, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee, AT JACKSON.
Headnote: In certain cases, parties may establish, by suitable evidence, that separate corporations should be treated as a single entity.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Evidence. Parol evidence could not be used by commercial landlord to prove purported existence of a Loan Guaranty Agreement entered into with tenants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Chicago Regional Council of Carpenters Pension Fund v. TMG Corporation
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: When attempting to discern whether a new company is another's alter ego, courts, or, at trial, finders of fact, engage in a fact intensive analysis, examining factors like whether the two companies have substantially identical management, business purpose, operation, equipment, customers, supervision, and ownership.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Egan v. Tenet Health Care
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: In Massachusetts, there is a presumption of corporate separateness: separate corporations are to be treated as separate entities absent an affirmative showing of compelling circumstances.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Parent and Subsidiary. Application of doctrine of corporate disregard was not warranted in employment action, and thus service on manager at subsidiary was insufficient.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Gopal v. Kaiser Foundation Health Plan, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: The doctrine of joint enterprise, or alter ego liability, is applied when one corporation uses another to perpetrate fraud, circumvent a statute, or accomplish some other wrongful or inequitable purpose; in these situations, a court may disregard the corporate entity and treat the corporation's acts as if they were done by the persons actually controlling the corporation.
Document Preview: HEALTH  HMOs. Health plan, hospital, and hospital group were not a single enterprise as required for health plan to be vicariously liable for medical negligence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Gopal v. Kaiser Foundation Health Plan, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: Two conditions are generally required for the application of joint enterprise liability: (1) such a unity of interest and ownership that the separate corporate personalities are merged, so that one corporation is a mere adjunct of another or the two companies form a single enterprise, and (2) an inequitable result if the acts in question are treated as those of one corporation alone.
Document Preview: HEALTH  HMOs. Health plan, hospital, and hospital group were not a single enterprise as required for health plan to be vicariously liable for medical negligence.

Title: Lim v. Miller Parking Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: In deciding whether corporation is mere instrumentality of another entity, Michigan courts look to the following factors: (1) whether corporation is undercapitalized, (2) whether separate books are kept, (3) whether there are separate finances for corporation, (4) whether corporation is used for fraud or illegality, (5) whether corporate formalities have been followed, and (6) whether corporation is sham.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate entities owned by members of same family were not alter egos, and veil that separated them could not be pierced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Airbus DS Optronics GmbH v. Nivisys LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Arizona.
Headnote: To establish a claim of lender liability under the instrumentality theory, where the theory is recognized, a plaintiff must make a strong showing that the creditor assumed actual, participatory, total control of the debtor and the facts must unmistakably show that the subservient corporation was being used to further the purposes of the dominant corporation and that the subservient corporation in reality had no separate, independent existence of its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment creditor pleaded sufficient factual allegations to establish unity of control by parent corporation over subsidiaries.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >

Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: In deciding whether corporation is mere instrumentality of another entity, Michigan courts look to the following factors: (1) whether corporation is undercapitalized, (2) whether separate books are kept, (3) whether there are separate finances for corporation, (4) whether corporation is used for fraud or illegality, (5) whether corporate formalities have been followed, and (6) whether corporation is sham.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Innovative Biodefense, Inc. v. VSP Technologies, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, whether a wrongdoer is a corporate defendant's alter ego is a fact specific matter that turns on such factors as the failure to adhere to corporate formalities, undercapitalization, intermingling of funds, overlap in ownership, staff and directorship, common use of office space, the degree of discretion shown by the wrongdoer, whether the dealings between the entities are at arms length, and whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers.

Title: Continental Cas. Co. v. Symons
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Indiana law on piercing corporate veil, indicia of common identity, excessive fragmentation, or single business enterprise corporations may include, among other factors, the intermingling of business transactions, functions, property, employees, funds, records, and corporate names in dealing with the public.

Title: Steiner Elec. Co. v. Maniscalco

Headnote: If one corporation is merely a dummy or sham for another corporation, the distinct corporate entities will be disregarded and the two corporations will be treated as one.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Che v. First Assembly of God, Ruston, LA
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Second Circuit.
Headnote: When determining whether a corporation is an alter ego, agent, tool or instrumentality of another corporation, the court is required to look to the substance of the corporate structure rather than its form.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Che v. First Assembly of God, Ruston, LA
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Second Circuit.
Headnote: When determining whether a corporation is an alter ego, agent, tool or instrumentality of another corporation under single-business enterprise doctrine, court looks at following factors: whether corporations have substantial identity of ownership, that is, ownership of sufficient stock to give actual working control over another corporation; common directors or officers; unified administrative control of corporations whose business functions are similar or supplementary; directors and officers of one corporation acting independently in the interest of that corporation; corporation financing another corporation; corporation paying the salaries and other expenses or losses of another corporation; receiving no business other than that given to it by its affiliated corporations; corporation using the property of another corporation as its own; noncompliance with corporate formalities; and common employees and services rendered by the employees of one corporation on behalf of another corporation.
Document Preview: TORTS - Negligence. Church's general council and church's district council were not responsible for child's brain injuries sustained at local church.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Lyondell Chemical Company
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Federal common law allows piercing of the corporate veil where (1) a corporation uses its alter-ego status to perpetrate a fraud or (2) where it so dominates and disregards its alter-ego's corporate form that the alter-ego was actually carrying on the controlling corporation's business instead of its own.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Jurisdiction. Creditors' trust in Chapter 11 case failed to establish that subsidiary was subject to personal jurisdiction as alter ego of parent company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Gillespie Community Unit School Dist. No. 7, Macoupin County v. Union Pacific R. Co.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Fourth District.
Headnote: Generally, before the separate corporate identity of one corporation will be disregarded and treated as the "alter ego" of another, it must be shown that it is so controlled and its affairs so conducted that it is a mere instrumentality of another, and it must further appear that observance of the fiction of separate existence would, under the circumstances, sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Mineral Rights and Interests. Comparative fault is no defense to claim that mine operator is strictly liable for subsidences resulting from removal of necessary subjacent support.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re ES2 Sports & Leisure, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. North Carolina, Greensboro Division.
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, in considering factors with respect to the element of control under the instrumentality rule to pierce the corporate veil, it is not the presence or absence of any particular factor that is determinative, rather, it is a combination of factors which suggest that the corporate entity attacked had no separate mind, will or existence of its own and was therefore the mere instrumentality or tool of the dominant corporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Debtor's parent company and its majority owner were liable for unjust enrichment for retaining security deposit rightfully payable to debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Clientron Corp. v. Devon IT, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Pennsylvania law does not allow recovery unless the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil on an alter ego theory establishes that the controlling corporation wholly ignored the separate status of the controlled corporation and so dominated and controlled its affairs that its separate existence was a mere sham.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Multimillion dollar business transactions were required to be in writing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Job v. Simply Wireless, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Alexandria Division.
Headnote: Under Virginia law, piercing corporate veil requires that: (1) there be unity of interest and ownership such that corporations' separate personalities no longer exist, and (2) entity sought to be held liable has controlled or used corporation to evade personal obligation, to perpetrate fraud or crime, to commit injustice, or to gain unfair advantage.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Penalty provision of installment contract for sale of company's stock was unenforceable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Daebo International Shipping Co., Ltd.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Among the factors considered in analyzing alter ego claims in maritime cases are: (1) disregard of corporate formalities, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) intermingling of funds, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address, and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) the degree of business discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the dealings between the entities are at arms length, (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between the entities.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Maritime attachments against foreign debtor's vessel were barred by Korean court's pre-attachment stay order.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Flame S.A. v. Freight Bulk Pte. Ltd.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Because numerous factors can support the conclusion that corporations are alter egos, the inquiry is fact-intensive and specific facts may be relevant in one case and irrelevant in another.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Charters. Registered owner of vessel and maritime company were alter egos.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Licea v. Curacao Drydock Company, Incorporated
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, one of the bases for disregarding the corporate form is the alter ego doctrine, whereby a corporation is organized and operated as a mere tool or business conduit of another corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Organizational charts were not evidence sufficient to justify jurisdictional veil piercing of non-resident garnishees.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Licea v. Curacao Drydock Company, Incorporated
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, in determining whether an alter ego relationship exists, the court should focus on the relationship between the corporation and the entity or individual that allegedly abused corporate formalities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Organizational charts were not evidence sufficient to justify jurisdictional veil piercing of non-resident garnishees.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Reynolds v. Lifewatch, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, a corporate veil-piercing analysis is fact specific inquiry, and courts may consider many factors, including (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of funds; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) the degree of discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the dealings between the entities are at arms length; (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity; and (10) intermingling of property between the entities.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Unfair Practices. Consumer's allegations stated deceptive trade practices claim against seller of medical alert devices.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Success, Inc. v. Curcio
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Courts will disregard the fiction of separate legal entity when a corporation is a mere instrumentality or agent of another corporation or individual owning all or most of its stock; under such circumstances the general rule, which recognizes the individuality of corporate entities and the independent character of each in respect to their corporate transactions, and the obligations incurred by each in the course of such transactions, will be disregarded, where the interests of justice and righteous dealing so demand.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Landlord and Tenant. Plaintiff claiming to own property invalidly conveyed to him by corporation was without standing in summary process action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Berjac of Oregon
Court: United States District Court, D. Oregon.
Headnote: Under Oregon law, plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil must prove that another entity actually controlled, or was under common control with, the corporation, that the other entity used its control over the corporation to engage in improper conduct, and that, as a result of the improper conduct, plaintiff was harmed.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Trustee's fraudulent transfer claim against banks was not pleaded with sufficient particularity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Federico v. Lincoln Military Housing, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Norfolk Division.
Headnote: Under Virginia law, the mere showing that one corporation is owned by another or that they share common officers is not a sufficient justification for a court to disregard their separate corporate structure.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - Immunity. Family's claim against company that managed military housing community was not barred by derivative immunity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: American Federated Title Corp. v. GFI Management Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Non-exhaustive factors considered in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil include: (1) the absence of the formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence, i.e., issuance of stock, election of directors, keeping of corporate records and the like, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the related corporations deal with the dominated corporation at arms length, (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) the payment or guarantee of debts of the dominated corporation by other corporations in the group, and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was not warranted after companies made loan repayments to their owners.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Sentry Ins. v. Brand Management Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, a party seeking to pierce the corporate veil, and thereby hold another entity or individual liable, must show (1) the alleged alter ego exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue, and (2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Principal of related professional employment organizations was liable for debt of those organizations under alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Sentry Ins. v. Brand Management Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, court ruling on veil piercing claim of complete domination over corporation must consider (1) absence of formalities and paraphernalia for corporate existence, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) use of funds for personal rather than corporate purposes, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address, and telephone numbers, (6) the amount of discretion displayed by allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether related corporations deal with dominated corporation at arms length, (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) payment or guarantee of debts of dominated corporation by other corporations, and (10) whether dominated corporation had property used by other corporations as if it were their own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Principal of related professional employment organizations was liable for debt of those organizations under alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Mike Avila Trustee v. Bronger Masonry, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Indiana, Indianapolis Division.
Headnote: Some relevant factors for analyzing an alter ego claim are whether the companies have substantially identical management, business purpose, operation, equipment, customers, supervision, and ownership.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Employee benefit funds failed to demonstrate they would likely suffer irreparable harm without adequate remedy at law if no injunction was issued.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Mike Avila Trustee v. Bronger Masonry, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Indiana, Indianapolis Division.
Headnote: When a business entity is the alter ego of another, they are the same entity and liability is not vicarious but direct.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Employee benefit funds failed to demonstrate they would likely suffer irreparable harm without adequate remedy at law if no injunction was issued.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Northbound Group, Inc. v. Norvax, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Generally, under Illinois law, before the separate corporate identity of one corporation will be disregarded and treated as the alter ego of another, it must be shown that it is so controlled and its affairs so conducted that it is a mere instrumentality of another, and it must further appear that observance of the fiction of separate existence would, under the circumstances, sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Subsidiary was not the alter ego of its parent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Carrano
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, a plaintiff may pierce the corporate veil pursuant to the "identity rule" if the plaintiff can show that there was such a unity of interest and ownership that the independence of the corporations had in effect ceased or had never begun, and adherence to the fiction of separate identity would serve only to defeat justice and equity by permitting the economic entity to escape liability arising out of an operation conducted by one corporation for the benefit of the whole enterprise.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debt for overpayment of rent fell within the discharge exception for debts obtained through embezzlement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Raymond
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, a claim may be brought against the alter ego of a corporation when there is active and direct participation by the representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in the activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of the intercorporate relationship, or when there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of the separate nature of the corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about the manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Case Administration. Trustee failed to state plausible claim for substantive consolidation of trusts and LLCs with the bankruptcy estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Linde v. Arab Bank, PLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Traditional corporate veil-piercing factors are: (1) disregard of corporate formalities, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) intermingling of funds, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) degree of discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the dealings between the entities are at arms length, (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between the entities.
Document Preview: TORTS - Terrorism. Video wills of suicide bombers were properly admitted in action against Jordanian bank under the Anti-Terrorism Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: AngioScore, Inc. v. TriReme Medical, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in deciding whether to pierce the corporate veil under California law include: commingling of funds and other assets of the two entities, the holding out by one entity that it is liable for the debts of the other, identical equitable ownership in the two entities, use of the same offices and employees, and use of one as a mere shell or conduit for the affairs of the other, as well as inadequate capitalization, disregard of corporate formalities, lack of segregation of corporate records, and identical directors and officers.
Document Preview: PATENTS  Jurisdiction. In suit for patent infringement and state-law claims related to development of competing device, court properly exercised supplemental jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Lothrop v. North American Air Charter, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, a relationship between two corporations may result in joint liability when there is active and direct participation by the representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in the activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of the inter-corporate relationship.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. District court could not exercise personal jurisdiction over defendant under alter-ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Lothrop v. North American Air Charter, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under New York law, a corporation is considered to be a mere alter ego when it has been so dominated by another corporation and its separate identity so disregarded, that it primarily transacted the dominator's business rather than its own.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. District court could not exercise personal jurisdiction over defendant under alter-ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Lothrop v. North American Air Charter, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Massachusetts standard for disregarding the separate entities of different corporations is a demanding one.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. District court could not exercise personal jurisdiction over defendant under alter-ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Lothrop v. North American Air Charter, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under New York law, the list of facts relevant to whether there is complete control by one corporation against another, as would support piercing the corporate veil, is: (1) the absence of the formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address, and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the related corporations deal with the dominated corporation at arms length, (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) the payment or guarantee of debts of the dominated corporation by other corporations in the group, and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. District court could not exercise personal jurisdiction over defendant under alter-ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Opus East, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, to prevail on alter ego claim, plaintiff must show that entities operated as single economic entity, in manner that resulted in overall element of injustice or unfairness.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Veil could not be pierced to augment estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Stewart v. Screen Gems–EMI Music, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: When assessing whether there is a unity of interest for the purposes of alter ego liability under California law, courts consider the commingling of funds and other assets of the entities, the holding out by one entity that it is liable for the debts of the other, identical equitable ownership of the entities, use of the same offices and employees, use of one as a mere shell or conduit for the affairs of the other, inadequate capitalization, disregard of corporate formalities, lack of segregation of corporate records, and identical directors and officers.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Songwriter's widow plausibly alleged that publisher and affiliates were single enterprise for purposes of her claim for breach of royalty contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Stewart v. Screen Gems–EMI Music, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: To invoke the alter ego doctrine under California law, a plaintiff must allege facts sufficient to support a plausible claim that: (1) there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the two corporations no longer exist, and (2) if the acts are treated as those of only one of the corporations, an inequitable result will follow.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Songwriter's widow plausibly alleged that publisher and affiliates were single enterprise for purposes of her claim for breach of royalty contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Meridian North Investments LP v. Sondhi
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: In considering whether two separate corporations should be treated as one, factors that may be considered include whether (1) similar corporate names were used; (2) multiple corporations shared common officers, directors, and employees; (3) the business purposes of the corporations were similar; and (4) the corporations were located in the same offices and used the same telephone numbers and business cards.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Landlord and Tenant. Provision of lease for office building that president signed purporting to absolve lessor from liability for injuries to tenants did not apply to president.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Gerritsen v. Warner Bros. Entertainment Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, a plaintiff may plead unity of interest between a corporation and its equitable owner, for purposes of establishing alter ego liability, by relying on a number of different factors, including commingling of funds and other assets of the two entities, the holding out by one entity that it is liable for the debts of the other, identical equitable ownership in the two entities, use of the same offices and employees, and use of one as a mere shell or conduit for the affairs of the other.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Author failed to allege that there was a contract between her and entertainment company that produced film allegedly based on her novel.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: U.S. v. Cochran
Court: United States District Court, E.D. North Carolina, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Several factors guide the determination of whether one entity constitutes the alter ego of another, such that piercing the corporate veil is warranted, including gross undercapitalization, insolvency, siphoning of funds, failure to observe corporate formalities and maintain proper corporate records, non-functioning of officers, control by a dominant stockholder, injustice or fundamental unfairness, as well as intermingling of funds, overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and other personnel, common office space, the degrees of discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation, and whether the dealings of the entities are at arm's length.
Document Preview: CIVIL RIGHTS - Pleading. United States failed to properly plead alter ego or piercing the corporate veil theory of liability under the FHA, and thus the theory was not actionable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Motorola Mobility LLC v. AU Optronics Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: A corporation is not entitled to establish and use its affiliates' separate legal existence for some purposes, yet have their separate corporate existence disregarded for its own benefit against third parties.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST - Pricing. Foreign companies' sale of price-fixed goods to plaintiff's foreign subsidiaries did not give rise to antitrust claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: DBT Yuma, L.L.C. v. Yuma County Airport Authority
Court: Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division 1.
Headnote: For one corporate entity to be the alter ego of another, as could support imposition of vicarious liability on the other, plaintiffs must show evidence of unity of control, that observance of alleged alter ego's corporate form would sanction a fraud or promote injustice, and that the individuality or separateness of the two has ceased to exist.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - Municipalities. Statute providing that airport authority functions as agency of county did not impose vicarious liability on county.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: DBT Yuma, L.L.C. v. Yuma County Airport Authority
Court: Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division 1.
Headnote: The factors to determine whether one corporate entity has substantial total control over another, as could support imposition of alter ego vicarious liability on entity with control, include whether one entity owned stock in the other entity, whether the two entities shared common officers or directors, whether one entity financed the other entity or paid the other entity's employees salaries or other expenses, whether one entity failed to maintain the formalities of corporate existence, whether the two entities shared similar logos, and whether one entity did not know it was a corporate entity separate from the other entity.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - Municipalities. Statute providing that airport authority functions as agency of county did not impose vicarious liability on county.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Liberty Synergistics, Inc. v. Microflo Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: On a claim to pierce the corporate veil under New York law, courts consider ten equitable factors in determining whether the alleged alter ego exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue, including: (1) the absence of the formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence, that is, issuance of stock, election of directors, keeping of corporate records and the like; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address, and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the related corporations deal with the dominated corporation at arms length; (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) the payment or guarantee of debts of the dominated corporation by other corporations in the group; and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: TORTS - Malicious Prosecution. Plaintiff established favorable termination element of malicious prosecution claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Ng v. Adler
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: In determining owners' domination of corporation, for purposes of piercing the corporate veil under New York law, courts consider, inter alia, the following factors: (1) whether corporate formalities are observed, (2) whether the capitalization is adequate, (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes, (4) whether there is overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) whether the corporation is treated as an independent profit center, and (6) whether others pay or guarantee debts of the dominated corporation; there is no set rule as to how many factors must be present in order to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Bankruptcy Court did not err in piercing corporate veil and holding debtor liable for debts of corporations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association v. United States Commodity Futures Trading Commission
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: When a corporate family chooses to use the corporate form to its advantage for some purpose, e.g., operational efficiency, tax or regulation avoidance, or limited liability, it cannot then disavow that form when it becomes inconvenient during litigation.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION  Trading and Markets. Regulations governing extraterritorial application of swaps trading were remanded to agency.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Davis v. Ricketts
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: In situations where the court is asked to disregard the separate and distinct form of legal entities, and consider entities as an integrated enterprise, the standards are narrow and rigorous, imposing a presumption of corporate separateness.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Unfair Labor Practices. Two entities were not integrated enterprise for purposes of Title VII numerosity requirement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Kutty v. U.S. Dept. of Labor
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, when determining whether to pierce corporate veil, court should consider not only whether entity has been used to work fraud or injustice in contravention of public policy, but also (1) whether there was failure to collect paid in capital; (2) whether corporation was grossly undercapitalized; (3) nonissuance of stock certificates; (4) sole ownership of stock by one individual; (5) use of same office or business location; (6) employment of same employees or attorneys; (7) corporation's use as instrumentality or business conduit for individual or another corporation; (8) diversion of corporate assets by or to stockholder or other entity to detriment of creditors, or manipulation of assets and liabilities in another; (9) corporation's use as subterfuge in illegal transactions; (10) formation and use of corporation to transfer to it existing liability of another person or entity; and (11) failure to maintain arms length relationships among related entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil was warranted to hold medical clinic operator personally liable for immigration violations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: American Federated Title Corp. v. GFI Management Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In considering whether a corporation has been sufficiently dominated to justify piercing the corporate veil, New York courts consider a number of factors, including: (1) the absence of the formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the related corporations deal with the dominated corporation at arms length; (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) the payment or guarantee of debts of the dominated corporation by other corporations in the group; and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment-creditor sufficiently alleged that three corporations were dominated and controlled by shareholders.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: A.V.E.L.A., Inc. v. Estate of Monroe
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, the factors to be considered when determining whether the corporate veil should be pierced include: (1) the absence of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and employees; (4) common office space, address, and telephone numbers; (5) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation; and (6) arms length business dealings between the related corporations.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Pleading. Neither undue delay, undue prejudice, nor futility precluded granting of a motion to amend a counterclaim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Ferrara v. Smithtown Trucking Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Test of alter ego status is flexible, allowing courts to weigh the circumstances of the individual case, while recognizing that the following factors are important: whether the two enterprises have substantially identical management, business purpose, operation, equipment, customers, supervision, and ownership.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Pleading. Trustees of multiemployer plan could amend pleading to join defendants to hold them liable under ERISA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Hasso v. Hapke
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Among the factors to be considered in applying the alter ego doctrine are commingling of funds and other assets of the two entities, the holding out by one entity that it is liable for the debts of the other, identical equitable ownership in the two entities, use of the same offices and employees, and use of one as a mere shell or conduit for the affairs of the other; no one characteristic governs, but the courts must look at all the circumstances to determine whether the doctrine should be applied.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION  Fraud. Trustee could not reasonably rely on any material misrepresentations about hedge fund investment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Flame S.A. v. Industrial Carriers, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Norfolk Division.
Headnote: Several factors guide the determination of whether one entity constitutes the alter ego of another, warranting piercing of the corporate veil, including gross undercapitalization, insolvency, siphoning of funds, failure to observe corporate formalities and maintain proper corporate records, non-functioning of officers, control by a dominant stockholder, injustice or fundamental unfairness, intermingling of funds, overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and other personnel, common office space, the degrees of discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation, and whether the dealings of the entities are at arm's length.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Attachment. Equitable vacatur of maritime attachments applies only domestically.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Sandoval v. Ali
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: In assessing alter ego under California law, courts consider the commingling of funds and other assets of the entities, the holding out by one entity that it is liable for the debts of the other, identical equitable ownership of the entities, use of the same offices and employees, use of one as a mere shell or conduit for the affairs of the other, inadequate capitalization, disregard of corporate formalities, lack of segregation of corporate records, and identical directors and officers.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Hours and Wages. Res judicata did not bar employees' putative class claims against employers, alleging violations FLSA and California's Unfair Competition Law (UCL).

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Lakah v. UBS AG
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In determining whether one entity dominates another, as required for piercing the corporate veil, courts consider many factors, including: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of funds; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) the degree of discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the dealings between the entities are at arm's length; (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity; and (10) intermingling of property between the entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil, so as to render arbitration agreement binding as against non-signatory, was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Norfolk Southern Ry. Co. v. National Union Fire Ins. of Pittsburgh, PA
Court: United States District Court, S.D. West Virginia.
Headnote: In West Virginia, the law presumes that two separately incorporated businesses are separate entities; however, justice may require that courts look beyond the bare legal relationship of the parties to prevent the corporate form from being used to perpetrate injustice, defeat public convenience or justify wrong.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Liability. Minimum coverage obligation was not a cap on obligation of insured to provide additional insured coverage.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Crowley Marine Services, Inc. v. Vigor Marine LLC
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Washington, at Seattle.
Headnote: The alter ego doctrine requires that the controlling corporate entity exercise total domination of the subservient corporation, to the extent that the subservient corporation manifests no separate corporate interests of its own and functions solely to achieve the purposes of the dominant corporation.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Collision. A ship repair service provider was not entitled to off-set of damages after ship it contracted to repair sank.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re JMK Construction Group, Ltd.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, in deciding whether piercing of the corporate veil is warranted, courts consider multiple factors to determine whether requisite domination and control of corporation exists, including (1) disregard of corporate formalities, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) intermingling of funds, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address, and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) degree of discretion shown by allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether dealings between entities are at arms length, (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) payment or guarantee of corporation's debts by dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between the entities.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Debtor's customer had standing and could assert claims for conversion and unjust enrichment against debtor's president.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Dry Handy Investments, Ltd. v. Corvina Shipping Co. S.A.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Norfolk Division.
Headnote: The alter ego doctrine may be used to hold shareholders liable for the debts of their corporation through traditional veil piercing, to hold a corporation liable for the debts of a sole shareholder through reverse veil piercing, or to hold parent, subsidiary, or affiliate corporations liable for the debts of another corporation.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Attachment. Alter ego relationship with claimant of attached ship was not shown.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Dry Handy Investments, Ltd. v. Corvina Shipping Co. S.A.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Norfolk Division.
Headnote: Factors that guide the determination of whether one entity constitutes the alter ego of another, for purposes of piercing the corporate veil, include gross undercapitalization, insolvency, siphoning of funds, failure to observe corporate formalities and maintain proper corporate records, non-functioning of officers, control by a dominant stockholder, injustice or fundamental unfairness, intermingling of funds, overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and other personnel, common office space, the degrees of discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation, and whether the dealings of the entities are at arm's length.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Attachment. Alter ego relationship with claimant of attached ship was not shown.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Bridge Street Automotive, Inc. v. Green Valley Oil, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, corporate formalities may be disregarded and the corporate veil may be pierced (1) when there is active and direct participation by the representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in the activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of the intercorporate relationship; or (2) when there is confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of the separate nature of the corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about the manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Gas station owner did not establish relatedness prong of test for specific jurisdiction over lessor's alleged alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re SK Foods, LP
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. California, Sacramento Division.
Headnote: Under California law, relevant factors considered in evaluating alter ego liability include (1) commingling of funds and other assets, failure to segregate funds of the separate entities, and the unauthorized diversion of corporate funds or assets to other than corporate uses, (2) treatment by an individual of the assets of the corporation as his own, (3) domination and control of the two entities by the equitable owners or managers of the entities, (4) disregard of legal formalities and the failure to maintain arm's length relationships among related entities, and (5) diversion of assets from a corporation by or to a stockholder or other person or entity, to the detriment of creditors, or the manipulation of assets and liabilities between entities so as to concentrate the assets in one and the liabilities in another.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Substantive consolidation of related entities with Chapter 11 debtors' estates was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Alkanani v. Aegis Defense Services, LLC
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under District of Columbia law, to pierce the corporate veil of two corporations and thereby for the purpose of establishing that one is the alter ego of the other, Plaintiff must show by affirmative evidence there is not only unity of ownership and interest between the two corporations, but also use of the corporate form to perpetrate fraud or wrong; in addition, the relevant time period for assessing whether two entities are alter egos is the time during which a business relationship existed between the plaintiff and defendant.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Subsidiary of military contractor could not be held liable for injuries caused, prior to its corporate existence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Alkanani v. Aegis Defense Services, LLC
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: To assess whether two corporations have a unity of ownership and interest sufficient to pierce the corporate veil, the court may consider: (1) the nature of the corporate ownership and control; (2) failure to maintain corporate minutes or records; (3) failure to maintain corporate formalities; (4) commingling of funds and assets; (5) diversion of one corporation's funds to the other's uses; and (6) use of the same office or business location.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Subsidiary of military contractor could not be held liable for injuries caused, prior to its corporate existence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Alkanani v. Aegis Defense Services, LLC
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: The relevant time period for examining whether two entities are alter egos, for purposes of piercing the corporate veil, is the time during which a business relationship existed between plaintiff and defendant.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Subsidiary of military contractor could not be held liable for injuries caused, prior to its corporate existence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Toho–Towa Co., Ltd. v. Morgan Creek Productions, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 5, California.
Headnote: A court may disregard the corporate form in order to hold one corporation liable for the debts of another affiliated corporation when the latter is so organized and controlled, and its affairs are so conducted, as to make it merely an instrumentality, agency, conduit, or adjunct of another corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Movie studio was properly added to judgment against affiliates as alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Toho–Towa Co., Ltd. v. Morgan Creek Productions, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 5, California.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, factors for the trial court to consider include the commingling of funds and assets of the two entities, identical equitable ownership in the two entities, use of the same offices and employees, disregard of corporate formalities, identical directors and officers, and use of one as a mere shell or conduit for the affairs of the other.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Movie studio was properly added to judgment against affiliates as alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Swan v. Board of Educ. of City of Chicago
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In determining whether the requisite degree of control is maintained by one corporation over another, a consideration in evaluating the applicability of the corporate veil-piercing doctrine, Illinois courts consider several factors, including (1) the failure to maintain adequate corporate records or to comply with corporate formalities; (2) the commingling of funds or assets; (3) undercapitalization; and (4) one corporation treating the assets of another corporation as its own.
Document Preview: EDUCATION - Disabled Students. Parents' action against city for allegedly discriminatory closure of public schools failed to state a claim for ADA violation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: McDaniel v. Board of Educ. of City of Chicago
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In determining whether the requisite degree of control for piercing the corporate veil is maintained by one corporation over another, Illinois courts consider several factors, including: (1) the failure to maintain adequate corporate records or to comply with corporate formalities; (2) the commingling of funds or assets; (3) undercapitalization; and (4) one corporation treating the assets of another corporation as its own.
Document Preview: EDUCATION - School Boards. Parents could not pierce school board's corporate veil to sue Chicago for board's closure of schools.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: McDaniel v. Board of Educ. of City of Chicago
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Plaintiffs do not have the right under Illinois law to pierce the corporate veil of a statutorily-created corporation to reach a municipality.
Document Preview: EDUCATION - School Boards. Parents could not pierce school board's corporate veil to sue Chicago for board's closure of schools.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: BP Environmental Services, Inc. v. Republic Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Pennsylvania law does not permit piercing of the corporate veil unless the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil on an alter-ego theory establishes that the controlling corporation wholly ignored the separate status of the controlled corporation and so dominated and controlled its affairs that its separate existence was a mere sham.
Document Preview: TORTS - Tortious Interference. A second waste hauler did not tortiously interfere with the contract between an original waste hauler and its client.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: W & W Steel, LLC v. BSC Steel, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: To arrive at a determination that one corporation is the alter ego of another, it must be shown that allowing the legal fiction of separate corporate structures results in an injustice.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Subcontractor stated a negligent misrepresentation claim against contractor and intermediary through which it was hired.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: JMB Mfg., Inc. v. Child Craft, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Indiana, New Albany Division.
Headnote: Under Indiana law, the corporate identity can be disregarded under the "alter ego" doctrine where one corporation is so organized and controlled and its affairs so conducted that it is a mere instrumentality or adjunct of another corporation.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. A fact issue existed as to whether a manufacturer waived its contractual remedies under the perfect tender rule.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: JMB Mfg., Inc. v. Child Craft, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Indiana, New Albany Division.
Headnote: Under Indiana law, application of the "alter ego" doctrine to disregard the corporate form and hold individuals personally liable is done to avoid the inequity that results when one corporation uses another corporation as a shield from liability.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. A fact issue existed as to whether a manufacturer waived its contractual remedies under the perfect tender rule.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: JMB Mfg., Inc. v. Child Craft, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Indiana, New Albany Division.
Headnote: Under Indiana law, factors in considering whether to apply the "alter ego" doctrine to disregard the corporate form and hold individuals personally liable are: (1) similar corporate name; (2) common principle corporate officers, directors, and employees; (3) similar business purposes; and (4) same office locations, telephone numbers, and business cards.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. A fact issue existed as to whether a manufacturer waived its contractual remedies under the perfect tender rule.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: National Integrated Group Pension Plan v. Dunhill Food Equipment Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, in determining whether owners exercised complete domination of corporation, such that piercing corporate veil is warranted, court should consider: (1) absence of formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of corporate existence, such as issuance of stock, election of directors, keeping of corporate records, and the like, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) amount of business discretion displayed by allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether related corporations deal with dominated corporation at arms length, (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) payment or guarantee of debts of dominated corporation by other corporations in group, and (10) whether corporation had property that was used by other corporations as if it were their own.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Employer's owner was jointly and severally liable for its withdrawal liability to multiemployer pension plan.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Gulf Fleet Holdings, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Louisiana, Lafayette Division.
Headnote: Delaware law recognizes the traditional alter ego doctrine as grounds to pierce the corporate veil in cases involving the members of a corporate group.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Trustee did not adequately allege claim to avoid repayment of insider's $4,000,000 loan as constructive fraudulent transfer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Gulf Fleet Holdings, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Louisiana, Lafayette Division.
