Headnote: Under Delaware law, if plaintiff seeks to establish alter ego liability for all members of a corporate group, it must establish liability with respect to each one of the entities.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Trustee did not adequately allege claim to avoid repayment of insider's $4,000,000 loan as constructive fraudulent transfer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Vitol, S.A. v. Primerose Shipping Co. Ltd.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Factors that guide the determination of whether one entity constitutes the alter ego of another include gross under-capitalization, insolvency, siphoning of funds, failure to observe corporate formalities and maintain proper corporate records, non-functioning of officers, control by a dominant stockholder, and injustice or fundamental unfairness; other factors properly considered include intermingling of funds, overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and other personnel, common office space, the degrees of discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation, and whether the dealings of the entities are at arm's length.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Jurisdiction. Legal action in Commercial Court of English High Court of Justice did not divest resulting judgment of admiralty character.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Canal Indem. Co. v. Regency Club Owners Ass'n
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Alabama, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Alabama law, a loan of money from one company to another does not make the two companies liable for one another's obligations.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Liability. General contractor was not covered by a policy provision affording coverage to additional insureds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Reed v. Reid
Court: Supreme Court of Indiana.
Headnote: While no one talismanic fact will justify with impunity piercing the corporate veil, a careful review of the entire relationship between various corporate entities, their directors and officers may reveal that such an equitable action is warranted.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Representation that allegedly hazardous waste to be dumped on landowner's property was clean fill could support fraud claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Michaels v. Banks
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Multiple factors are considered in determining whether domination and control is established, for purposes of piercing a corporate veil, such as the following: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of funds; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) the degree of discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the dealings between the entities are at arms length; (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between the entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Triable fact issues regarding piercing of the corporate veil precluded summary judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Cleveland v. Johnson
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 8.
Headnote: If a corporation organizes another corporation with practically the same shareholders and directors, transfers all the assets but does not pay all the first corporation's debts, and continues to carry on the same business, the separate entities may be disregarded and the new corporation held liable for the obligations of the old, and whether that has happened depends on all the facts and circumstances.
Document Preview: E-COMMERCE - Business Organizations. Corporation was subject to successor liability for another company's separate line of business.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: NECA-IBEW Pension Trust Fund v. Bays Elec., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. Illinois, Urbana Division.
Headnote: Alter ego analysis is very fact intensive and centers around several factors which involve whether the enterprises share substantially identical: (1) management; (2) business purposes; (3) operations; (4) equipment; (5) customers; (6) supervision; and (7) ownership.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Alter ego theory applied to render defendants liable for ERISA fund contributions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: NECA-IBEW Pension Trust Fund v. Bays Elec., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. Illinois, Urbana Division.
Headnote: No one factor of the alter ego analysis is determinative, and thus, alter-ego status may be established where one or more of the elements is missing and, consequently, an alter ego relationship may exist even though there is no evidence of actual common ownership.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Alter ego theory applied to render defendants liable for ERISA fund contributions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Tryco Enterprises, Inc. v. Robinson
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: In determining whether the persons or corporate entities sought to be charged with liability are alter egos of the primary debtor, as required to disregard the corporate form and pierce the corporate veil, the relationship between corporate entities can be assessed using factors such as: (1) whether the entities shared a common business name, common offices, common employees, or centralized accounting; (2) whether one entity paid the wages of the other entity's employees; (3) whether one entity's employees rendered services on behalf of the other entity; (4) whether one entity made undocumented transfers of funds to the other entity; and (5) whether the allocation of profits and losses between the entities is unclear. V.T.C.A., Bus. & C. § 21.223(a)(2).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate forms of former employer and employer's successor were alter egos of owners, as grounds for piercing corporate veil to enforce judgment against employer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Chinese Manufactured Drywall Products Liability Litigation
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, the factors to be considered to determine whether one entity is an alter ego of another, or whether two entities are a single business enterprise, are similar, and include but are not limited to: (1) common ownership; (2) common directors and officers; (3) common employees; (4) common offices; (5) unified administrative control; (6) similar or supplementary business functions; (7) one corporation financing the other; (8) inadequate capitalization; (9) one corporation's creation of the other; (10) one corporation paying the salaries, expenses, or losses of the other corporation; (11) one corporation receiving no business other than that given to it by the affiliated corporation; (12) shared property; (13) noncompliance with corporate formalities; (14) services rendered by the employees of one corporation on behalf of another corporation; (15) centralized accounting; (16) undocumented transfer of funds between corporations; (17) unclear allocation of profits and losses between corporations; and (18) excessive fragmentation of a single enterprise into separate corporations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Chinese manufacturer's wholly-owned subsidiary operated as alter ego or agent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Konrad Motor and Welder Service, Inc. v. Magnetech Industrial Services, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Corporate identity may be disregarded where one corporation is so organized and controlled and its affairs so conducted that it is a mere instrumentality or adjunct of another corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. New company was contractor's alter ego and thus was liable for judgment against contractor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Konrad Motor and Welder Service, Inc. v. Magnetech Industrial Services, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: The corporate alter ego doctrine is a device by which a plaintiff tries to show that two corporations are so closely connected that the plaintiff should be able to sue one for the actions of the other.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. New company was contractor's alter ego and thus was liable for judgment against contractor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Konrad Motor and Welder Service, Inc. v. Magnetech Industrial Services, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: The purpose of the corporate alter ego doctrine is to avoid the inequity that results when one corporation uses another corporation as a shield from liability.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. New company was contractor's alter ego and thus was liable for judgment against contractor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Konrad Motor and Welder Service, Inc. v. Magnetech Industrial Services, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: When a plaintiff seeks to pierce the corporate veil using the alter ego doctrine, the court considers factors including whether: (1) similar corporate names were used, (2) the corporations shared common principal corporate officers, directors, and employees, (3) the business purposes of the corporations were similar, and (4) the corporations were located in the same offices and used the same telephone numbers and business cards.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. New company was contractor's alter ego and thus was liable for judgment against contractor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Konrad Motor and Welder Service, Inc. v. Magnetech Industrial Services, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Factors indicating that a corporation is the alter ego of another may include the intermingling of business transactions, functions, property, employees, funds, records, and corporate names in dealing with the public.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. New company was contractor's alter ego and thus was liable for judgment against contractor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Bank of Montreal v. SK Foods, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California, San Jose Division.
Headnote: To determine whether there is sufficient unity of interest and ownership to support alter ego liability under California law, courts consider non-exhaustive list of factors: (1) commingling of funds and other assets, failure to segregate funds of separate entities, and unauthorized diversion of corporate funds or assets to other than corporate uses, (2) treatment by individual of corporate assets as his own, (3) failure to obtain authority to issue stock or to subscribe to or issue same, (4) holding out by individual that he is personally liable for debts of corporation, (5) failure to maintain minutes or adequate corporate records, and confusion of records of separate entities, (6) identical equitable ownership in two entities, (7) identification of equitable owners thereof with domination and control of two entities, (8) identification of directors and officers of two entities in responsible supervision and management, (9) sole ownership of all of stock in corporation by one individual or members of family, (10) use of same office or business location, (11) employment of same employees and/or attorney, (12) failure to adequately capitalize corporation, (13) total absence of corporate assets and undercapitalization, (14) use of corporation as mere shell, instrumentality, or conduit for single venture or business of individual or another corporation, (15) concealment and misrepresentation of identity of responsible ownership, management, and financial interest, or concealment of personal business activities, (16) disregard of legal formalities and failure to maintain arm's length relationships among related entities, (17) use of corporate entity to procure labor, services, or merchandise for another person or entity, (18) diversion of assets from corporation by or to stockholder or other person or entity, to detriment of creditors, or manipulation of assets and liabilities between entities so as to concentrate assets in one and liabilities in another, (19) contracting with another with intent to avoid performance by use of corporate entity as shield against personal liability, or use of corporation as subterfuge of illegal transactions, and (20) formation and use of corporation to transfer to it existing liability of another person or entity.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Jurisdiction. Transfer or dismissal of action related to substantive consolidation proceeding before bankruptcy court was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Continental Motors, Inc. v. Jewell Aircraft, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Alabama law, the corporate veil cannot be pierced unless the dominant corporation: (1) misused that control, and (2) proximately caused harm to the plaintiff through such misuse.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Piercing the corporate veil so as to establish personal jurisdiction against nonresident defendants was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Sperry Associates Federal Credit Union v. Space Coast Credit Union
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Orlando Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, a plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil and hold a corporation responsible for actions of another entity must show that: (1) the corporation dominated the entity to such an extent that its separate existence was non-existent; (2) the corporate form was used fraudulently or for an improper purpose; and (3) this fraudulent use of the corporate structure caused plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. LLC was not alter ego of its managing member.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Dollar Tree Stores Inc. v. Toyama Partners LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, when courts consider the alter ego doctrine they look to numerous factors, including inadequate capitalization, commingling of funds and other assets of the two entities, the holding out by one entity that it is liable for the debts of the other, identical equitable ownership in the two entities, use of the same offices and employees, use of one as a mere conduit for the affairs of the other, disregard of corporate formalities, lack of segregation of corporate records, and identical directors and officers.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Landlord and Tenant. Under California law, liquidated damages provision in commercial lease was an unenforceable penalty.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Mama's Enterprises, LLC v. U.S.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Alabama, Northeastern Division.
Headnote: Alabama law provides that a corporation may be the alter-ego of a person or another entity, and that the corporate veil may be pierced when evidence establishes that to be the case.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Collection. Internal Revenue Service could levy funds from limited liability companies to recover member's tax deficiencies.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Battino v. Cornelia Fifth Ave., LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, factors that courts consider when determining whether it is appropriate to pierce the corporate veil include: (1) the absence of the formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence, i.e., issuance of stock, election of directors, keeping of corporate records and the like, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the related corporations deal with the dominated corporation at arms length, (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) the payment or guarantee of debts of the dominated corporation by other corporations in the group, and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Judgment. Issues of material fact precluded summary judgment on issue of successor liability in FLSA unpaid wages action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Rev O, Inc. v. Woo
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: It is not the presence or absence of any particular factor that is determinative of the level of control exercised over a corporation, for purposes of a request to pierce the corporate veil; rather, it is a combination of factors which suggest that the corporate entity attacked had no separate mind, will or existence of its own and was therefore the mere instrumentality or tool of the dominant corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. LLC manager's asset sale and distribution to member did not result in an inability to pay debts as they came due.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: A.P.I., Inc. Asbestos Settlement Trust v. Home Ins. Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, agency relationship can exist between corporations, such as when one corporation makes contract on other's account; likewise, subsidiary may become agent for corporation which controls it.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parent corporation did not abuse corporate form by creating subsidiary to manage insurance company it had acquired.

Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, simply requiring one company to cooperate with another does not create agency relationship.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parent corporation did not abuse corporate form by creating subsidiary to manage insurance company it had acquired.

Title: Admiral Ins. Co., Inc. v. Arrowood Indem. Co.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Under Texas alter ego law, factors to be considered when determining whether constituent corporations have not been maintained as separate entities include, but are not limited to, the following: common employees; common offices; centralized accounting; payment of wages by one corporation to another corporation's employees; common business name; services rendered by employees of one corporation on behalf of another corporation; undocumented transfers of funds between corporations; and unclear allocation of profits and losses between corporations.

Title: In re Adler
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors relevant to determining whether a corporation has been dominated by its owners, for purposes of claim to pierce the corporate veil, include (1) absence of formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of corporate existence, such as issuance of stock, election of directors, keeping of corporate records and the like, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address, and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) amount of business discretion displayed by allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether related corporations deal with dominated corporation at arms length, (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) payment or guarantee of debts of dominated corporation by other corporations in group, and (10) whether corporation had property that was used by another corporation as if it were its own.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Debtor's domination of corporations and use of those corporations to commit wrong permitted piercing corporate veil.

Title: Road Sprinkler Fitters Local Union No. 669, U.A., AFL-CIO v. Dorn Sprinkler Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Where two companies are engaged in the same business in the same marketplace, courts ask whether the two enterprises have substantially identical management, business purpose, operation, equipment, customers, supervision, and ownership to decide whether one is the alter ego of the other.

Title: Rapid Settlements, Ltd.'s Application for Approval of Transfer of Structured Settlement Payment Rights
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 3.
Headnote: A court will pierce the corporate veil and find a corporate entity is one and the same with another corporate entity when the corporate form has been intentionally used to violate or evade a duty.

Title: Clipper Wonsild Tankers Holding A/S v. Biodiesel Ventures, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors relevant to determining whether one entity is the alter ego of another, and thus whether to pierce the corporate veil, include: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of funds; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) the degree of business discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the dealings between the entities are at arms length; (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between the entities.

Title: Oracle 1031 Exchange, LLC v. Bourque
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Corporations are generally recognized as separate entities; however, the legal fiction of a distinct corporate entity may be disregarded when a corporation is so organized and controlled as to make it merely an instrumentality or adjunct of another corporation.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Mineral Rights and Interests. Assigned oil lessee, well operator and driller were liable in solido for penalties and attorney fees for failing to pay royalties.

Title: Metso Minerals, Inc. v. Powerscreen Intern. Distribution Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: To determine whether the necessary dominion and control exists for the court to pierce the corporate veil, the court must examine several factors, including (1) the sharing of a common office, staff, and ownership, (2) the intermingling of funds, (3) the treatment of the corporations as one, not separate, profit centers, (4) the lack of the conventions of corporate existence, and (5) any inadequate earnings.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Evidence. Alleged discovery of newly discovered evidence did not warrant new trial on patent infringement.

Title: Howsden v. Roper's Real Estate Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: When two companies are corporations which benefit from legally recognized identities separate and apart from one another, they must also bear the responsibility and liability of such separation when sued by an injured employee.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Corporate employee's claim against separate legal entity owned by same shareholders was not barred by exclusive remedy provision.

Title: Canal Ins. Co. v. Montello, Inc.

Headnote: Under Oklahoma law, one corporation may be held liable for the acts of another under the theory of alter-ego liability if (1) the separate existence is a design or scheme to perpetuate a fraud or (2) one corporation is merely an instrumentality or agent of the other.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Insured stated a claim against insurer's owner for alter-ego liability under Indiana law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Canal Ins. Co. v. Montello, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Oklahoma.
Headnote: Under Oklahoma law, courts may consider a list of nine factors, hinging primarily on control, when determining whether to hold one corporation liable for the acts of another corporation, including (1) whether the dominant corporation owns or subscribes to all the subservient corporation's stock, (2) whether the dominant corporation and subservient corporations have common directors and officers, (3) whether the dominant corporation provides financing to the subservient corporation, (4) whether the subservient corporation is grossly undercapitalized, (5) whether the dominant corporation pays the salaries, expenses, or losses of the subservient corporation, (6) whether most of the subservient corporation's business is with the dominant corporation or the subservient corporation's assets were conveyed from the dominant corporation, (7) whether the dominant corporation refers to the subservient corporation as a division or department, (8) whether the subservient corporation's officers or directors follow the dominant corporation's directions, and (9) whether the corporations observe the legal formalities for keeping the entities separate.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Insured stated a claim against insurer's owner for alter-ego liability under Indiana law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Constellation Energy Commodities Group Inc. v. Transfield ER Cape Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: A number of factors are relevant to determining whether to pierce the corporate veil: (1) disregard of corporate formalities, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) intermingling of funds, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address, and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) degree of discretion shown by allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether dealings between entities are at arms length, (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) payment or guarantee of corporation's debts by dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Arbitration. Maryland corporation's two London arbitration awards against British Virgin Islands (BVI) corporation were enforceable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Phillips, Spallas & Angstadt, LLP v. Fotouhi
Court: Court of Appeal, First District, Division 5, California.
Headnote: If a corporation organizes another corporation with practically the same shareholders and directors, transfers all the assets but does not pay all the first corporation's debts, and continues to carry on the same business, the separate entities may be disregarded and the new corporation held liable for the obligations of the old.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Court could apply to new professional corporation order charging debtor attorney's interest in partnership.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Walsh v. Kindred Healthcare
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, among the factors to be considered in applying the alter ego doctrine are commingling of funds and other assets of the two entities, the holding out by one entity that it is liable for the debts of the other, identical equitable ownership in the two entities, use of the same offices and employees, and use of one as a mere shell or conduit for the affairs of the other.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Skilled nursing facility (SNF) residents' allegations were sufficient to invoke alter ego doctrine for class action claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Wehlage v. EmpRes Healthcare, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, factors that a court may consider in determining whether defendant business entities are subject to the alter ego doctrine include the commingling of funds and assets of the two entities, identical equitable ownership in the two entities, use of the same offices and employees, disregard of corporate formalities, identical directors and officers, and use of one as a mere shell or conduit for the affairs of the other.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Residential Facilities. Skilled nursing facility (SNF) resident stated claim against SNF operator for violation of nurse staffing requirement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Peery v. United Capital Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Factors considered in determining whether veil-piercing is warranted include: (1) absence of formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence, that is, issuance of stock, election of directors, keeping of corporate records, and the like, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address, and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) amount of business discretion displayed by allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether related corporations deal with dominated corporation at arms length, (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) payment or guarantee of debts of dominated corporation by other corporations in group, and (10) whether corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Lessor stated cause of action to hold defendants liable for breach of commercial lease under a veil-piercing theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Expert South Tulsa, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Under Oklahoma law, the "alter ego" doctrine allows plaintiff to reach a second corporation or individual upon a cause of action that otherwise would have existed only against the first corporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Debtor Protections. Postpetition actions taken against debtor's principals in state court violated automatic stay, and were void.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Alki Partners, L.P. v. Vatas Holding GmbH
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, factors court considers in determining whether to pierce corporate veil include: corporate organizational and structural factors such as the failure to adhere to corporate formalities, undercapitalization, intermingling of funds, overlap in ownership, staff and directorship, common use of office space, degree of discretion shown by wrongdoer, whether dealings between entities are at arms' length, and whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Jurisdiction. Court had personal jurisdiction over Swiss broker.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Trenwick America Reinsurance Corp. v. IRC, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, a court may disregard the separateness of legal entities only in rare situations where it is necessary to prevent gross inequity, and when there is evidence of (1) a fraudulent or injurious consequence of the intercorporate relationship or (2) a confused intermingling of activity with substantial disregard of the separate nature of the corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about the manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Unfair Practices. Reinsurer engaged in unfair and deceptive trade practices in violation of Massachusetts law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Salkin v. United Services Auto. Ass'n
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, factors court should consider in determining whether to apply alter ego doctrine are: commingling of funds and other assets of two entities, holding out by one entity that it is liable for debts of the other, identical equitable ownership in the two entities, use of same offices and employees, and use of one as mere shell or conduit for affairs of the other.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Removal. Life insurer's parent company was fraudulently joined to defeat removal based on diversity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Atkinson, Haskins, Nellis, Holeman, Phipps, Brittingham & Gladd v. Vector Securities, Inc.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 4.
Headnote: One corporation, or a shareholder, may be held liable for the acts of another if the other is determined to be merely an instrumentality or agent of the other corporation or shareholder.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Judgment. Offensive nonmutual collateral estoppel applied to establish that corporate defendants were alter egos of one another.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Atkinson, Haskins, Nellis, Holeman, Phipps, Brittingham & Gladd v. Vector Securities, Inc.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 4.
Headnote: The factors relevant to determining alter ego include: (1) whether the dominant corporation owns or subscribes to all the subservient corporation's stock; (2) whether the dominant and subservient corporations have common directors and officers; (3) whether the dominant corporation provides financing to the subservient corporation; (4) whether the subservient corporation is grossly undercapitalized; (5) whether the dominant corporation pays the salaries, expenses or losses of the subservient corporation; (6) whether most of the subservient corporation's business is with the dominant corporation or the subservient corporation's assets were conveyed from the dominant corporation; (7) whether the dominant corporation refers to the subservient corporation as a division or department; (8) whether the subservient corporation's officers or directors follow the dominant corporation's directions; and (9) whether the corporations observe the legal formalities for keeping the entities separate.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Judgment. Offensive nonmutual collateral estoppel applied to establish that corporate defendants were alter egos of one another.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Antone's Records, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Texas, Austin Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, corporate veil may be pierced when corporation was formed and operated to serve as tool or conduit of person or another corporation as alter ego.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Showing of actual fraud was necessary to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Shaoxing County Huayue Import & Export v. Bhaumik
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 5, California.
Headnote: Factors for the trial court to consider when determining whether to pierce the corporate veil include the commingling of funds and assets of the two entities, identical equitable ownership in the two entities, use of the same offices and employees, disregard of corporate formalities, identical directors and officers, and use of one as a mere shell or conduit for the affairs of the other; no one characteristic governs, but the courts must look at all the circumstances to determine whether the doctrine should be applied.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Alter ego allegations did not become the property of the bankruptcy estate once corporate debtor filed for bankruptcy.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Weitz Co. v. MH Washington
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Missouri law, when one corporation so dominates and controls another that it becomes a mere alter ego of the first and the formal corporate separateness is used to accomplish a fraud, injustice, or some unlawful purpose, then the separate formal corporate structures are ignored.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Developer of townhome property controlled corporation for purposes of liability for breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Weitz Co. v. MH Washington
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Missouri's alter ego rule, court may disregard a separate corporation if the separateness is used to defraud a creditor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Developer of townhome property controlled corporation for purposes of liability for breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Weitz Co. v. MH Washington
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: In order to establish a principal-agent relationship between two corporations, under Missouri law, for purposes of imposing liability on principal for agent's actions, there must be such domination and control that the controlled corporation has, so to speak, no separate mind, will or existence of its own and is but a business conduit for its principal.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Developer of townhome property controlled corporation for purposes of liability for breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Tronox, Inc. Securities Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, while one corporation whose shares are owned by a second corporation does not, by that fact alone, become agent of second company, a corporation completely independent of a second corporation may assume role of second corporation's agent in the course of one or more specific transactions.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Fraud. Investors sufficiently alleged control person liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Greenspan v. LADT, LLC
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: The alter ego test encompasses a host of factors, including: (1) commingling of funds and other assets, failure to segregate funds of the separate entities, and the unauthorized diversion of corporate funds or assets to other than corporate uses, (2) the treatment by an individual of the assets of the corporation as his own, (3) the failure to obtain authority to issue stock or to subscribe to or issue the same, (4) the holding out by an individual that he is personally liable for the debts of the corporation, the failure to maintain minutes or adequate corporate records, and the confusion of the records of the separate entities, (5) the identical equitable ownership in the two entities, the identification of the equitable owners thereof with the domination and control of the two entities, identification of the directors and officers of the two entities in the responsible supervision and management, sole ownership of all of the stock in a corporation by one individual or the members of a family, (6) the use of the same office or business location, the employment of the same employees and/or attorney, (7) the failure to adequately capitalize a corporation, the total absence of corporate assets, and undercapitalization, (8) the use of a corporation as a mere shell, instrumentality or conduit for a single venture or the business of an individual or another corporation, (9) the concealment and misrepresentation of the identity of the responsible ownership, management and financial interest, or concealment of personal business activities, (10) the disregard of legal formalities and the failure to maintain arm's length relationships among related entities, (11) the use of the corporate entity to procure labor, services or merchandise for another person or entity, (12) the diversion of assets from a corporation by or to a stockholder or other person or entity, to the detriment of creditors, or the manipulation of assets and liabilities between entities so as to concentrate the assets in one and the liabilities in another, (13) the contracting with another with intent to avoid performance by use of a corporate entity as a shield against personal liability, or the use of a corporation as a subterfuge of illegal transactions, and (14) and the formation and use of a corporation to transfer to it the existing liability of another person or entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Res judicata did not prohibit amendment of judgment to add debtor, under alter ego theory, who was successful in underlying arbitration.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: IMark Marketing Services, LLC v. Geoplast S.p.A.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under District of Columbia law, in determining whether one corporation is alter ego of another, court must consider whether: (1) there is unity of interest and ownership between corporations such that their separate corporate personalities no longer exist; and (2) inequitable result will occur if acts are treated as only those of other corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Subsidiary's contacts were attributable to parent for purposes of establishing personal jurisdiction over it.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: TechTarget, Inc. v. Spark Design, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, a court may disregard corporate formalities and pierce the corporate veil when there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in common enterprise with substantial disregard of the separate nature of the corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about the manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Advertising firm could not pierce the corporate veil of client.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Port Drivers Federation 18, Inc. v. All Saints Exp., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil under New Jersey law is appropriate where one corporation so dominated another corporation that it had no separate existence and was merely conduit of another corporation, and dominant corporation used controlled company to perpetuate fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: TRANSPORTATION - Carriers. Primary business exemption to federal Truth in Leasing regulations was inapplicable to truckers' claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Port Drivers Federation 18, Inc. v. All Saints Exp., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Relevant factors in determining whether one corporation is organized and operated as to make it mere instrumentality of another corporation, as required to pierce corporate veil under New Jersey law, include: (1) gross undercapitalization; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) non-payment of dividends; (4) insolvency of debtor corporation at time; (5) non-functioning of other officers or directors; (6) absence of corporate records; and (7) fact that corporation is merely façade for operations of dominant stockholder or stockholders.
Document Preview: TRANSPORTATION - Carriers. Primary business exemption to federal Truth in Leasing regulations was inapplicable to truckers' claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Breen v. Judge
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Courts, in assessing whether an entity is dominated or controlled, for purposes of determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, look for the presence of a number of factors, including: (1) the absence of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) overlapping ownership, officers, directors, personnel; (5) common office space, address, phones; (6) the amount of business discretion by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the corporations dealt with each other at arm's length; (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of debts of the dominated corporation; and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Judgment creditors were not entitled to piercing of LLC's corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Motorola Credit Corp. v. Uzan
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, party seeking to pierce corporate veil must establish that controlling corporation abused privilege of doing business in corporate form to perpetrate wrong or injustice against that party such that court in equity will intervene.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Cypriot company was judgment debtors' alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Flynn v. R.D. Masonry, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: To determine whether two businesses are alter egos, the court evaluates similarities between two enterprises in their ownership, management, business purpose, operations, equipment, and customers; in analysis, no single factor is controlling, and all need not be present to support finding of alter ego status.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. ERISA provision authorizing nationwide service of process on defendants granted District Court personal jurisdiction over employers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Broadstripe, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: To prevail on an alter ego claim under Delaware law, a plaintiff must show (1) that the companies operated as a single economic entity, and (2) that an overall element of injustice or unfairness is present.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Summary judgment was not warranted in committee's action for equitable subordination.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Jackson v. Tanfoglio Giuseppe, S.R.L.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, the factors to be considered to determine whether one entity is an alter ego of another, or whether two entities are a single business enterprise, such that court with jurisdiction over the entity has jurisdiction over the alter ego, include, but are not limited to (1) common ownership, directors and officers, employees, and offices; (2) unified control; (3) inadequate capitalization; (4) noncompliance with corporate formalities; (5) centralized accounting; (6) unclear allocation of profits and losses between corporations; (7) one corporation paying the salaries, expenses, or losses of another corporation; and (8) undocumented transfers of funds between entities.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Jurisdiction. Court lacked personal jurisdiction over Italian firearms manufacturer in products liability suit.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Tall v. Comcast of Potomac, LLC
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under District of Columbia law, to establish that one corporation is an alter ego of a second corporation, plaintiff must show by affirmative evidence that there is not only unity of ownership and interest between the two corporations, but also use of the corporate form to perpetrate fraud or wrong.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Common website of national and local cable companies did not establish a agency relationship.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Tall v. Comcast of Potomac, LLC
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under District of Columbia law, relevant factors in determining whether there is a unity of interest between two corporations, as would establish that one is an alter ego of the other, include whether corporate formalities have been disregarded, and whether there has occurred an intermingling of corporate and personal funds, staff, property.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Common website of national and local cable companies did not establish a agency relationship.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Zimmerman v. Puccio
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Court of Appeals treads carefully when determining whether it is appropriate to put aside the basic tenet of corporate law that corporations, notwithstanding relationships between or among them, ordinarily are regarded as separate and distinct entities, and thereby to allow a plaintiff to pierce the corporate veil of limited liability.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Consumer Protection. Credit counseling agency was credit repair organizations within meaning of Credit Repair Organizations Act (CROA).

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Federal Nat. Mortg. Ass'n v. Olympia Mortg. Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: In determining whether an owner exercised complete domination over corporation, so as to warrant piercing of corporate veil under New York law, courts look to a number of factors, including: (1) the absence of the formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the related corporations deal with the dominated corporation at arms length, (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) the payment or guarantee of debts of the dominated corporation by the corporation, and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by the corporation as if it were its own.

Title: Foley v. Trinity Industries Leasing Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: To "fuse" two corporations for purposes of personal jurisdiction, the plaintiff must prove one company controls the internal business operations and affairs of the other, and the degree of control exercised must be greater than that normally associated with common ownership and directorship; the evidence must show that the two entities cease to be separate so that the corporate fiction should be disregarded to prevent fraud or injustice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Foley v. Trinity Industries Leasing Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: To determine whether two corporations should be "fused" for purposes of personal jurisdiction, all of the relevant facts and circumstances surrounding the operations of the two corporations must be examined to determine whether two separate and distinct corporate entities exist, and these factors include the amount of the corporation's stock owned by the other entity, the existence of separate headquarters, the observance of corporate formalities, and the degree of one corporation's control over the general policy and administration of the other entity.

Title: Martin v. ReliaStar Life Ins. Co.

Headnote: Fiction of corporate entity may be disregarded, where one corporation is so organized and controlled and its affairs are so conducted that it is, in fact, a mere instrumentality or adjunct of another corporation.
