Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Johnson v. Avco Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: A court can consider several factors in deciding whether to pierce the corporate veil under Indiana law, including: (1) whether the corporations used similar names, (2) whether the corporation shared common principal corporate officers, (3) whether the corporations' business purposes were similar, (4) whether the corporations were located in the same offices and used the same telephone numbers and business cards, or (5) whether the corporations are manipulated or controlled as one enterprise to cause illegality, fraud, or injustice.
Document Preview: TRANSPORTATION - Aviation. Dismissal as sanction for spoliation of evidence was not warranted in wrongful death action arising out of airplane crash.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Naples v. Keystone Bldg. and Development Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Courts, in assessing whether an entity is dominated or controlled, for purposes of piercing the corporate veil, consider a number of factors, including: (1) the absence of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) overlapping ownership, officers, directors, personnel; (5) common office space, address, phones; (6) the amount of business discretion by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the corporations dealt with each other at arm's length; (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of debts of the dominated corporation; and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Vendor and Purchaser. Amount of damages awarded to new home purchasers was clearly erroneous.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Naples v. Keystone Bldg. and Development Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The identity rule, as basis for piercing the corporate veil, is applicable against individuals, as well as corporations.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Vendor and Purchaser. Amount of damages awarded to new home purchasers was clearly erroneous.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Trabucco v. Intesa Sanpaolo, S.p.A.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, one corporation is considered to be mere alter ego when it has been so dominated by another corporation and its separate identity so disregarded, that it primarily transacted dominator's business rather than its own.
Document Preview: FINANCE AND BANKING - Jurisdiction. Bank purposefully availed itself of privilege of conducting activities within New York forum.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Koninklijke Philips Electronics N.V. v. The ADS Group
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: On a claim to pierce the corporate veil under New York law, when analyzing the domination and control element, a court considers: (1) whether corporate formalities are observed; (2) whether the capitalization is adequate; (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) whether there is overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) whether the corporate entities share common office space, address and telephone numbers; (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the alleged dominator deals with the dominated corporation at arms length; (8) whether the corporation is treated as an independent profit center; (9) whether others pay or guarantee debts of the dominated corporation; and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by the alleged dominator as if it were the dominator's own.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Computers and Electronics. Controlling corporation to produce products that infringed patent was not inducement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Schreiber v. Philips Display Components Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Test to determine alter ego status is whether the two enterprises have substantially identical management, business purpose, operation, equipment, customers, supervision and ownership.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Collective Bargaining. Employer's successor was not alter ego of employer and thus did not retain employer's labor law obligations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Schreiber v. Philips Display Components Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Essential inquiry under an alter ego analysis is whether there was a bona fide discontinuance and a true change of ownership or merely a disguised continuance of the old employer.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Collective Bargaining. Employer's successor was not alter ego of employer and thus did not retain employer's labor law obligations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Schreiber v. Philips Display Components Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Deciding whether a successor corporation is really the predecessor corporation by another name, as required to prove alter ego status, requires an examination of all the circumstances of the case, and a weighing of all the relevant factors.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Collective Bargaining. Employer's successor was not alter ego of employer and thus did not retain employer's labor law obligations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Williams v. Lovell Safety Management Co., LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Corporate veil will be pierced to achieve equity, even absent fraud, when corporation has been so dominated by individual or another corporation and its separate entity so ignored that it primarily transacts dominator's business instead of its own and can be called the other's alter ego.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Injured plaintiff could not pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Industrial Technology Ventures LP v. Pleasant T. Rowland Revocable Trust
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, lender liability through use of instrumentality doctrine is predicated on unmistakable showing that subservient corporation in reality has no separate, independent existence of its own and was being used to further dominant corporation's purposes.
Document Preview: TORTS - Tortious Interference. Majority shareholders and CEO did not tortiously interfere with minority shareholder's right of first refusal.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Brookridge Funding Corp. v. Aquamarine, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, a corporation or other person controlling a corporation and directing, or participating actively in its operations may become subject to civil or criminal liability on principles of agency or of causation.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Fish buyer was not unjustly enriched at secured lender's expense.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Ypsilanti Community Utilities Authority v. Meadwestvaco Air Systems, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: In order to move behind the corporate form to impose liability on one company for the actions of another, a plaintiff must demonstrate, under Michigan law, (1) that the corporate entity to be disregarded was a mere instrumentality of another entity; (2) that this corporate entity was used to commit a fraud or wrong; and (3) that the plaintiff suffered an unjust loss.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Representations made by joint venture's principal owner were not mere puffery or opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Fantazia Intern. Corp. v. CPL Furs New York, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: In order to pierce corporate veil, a plaintiff must show that the dominant corporation exercised complete domination and control with respect to the transaction attacked, and that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong causing injury to the plaintiff.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. New York furrier was not alter ego of German corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Fantazia Intern. Corp. v. CPL Furs New York, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining whether to pierce corporate veil include: the disregard of corporate formalities, inadequate capitalization, intermingling of funds, overlap in ownership, officers, directors and personnel, common office space or telephone numbers, the degree of discretion demonstrated by the allegedly dominated corporation, whether dealings between the entities are at arm's length, whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, and the payment or guaranty of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity; but no one factor is dispositive.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. New York furrier was not alter ego of German corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Fischer Inv. Capital, Inc. v. Catawba Development Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: The presence or absence of any particular factor under the instrumentality test is not determinative in establishing a claim for disregarding the corporate entity or piercing the corporate veil; rather, it is a combination of factors which suggest that the corporate entity attacked had no separate mind, will or existence of its own and was therefore the mere instrumentality or tool of the dominant corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Lender sufficiently alleged claim to pierce corporate veil of corporation of which guarantor was majority shareholder.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Callahan
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, there are two circumstances in which piercing corporate veil is appropriate: (1) when there is active and direct participation by representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising form of pervasive control, in activities of another, and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of the intercorporate relationship; or (2) when there is confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in common enterprise, with substantial disregard of separate nature of corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about manner and capacity in which various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Liens. Tax lien did not attach to property titled solely in name of taxpayer's wife.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Washington Mut., Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Under "alter ego theory," under Washington law, a court may disregard the corporate form to defeat fraud or injustice to third parties if one corporation so dominates and controls another as to make that other merely an adjunct to it.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Mortgages and Deeds of Trust. Mortgagor's complaint did not state plausible claim that holding company was liable for misconduct in servicing mortgage.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: All Star Enterprise, Inc. v. Buchanan
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil for jurisdictional purposes, a plaintiff must prove that one company controls the internal business operations and affairs of the other to such an extent that the two entities cease to be separate so that the corporate fiction should be disregarded to prevent fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: E-COMMERCE - Jurisdiction. Website was too passive to establish systematic and continuous contacts sufficient to support general jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: All Star Enterprise, Inc. v. Buchanan
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: A blurring of the distinction between corporate entities is insufficient to support jurisdictional veil-piercing, because if affiliated companies maintain separate and distinct corporate entities, the presence of one in a forum state may not be attributed to the other.
Document Preview: E-COMMERCE - Jurisdiction. Website was too passive to establish systematic and continuous contacts sufficient to support general jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: McAnaney v. Astoria Financial Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York., E.D. New York.
Headnote: Courts look to several non-exclusive factors to determine whether the necessary dominion and control exists to pierce the corporate veil under New York law, including: (1) the absence of the formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors and personnel; (5) common office space, addresses and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the related corporations deal with the dominated corporation at arms length; (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) the payment or guarantee of debts of the dominated corporation by other corporations in the group; and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were their own.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - States. Mortgagors' claim against mortgagees under New York Real Property Law was preempted by Home Owners' Loan Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Laborers' Pension Fund v. Lay-Com, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, in the veil-piercing analysis a laundry list of factors is considered to determine whether there is a unity of interest between two corporations or between a corporation and a controlling shareholder or other dominant personality, but the focus is on whether the corporations have respected corporate formalities, that is, respected their separateness from each other, or whether one was a sham acting at the whim of the other.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was warranted to recover unpaid contributions to union-administered pension and welfare funds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Board of Managers of 195 Hudson Street Condominium v. Jeffrey M. Brown Associates, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In order to determine whether corporation is dominated, for purposes of piercing corporate veil under New York law, courts consider: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of funds; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers; (6) amount of discretion shown by allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether alleged dominator deals with corporation at arms length; (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) whether others pay or guarantee debts of dominated corporation; and (10) intermingling of property between alleged dominator and corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Judgment. Condominium association board's claim against holding company was precluded by res judicata.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Wilson v. Davis
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Although the relationship between two entities is one consideration to disregarding the corporate form, the other consideration is whether the entities' use of limited liability was illegitimate.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Fact issue barred summary judgment for closely held corporation on alter ego theory of liability for fatal accident.

Title: New York Dist. Council of Carpenters Pension Fund v. Perimeter Interiors, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Two businesses are alter egos if they have substantially identical management, business purpose, operation, equipment, customers, supervision, and ownership.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Corporation did not have to pay contributions for payments to president, precluding pension funds' recovery in ERISA action.

Title: RaceRedi Motorsports, LLC v. Dart Machinery, Ltd.

Headnote: Maryland courts generally employ great caution and reluctance in applying the alter-ego theory to separate legal entities.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Gass v. Anna Hosp. Corp.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Fifth District.
Headnote: Stock ownership alone in one corporation by another neither creates an identity of corporate interest between the two companies nor renders the stockholding company the owner of the property of the other nor creates the relation of principal and agent, representative, or alter ego between the two.

Title: Gass v. Anna Hosp. Corp.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Fifth District.
Headnote: If one corporation is merely a dummy or sham for another corporation, the distinct corporate entities will be disregarded and the two corporations will be treated as one.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Venue. Personal representative of patient's estate failed to join hospital's parent corporation in good faith.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Gass v. Anna Hosp. Corp.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Fifth District.
Headnote: A party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must make a substantial showing that (1) there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporations no longer exist, and (2) circumstances exist so that adherence to the fiction of a separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or promote inequitable consequences.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Venue. Personal representative of patient's estate failed to join hospital's parent corporation in good faith.

Title: Tredit Tire & Wheel Co., Inc. v. Regency Conversions, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, to pierce the corporate veil so as to reach past the separate corporate existence and impose one company's liability upon another, a plaintiff must show: (1) that the corporate entity to be disregarded was a mere instrumentality of another entity; (2) that this corporate entity was used to commit a fraud or wrong; and (3) that the plaintiff suffered an unjust loss.

Title: In re South African Apartheid Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors that are relevant to determining whether a corporation's form should be respected include: (1) disregard of corporate formalities, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) intermingling of funds, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) the degree of discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the dealings between the entities are at arms length, (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between the entities.

Title: R & D Muller, Ltd. v. Fontaine's Auction Gallery, LLC
Court: Appeals Court of Massachusetts.
Headnote: Despite the general rule that a corporation and its stockholders are separate legal entities, one corporation, or a person controlling it, may become liable for the acts or torts of an affiliate or a subsidiary under common control, where additional facts permit the conclusion that an agency or similar relationship exists between the entities.
Document Preview: LEGAL SERVICES - Conflict of Interest. Plaintiff's law firm's prior representation of defendant was substantially related to current action such that firm was disqualified.

Title: R.F.M.A.S., Inc. v. Mimi So
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To succeed on an "alter ego" claim under Delaware law, and permit piercing the corporate veil of a company to assert liability, plaintiff must show that the two corporations operated as a single economic entity and that there is an overall element of injustice or unfairness present.
Document Preview: COPYRIGHTS - Art and Architecture. Competitors did not directly infringe owner's copyright to pieces of jewelry.

Title: R.F.M.A.S., Inc. v. Mimi So
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, a variety of factors may be examined to determine whether separate legal entities should be considered as alter egos, including whether the corporation was adequately capitalized, paid regular dividends, kept corporate records and observed other corporate formalities.
Document Preview: COPYRIGHTS - Art and Architecture. Competitors did not directly infringe owner's copyright to pieces of jewelry.

Title: In re The Heritage Organization, L.L.C.

Headnote: Under Delaware law, no single factor can justify a decision to disregard the corporate entity; law requires a strong case to induce court of equity to consider two corporations as one.

Title: In re The Heritage Organization, L.L.C.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, when two entities with common ownership fail to follow legal formalities when contracting with each other, this is tantamount to declaring that they are indeed one in the same, for veil-piercing purposes.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. LLC's membership distributions were actually fraudulent to creditors under Texas law.

Title: In re Friedlander Capital Management Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida, West Palm Beach Division.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, "identity rule" requires that proponent of veil piercing claim show that there was such a unity of interest and ownership that the independence of the corporations had in effect ceased or had never begun, and adherence to the fiction of separate identity would serve only to defeat justice and equity by permitting the economic entity to escape liability arising out of an operation conducted by one corporation for the benefit of the whole enterprise.

Title: Classic Maritime Inc. v. Limbungan Makmur SDN BHD
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To determine whether a company is the alter ego of another, as would warrant piercing of corporate veil, a court considers the following factors, among others: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of funds; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) degree of discretion shown by allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether dealings between entities are at arm"s length; (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of corporation's debts by dominating entity; and (10) intermingling of property between entities.

Title: Arctic Ocean Intern., Ltd. v. High Seas Shipping Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: When considering whether to pierce a corporate veil based on allegations of alter ego liability, courts may consider the following factors: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of funds; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) the degree of discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the dealings between the entities are at arms length; (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between the entities.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Attachment. Eleven months of failed attempts at locating funds subject to Rule B maritime attachment rendered court without jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Ramirez v. STi Prepaid LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law, a plaintiff may state a claim for piercing the corporate veil by showing: (1) one corporation is organized and operated as to make it a mere instrumentality of another corporation, and (2) the dominant corporation is using the subservient corporation to perpetrate fraud, to accomplish injustice, or to circumvent the law.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegations were insufficient to pierce corporate veil and hold company liable under New Jersey Consumer Fraud Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: LaSalle Nat. Bank Ass'n v. Paloian
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Illinois courts apply two-part test to determine whether one corporation is alter ego of another, looking first to whether corporation is so controlled and its affairs are so conducted that it is mere instrumentality of another, and secondly to whether observance of fiction of separate existence would, under the circumstances, sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Trust was initial transferee of fraudulently transferred funds even without carte blanche authority over funds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Gateway I Group, Inc. v. Park Ave. Physicians, P.C.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Indicia of a situation warranting veil-piercing include: (1) the absence of the formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence, i.e., issuance of stock, election of directors, keeping of corporate records and the like, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the related corporations deal with the dominated corporation at arms length, (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) the payment or guarantee of debts of the dominated corporation by other corporations in the group, and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Landlord and Tenant. Landlord's allegations were sufficient to state claim that medical groups assumed assignment of lease.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Budisukma Permai SDN BHD v. N.M.K. Products & Agencies Lanka (Private) Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Although guiding principle for determining whether to pierce the corporate veil is achieving an equitable result, relevant factors in evaluating sufficiency of veil-piercing claim include (1) disregard of corporate formalities, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) intermingling of funds, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address, and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) the degree of discretion shown by allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether dealings between entities are at arms-length, (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) payment or guarantee of corporation's debts by dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between entities.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Attachment and Garnishment. Plaintiff need only make prima facie showing of alter ego liability to avoid vacatur of maritime attachment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Old Orchard Urban Limited Partnership v. Harry Rosen, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: The use of common officers and directors, or the sharing of office space, without more, does not render one corporation liable for the obligations of another.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Illinois courts did not have specific jurisdiction over Canadian parent corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Troyk v. Farmers Group, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: Factors for the trial court to consider in applying alter ego doctrine include the commingling of funds and assets of the two entities, identical equitable ownership in the two entities, use of the same offices and employees, disregard of corporate formalities, identical directors and officers, and use of one as a mere shell or conduit for the affairs of the other; no one characteristic governs, but the courts must look at all the circumstances to determine whether the doctrine should be applied.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Premiums. Premium in statute requiring insurance policy to state the premium, includes service charge imposed for payment of stated insurance premium for term policy.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Guinan v. A.I. duPont Hosp. for Children
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Factors to consider when determining whether complete domination exists, for purposes of determining whether to pierce the corporate veil under New York law, include: (1) disregard of corporate formalities, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) intermingling of funds, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) the degree of discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the dealings between the entities are at arms length, (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between the entities.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Warranties. Minor child who received heart stent did not have breach of implied warranty claim against stent manufacturer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Wooley v. Lucksinger
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, alter ego, rather than single business enterprise, is the proper description for piercing the corporate veil. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21(A)(2).
Document Preview: HEALTH - HMOs. Seller and buyer of health maintenance organization did not operate as single business enterprise prior to or after sale.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Wooley v. Lucksinger
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, the factors to be considered in determining whether the corporate veil should be pierced and separate corporations be treated as one enterprise include: (1) common employees, (2) common offices, (3) centralized accounting, (4) payment of wages by one corporation to another corporation's employees, (5) common business name, (6) services rendered by employees of one corporation on behalf of another corporation, and (7) unclear allocation of profits and losses between corporations.
Document Preview: HEALTH - HMOs. Seller and buyer of health maintenance organization did not operate as single business enterprise prior to or after sale.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Telenor Mobile Communications AS v. Storm LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, in determining whether to pierce corporate veil, court should consider: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of funds; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address, and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) degree of discretion shown by allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether dealings between entities are at arms length; (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of corporation's debts by dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Contempt. Sanction of $100,000 per day, doubling every 30 days until shareholder complied with arbitration award, was appropriate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: SSP Partners v. Gladstrong Investments (USA) Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: Corporations are not liable for each other's obligations merely because of centralized control, mutual purposes, and shared finances; there must also be evidence of abuse, or injustice and inequity, meaning not a subjective perception of unfairness by an individual judge or juror, but rather, fraud, evasion of existing obligations, circumvention of statutes, monopolization, criminal conduct, and the like.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporations can not be held liable for each other's obligations merely because they are part of a single business enterprise.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: SSP Partners v. Gladstrong Investments (USA) Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: Disregarding the corporate structure involves two considerations; one is the relationship between two entities, and the other is whether the entities' use of limited liability was illegitimate.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporations can not be held liable for each other's obligations merely because they are part of a single business enterprise.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: SSP Partners v. Gladstrong Investments (USA) Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: Determination of whether two entities' use of limited liability was illegitimate, as would support disregarding the corporate structure, must be based on a careful evaluation of the policies supporting the principle of limited liability.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporations can not be held liable for each other's obligations merely because they are part of a single business enterprise.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Amaranth Natural Gas Commodities Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors that are relevant under New York law to determining whether to pierce the corporate veil are: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of fluids; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) the degree of discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the dealings between the entities are at arms length; (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between the entities.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Commodity Futures. Repeatedly sale of futures before close of settlement period gave rise to commodities manipulation claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: French-Tex Cleaners, Inc. v. Cafaro Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: A plaintiff seeking to pierce corporate veil in order hold an alleged alter ego corporation liable for the acts of another corporation has burden to establish that other corporation was so ignored, controlled, or manipulated that it was merely the instrumentality of alleged alter ego corporation and that the misuse of the corporate form would constitute a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Landlord and Tenant. Landlord could not be liable for conversion based on its alleged breach of commercial lease.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: French-Tex Cleaners, Inc. v. Cafaro Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil in order hold one corporation liable for the acts of another requires evidence of: (1) undercapitalization; (2) absence of corporate records; (3) fraudulent representation by corporation shareholders or directors; (4) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice or illegal activities; (5) payment by the corporation of individual obligations; (6) commingling of assets and affairs; (7) failure to observe required corporate formalities; or (8) other shareholder acts or conduct ignoring, controlling, or manipulating the corporate form.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Landlord and Tenant. Landlord could not be liable for conversion based on its alleged breach of commercial lease.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Citgo Petroleum Corp. v. Ranger Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: To disregard the corporate entity and pierce the corporate veil, a party must show either (1) that the separate corporate existence is a design or scheme to perpetuate fraud; or (2) that one corporation is so organized and controlled and its affairs so conducted that it is merely an instrumentality or adjunct of another corporation.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Petroleum Marketing Practices Act. Gas station franchisee did not reasonably rely on statement of franchisor's representative, which at most modified agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: NetJets Aviation, Inc. v. LHC Communications, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, numerous factors come into play when determining whether separate legal entities should be regarded as alter egos, and the legal test for determining when a corporate form should be ignored in equity cannot be reduced to a single formula that is neither over-nor under-inclusive.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Plaintiff's breach of contract claims were not duplicative of its claims for account stated.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: NetJets Aviation, Inc. v. LHC Communications, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, the inquiry in determining whether separate legal entities should be regarded as alter egos initially focuses on whether those in control of a corporation did not treat the corporation as a distinct entity, and, if they did not, the court then seeks to evaluate the specific facts with a standard of fraud or misuse or some other general term of reproach in mind, such as whether the corporation was used to engage in conduct that was inequitable, prohibited, an unfair trade practice, or illegal.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Plaintiff's breach of contract claims were not duplicative of its claims for account stated.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Sullivan v. General Helicopters, Int'l
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Factors necessary for a court to disregard corporate form in determining whether one corporate entity is the alter ego of another include: gross undercapitalization, insolvency, siphoning of funds, failure to observe corporate formalities and maintain proper corporate records, non-functioning of officers, control by a dominant stockholder, and injustice or fundamental fairness.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Salvage. District court had admiralty jurisdiction over marine salvage award action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Ketchem v. American Acceptance, Co., LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Indiana, Hammond Division.
Headnote: Under Indiana law, while no one talismanic fact will justify with impunity piercing the corporate veil, a careful review of the entire relationship between various corporate entities, their directors, and officers, may reveal that such an equitable action is warranted.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Debtor stated claim under FDCPA for improperly seeking attorney fees for representation by related entity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Connecticut Light and Power Co. v. Westview Carlton Group, LLC
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Courts, in assessing whether a corporation is dominated or controlled by another corporation in which defendant is a shareholder, for purposes of piercing the corporate veil, look for the presence of a number of factors, including: (1) absence of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) overlapping ownership, officers, directors, personnel; (5) common office space, address, phones; (6) amount of business discretion by allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether corporations dealt with each other at arm's length; (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of debts of allegedly dominated corporation; and (10) whether allegedly dominated corporation had property that was used by other corporation as if it were its own.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Landlord and Tenant. Utility was not required to apply for appointment of rent receiver.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Michigan Elec. Employees Pension Fund v. Encompass Elec. & Data, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: To determine "alter ego" status in situation where new employer is merely disguised continuance of the old, court asks whether the two enterprises have substantially identical management, business, purpose, operation, equipment, customers, supervision, and ownership; no one of these factors is controlling but rather analysis is flexible, and court evaluates all relevant factors together and can find alter ego status even if not all of them are present.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Collective Bargaining. Electrical contractor whose president signed letters of assent was bound by CBAs expressly incorporated by reference therein.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Sandoval v. American Building Maintenance Industries, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Factors for ascertaining whether one company so dominates or controls another company such that liability must be imputed to first company include: (1) interrelation of operations; (2) centralized control of labor relations; (3) common management; and (4) common ownership or financial control.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Alleged sexual harassers lacked actual authority to make significant changes in employee status.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Saft America, Inc. v. Plainview Batteries, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: When the corporation is so operated that it is a mere instrumentality or alter ego of the sole or dominant shareholder and a shield for his activities in violation of the declared public policy or statute of the state, the corporate entity will be disregarded and the corporation and the shareholder treated as one and the same person, it being immaterial whether the sole or dominant shareholder is an individual or another corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegations in complaint stated basis for claim of piercing corporate veil to establish personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: AGS Capital Corp., Inc. v. Product Action Intern., LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: The doctrine of "piercing the corporate veil" can be used in certain circumstances to hold individuals or another corporation liable for the actions of a corporation.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Trade Secrets. Civil remedy portion of Indiana's RICO statute is not preempted by Indiana Uniform Trade Secrets Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Greenfield Energy, Inc. v. Duprey
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Generally, whether one describes the theory for imputing one corporation's contacts to another as a theory of agency or alter ego, the critical test remains that of the right or exercise of control.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Subsidiaries did not serve as parent corporations's agents for purposes of imputing subsidiaries' jurisdictional contacts.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Galvan v. Caviness Packing Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Amarillo Division.
Headnote: In determining if a company is the alter ego of another, district courts consider a "laundry list" of factors, including whether or not the two companies have common stock ownership, common directors or officers, common business departments, file consolidated tax returns or financial statements, are jointly financed, are incorporated together, if one operates with grossly inadequate capital, if salaries and expenses of one are paid by the other, if all business of one is provided by the other, if property of one is used by the other as its own, if daily operations are not kept separately, and if one company does not observe the basic corporate formalities.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Several plaintiffs in representative action could not maintain retaliation claims against their employer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Jackson v. Loews Washington Cinemas, Inc.
Court: District of Columbia Court of Appeals.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil between two corporations and thereby establish that one is the alter ego of the other, a plaintiff must show by affirmative evidence that there is not only unity of ownership and interest between the two corporations, but also use of the corporate form to perpetrate fraud or wrong; the fraud, however, need not directly taint the obligation on which the plaintiff is suing.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Operator of theater outside District of Columbia did not transact business within District, as necessary for long-arm jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Jackson v. Loews Washington Cinemas, Inc.
Court: District of Columbia Court of Appeals.
Headnote: Unity of interest and ownership, as required for piercing corporate veil and finding one corporation to be the alter ego of another, can be established by showing domination and control of one corporation over the other.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Operator of theater outside District of Columbia did not transact business within District, as necessary for long-arm jurisdiction.

Title: Scott v. NG U.S. 1, Inc.
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Suffolk.
Headnote: Absent evidence that an agency or similar relationship exists between the entities, violation by one corporation of its obligations presents no occasion to disregard the corporate form of another corporation.

Title: Massey v. Conseco Services, L.L.C.

Headnote: The legal fiction of a corporation may be disregarded where one corporation is so organized and controlled and its affairs so conducted that it is a mere instrumentality or adjunct of another corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Massey v. Conseco Services, L.L.C.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Indiana courts refuse to recognize corporations as separate entities where the facts establish that several corporations are acting as the same entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Subsidiary corporation that loaned money for purchase of parent corporation stock was not alter ego of parent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Zimmerman v. Cambridge Credit Counseling Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Massachusetts law permits piercing of the corporate veil under the alter ego doctrine where there is active and direct participation by the representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in the activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of the intercorporate relationship or when there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of the separate nature of the corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about the manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.

Title: Greater St. Louis Const. Laborers Welfare Fund v. Mertens Plumbing and Mechanical, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Missouri law presumes that corporations are separate entities, and courts do not lightly disregard the corporate form to hold one corporation liable for the behavior of another.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Greater St. Louis Const. Laborers Welfare Fund v. Mertens Plumbing and Mechanical, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In determining whether one corporation exercised control over another to the extent necessary to pierce the corporate veil, under Missouri law, courts look to the ownership and creation of both corporations, the management of the corporations, the physical location of corporate offices, and the transfer of assets, contracts, and employees between the corporations.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. LLC and corporation were alter egos of judgment debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Cement-Lock v. Gas Technology Institute
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In assessing unity of interest and ownership, for purposes of piercing corporate veil under Illinois law, court considers: (1) failure to maintain adequate corporate records or to comply with corporate formalities; (2) commingling of funds or assets; (3) undercapitalization; and (4) one corporation treating assets of another corporation as its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Fact issues existed as to breach of fiduciary duty claims brought by LLC members against development companies and officers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re JNS Aviation, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Amarillo Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, the corporate fiction is disregarded, even though corporate formalities have been observed and corporate and individual property have been kept separately, when the corporate form has been used as part of a basically unfair device to achieve an inequitable result; specifically, the corporate fiction is disregarded (1) when the fiction is used as a means of perpetrating fraud, (2) where a corporation is organized and operated as a mere tool or business conduit of another corporation, (3) where the corporate fiction is resorted to as a means of evading an existing legal obligation, (4) where the corporate fiction is employed to achieve or perpetrate monopoly, (5) where the corporate fiction is used to circumvent a statute, (6) where the corporate fiction is relied upon as a protection of crime or to justify wrong, and (7) in the case of inadequate capitalization.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Creditor could pierce debtor-LLC's veil so as to hold nondebtor owners liable for default judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Wade Cook Financial Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Appellate Panel of the Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Washington law, two elements must be proven before court may disregard separateness of corporate entities: (1) that corporate form was intentionally used to violate or evade duty; and (2) that such a disregard is necessary to prevent unjustified loss to injured party.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. IRS was not exempt from setoff requirements of bankruptcy statute.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Wade Cook Financial Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Appellate Panel of the Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Washington law, in order to disregard the separateness of corporate entities, court must find an abuse of the corporate form, such as fraud, misrepresentation or some other kind of manipulation of corporation for benefit of stockholder and to detriment of creditor.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. IRS was not exempt from setoff requirements of bankruptcy statute.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Wade Cook Financial Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Appellate Panel of the Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Washington law, in order to disregard the separateness of corporate entities, court must find that the wrongful activities of corporation actually harmed the party seeking relief, so that disregard is necessary; in other words, corporation's intentional misconduct must be the cause of harm.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. IRS was not exempt from setoff requirements of bankruptcy statute.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Wade Cook Financial Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Appellate Panel of the Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Washington law, mere fact that corporation is the owner of stock of another and that the two are intimately related in carrying on their business for purpose of their mutual benefit is not enough to characterize one corporation as the "alter ego" of the other.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. IRS was not exempt from setoff requirements of bankruptcy statute.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Wade Cook Financial Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Appellate Panel of the Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: For separate corporations to be regarded as "alter egos" under Washington law, there must be such a commingling of their affairs as to work an injustice upon third parties if their separate status is recognized; their property rights must be so commingled, and their affairs so intimately related in management, as to render it apparent that they are, in fact and in intent, one, and, so related, to have them regarded otherwise would work a fraud upon third persons.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. IRS was not exempt from setoff requirements of bankruptcy statute.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: HOK Sport, Inc. v. FC Des Moines, L.C.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Iowa law, in addition to applying to persons using a corporate entity as a mere instrumentality, the alter ego doctrine also applies to a corporate entity using another corporate entity as a mere instrumentality.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Non-profit Entities. Person who was nonprofit's president and only officer and board member was liable for nonprofit's debts as alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Parmalat Securities Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Fact that one corporation finances some of the operations of another does not necessarily establish an agency relationship under New York law.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Auditor was not liable for looting of subsidiary's assets by parent's corrupt insiders.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Heller v. Nicholas Applegate Capital Management, LLC
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: The mere ownership of the capital stock of one corporation by another does not create an identity of corporate interest between the two companies, or create the relationship of principal and agent under District of Columbia law.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Jurisdiction. German company's negotiations to purchase investment manager did not constitute minimum contacts.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Anchia v. DaimlerChrysler AG
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: The Court of Appeals does not disregard separate legal entities simply because one owns stock in the other unless the relationship is being used to defeat public convenience or to justify wrongs.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Evidence that subsidiary was wholly owned by manufacturer was insufficient to establish manufacturer controlled subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Four Seasons Mfg., Inc. v. 1001 Coliseum, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: In a case where a plaintiff seeks to pierce the corporate veil in order to hold one corporation liable for another closely related corporation's debt, the eight factors generally applied to determine whether to pierce the corporate veil are not exclusive, and the court may consider additional factors, including whether: (1) similar corporate names were used; (2) the corporations shared common principal corporate officers, directors, and employees; (3) the business purposes of the corporations were similar; and (4) the corporations were located in the same offices and used the same telephone numbers and business cards.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Piercing of corporate veil of LLC was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Davey v. Shaw
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: "Alter ego" is a basis for disregarding the corporate fiction where a corporation is organized and operated as a mere tool or business conduit of another corporation.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Jurisdiction. Alter ego theory could not be applied to confer personal jurisdiction over nonresident corporate and individual defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Tzovolos v. Wiseman
Court: Superior Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Under identity rule, the corporate veil may be pierced if plaintiff can show that there was such a unity of interest and ownership that the independence of the corporations had in effect ceased or had never begun, and an adherence to the fiction of separate identity would serve only to defeat justice and equity by permitting the economic entity to escape liability arising out of an operation conducted by one corporation for the benefit of the whole enterprise.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Justice required piercing corporate veils of corporate entities, including corporation and LLCs, of buyers of kitchen equipment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Oklahoma Oncology & Hematology P.C. v. US Oncology, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Oklahoma.
Headnote: Generally, a corporation is a distinct legal entity separate and apart from other legal entities unless separate corporate existence is a scheme to perpetrate a fraud, or one corporation is organized and controlled by the other corporation as a mere instrumentality or adjunct so that it is a dummy or sham corporation.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Alternative Dispute Resolution. Arbitration clause applicable when parties could not agree to amend health clinic management agreement was not enforceable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Judson Atkinson Candies, Inc. v. Latini-Hohberger Dhimantec
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: To determine whether there is sufficient "unity of interest and ownership" between two corporations to warrant piercing the corporate veil, Illinois courts consider: (1) inadequate capitalization; (2) failure to issue stock; (3) failure to observe corporate formalities; (4) nonpayment of dividends; (5) insolvency of the debtor corporation; (6) nonfunctioning of the other officers or directors; (7) absence of corporate records; (8) commingling of funds; (9) diversion of assets from the corporation by or to a stockholder or other person or entity to the detriment of creditors; (10) failure to maintain arm's-length relationships among related entities; and (11) whether, in fact, the corporation is a mere facade for the operation of the dominant stockholders.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parent corporation was not liable for judgment against subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Doctors Hosp. of Hyde Park, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, before separate corporate identity of one corporation will be disregarded and treated as alter ego of another, it must be shown that it is so controlled and its affairs so conducted that it is mere instrumentality of another, and it must further appear that observance of fiction of separate existence would, under circumstances, sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Debtor-hospital operator was insolvent at time it made rent payments.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Doctors Hosp. of Hyde Park, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, in order to pierce corporate veil on ground that failure to do so would result in unjust enrichment, plaintiff must show something like intentional scheme to squirrel assets into liability-free corporation while heaping liabilities upon asset-free corporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Debtor-hospital operator was insolvent at time it made rent payments.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Ontos, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, a claim may be brought against the "alter ego" of a corporation when there is active and direct participation by the representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in the activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of the intercorporate relationship, or when there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of the separate nature of the corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about the manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting; in such circumstances, courts may allow a plaintiff to pierce the corporate veil of limited liability in order to provide a meaningful remedy for injuries and to avoid injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Trustee had standing to settle claims brought by debtor's former officers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Southern Capitol Enterprises, Inc. v. Conseco Services, L.L.C.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: In Louisiana, corporations are generally recognized as distinct legal entities; however, the legal fiction of a distinct corporate entity may be disregarded when a corporation is so organized and controlled as to make it merely an instrumentality of another corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Under single business enterprise theory, affiliated corporations could be liable for acts of separate corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Southern Capitol Enterprises, Inc. v. Conseco Services, L.L.C.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, when corporations have the same interest at stake, courts are free to disregard their separate corporate identity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Under single business enterprise theory, affiliated corporations could be liable for acts of separate corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Banks v. Correctional Services Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Courts in New York are reluctant to disregard the distinction between corporate entities.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Putative employee sufficiently stated age discrimination claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Kalin v. Xanboo, Inc
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: New York courts apply presumption of separateness to corporations and are hesitant to disregard corporate form.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Corporation's principals' alleged scheme to fraudulently induce employee could not be attributed to related company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: McCall v. Chesapeake Energy Corp.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 2.
