Headnote: When one corporation is but an instrumentality or adjunct of another by which it is dominated and controlled, a court may look beyond the form to the substance of the situation, and disregard the theory of distinct legal entity, for the purpose of holding the dominant corporation responsible for the liabilities of the sham corporation.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Oil and Natural Gas. Owner of working shares in gas wells could not market share with operator under Oklahoma's Natural Gas Market Sharing Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: John John, LLC v. Exit 63 Development, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally considered in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil and hold one corporation liable for the acts of another are such factors as whether there is an overlap in ownership, officers, directors and personnel, inadequate capitalization, a commingling of assets, or an absence of separate paraphernalia that are part of the corporate form such that one of the corporations is a mere instrumentality, agent and alter ego of the other.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Building company, real estate company, and development company were not alter egos of each other, for veil-piercing purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Meredith
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Virginia, Richmond Division.
Headnote: Accounting firm and financial services corporation formed by firm's principal and his wife were alter egos of each other, and thus could not be treated distinctly, given that principal moved his accounting business from firm to corporation, that nothing changed for principal's clients as a result of such move, that work being done by principal did not vary, address and telephone numbers did not change, and other work being done did not change business's character, and that income stream generated from accounting business was primary income for both firm and corporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Transfers of assets of Chapter 7 debtor were made with fraudulent intent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Gish v. ECI Services of Oklahoma, Inc.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 1.
Headnote: When determining if one corporation is but an instrumentality or agent of another, corporate distinctions must be disregarded and the two separate entities must be treated as one.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Parol evidence was admissible in a fraud trial.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Wajilam Exports (Singapore) Pte. Ltd. v. ATL Shipping Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors as relevant to the question of corporate alter ego include: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of funds; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) the degree of discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the dealings between the entities are at arms length; (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between the entities.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Attachment. Vessel owner showed reasonable grounds for maritime attachment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Teknek, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In deciding whether the requisite unity of interest exists between individual and corporation, as first prerequisite for piercing corporate veil under Illinois law, courts consider the following criteria: (1) whether there was failure to maintain adequate corporate records or to comply with corporate formalities; (2) whether there was commingling of funds or assets; (3) whether corporation was undercapitalized; and (4) whether one corporation treated assets of another corporation as its own.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Jurisdiction. Debtor-LLC's contacts could be counted as contacts of its members in order to establish personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Laborers' Pension Fund v. Lay-Com, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, piercing of corporate veil requires that: (1) there be such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and individual, or other corporation, no longer exist, and (2) circumstances be such that adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Collective Bargaining. Company was successor to dissolved entity, and bound by its union agreements, given identity of successor's operations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Old Farms Associates v. Commissioner of Revenue Services
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Although it is true that, courts will disregard the fiction of separate legal entity when a corporation is a mere instrumentality or agent of another corporation or individual owning all or most of its stock, the circumstance that control is exercised merely through dominating stock ownership is not enough; there must be such domination of finances, policies and practices that the controlled corporation has, so to speak, no separate mind, will, or existence of its own and is but a business conduit for its principal.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Real Property. Land seller could not be assessed conveyance tax on consideration paid by buyer to builder for the construction of a house.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: LM Ins. Corp. v. SourceOne Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In order to establish alter ego claim under Illinois law, evidence of control and instrumentality is usually shown by analyzing several factors including that entities shared officers or employees, did not maintain separate corporate records or comply with corporate formalities, that one entity was kept undercapitalized at expense of another, or that corporate funds were commingled.
Document Preview: TORTS - Conversion. Insurer failed to establish conversion claim against insured.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re WorldClass Processing, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Fraud or injustice must be shown proximately to result from misuse of control to establish lender liability of controlling corporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Plans. Confirmed Chapter 11 plan barred debtor's assertion that creditor was undersecured as of petition date.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Gilbert v. Security Finance Corp. of Oklahoma, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Oklahoma.
Headnote: Corporations are distinct legal entities, and generally one corporation will not be held responsible for the acts of another.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Damages. Punitive damages statute is constitutional without requiring consideration of factors for determining excessiveness.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Gilbert v. Security Finance Corp. of Oklahoma, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Oklahoma.
Headnote: One corporation may be held liable for the acts of another under the theory of alter-ego liability if (1) the separate existence is a design or scheme to perpetuate a fraud, or (2) one corporation is merely an instrumentality or agent of the other.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Damages. Punitive damages statute is constitutional without requiring consideration of factors for determining excessiveness.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Gilbert v. Security Finance Corp. of Oklahoma, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Oklahoma.
Headnote: The factors for determining if one corporation may be held liable for the acts of another hinge primarily on control and include whether (1) dominant corporation owns or subscribes to all the subservient corporation's stock, (2) dominant and subservient corporations have common directors and officers, (3) dominant corporation provides financing to the subservient corporation, (4) subservient corporation is grossly undercapitalized, (5) dominant corporation pays the salaries, expenses, or losses of the subservient corporation, (6) most of the subservient corporation's business is with the dominant corporation or the subservient corporation's assets were conveyed from the dominant corporation, (7) dominant corporation refers to the subservient corporation as a division or department, (8) subservient corporation's officers or directors follow the dominant corporation's directions, and (9) the corporations observe the legal formalities for keeping the entities separate.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Damages. Punitive damages statute is constitutional without requiring consideration of factors for determining excessiveness.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Access Cardiosystems, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: When one legal entity is but an instrumentality or alter ego of another by which it is dominated, a court may look beyond form to substance and may disregard the theory of distinct legal entities in determining ownership of assets.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Debtor's former officer violated his fiduciary duties in developing and patenting his invention.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Flynn v. Veazey Const. Corp.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: To determine whether two businesses are alter egos, the court evaluates the similarities between the two enterprises in their ownership, management, business purpose, operations, equipment, and customers; in this analysis, no single factor is controlling and all need not be present to support a finding of alter ego status.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Evidence from after expiration of labor contract was admissible in action to collect pension plan contributions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Berry v. Lee
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, factors weighing in favor of fusing corporations and/or individuals for jurisdictional purposes include: common business names, business departments, offices, directors or officers, employees, stock ownership, financing, accounting, and payment of wages by one corporation to another corporation's employees and the rendering of services by employees of one corporation on behalf of another corporation.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Chinese corporation and other corporate entities were a single business enterprise for jurisdictional purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Robinson v. Terex Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Separate corporate entities should be disregarded only when there is some abuse of the privilege to operate as separate corporations to the detriment of a third party.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Parent corporation could not be liable for subsidiary corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Ullises Shipping Corp. v. FAL Shipping Co. Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Federal common law allows piercing of the corporate veil where (1) a corporation uses its alter ego to perpetrate a fraud or (2) where it so dominates and disregards its alter ego's corporate form that the alter ego was actually carrying on the controlling corporation's business instead of its own.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Attachment. Vessel owner could attach charterer's electronic funds transfers in New York.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Fontana v. TLD Builders, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Second District.
Headnote: A court may disregard a corporate entity and pierce the veil of limited liability where the corporation is merely the alter ego or business conduit of another person or entity; this doctrine imposes liability on the individual or entity that uses a corporation merely as an instrumentality to conduct that person's or entity's business.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of the corporate veil of construction company to hold president liable was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Fontana v. TLD Builders, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Second District.
Headnote: A party seeking to pierce the corporate veil has the burden of making a substantial showing that one corporation is really a dummy or sham for another, and courts will pierce the corporate veil only reluctantly.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of the corporate veil of construction company to hold president liable was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Carlson Mfg., Inc. v. Smith
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Beaumont.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining whether separate corporations should be treated as one enterprise include: (1) common employees; (2) common offices; (3) centralized accounting; (4) payment of wages by one corporation to another corporation's employees; (5) common business name; (6) services rendered by employees of one corporation on behalf of another corporation; (7) undocumented transfers of funds between corporations; and (8) unclear allocation of profits and losses between corporations.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Long-arm jurisdiction could not be maintained over foreign corporation on theory of single business entity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Carlson Mfg., Inc. v. Smith
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Beaumont.
Headnote: Reasons recognized for disregarding corporate fiction are: (1) when it is used as means of perpetrating fraud; (2) where corporation is organized and operated as mere tool or business conduit of another corporation; (3) where it is used to evade existing legal obligation; (4) where it is employed to achieve or perpetrate monopoly; (5) where it is used to circumvent statute; and (6) where corporate fiction is relied on as protection of crime or to justify wrong.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Long-arm jurisdiction could not be maintained over foreign corporation on theory of single business entity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Little v. State
Court: Court of Appeals of Kansas.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil may apply not only in the traditional situation of a dominant sole shareholder and his or her captive corporation, but also to two corporations.
Document Preview: EDUCATION - Labor and Employment. A veteran made the required allegation to subject an education association to the veterans hiring preference statute.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Beck v. Consolidated Rail Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, the party who seeks to pierce the corporate veil of a parent company must make a two-part showing: (1) that the owner exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.
Document Preview: TORTS - Premises Liability. Former owner of property owed no direct duty to pedestrian injured when curb broke under her foot.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Alto Eldorado Partnership v. Amrep
Court: Court of Appeals of New Mexico.
Headnote: Liability under the alter ego theory to pierce the corporate veil and exercising personal jurisdiction over a nonresident corporation under an alter ego theory that attributes in-state contacts of the corporation's subsidiary to the corporation are different inquiries that focus on different principles and frequently on different bodies of law. (Per Kennedy, J., with one judge specially concurring.) West's NMSA § 38-1-16(A).
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Jurisdiction. Court could exercise jurisdiction over foreign corporation in landowners' action against water utility subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Brentwood Golf Club, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, separate corporate identities will be respected, and thus corporate veils will be pierced only to prevent fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Case Administration. Substantive consolidation of debtor-golf course and tavern was appropriate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Brentwood Golf Club, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, the separate existence of two corporations will be ignored and both will be regarded as one where they are so organized and carried on that one is a mere instrumentality or agent or adjunct to the other.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Case Administration. Substantive consolidation of debtor-golf course and tavern was appropriate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Brentwood Golf Club, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: In the Sixth Circuit, factors to consider in making a determination of an alter ego include whether the two enterprises have substantially identical management, business purpose, operation, equipment, customers, supervision, and ownership.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Case Administration. Substantive consolidation of debtor-golf course and tavern was appropriate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Davlyn Mfg. Co., Inc. v. H&M Auto Parts, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: In determining whether an individual or corporation is an alter ego or successor of a corporation, the court should consider the nature of the corporate entities' ownership and control, including commonality of stockholders or officers, common use of employees, business locations, or sales systems, common marketing or trademarking; similarity of core business lines, and commingling of funds and assets; court should also consider the sufficiency of consideration paid for the transfer of the predecessor's assets or product line, as well as any other indicia of fraudulent intent in the creation of the second entity.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Court lacked personal jurisdiction over defendants in patent infringement action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Morris v. Cee Dee, LLC
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: If plaintiff can show that there was such a unity of interest and ownership that the independence of the corporations had in effect ceased or had never begun, an adherence to the fiction of separate identity would serve only to defeat justice and equity by permitting the economic entity to escape liability arising out of an operation conducted by one corporation for the benefit of the whole enterprise.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of LLC's veil was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Great Lakes Factors, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Ohio.
Headnote: Alter ego doctrine allows a litigant to disregard the corporate form so as to reach assets otherwise unattainable.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discovery. Discovery requests were relevant to equitable subordination claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Great Lakes Factors, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Ohio.
Headnote: Under alter ego doctrine, the primary issue is whether two business entities are fundamentally indistinguishable from one another.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discovery. Discovery requests were relevant to equitable subordination claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Parmalat Securities Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Illinois will find an alter ego relationship when one entity so controlled and dominated the affairs of a wrongdoer that the wrongdoer may be said to be its instrumentality and observance of the fiction of separate existence would, under the circumstances, sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Joint Ventures. Complaint failed to allege that affiliates of global firm audited client as a joint venture.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Parmalat Securities Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Overlap of some personnel, without more, is insufficient under Illinois law to conclude that an alter ego relationship exists.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Joint Ventures. Complaint failed to allege that affiliates of global firm audited client as a joint venture.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Kantor v. Mesibov
Court: Supreme Court, Nassau County, New York.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, generally considered are such factors as whether there is an overlap in ownership, officers, directors and personnel, inadequate capitalization, a commingling of assets or an absence of the separate paraphernalia that are part of the corporate form such that one of the corporations is a mere instrumentality, agent and alter ego of the other.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Partnerships. Business judgment rule did not protect conduct of managing partner from breach of fiduciary duty claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Simeone ex rel. Estate Of Albert Francis Simeone, Jr. v. Bombardier-Rotax GmbH
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Question of whether alter ego relationship exists should be examined in terms of legal interrelationship of entities, authority to control and actual exercise of control, administrative chains of command and organizational structure, performance of functions, and public's perception.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Jurisdiction. Austrian aircraft engine manufacturer was subject to personal jurisdiction under alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Worldclass Processing, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: The degree of control required for the instrumentality doctrine to apply under Pennsylvania law amounts to total domination of the subservient corporation, to the extent that the subservient corporation manifests no separate corporate interests of its own and functions solely to achieve the purposes of the dominant corporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Debtor could not recoup amounts that were paid, or set aside to be paid, to creditor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Bank of Belton v. Bogar Farms, Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: Ordinarily, the separate legal identities of two corporations will be protected.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporations' financial transfers were not proximate cause of bank's injury of uncollectible judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Bank of Belton v. Bogar Farms, Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: If an alter ego relationship between two corporations is used to accomplish a fraud or unlawful purpose, then courts can disregard the separate formal corporate structures, thereby piercing the corporate veil to hold the dominant corporation liable for the debts its adjunct corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporations' financial transfers were not proximate cause of bank's injury of uncollectible judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Bank of Belton v. Bogar Farms, Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: Party seeking to pierce the corporate veil on an alter ego theory must demonstrate that: (1) alleged dominant corporation exercised such complete control and domination over alleged adjunct corporation that adjunct corporation had no separate mind, will, or existence with regard to the financial transactions at issue, (2) dominant corporation used its control and domination over adjunct corporation to commit fraud or violations of legal duties in contravention of party's rights, and (3) dominant corporation's control of adjunct corporation and breach of duty caused injury to party.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporations' financial transfers were not proximate cause of bank's injury of uncollectible judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Brigham Young University v. Tremco Consultants, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Utah.
Headnote: In cases involving liability between and among corporations, findings of alter ego or a piercing of the corporate veil could suffice to establish the appropriateness of extending or transferring the liability of one corporate entity to another; absent such findings, however, liability cannot be imposed upon the second entity without displacing substantive precepts of corporate law. Restatement (Second) of Judgments § 59.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Indemnity. Indemnitor was not liable for university's judgment against software company under indemnity agreement with affiliated company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Sitaram v. Aetna U.S. Healthcare of North Texas, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: As a general presumption courts will recognize the separate identities of corporations even when one corporation dominates or controls another or even treats the other corporation as a mere department, instrumentality, or agency of the other.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Mergers and Acquisition. Acquiring corporation's subsidiaries were not liable on insurance agents' agreement with subsidiary's HMO.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Nunn v. C.C. Midwest
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: Only when one corporation shows such domination and control over the other, such that the latter is merely the alter ego of the first, does court ignore the separate legal identities of the individual corporations.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Truck driver was an employee, rather than independent contractor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Lee v. Clinical Research Center of Florida, L.C.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Courts can pierce the corporate veil of a corporation to impose liability on one corporation for the acts of another corporation under the single business enterprise theory; "piercing the corporate veil" is a process by which courts disregard the limited liability normally afforded corporations to redress corporate misdeeds by the imposition of liability on another person or entity that would otherwise enjoy the benefits of the corporation's limited liability.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Limited liability companies were not being run as a single business enterprise with employer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Rondout Valley Central School Dist. v. Coneco Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Massachusetts courts will pierce corporate veil only when there is compelling evidence of one of two situations: (1) that there is active and pervasive control of related business entities by same controlling persons, as well as a fraudulent or injurious consequence by reason of relationship among these business entities; or (2) there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in common enterprise with substantial disregard of separate nature of corporate entities, or a serious ambiguity about manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: EDUCATION - Property and Contracts. Contractor's actual performance was admission of obligation to perform.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Rondout Valley Central School Dist. v. Coneco Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Twelve factors that Massachusetts courts consider in deciding whether pierce corporate veil are: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business activity and assets, (4) thin capitalization; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) nonpayment of dividends; (8) insolvency at time of litigated transaction; (9) siphoning away of corporate assets by dominant shareholders; (10) non-functioning of officers and directors; (11) use of corporation for transactions of dominant shareholders; and (12) use of corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: EDUCATION - Property and Contracts. Contractor's actual performance was admission of obligation to perform.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Rondout Valley Central School Dist. v. Coneco Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Twelve factors that Massachusetts courts consider in determining whether to pierce corporate veil are not of equal importance, and veil-piercing analysis is not simple matter of counting factors; rather, factors should be used in balancing test to decide whether the over-all corporate structure and operation mislead.
Document Preview: EDUCATION - Property and Contracts. Contractor's actual performance was admission of obligation to perform.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: National Plan Administrators, Inc. v. National Health Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: Courts are willing to disregard the corporate form when it is used as part of an unfair device to achieve an inequitable result, such as when a corporation is organized and operated as a mere tool or business conduit of another corporation, or when the corporate fiction is resorted to as a means of evading an existing legal obligation.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Agents and Brokers. Third-party administrator and parent corporation were liable to health insurer for breach of fiduciary duty.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Lernout & Hauspie Securities Litigation
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Massachusetts law permits piercing the corporate veil where there is evidence of (1) fraud, (2) pervasive control beyond mere common ownership and management, or (3) a confused intermingling of activity with substantial disregard of the separate nature of the corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about the manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Fund's subsidiary was the agent of fund for jurisdictional purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Fluorine On Call, Ltd. v. Fluorogas Ltd.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas' alter ego theory, where corporation is organized and operated as mere tool or business conduit of another corporation, first corporation's wrongful acts are properly attributed to controlling corporation.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Evidence did not support award of lost asset damages.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Sunbelt Environmental Services, Inc. v. Rieder's Jiffy Market, Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Southern District, Division Two.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, a plaintiff must show: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked, so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) that such control was used by the corporation to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest or unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) that control and breach of duty proximately caused the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence warranted piercing corporate veil to impose liability on trustee, store, and transferee corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Ticketplanet.com
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors in deciding whether entities acted as single economic unit, as required to support "alter ego" claim under Delaware law, include: whether corporation was adequately capitalized for corporate undertaking; whether corporation was solvent; whether dividends were paid, corporate records kept, officers and directors functioned properly, and other corporate formalities were observed; whether the dominant shareholder siphoned corporate funds; and whether, in general, corporation simply functioned as facade for dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Secured Transactions. Problems with post-default foreclosure sale did not cause it to be a conversion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Ticketplanet.com
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Mere allegations of domination or control by one entity over another are insufficient to support a veil-piercing claim under Delaware law; rather, extent of this domination and control must preclude the controlled entity from having legal or independent significance of its own.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Secured Transactions. Problems with post-default foreclosure sale did not cause it to be a conversion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Rymal v. Baergen
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: For corporate veil to be pierced, corporate entity must be a mere instrumentality of another individual or entity, corporate entity must have been used to commit a wrong or fraud, and there must have been an unjust injury or loss to plaintiff.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Supervisor could be held individually liable for retaliation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Porras
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Texas, El Paso Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, alter ego remedy is one of six distinct methods of piercing corporate veil, one which applies when there is such identity or unity between corporation and another entity that all separateness between them has ceased and failure to disregard corporate form would be unfair or unjust.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Fact issues precluded summary judgment on whether trust property was part of Chapter 7 estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Advanced Telephone Systems, Inc. v. Com-Net Professional Mobile Radio, LLC
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: "Alter ego" theory for piercing the corporate veil is applicable when the individual or corporate owner controls the corporation to be pierced and the controlling owner is to be held liable; it is available whenever one party seeks to hold the corporation owner liable for any claim or debt.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. There is no right to jury trial for alter-ego claim seeking piercing of corporate veil of LLC.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Webster Industries, Inc. v. Northwood Doors, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Iowa, Central Division.
Headnote: While corporate veil doctrine is most frequently applied, under Iowa law, to avoid fraud, it is equally appropriate under other circumstances when one corporation is used as mere sham for another.
Document Preview: TORTS - RICO. Plaintiffs failed to plead mail fraud, as predicate act for RICO claim, with particularity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Bowoto v. Chevron Texaco Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: When customary agency, as opposed to alter ego, is alleged against a corporation, the proponent must demonstrate a relationship between the corporation and the cause of action; not only must an arrangement exist between the two corporations so that one acts on behalf of the other and within usual agency principles, but the arrangement must be relevant to the plaintiff's claim of wrongdoing.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Whether to pierce corporate veil on ratification theory was triable fact issue.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Flutie New York Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors that New York courts consider when evaluating whether a corporation has been so controlled or dominated as to permit a piercing of corporate veil include: (1) absence of corporate formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of corporate existence; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone number; (6) amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the related corporations deal with the dominated corporation at arms length; (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of debts of the dominated corporation by other corporations in group; and (10) whether corporation in question had property which was used by other corporations as if were their own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Veil would be pierced to hold debtor's principal personally liable for debts of bankruptcy estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Richmond v. Indalex Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. North Carolina.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, corporate veil piercing requires pleading of facts supporting an inference that the corporation, through its alter-ego, has created a sham entity designed to defraud investors and creditors.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parent companies' alleged control of an employer would not permit piercing corporate veil for employee's injury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: JSC Foreign Economic Ass'n Technostroyexport v. International Development and Trade Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, courts consider several factors when determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, including: (1) absence of formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence, i.e., issuance of stock, election of directors, keeping of corporate records and the like; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether related corporations deal with dominated corporation at arms length; (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of debts of dominated corporation by other corporations in group; and (10) whether corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Likelihood of success on corporate veil-piercing claim supported propriety of attachment order.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Holly & Smith Architects, Inc. v. St. Helena Congregate Facility
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Legal fiction of a distinct corporate entity may be disregarded when a corporation is so organized and controlled as to make it merely an instrumentality or adjunct of another corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Client was corporation's alter ego, and thus corporation was liable for arbitration award.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Holly & Smith Architects, Inc. v. St. Helena Congregate Facility
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: If one corporation is wholly under the control of another, the fact that it is a separate entity does not relieve the dominant corporation from liability; in such an instance, the former corporation is merely an alter ego or business conduit of the dominant corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Client was corporation's alter ego, and thus corporation was liable for arbitration award.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Holly & Smith Architects, Inc. v. St. Helena Congregate Facility
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Some of the factors that may be considered when determining whether to pierce corporate veil to reach dominant corporation are: (1) identity of stock ownership, (2) common directors and officers, (3) unified administrative control, (4) directors and officers of one entity operate independently in interest of the other, (5) one corporation financing another, (6) inadequate capitalization, (7) corporation causing incorporation of another, (8) one corporation paying salaries and expenses of another, (9) corporation receives no business except from other corporation, (10) corporation using property of the other as its own, (11) noncompliance with corporate formalities, (12) common employees, (13) common offices, (14) central accounting, (15) undocumented transfer of funds, (16) unclear allocation of profit and loss between the two corporate entities, and (17) excessive fragmentation of single business enterprise into separate corporations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Client was corporation's alter ego, and thus corporation was liable for arbitration award.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Holly & Smith Architects, Inc. v. St. Helena Congregate Facility
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: No one factor is dispositive when determining whether to pierce corporate veil to reach dominant corporation, and the totality of the circumstances should be considered.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Client was corporation's alter ego, and thus corporation was liable for arbitration award.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Cherry v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: "Piercing the corporate veil" of a corporation allows a plaintiff to impose legal liability for a corporation's obligations, or for torts committed by the corporation, upon some other company or individual that controls and dominates the corporation.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Automobile. Vehicle that operator was driving did not constitute a temporary substitute vehicle.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: JSC Foreign Economic Ass'n Technostroyexport v. International Development and Trade Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Courts will consider following factors when determining whether to pierce corporate veil under New York law: (1) absence of formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of corporate existence; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) amount of business discretion displayed by allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether related corporations deal with dominated corporation at arms length; (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of debts of dominated corporation by other corporations in group; and (10) whether corporation in question had property that was used by other corporation as if it were its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Russian metal seller properly stated veil-piercing claim against corporate purchasers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: DCA Advertising, Inc. v. The Fox Group, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Evidence of domination of one entity by another does not alone suffice for liability on part of the dominating entity relating to subordinate party's contract without additional showing that domination led to inequity, fraud, or malfeasance.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Novation elements of valid new contract and extinguishment of old one were not established.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Crosse v. BCBSD, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Delaware.
Headnote: To state a veil-piercing claim, the plaintiff must plead facts supporting an inference that the corporation, through its alter-ego, has created a sham entity designed to defraud investors and creditors.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Health. Non-profit health insurer owes no fiduciary duty to insureds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Osborn v. University Medical Associates of Medical University of South Carolina
Court: United States District Court, D. South Carolina, Charleston Division.
Headnote: The "instrumentality doctrine" or alter ego theory generally provides that, when lender controls business decisions and actions of its borrower, borrower becomes instrument or alter ego of lender.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Non-profit Entities. Individual directors of South Carolina nonprofit were statutorily immune from liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Osborn v. University Medical Associates of Medical University of South Carolina
Court: United States District Court, D. South Carolina, Charleston Division.
Headnote: Before instrumentality doctrine may be applied, two elements must be present: first, dominant corporation must have controlled subservient corporation, and second, dominant corporation must have proximately caused plaintiff harm through misuse of this control.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Non-profit Entities. Individual directors of South Carolina nonprofit were statutorily immune from liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Osborn v. University Medical Associates of Medical University of South Carolina
Court: United States District Court, D. South Carolina, Charleston Division.
Headnote: The "instrumentality doctrine" is but variation of piercing the corporate veil principle, in which court may in certain instances disregard corporate device of limited liability where it has been misused by its owners; under this doctrine, corporation may become liable for debts of another corporation when it misuses that corporation by treating it, and by using it, as mere business conduit for purposes of dominant corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Non-profit Entities. Individual directors of South Carolina nonprofit were statutorily immune from liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Dominguez v. Payne
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi–Edinburg.
Headnote: "Alter ego" is a basis for disregarding the corporate fiction, where a corporation is organized and operated as a mere tool or business conduit of another corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Fact issues existed regarding whether shareholder was alter ego of corporate developer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: IGEN Intern., Inc. v. Roche Diagnostics GmbH
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, mere control and even total ownership of one corporation by another is not sufficient to warrant the disregard of a separate corporate entity, and a common central management alone is not a proper basis for disregarding separate corporate existence.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Unfair Practices. Continuation of suit against licensor was not sham, so licensee was immune from tort liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Bielagus v. EMRE of New Hampshire Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of New Hampshire.
Headnote: The key factor to piercing the corporate veil and finding a de facto merger for purposes of successor liability is the conduct of the shareholders; when there is no exchange of stock, no continuity of shareholders, and more than one corporation remains in the free market race, courts should be reluctant to impose successor liability by de facto merger upon a corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Purchase of seller's real estate operation did not amount to a de facto merger of seller and purchaser.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: National Hotel Associates ex rel. M.E. Venture Management, Inc. v. O. Ahlborg & Sons, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Rhode Island.
Headnote: In evaluating the degree of separateness between two corporations, for purposes of piercing the corporate veil to impose liability on non-corporate defendants, courts look to the totality of the circumstances and examine such factors as stock ownership, capitalization, dual office holding and directorships, financial support or dependence, a lack of substantial business contracts independent from the other corporation and a domination of finances, policies and practices.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. First corporation was operated as an instrumentality of second corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Mid America Title Co. v. Transnation Title Ins. Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Arizona law, mere common ownership of corporations is insufficient to permit piercing of corporate veil based on alter ego relationship; showing is required that corporations share unity of control and that observance of corporate form would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Common ownership and consolidation of operations was insufficient to allow veil piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Mountview Plaza Associates, Inc. v. World Wide Pet Supply, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Courts will disregard the fiction of separate legal entity when a corporation is a mere instrumentality or agent of another corporation or individual owning all or most of its stock, and under such circumstances the general rule, which recognizes the individuality of corporate entities and the independent character of each in respect to their corporate transactions, and the obligations incurred by each in the course of such transactions, will be disregarded, where the interests of justice and righteous dealing so demand.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Default judgment conclusively determined shareholder's liability for corporation's breach of lease agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Rus, Inc. v. Bay Industries, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, no proof of fraud is necessary when piercing corporate veil will result in liability of another corporation, rather than individual.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Fact issues regarding delivery of satisfactory environmental audit precluded summary judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Pfohl Brothers Landfill Site Steering Committee v. Allied Waste Systems, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: New York law permits a court to pierce the corporate veil of one corporation to reach the assets of an affiliated corporation only where the plaintiff demonstrates both (1) that the owner exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Rubber waste processer was liable for CERCLA cleanup contribution costs.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Orenbuch v. North Shore Health Systems, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: In order to establish an abandonment of separateness which would warrant piercing the corporate veil under New York law, a plaintiff must demonstrate that: (1) the corporation exercised domination over another corporation regarding the alleged violation; and (2) that such domination was used to commit the alleged violation.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Debt collector's nondisclosure of relationship with affiliated organizations did not violate FDCPA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Orenbuch v. North Shore Health Systems, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: To determine whether the necessary dominion and control exists for the court to pierce the corporate veil under New York law, the court must examine several factors, including (1) the sharing of a common office, staff, and ownership; (2) the intermingling of funds; (3) the treatment of the corporations as one, not separate, profit centers; (4) the lack of the conventions of corporate existence; and (5) any inadequate earnings.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Debt collector's nondisclosure of relationship with affiliated organizations did not violate FDCPA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Island Seafood Co., Inc. v. Golub Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: The corporate veil will be pierced to achieve equity, even absent fraud, when a corporation has been so dominated by an individual or another corporation and its separate entity so ignored that it primarily transacts the dominator's business instead of its own and can be called the other's alter ego.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Party seeking to pierce corporate veil failed to prove dominion over alleged alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Island Seafood Co., Inc. v. Golub Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Where a corporation is a fragment of a larger corporate combine which actually conducts the business, the larger corporate entity may be held financially responsible for the acts of that corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Party seeking to pierce corporate veil failed to prove dominion over alleged alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Island Seafood Co., Inc. v. Golub Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally considered in determining whether a corporation is dominated by others, such that the corporation is a mere instrumentality, agent, and alter ego of the others, are such factors as whether there is an overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, inadequate capitalization, a commingling of assets, or an absence of separate paraphernalia that are part of the corporate form.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Party seeking to pierce corporate veil failed to prove dominion over alleged alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Firstar Bank, N.A. v. Faul Chevrolet, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, partial integration of workforce will not subject company to veil piercing.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Automobile dealership's creditor was not entitled to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Comninellis v. Comninellis
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: The test for piercing the corporate veil is two pronged: first, the corporation must be controlled and influenced by persons or by another corporation; and second, the evidence must establish the corporate cloak was used as a subterfuge to defeat public convenience, justify a wrong or to perpetuate a fraud.
Document Preview: FAMILY LAW - Equitable Distribution. House, which was acquired during the marriage, was nonmarital property.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Magic House AB v. Shelton Beverage L.P.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: State law presumes that two separate corporations are indeed distinct entities.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Distributor was not alter ego of nonresident corporate manufacturer for jurisdictional purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Magic House AB v. Shelton Beverage L.P.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: To apply alter ego doctrine, the degree of control exercised by one corporation over the other must be greater than that normally associated with common ownership and directorship.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Distributor was not alter ego of nonresident corporate manufacturer for jurisdictional purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Magic House AB v. Shelton Beverage L.P.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: The alter ego doctrine applies if one corporation is simply a conduit through which another corporation conducts its business.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Distributor was not alter ego of nonresident corporate manufacturer for jurisdictional purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: U.S. ex rel. Reagan v. East Texas Medical Center Regional Healthcare System
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: A court applying the alter ego theory in a corporate context under Texas law will disregard the separate legal existence of the alter ego entity and view it as a mere conduit through which the primary corporate entity exercised power over all decisions.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Hospitals. Former hospital director was not original source so as to maintain Medicare fraud action under False Claims Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Horizon Marketing v. Kingdom Intern. Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: The law of piercing the corporate veil applies when a party wishes to hold an individual or a related corporation liable for the acts of another corporation.
Document Preview: AGRICULTURE - Perishable Commodities. Produce sellers were entitled to preliminary injunctive relief pursuant to PACA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Strawbridge v. Sugar Mountain Resort, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. North Carolina, Asheville Division.
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, when a corporation is so operated that it is a mere instrumentality or alter ego of the sole or dominant shareholder and a shield for his activities in violation of the declared public policy or statute of the state, the corporate entity will be disregarded and the corporation and the shareholder treated as one and the same person for liability purposes, it being immaterial whether the sole or dominant shareholder is an individual or another corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Claim to pierce corporate veil could be filed for first time in recommenced complaint.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Hazard Coal Corp. v. Kentucky West Virginia Gas Co., L.L.C.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, separate corporate interests, including subsidiaries and affiliates, are separate legal entities and must be recognized and treated as such unless there is some reason to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Oil and Gas. Mineral rights owner, its lessee, and coal mining company had to pay for relocation of gas pipelines.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Hazard Coal Corp. v. Kentucky West Virginia Gas Co., L.L.C.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, if a business wishes to reap the benefits of establishing separate corporations, it must also accept the burdens.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Oil and Gas. Mineral rights owner, its lessee, and coal mining company had to pay for relocation of gas pipelines.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Cahaly v. Benistar Property Exchange Trust Co., Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: In context of piercing the corporate veil, "identity rule" primarily applies to prevent injustice in situation where two corporate entities are, in reality, controlled as one enterprise because of existence of common owners, officers, directors, or shareholders and because of lack of observance of corporate formalities between two entities.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Attachment and Garnishment. Plaintiff could pursue prejudgment attachment while awaiting final judgment in another state.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Sunbeam Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, purpose of allowing corporate veil to be pierced upon alter ego theory is to hold the party actually responsible for inequitable conduct accountable and to prevent party from using another corporation to shield itself from liability.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Transactions could not be collapsed for fraudulent transfer avoidance purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Hersey v. Lonrho, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Courts will disregard the fiction of separate legal entity when a corporation is a mere instrumentality or agent of another corporation or individual owning all or most of its stock, and under such circumstances the general rule, which recognizes the individuality of corporate entities and independent character of each in respect to their corporate transactions, and obligations incurred by each in the course of such transactions, will be disregarded, where interests of justice and righteous dealing so demand.
