Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil properly was not pierced for jurisdictional purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Yukon Partners, Inc. v. Lodge Keeper Group, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: By whatever means the conclusion to disregard corporate entity and pierce the corporate veil is arrived at, when it is reached, it merely means that under the facts of the case, the person or corporation in control of a subservient corporation is held liable for the acts or omissions of the subservient corporation.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Georgia did not have long-arm jurisdiction over Missouri defendants in suit by Ohio corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: U.S. Fidelity and Guar. Co. v. Braspetro Oil Services Co.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: With respect to New York rule for "piercing the corporate veil," liability may be predicated either upon a showing of fraud or upon complete control by the dominating corporation that leads to a wrong against third parties.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Bonds. Sureties' obligations under performance bonds arose after owner fulfilled conditions precedent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: U.S. Fidelity and Guar. Co. v. Braspetro Oil Services Co.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors that tend to show domination, for purposes of New York rule for "piercing the corporate veil," include: (1) the absence of the formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence, i.e., issuance of stock, election of directors, keeping of corporate records and the like, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the related corporations deal with the dominated corporation at arms length, (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) the payment or guarantee of debts of the dominated corporation by other corporations in the group, and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Bonds. Sureties' obligations under performance bonds arose after owner fulfilled conditions precedent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Oliver v. Pinnacle Homes, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: The legal fiction of a corporation may be disregarded, and the corporate veil pierced, where one corporation is so organized and controlled, and its affairs so conducted, that it is a mere instrumentality or adjunct of another corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Manufacturer of modular home was not alter ego of builder for purposes of debt liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Oliver v. Pinnacle Homes, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Indiana courts refuse to recognize corporations as separate entities, and will pierce the corporate veil, where facts establish that several corporations are acting as the same entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Manufacturer of modular home was not alter ego of builder for purposes of debt liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Oliver v. Pinnacle Homes, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: While no one talismanic fact will justify with impunity piercing the corporate veil, a careful review of the entire relationship between various corporate entities, their directors, and officers may reveal that such an equitable action is warranted.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Manufacturer of modular home was not alter ego of builder for purposes of debt liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Oliver v. Pinnacle Homes, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Where a plaintiff seeks to pierce the corporate veil in order to hold one corporation liable for another closely related corporation's debt, a court may consider various factors, including whether: (1) similar corporate names were used, (2) the corporations shared common principal corporate officers, directors, and employees, (3) the business purposes of the corporations were similar, and (4) the corporations were located in the same offices and used the same telephone numbers and business cards.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Manufacturer of modular home was not alter ego of builder for purposes of debt liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Oliver v. Pinnacle Homes, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: The indicia of common identity, excessive fragmentation, or single-business-enterprise corporations may include, among other factors justifying piercing the corporate veil, the intermingling of business transactions, functions, property, employees, funds, records, and corporate names in dealing with the public.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Manufacturer of modular home was not alter ego of builder for purposes of debt liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Scandinavian Satellite System, AS v. Prime TV Ltd.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, District of Columbia Circuit.
Headnote: Ownership, alone, of capital stock in one corporation by another, does not create an identity of corporate interest between the two companies, such that one can be held accountable for the actions of the other.
Document Preview: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY - Jurisdiction. Contract defense did not preclude district court jurisdiction over copyright claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Fairfield Development, Inc. v. Georgetown Woods Sr. Apartments Ltd. Partnership
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: While no one talismanic fact will justify with impunity piercing the corporate veil, a careful review of the entire relationship between various corporate entities, their directors and officers may reveal that such an equitable action is warranted.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Construction corporation was alter ego of family.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Wallace v. Ramon
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, San Antonio.
Headnote: The corporate fiction is properly disregarded: (1) when the fiction is used as a means of perpetrating fraud; (2) where a corporation is organized and operated as a mere tool or business conduit of another corporation; (3) where the corporate fiction is resorted to as a means of evading an existing legal obligation; (4) where the corporate fiction is employed to achieve or perpetrate monopoly; (5) where the corporate fiction is used to circumvent a statute; and (6) where the corporate fiction is relied upon as a protection of crime or to justify wrong.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Evidence was sufficient to establish breach of contract in post-answer default judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Wady v. Provident Life and Accident Ins. Co. of America
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in applying alter ego doctrine include: commingling of funds and other assets of two entities, holding out by one entity that it is liable for debts of other, identical equitable ownership in two entities, use of same offices and employees, and use of one as mere shell or conduit for affairs of other.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Bad Faith and Unfair Practices. Parent holding company could not be held liable for insurer's actions under alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Dimmitt & Owens Financial, Inc. v. Superior Sports Products, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In order to pierce corporate veil, under Illinois law, there must be such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and individual or other corporation no longer exist, and circumstances must be that such adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Circumstances warranted piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Eure v. Norfolk Shipbuilding & Drydock Corp., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Virginia.
Headnote: The separate corporate entities of corporations will be observed by the courts unless a corporation is shown to be the adjunct, creature, instrumentality, device, stooge, or dummy of another corporation.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Agreement was ambiguous as to continuation of officers' medical expense reimbursement plan.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Eure v. Norfolk Shipbuilding & Drydock Corp., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Virginia.
Headnote: Generally, courts will observe the separate corporate entity, even though one corporation may dominate or control another, or may treat it as a mere department or instrumentality, but courts will disregard the separate legal identities of the corporation if they are used to defeat public convenience, justify wrongs, or protect fraud or crime.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Agreement was ambiguous as to continuation of officers' medical expense reimbursement plan.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Marvelli v. Chaps Community Health Center
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Law allows corporation to organize so as to isolate liabilities among separate entities; under doctrine of limited liability, corporate entity is liable for acts of separate, related entity only under extraordinary circumstances.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Supervisor did not create racially hostile work environment in violation of § 1981.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Keener Lumber Co., Inc. v. Perry
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: The piercing the corporate veil doctrine allows courts to disregard the corporate form of a corporation where some alternate entity, whether an individual or another company, exerts complete domination over the corporation's policy, finances and business practices.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Creditor's filing of proof of claim in bankruptcy action did not deprive trial court of jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Bagel Bros. Maple, Inc. v. Ohio Farmers, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, courts will pierce corporate veil, and thereby hold two corporations to constitute a single legal unit, only where one is so related to, or organized, or controlled by, the other as to be its instrumentality or alter ego; mere fact that both corporations have identical controlling shareholders, officers and directors does not, by itself, suffice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Veil Piercing. Debtor-corporation could not be held liable for related corporate entities' debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Kellers Systems, Inc. v. Transport Intern. Pool, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, courts will abrogate separate corporate identity where it is shown that corporation is so controlled and its affairs so conducted that it is a mere instrumentality of another, and it must further appear that observance of the fiction of separate existence would, under the circumstances, sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Contract's indemnification provisions did not encompass fee-shifting in lawsuit between parties.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: MAG Portfolio Consult, GMBH v. Merlin Biomed Group LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Under New York law, factors in whether veil-piercing is appropriate include: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of funds; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) degree of discretion shown by allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether dealings between entities are at arm's length; (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of corporation's debts by dominating entity; and (10) intermingling of property between entities.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Successor companies could not be compelled to arbitrate under agreement they were not party to.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Gilbert v. James Russell Motors, Inc.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Alabama.
Headnote: Automobile seller did not present evidence that supported conclusion, for purposes of piercing the corporate veil, that shareholders had a fraudulent purpose in their conception of, or in their operation of, corporate automobile broker that purchased vehicles from seller.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Creditor failed to establish grounds for piercing corporate veil of automobile broker.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: One Pacific Towers Homeowners' Ass'n v. HAL Real Estate Investments, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 1.
Headnote: Courts will not imply an overt intent to disregard the corporate form from the presence of common directors, shareholders, or a common business address.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Condominiums. Holding corporation and its subsidiaries were declarants under the condominium act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: One Pacific Towers Homeowners' Ass'n v. HAL Real Estate Investments, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 1.
Headnote: For the court to treat multiple corporate entities as one, it must appear that the one so dominates the other as to make the other a mere tool and that their funds and property interests are commingled; the fact that one person dominates both corporations is immaterial if the domination was exerted upon each as a separate concern.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Condominiums. Holding corporation and its subsidiaries were declarants under the condominium act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: North American Van Lines, Inc. v. Emmons
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Beaumont.
Headnote: Proportionate responsibility statute did not do away with the application of partnership and agency theories, nor did it replace equitable doctrines imposing liability on one corporation for the acts of another. V.T.C.A., Civil Practice & Remedies Code § 33.013(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Interstate carrier and its subsidiary were operated as a single business enterprise.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: McClellan v. Northridge Park Townhome Owners Ass'n, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: If a corporation organizes another corporation with practically the same shareholders and directors, transfers all the assets but does not pay all the first corporation's debts, and continues to carry on the same business, the separate entities may be disregarded and the new corporation held liable for the obligations of the old.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Condominiums. Evidence supported finding that homeowners association was mere continuation of predecessor association.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Pearson v. Component Technology Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: No single factor of the integrated enterprise test for determining whether a corporate veil should be pierced in the labor context is dispositive; rather, single employer status under this test ultimately depends on all the circumstances of the case.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Layoffs. Secured creditor was not liable under WARN for employer's unnoticed plant closure.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: King v. Modern Music Co.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 4.
Headnote: To disregard the corporate entity, plaintiff must show either that the separate corporate existence is a design or scheme to perpetuate fraud or that one corporation is so organized and controlled and its affairs so conducted that it is merely an instrumentality or adjunct of another corporation; in other words, it must appear that one corporation is merely a dummy or sham, and in such cases, the distinct corporate entity will be disregarded and the two corporations will be treated as one.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate shield would not be disregarded so as to hold company, which leased premises to tavern, responsible for motorists' injuries.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Real Estate Investors Four, Inc. v. American Design Group Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Five.
Headnote: Ordinarily, courts protect the separate legal identities of individual corporations; however, there are situations in which one corporation shows such domination and control over another that the latter corporation becomes an adjunct or alter ego of the first.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Actual occupant of premises leased to corporation was liable to lessor under alter-ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Real Estate Investors Four, Inc. v. American Design Group Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Five.
Headnote: When the formal corporate separateness and the arrangements between two corporations are devised or used to accomplish a fraud, injustice, or some unlawful purpose, then the separate formal corporate structures will be ignored.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Actual occupant of premises leased to corporation was liable to lessor under alter-ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Real Estate Investors Four, Inc. v. American Design Group Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Five.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil and hold one corporation liable for acts of another, plaintiff must show: (1)control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to transaction attacked so that corporate entity as to this transaction had at time no separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) such control must have been used by corporation to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) control and breach of duty must proximately cause injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Actual occupant of premises leased to corporation was liable to lessor under alter-ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Smith v. McLeod Distributing, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Courts refuse to recognize corporations as separate entities, and piercing of corporate veil is warranted where the facts establish several corporations are acting as the same entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could be pierced to hold another corporation liable for commercial debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Smith v. McLeod Distributing, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: While no one talismanic fact will justify with impunity piercing the corporate veil, a careful review of entire relationship between various corporate entities, their directors and officers may reveal that such an equitable action is warranted.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could be pierced to hold another corporation liable for commercial debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Smith v. McLeod Distributing, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Indicia of common "identity," "excessive fragmentation," or "single business enterprise" corporations, as required to pierce the corporate veil, may include, among other factors, intermingling of business transactions, functions, property, employees, funds, records, and corporate names in dealing with the public.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could be pierced to hold another corporation liable for commercial debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Ex parte Thorn
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: The piercing-the-corporate-veil doctrine is an equitable doctrine, but is not a claim; it merely furnishes a means for a complainant to reach a second corporation or individual upon a cause of action that otherwise would have existed only against the first corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing-the-corporate-veil issues had to be decided by trial court, not jury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Grayson v. R.B. Ammon and Associates, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: If one corporation is wholly under the control of another, the fact that it is a separate entity does not relieve the latter from liability; in such an instance, the former corporation is merely an alter ego or a business conduit of the latter.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Related temporary staffing companies could be deemed single business enterprise for liability purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Grayson v. R.B. Ammon and Associates, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: When corporations represent precisely the same single interest, the court is free to disregard their separate corporate identity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Related temporary staffing companies could be deemed single business enterprise for liability purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Grayson v. R.B. Ammon and Associates, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: When determining whether a corporation is an alter ego, agent, tool, or instrumentality of another corporation, the court is required to look to the substance of the corporate structure rather than its form.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Related temporary staffing companies could be deemed single business enterprise for liability purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Greater Hammond Community Services, Inc. v. Mutka
Court: Supreme Court of Indiana.
Headnote: Corporate alter ego doctrine is a device by which a plaintiff tries to show that two corporations are so closely connected that the plaintiff should be able to sue one for the actions of the other.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - Immunity. Regional community services organization was not protected by Tort Claims Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Consolidated Non-Filing Ins. Fee Litigation
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Alabama, Northern Division.
Headnote: Corporate veils of publicly traded holding company, its consumer finance and insurance subsidiaries, and the company that provided them with centralized management services would be pierced, and court would deem holding company's consumer finance and insurance subsidiaries as the holding company's alter ego, where, inter alia, holding company distributed policies and procedures for subsidiaries' employees, funded operation of the finance subsidiaries, and filed consolidated tax return that included the finance subsidiaries, and the management company prepared financing documents used by the finance subsidiaries, and its headquarters were used as repository of subsidiaries' corporate records and as meeting place for subsidiaries' boards of directors, several of whom held similar positions with the management company; further, management company negotiated terms of non-filing insurance between the insurance subsidiaries and the finance subsidiaries, and decided whether finance subsidiaries would use non-filing insurance.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Consumer Credit. Class was certified in case involving challenge to non-filing insurance fees.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Aluminum Chemicals (Bolivia), Inc. v. Bechtel Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Concepts of "alter ego" and "joint enterprise" were not merely different ways of describing the same legal issue, and, thus, partial summary judgment for defendant corporation on claim that another corporation was its alter ego did not amount to summary judgment on a theory of joint enterprise.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Concepts of alter ego and joint enterprise are not different ways of describing same legal issue.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Phillips Petroleum Co. v. AIG Technical Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Galveston Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, alter ego status may be found where a corporation is organized and operated as a mere tool or business conduit of another corporation.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Removal. No fraudulent joinder existed where defendant's nondiverse affiliate was possible alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers v. Springfield Terminal Ry. Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: A corporate veil may be pierced if one corporation is not an independent entity, but rather the mere alter ego of another.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Pennmark Resources Co. v. Oklahoma Corp. Com'n

Headnote: Corporate distinctions may be disregarded and two separate entities may be treated as one if one corporation is but an instrumentality or agent of another.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re SunSport, Inc.

Headnote: If two corporations have an identity of corporate officers and shareholders, and in addition they commingle their assets and business affairs, court may conclude that the technical legal separateness of the two entities should be ignored.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Successor liability would be imposed on company that acquired Chapter 7 debtor's assets prepetition.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Preussag Aktiengesellschaft v. Coleman

Headnote: The "alter ego theory" of personal jurisdiction generally allows one corporation's actions to be ascribed to another by disregarding their distinct corporate entities.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Paredes v. Abercrombie & Kent Intern., Inc.

Headnote: Where one corporation so controls and manipulates another that it becomes a mere instrumentality of the dominant corporation, a corporate creditor may disregard the corporate identity.

Title: Paredes v. Abercrombie & Kent Intern., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, courts will only pierce the corporate veil when: (1) there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporations no longer exist, and (2) circumstances are such that adherence to the fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Paredes v. Abercrombie & Kent Intern., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, the following factors should be analyzed in determining whether there is such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporations no longer exist, for purposes of determining whether to pierce a corporate veil: (1) misrepresentation; (2) commingling of funds, assets, or identities; (3) undercapitalization; (4) failure to operate at arms length; and (5) failure to comply with corporate formalities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Passengers failed to pierce the corporate veil so as to hold cruise line liable for tour operator's conduct.

Headnote: A dominant lender corporation may be liable for the obligations of a debtor corporation if the lender is so involved with the debtor that it is in fact managing the debtor's affairs.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Pearson v. Component Technology Corp.

Headnote: To succeed in holding a corporation liable under the alter ego theory, plaintiffs must establish that the controlling corporation wholly ignored the separate status of the controlled corporation and so dominated and controlled its affairs that its separate existence was a mere sham.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Layoffs. Secured creditor was not liable for failing to inform debtor's employees of plant closure.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Lewis v. Central Oklahoma Medical Group, Inc.

Headnote: The court, when determining whether one corporation is simply the instrumentality of another corporation and should be treated as one corporation for the purpose of tort law, should consider the commonality of purpose between the corporations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Berclain America Latina v. Baan Co.

Headnote: Generally, a corporate entity does not assume the rights, duties, and benefits of another entity which it acquires in a stock purchase, and the two entities are assumed to remain separate absent circumstances justifying their treatment as a single entity, such as an alter ego showing or an asset purchase.

Title: People ex rel. Vacco v. World Interactive Gaming Corp.

Headnote: The corporate form will be pierced only if one corporation is so controlled by the other as to be a mere agent, department or alter ego of the other.

Title: In re Cambridge Biotech Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Federal Circuit.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, corporations are generally to be regarded as separate from each other and from their respective stockholders where there is no occasion to look beyond the corporate form for the purpose of defeating fraud or wrong, or for the remedying of injuries, although this general principle is not of unlimited application.

Gorton, J., 212 B.R. 10, affirmed bankruptcy court's denial of plaintiffs' motion to dismiss certain portions of defendant's answer and counterclaim, affirmed grant of summary judgment that defendant did not infringe two of assignee's patents, and affirmed determination of 1% royalty rate as damages for past infringement and as compensation for future practice of third patent. Title: Weinstein v. Willow Lake Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that (1) one corporation exercised complete domination of another with respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in the plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegations by commercial landlord were sufficient to establish basis to pierce veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Weinstein v. Willow Lake Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must establish that the controlling corporation abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form to perpetrate a wrong or injustice against that party such that a court in equity will intervene.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegations by commercial landlord were sufficient to establish basis to pierce veil.

Title: Doe v. Gelineau
Court: Supreme Court of Rhode Island.
Headnote: The mere fact that a person holds an office in two corporations that may be dealing with each other and that have offices in the same building, without more, is not enough to make them identical in contemplation of law.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was unwarranted to hold church liable for abuse of children at orphanage.

Title: Hefner v. Dausmann
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Southern District. Division One.
Headnote: Generally, two different corporations are treated as two different persons, even if one corporation is the sole shareholder of the other.

Title: Hefner v. Dausmann
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Southern District. Division One.
Headnote: Two separate corporations may be treated as one only where there is such dominion and control that the controlled corporation has no separate mind, will or existence of its own and is but an alter ego for its principal; such dominion and control must be established by evidence, and is not presumed.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Hospitals. Plaintiffs could not pierce corporate veil to bring action against hospital affiliated with medical clinic.

Title: Hefner v. Dausmann
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Southern District. Division One.
Headnote: Use of terms "mind" or "will" in regard to corporations means the mind or will of one controlling the corporation or the collective minds or wills of those controlling the corporation.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Hospitals. Plaintiffs could not pierce corporate veil to bring action against hospital affiliated with medical clinic.

Headnote: To establish a principal-agent relationship between two corporate entities, the controlled corporation must be merely a business conduit for its principal.

Title: Securities Investor Protection Corp. v. Stratton Oakmont, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Corporation may be held to be alter ego of another corporation and not only of shareholders or principals of that corporation; in such situations, corporations are treated as one or, in other words, "collapsed" into one.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Securities Investor Protection Corp. v. Stratton Oakmont, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors considered in the Second Circuit to determine whether disregarding corporate separateness is an appropriate remedy are as follows: (1) absence of formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of corporate existence, such as issuance of stock, election of directors, and keeping of corporate records and the like, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address, and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) amount of business discretion displayed by allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the related corporations deal with dominated corporation at arms length, (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) payment or guarantee of debts of dominated corporation by other corporations in the group, and (10) whether corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. SIPA trustee's reverse veil-piercing theory survived dismissal motions.

Title: In re Plantation Realty Trust
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, corporate veil may be pierced in order to impute liability among differing corporate entities: (a) when there is active and direct participation by representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of that intercorporate relationship, or (b) when there is confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of separate nature of corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could be pierced in order to permit creditor's proof of claim.

Title: Magnus v. Fortune Brands, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Maine law, the corporate entity may be pierced if it is merely the alter ego of an individual or other corporation, and the corporate entity will be disregarded when used to cover fraud or illegality.
Document Preview: Cigarette smokers and smoker's survivor brought products liability action against cigarette manufacturers, their parent corporations, and tobacco industry-related trade and research associations. The District Court, Gershon, District Judge, held that: (1) smokers' claim that manufacturers breached special duty to protect public by providing information about effects of tobacco use was not preempted by Federal Cigarette Labeling and Advertising Act; (2) smokers' fraud and deceit claims were not preempted by Act; (3) smokers' breach of implied warranty claims were not preempted by Act; (4) smokers' complaint sufficiently specific to state alter ego claim against manufacturers' parent corporations; (5) trade and research associations could not be held liable to smokers under failure to warn, negligent and defective design, or strict products liability theories; (6) smokers could bring fraud action against trade and research associations; (7) New Jersey smoker's common law claims for...

Title: Saidawi v. Giovanni's Little Place, Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Three.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, a plaintiff must meet a two-part test: first, the corporation must be controlled and influenced by persons or another corporation; second, evidence must establish that the corporate cloak was used as a subterfuge to defeat public convenience, to justify a wrong, or to perpetrate a fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Workers' compensation claimant stated claim against employer's shareholders on alter-ego theory.

Title: Bostick v. Schall's Brakes and Repairs, Inc.
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: To determine whether a successor corporation has been established as an "alter ego" of a former corporation and, thus, may be held liable for the former corporation's debts and liabilities, a court must analyze the following factors with respect to the two entities: (1) centralized control of labor relations; (2) common management; (3) interrelation of operations; and (4) common ownership and financial control.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Fact questions precluded summary judgment in action to establish putative successor's liability.

Title: Ritter v. BJC Barnes Jewish Christian Health Systems
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Five.
Headnote: Generally, two separate corporations act as distinct legal entities, even if one partly or wholly owns stock in the other.

Title: Ritter v. BJC Barnes Jewish Christian Health Systems
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Five.
Headnote: Two factors must be met to pierce the corporate veil and disregard corporate forms: (1) the corporation must be controlled or influenced by another corporation; and (2) there must be evidence that the corporate cloak was used as a subterfuge to defeat public convenience, to justify a wrong, or to perpetuate a fraud.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Hospitals. Hospital's parent corporation was not liable for hospital's allegedly negligent medical care.

Title: Ritter v. BJC Barnes Jewish Christian Health Systems

Headnote: In order to pierce the corporate veil and disregard corporate forms, the control exercised by one corporation over another must not be over just finances; it must also be over the policy and business practice with respect to the particular transaction at issue.

Title: West Virginia Highlands Conservancy, Inc. v. Public Service Com'n of West Virginia
Court: Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia.
Headnote: While the law presumes that two separately incorporated businesses are distinct entities, this presumption can be disregarded when the corporate form is being used to perpetrate injustice, defeat public convenience, or justify wrongful or inequitable conduct.

Title: Herman v. Blockbuster Entertainment Group
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: A corporate entity is liable for the acts of a separate, related entity only under extraordinary circumstances.
Document Preview: Former employees brought employment discrimination action against their former corporate employer's major shareholder and its parent corporation, alleging violations of Title VII of Civil Rights Act of 1964 and New York Human Rights Law. Shareholder and parent corporation moved for summary judgment. The District Court, Lowe, J., held that: (1) former employer and its major shareholder did not constitute single employer for Title VII purposes; (2) shareholder could not be held liable as employer under Human Rights Law; and (3) shareholder could not be held liable as former employer's partner. Motion granted.

Title: American Institute of Certified Public Accountants v. Affinity Card, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In Massachusetts, corporate form will be disregarded only when: (1) there is an active and direct exercise of pervasive control by the representatives of one corporation over the activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence; or (2) there is a confused intermingling of the activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of the separate nature of the corporate entities.
Document Preview: In suit for breach of contract, defendant corporation moved to vacate default judgment. The District Court, Scheindlin, J., held that: (1) assistant vice president of corporation separate from and unaffiliated with defendant, but sharing office and having common president and partial owner, was not sufficiently integrated with defendant to allow the inference that he had authority to receive service of process for defendant; (2) fact that president of defendant actually received summons and complaint on the very same day was not sufficient to cure defective service; (3) service on separate corporation would not be deemed to constitute effective service on defendant on ground that they were both virtual alter egos of person who was president and part owner of each, under Massachusetts law; (4) service was ineffective under New York law, where service was on a non-employee who made no representations as to authorization to receive service; (5) service was also...

Title: Johnson v. Koplovsky Foods, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, piercing the corporate veil is permitted only (1) where one corporation actively and directly participates in activities of second corporation, apparently exercising pervasive control, and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of intercorporate relationship, or (2) there is a confused intermingling between corporate entities engaged in common enterprise.
Document Preview: Cranberry suppliers brought action for damages and injunctive relief against corporations which had contracted to purchase cranberries, principals of corporations, and other entities. After preliminary injunction and writs of attachment were issued, the District Court, Harrington, J., held that: (1) regulation requiring private agreements to call for payment within 30 days of receipt in order for trust protection under Perishable Agricultural Commodities Act (PACA) to be available was reasonable; (2) contract calling for 75% of payment to be made more than 30 days after receipt did not comply with regulation; (3) amounts owed under contract containing no terms regarding payment were payable within 10 days, so that trust protection was available; but (4) failure to provide written notice of intent to preserve benefits of trust deprived seller of trust protection; and (5) no reasonable likelihood of success existed on claim against principals under Massachusetts unfair trade...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Chisholm v. Foothill Capital Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, separate existence of corporation will be disregarded and veil of limited liability will be pierced if: (1) there is such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and individual, or other corporation, no longer exist and (2) situation is such that adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Former employee brought action against her former employer, related corporation, former supervisor and former co-worker, claiming sex discrimination and retaliation in violation of Title VII of Civil Rights Act of 1964, wage disparity in violation of Title VII and Equal Pay Act (EPA), defamation and invasion of privacy. Defendants moved for summary judgment. The District Court, Gettleman, J., held that: (1) former employer and related corporation were not single employer for purposes of employment discrimination liability; (2) former employee failed to show that she was constructively discharged in violation of Title VII; (3) genuine issue of material fact precluded summary judgment on the EPA and Title VII wage claims; (4) various actions identified by former employee were not adverse employment actions for purposes of Title VII retaliation claim; (5) former employee lacked admissible evidence to establish defamation claim; and (6) co-worker's disclosure of fact that former...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Pirelli Armstrong Tire Corp. v. Titan Tire Corp.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. Illinois.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce corporate veil, Illinois courts consider: (1) inadequate capitalization; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) commingling of funds; (4) absence of corporate records; and (5) failure to maintain arm's-length relationships among related entities.
Document Preview: Tire manufacturer brought action against buyer of its plant and buyer's parent company alleging violations of federal trademark laws and Illinois Uniform Deceptive Trade Practices Act, deceptive trade practices, unfair competition, and breach of asset purchase and intellectual property agreements. On parties' cross-motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Richard Mills, J., held that: (1) piercing of corporate veil was not warranted; (2) trademarks were valid; (3) manufacturer's claims were not barred by doctrines of estoppel or laches; (4) defendant infringed and diluted manufacturer's trademarks; (5) defendant unlawfully passed off its tires as those of manufacturer; and (6) defendant breached asset purchase and intellectual property agreements. Judgment for tire manufacturer against competitor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Hiller Cranberry Products, Inc. v. Koplovsky Foods, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil is permitted, under Massachusetts law, only: (1) where one corporation actively and directly participates in the activities of the second corporation, apparently exercising pervasive control, and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of the intercorporate relationship, or (2) there is a confused intermingling between corporate entities engaged in a common enterprise.
Document Preview: Cranberry supplier, who had not received payment, brought action against buyer, buyer's controlling shareholder, and company to which buyer had delivered the cranberries, asserting claims under the Perishable Agricultural Commodities Act (PACA), for misrepresentation, and for violations of the Massachusetts Fraudulent Conveyance Act and the Massachusetts Unfair Trade Practices Act.  The District Court, Harrington, J., held that: (1) supplier was not entitled to PACA trust protection; (2) alter-ego theory did not apply, so as to impose liability for debt on either shareholder or transferee company; (3) shareholder was not liable for any misrepresentation; and (4) shareholder's transfers of property were not fraudulent conveyances. So ordered.

Title: Hiller Cranberry Products, Inc. v. Koplovsky Foods, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, Massachusetts courts consider twelve factors: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business activity, assets or management; (4) insufficient capitalization for purposes of the corporate undertaking; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) nonpayment of dividends; (7) insolvency of corporation at the time of the transaction; (8) siphoning of corporate funds by the dominant shareholders; (9) nonfunctioning of officers and directors other than the shareholders; (10) absence of corporate records; (11) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholders; and (12) use of the corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: Cranberry supplier, who had not received payment, brought action against buyer, buyer's controlling shareholder, and company to which buyer had delivered the cranberries, asserting claims under the Perishable Agricultural Commodities Act (PACA), for misrepresentation, and for violations of the Massachusetts Fraudulent Conveyance Act and the Massachusetts Unfair Trade Practices Act.  The District Court, Harrington, J., held that: (1) supplier was not entitled to PACA trust protection; (2) alter-ego theory did not apply, so as to impose liability for debt on either shareholder or transferee company; (3) shareholder was not liable for any misrepresentation; and (4) shareholder's transfers of property were not fraudulent conveyances. So ordered.

Title: Richfood, Inc. v. Jennings
Court: Supreme Court of Virginia.
Headnote: Mere showing that one corporation is owned by another or that they share common officers is not sufficient justification for court to disregard their separate corporate structure.
Document Preview: Food distributor and its wholly-owned subsidiary insurance company brought action seeking reimbursement of insurance premium refund from former shareholders of grocery store corporation, of which food distributor had also been shareholder, following sale of grocery store corporation. The Supreme Court, Kinser, J., held that: (1) release agreement, in which food distributor released former shareholders from any and all claims in connection with grocery store corporation, clearly and unambiguously applied only to claims that accrued prior to its execution; (2) alleged wrongful conduct of shareholders in withholding insurance premium refund did not transpire until after execution of release agreement, and thus was not subject to release; and (3) insurance company's status as wholly-owned...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Rivera Rojas v. Loewen Group Intern., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: In order to pierce corporate veil, there must be evidence that integrity of corporate form has been violated; critical question is whether two corporations have preserved their separate corporate identities.
Document Preview: Sellers of funeral home business brought breach of contract action against corporate buyer for alleged mismanagement of company, onerous loan agreement, and misappropriation of profits.  Buyer moved to dismiss for failure to join its subsidiary, allegedly a necessary party.  The District Court, Laffitte, J., held that: (1) subsidiary was an indispensable party, and (2) subsidiary was not alter ego of buyer. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Today's Child Learning Center Inc. v. U.S.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Critical factors in making determination as to alter ego status of successor corporation include who has active or substantial control as well as similarities that exist between two businesses; courts should consider whether old and new corporations share substantially identical management, business purpose, operation, equipment, customers and supervision, as well as ownership.
Document Preview: Corporation brought wrongful levy action against government. Following bench trial, the District Court, Newcomer, J., held that: (1) corporation was mere continuation or successor in interest of corporate taxpayer, and, thereby liable for taxpayer's federal employment taxes, and (2) corporation was alter ego of taxpayer. Judgment entered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Olympic Financial Ltd. v. Consumer Credit Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, the factors to consider in determining whether two or more corporations have been operated as a single business enterprise include whether the corporations had: (1) common employees; (2) common record keeping; (3) centralized accounting; (4) payment of wages by one corporation to another corporation's employees; (5) a common business name; (6) services rendered by the employees of one corporation on behalf of another; (7) undocumented transfers between corporations; (8) unclear allocation of profits and losses between the corporations; (9) the same officers; (10) the same shareholders; and (11) the same telephone number.
Document Preview: Finance company sued automobile seller for breach of consignment contract under which seller sold repossessed automobiles, and also against other dealers with which finance company had master dealership agreements. On defendants' motion for partial summary judgment, the District Court, Atlas, J., held that: (1) seller and other dealers were not operated as single business entity; (2) there was no actual fraud by seller; and (3) there was no fiduciary duty on part of seller. Motion granted.

Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Fort Worth.
Headnote: Alter ego comes into play when corporation is organized and operated as mere tool or business conduit of another corporation.

Title: Expediters Intern. of Washington, Inc. v. Direct Line Cargo Management Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: When one corporation acts as agent of disclosed principal corporation, latter corporation may be liable on contracts made by agent.
Document Preview: Complainant who was purported holder of rights to copyrighted computer program, obtained from Taiwan corporation with which it was affiliated, sued competitor formerly affiliated with Taiwan corporation, alleging violation of Copyright Act, trade secret misappropriation, and breach of contract. Competitor moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Pisano, United States Magistrate Judge, held that: (1) material issues of fact, precluding summary judgment, existed as to whether competitor authorized foreign affiliates to utilize program after license agreement expired, so as to be primarily liable for violation of Copyright Act; (2) provision of Copyright Act, allowing for copying of computer programs, did not apply to facts of case; (3) state trade secret claim was not preempted by Copyright Act; (4) there was fact issue whether competitor could be found liable for breach of confidentiality agreements between complainant and foreign corporations using programs;...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Harrison v. NBD Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil under Delaware law, plaintiff must show that controlling corporation wholly ignored separate status of controlled corporation and so dominated and controlled its affairs that separate existence was a sham.
Document Preview: Consumer who incurred debt for home study course brought putative class action against creditor-correspondence school and collection agency, alleging that demand letter sent by agency violated the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA).  Defendants moved for partial dismissal for failure to state a claim and consumer moved for leave to amend complaint, if necessary.  The District Court, Spatt, J., held that: (1) allegations in complaint were inadequate to establish that school was a debt collector subject to liability under FDCPA, and (2) consumer was entitled to amend complaint. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Wilshire Credit Corp. v. Karlin
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Maryland law, corporate entity is disregarded under alter ego doctrine when it is so organized and controlled, and its affairs are so conducted, as to make it merely an instrumentality, agency, conduit, or adjunct of another corporation.
Document Preview: Settlors' judgment creditor sought to recover assets of trust established for benefit of settlors' children as satisfaction of debt.  Parties cross-moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Williams, J., held that: (1) trust assets were beyond creditor's reach, since settlors did not retain ownership interest in trust corpus, and (2) alter ego principles could not be invoked to allow creditor to recover settlors' debt from trust property. Settlors' summary judgment motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Anderson Street Realty Corp. v. RHMB New Rochelle Leasing Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil requires showing that one corporation exercised complete domination of other with respect to transaction attacked, that domination was used to commit wrong against plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury, and controlling corporation abused privilege of doing business in corporate form to perpetrate wrong or injustice against plaintiff such that court in equity will intervene.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Lessor could pierce corporate veil to reach lessee's parent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Fleming Companies, Inc. v. Rich
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil on "alter ego" theory, plaintiff must show: (1) that corporation was controlled and influenced by persons or another corporation, and (2) that corporate cloak was used as subterfuge to defeat public convenience, to justify wrong, or to perpetrate fraud.
Document Preview: Judgment creditors brought action for creditor's bill to enforce judgments previously entered against corporate entities by having certain conveyances voided as fraudulent and by piercing corporate veil.  The District Court, Limbaugh, J., held that: (1) passage of the Missouri Uniform Fraudulent Transfer Act (MoUFTA) was not meant to extinguish long-standing equitable remedy of creditor's bill, as remedy available to creditor to set aside transfer by debtor on ground of fraud; (2) grocery store's rental payments to parents of its director and sole shareholder, pursuant to renewal of alleged lease on which no rent had ever been paid, were made with actual intent to hinder, delay, or defraud creditors; (3) transaction by which insolvent grocery store pledged certificate of deposit as substitute collateral to obtain release of certificate of deposit belonging to its director's parents was likewise void as fraudulent conveyance; and (4) corporate veil could be...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Commonwealth Aluminum Corp. v. Baldwin Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, successful invocation of alter ego doctrine requires showing that businesses, although separately incorporated, have been operated in so imbricated a manner as to justify reasonable perception that they are one and the same.
Document Preview: Suppliers brought action against, inter alia, vice president of corporation that owed them money and company that was erroneously represented as the imminent purchaser of the corporation, alleging breach of contract and fraud. Defendants moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Ponsor, J., adopted the opinion of Neiman, United States Magistrate Judge, which held that: (1) company was not liable for corporation's debts; (2) statute of frauds barred suppliers' breach of contract claim against company; (3) suppliers did not confer measurable benefit on company, as required for quantum meruit claim; (4) fact questions precluded summary judgment on misrepresentation claims against vice president of corporation and company; (5) vice president of corporation was not agent of company; (6) fact questions precluded summary judgment on estoppel claims against company; and (7) fact questions precluded summary judgment on unfair and deceptive trade practices claims against...

Title: Commonwealth Aluminum Corp. v. Baldwin Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, it is permissible to pierce alleged corporate veil when there is either confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in common enterprise with substantial disregard of separate nature of corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about matter and capacity in which various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.

Defendants moved for summary judgment.
