Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Commonwealth Aluminum Corp. v. Baldwin Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, in deciding whether to penetrate corporate form, court will consider: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business activity, assets or management; (4) thin capitalization; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) nonpayment of dividends; (8) insolvency at time of litigated transaction; (9) siphoning away of corporate assets by dominant shareholders; (10) nonfunctioning of officers and directors; (11) use of corporation for transactions of dominant shareholders; and (12) use of corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: Suppliers brought action against, inter alia, vice president of corporation that owed them money and company that was erroneously represented as the imminent purchaser of the corporation, alleging breach of contract and fraud. Defendants moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Ponsor, J., adopted the opinion of Neiman, United States Magistrate Judge, which held that: (1) company was not liable for corporation's debts; (2) statute of frauds barred suppliers' breach of contract claim against company; (3) suppliers did not confer measurable benefit on company, as required for quantum meruit claim; (4) fact questions precluded summary judgment on misrepresentation claims against vice president of corporation and company; (5) vice president of corporation was not agent of company; (6) fact questions precluded summary judgment on estoppel claims against company; and (7) fact questions precluded summary judgment on unfair and deceptive trade practices claims against...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Ost-West-Handel Bruno Bischoff GmbH v. Project Asia Line, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Norfolk Division. .
Headnote: Because demonstrating that one corporation is merely the alter-ego of another is difficult to do through direct evidence, courts look for certain indicia that strongly suggest a disregard for the corporate form, including: gross under-capitalization of subservient corporation; failure to observe corporate formalities between the two; nonpayment of dividends; insolvency of subservient corporation; siphoning of funds from subservient corporation; non-functioning officers or directors; absence of corporate records; and complete control by dominant stockholder.
Document Preview: Vessel owner filed complaint against charterer of another vessel in personam, and against the other vessel in rem, seeking to attach the vessel and its bunkers, based on claim that charterer had failed to pay amounts owing pursuant to charter party involving its vessel. Bank filed intervening complaint seeking to foreclose and assert first preferred Liberian ship mortgage on vessel. Third claimant filed claim for amounts owing on time charter involving third vessel. After arrested vessel was sold, bench trial was conducted to resolve respective priorities among claimants. The District Court, MacKenzie, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) evidence that attorney retained to organize corporation which was registered owner of arrested vessel and to facilitate sale of vessel billed work to charterer which managed vessel, and that chief financial officer of charterer had brief tenure as president of registered owner, was insufficient to find that charterer and...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Trans-World Intern., Inc. v. Smith-Hemion Productions, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: In determining whether individual or corporation is alter ego of another corporation under both Delaware and California law, question ultimately is whether dominant shareholder should be held liable for misdeeds perpetrated by that shareholder in name of corporation.
Document Preview: Production company sued musical performers in family group and performers' corporation, alleging promissory estoppel, fraud, and alter ego claims arising out of cancelled televised performance.  After mistrial, plaintiff dismissed fraud claim and parties submitted claims to court based on record created during trial.  The District Court, Laughlin E. Waters, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) production company failed to establish promissory estoppel claim against performer who stated intent to appear on show; (2) dismissal of fraud claim did not preclude alter ego claims; and (3) performers were not alter egos of corporation. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: U.S. v. Cordova Chemical Co. of Michigan
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, demonstration of patent abuse of corporate form is required in order to pierce corporate veil, and there must be such a unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporations cease to exist, and circumstances must be such that adherence to the fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: United States filed action under Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act (CERCLA) regarding responsibility for past and future costs incurred in cleanup of soil, surface water, and ground waters surrounding dormant chemical manufacturing plant. The United States District Court for the Western District of Michigan, Douglas W. Hillman, Senior District Judge, 777 F.Supp. 549, imposed liability against owners of site, and on appeal, the Court of Appeals, 59 F.3d 584, affirmed in part, reversed in part and remanded. Rehearing en banc was granted, and the Court of Appeals judgment was vacated, 67 F.3d 586. On rehearing en banc, the Court of Appeals, Alan E. Norris, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) parent corporation could incur operator liability under CERCLA for conduct of subsidiaries only if requirements necessary to pierce corporate veil were met; (2) CERCLA precluded imposition of arranger liability against state Department of Natural Resources...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Robbins v. Blecher
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 5, California.
Headnote: Under alter ego doctrine, where corporation is used by individual or individuals, or by another corporation, to perpetrate fraud, circumvent statute, or accomplish some other wrongful or inequitable purpose, court may disregard corporate entity and treat corporation's acts as if they were done by persons actually controlling corporation.
Document Preview: TORTS - Malicious Prosecution. Voluntary dismissal of action was not favorable termination on merits supporting subsequent malicious prosecution action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Robbins v. Blecher
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 5, California.
Headnote: In general, requirements for applying alter ego doctrine are that there is such unity of interest and ownership between corporation and individual or organization controlling it that their separate personalities no longer exist, and that failure to disregard corporate entity would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: TORTS - Malicious Prosecution. Voluntary dismissal of action was not favorable termination on merits supporting subsequent malicious prosecution action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re RCS Engineered Products Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, court may find that one entity is alter ego of another and pierce corporate veil upon proof of the following: corporate entity must be mere instrumentality of another; corporate entity must be used to commit fraud or wrong; and there must have been unjust loss or injury to plaintiff.
Document Preview: Corporations. Alter ego claim against parent corporation did not become estate property when debtor-subsidiary filed petition as subsidiary may not bring alter ego claim against its parent under Michigan law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Chicago Dist. Council of Carpenters Pension Fund v. P.M.Q.T., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois.
Headnote: "Alter ego doctrine" treats two nominally separate business entities as if they were a single, continuous employer to prevent a corporation that has acted fraudulently or unjustly from protecting itself from liability by shielding itself with the protective mantle of the corporate forum; rationale behind the doctrine is that, if the corporations themselves disregard the legal separation and proper formalities, then the law will likewise disregard them insofar as is necessary to protect other individuals' rights.
Document Preview: Trust funds brought action for delinquent contributions against employer, who was signatory to multiemployer collective bargaining agreement with union, and against company, who trust funds alleged was employer's alter ego.  The District Court, Keys, United States Magistrate Judge, held that company was the alter ego of employer and as such, company was bound by the terms of the collective bargaining agreement entered into by employer and company's funds could be reached in order to pay what was owed to trust funds. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Chicago Dist. Council of Carpenters Pension Fund v. Vacala Masonry, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Alter ego analysis is very fact intensive and centers around several factors which involve whether the two enterprises share substantially identical management, business purposes, operations, equipment, customers, supervision and ownership; no one factor is determinative and, thus, alter ego status may be established where one or more of the elements is missing.
Document Preview: Pension and welfare funds and apprentice program (funds) brought action against construction companies, alleging breach of collective bargaining agreement as result of failure to make monetary contributions to funds for each hour worked by companies' employees and nonunion subcontractors and for refusing to allow funds access to company's books to verify compliance with terms of agreement.  Companies moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Ashman, United States Magistrate Judge, held that: (1) companies lacked unlawful intent necessary to find first company alter ego of second company, for purposes of funds' claims against first company under alter ego theory; (2) material issue of fact as to whether second company under-reported hours worked and, therefore, owed contributions to funds precluded summary judgment for second company; and (3) evidence was insufficient to raise genuine issue of material fact as to first construction company's alter ego status...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Chicago Dist. Council of Carpenters Pension Fund v. Vacala Masonry, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Alter ego doctrine is applicable in situations in which entity exists side-by-side with its alleged alter ego.
Document Preview: Pension and welfare funds and apprentice program (funds) brought action against construction companies, alleging breach of collective bargaining agreement as result of failure to make monetary contributions to funds for each hour worked by companies' employees and nonunion subcontractors and for refusing to allow funds access to company's books to verify compliance with terms of agreement.  Companies moved for summary judgment. Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: NEC Technologies, Inc. v. Nelson
Court: Supreme Court of Georgia.
Headnote: To establish alter ego doctrine plaintiff must show that defendant disregarded separateness of legal entities by commingling on interchangeable or joint basis or by confusing otherwise separate properties, records, or control, or by showing that disregard of corporate entity made it mere instrumentality for transaction of other entity's own affairs and that there is such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporations no longer exist; evidence must be such that to adhere to doctrine of corporate entity would promote injustice or protect fraud.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Warranties. Warranty on television set excluding consequential damages was not procedurally or substantively unconscionable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: NEC Technologies, Inc. v. Nelson
Court: Supreme Court of Georgia.
Headnote: Importer of television components was not alter ego of manufacturer, absent evidence of any commingling of money, facilities, or records between two corporations or evidence that corporations shared officers or employees.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Warranties. Warranty on television set excluding consequential damages was not procedurally or substantively unconscionable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Theberge v. Darbro, Inc.
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Maine.
Headnote: Although corporate entity may be pierced if it is merely alter ego of individual or other corporation, courts are to disregard legal entity of corporation with caution and only when necessary in interest of justice.
Document Preview: Vendor and purchaser/subsequent vendor of real property sued person controlling ultimate purchaser, and another corporation controlled by him, seeking to recover amount remaining on note executed by purchaser/subsequent vendor to secure purchase price of property, which had been assumed by ultimate purchaser.  The Superior Court, Androscoggin County, Brennan, J., entered judgment for original vendor and purchaser/subsequent vendor and appeal was taken.  The Supreme Judicial Court, Glassman, J., held that evidence did not support piercing of corporate veil, even though controlling person had allegedly represented that he would stand behind ultimate purchaser's obligations, as controlling person had not guaranteed note in question. Vacated and remanded. Lipez, J., dissented and filed opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Bridgestone/Firestone, Inc. v. Recovery Credit Services, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate veil will be pierced, under New York law, only when corporate forum has been used to achieve fraud, or when corporation has been so dominated by an individual or another corporation, and its separate entity so disregarded, that corporation primarily transacted dominator's business rather than its own and can be called dominator's alter ego.
Document Preview: Creditor brought suit against corporations which had performed collection services for it under contract, and also against principal of corporations, seeking recovery of funds collected from debtors which had not been paid over to creditor.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, John S. Martin, Jr., J., entered judgment for creditor and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Winter, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) corporate veil could be pierced, to attribute liability of corporations to principal; (2) damages could be based upon rate of nonpayment taken from most recent year, and applying it to prior years, as defendants' own destruction of records for earlier years precluded more accurate damages estimates; (3) creditor failed to establish that principal had committed fraud when promising to honor contractual commitments; (4) contract provision calling for award of attorney fees when indemnification was involved, was not...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Stoecker
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Bankruptcy court will not disregard the legal fiction of separate corporate entities and pierce corporate veil without adequate supporting evidence.
Document Preview: Tax Liability. State failed to prove that Chapter 7 debtor was responsible officer of nondebtor corporation who willfully failed to pay use tax assessed against the corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Stoecker
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, corporate entity will be disregarded, and its veil of limited liability pierced, when there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the two corporations no longer exist, and adherence to the fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote an injustice.
Document Preview: Tax Liability. State failed to prove that Chapter 7 debtor was responsible officer of nondebtor corporation who willfully failed to pay use tax assessed against the corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Stoecker
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, factors considered in determining whether there is such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of two corporations no longer exist, so that corporate entity will be disregarded and veil of limited liability pierced, include the failure to maintain adequate corporate records or to comply with corporate formalities, commingling of funds or assets, undercapitalization, and one corporation treating the assets of another corporation as its own.
Document Preview: Tax Liability. State failed to prove that Chapter 7 debtor was responsible officer of nondebtor corporation who willfully failed to pay use tax assessed against the corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: National Soffit & Escutcheons, Inc. v. Superior Systems, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Second corporation was not alter ego of first corporation, so as to allow piercing of corporate veil under Indiana law and enforcement against second corporation of judgment covering first corporation, even though both corporations were in same business and shared same president and vice president; there was no indication of undercapitalization of second corporation or failure to observe separate corporate formalities, directors and shareholders of second corporation had not been involved in wrongdoing leading to judgment in question, and second corporation's purchase of $700 of first corporation's tools at fair market value did not constitute sufficient commingling of assets.
Document Preview: Suit was brought against second corporation, to enforce state court judgment obtained against first corporation.  The United States District Court for the Northern District of Indiana, Robert L. Miller, Jr., J., granted summary judgment for second corporation and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Bauer, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) second corporation was not alter ego of first corporation, so as to allow for piercing of corporate veil, even though corporations had some officers in common and were in same line of business, and (2) second corporation was not successor of first corporation. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Montclair Homes
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors tending to show shareholder domination and control, of kind which may permit piercing of corporate veil under New York law, include absence of corporate formalities; inadequate capitalization; use of corporate funds for personal rather than corporate purposes; overlapping ownership, officers, directors and personnel; common office space, addresses and telephone numbers for corporate entities; and payment or guaranty of debts of corporation by owners or other related corporate entities.
Document Preview: Veil Piercing. Corporate veil would be pierced to hold corporate principal personally liable for Chapter 7 debtor's obligations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Salazar v. Coastal Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: The doctrine of "alter ego" is applicable where a corporation is organized and operated as a mere tool or business conduit of another corporation.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Texas choice of law provision applicable despite performance in Ecuador.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Salazar v. Coastal Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Alter ego is often established by evidence showing a blending of identities, or a blurring of lines of distinction between corporations, and important factors in making a determination of alter ego include the identity of shareholders, directors, officers, and employees, or failure to distinguish in ordinary business between different entities.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Texas choice of law provision applicable despite performance in Ecuador.

Title: Great West Cas. Co. v. Travelers Indem. Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Dakota, Western Division.
Headnote: To hold dominant corporation liable for debts of subservient corporation on instrumentality theory, South Dakota courts require that dominant corporation assume actual, participatory, total control of subservient corporation; merely taking active part in management of subservient corporation does not automatically constitute "control," as required under instrumentality doctrine.

Title: Great West Cas. Co. v. Travelers Indem. Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Dakota, Western Division.
Headnote: Under South Dakota law, evidence that creditor designates order in which debtor's creditors are to be paid is not evidence of "control," of kind which is necessary for creditor to become liable on corporate instrumentality theory for debtor's liabilities.
Document Preview: Creditors of insurance agency which had filed for Chapter 7 relief brought adversary proceeding against corporate lender which had financed management's acquisition of stock of agency, seeking to hold corporate lender liable for agency's debts on corporate instrumentality theory.  Creditors also asserted claims against lender for its alleged conversion of insurance premiums which should have been paid to them, tortious interference with their contractual relations with insurance agency, and negligence and breach of fiduciary duty. On lender's motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Battey, Chief Judge, held that: (1) corporate lender which financed borrower's acquisition of stock of insurance agency did not exercise such actual, participatory and total control over business of agency that it could he held liable for agency's debts to third party creditors on corporate instrumentality theory; (2) creditors failed to show that lender had converted...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: U.S. v. Wallace
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: For liability to attach under alter ego doctrine, dominant corporation's control must amount to total domination of subservient corporation to extent that subservient corporation manifests no separate corporate interests of its own and functions solely to achieve purposes of dominant corporation with no separate mind, will or existence of its own.
Document Preview: Federal and state governments filed separate actions under Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) concerning cleanup of waste treatment and disposal facility, and cases were consolidated. On motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Solis, J., held that: (1) evidence that semiconductor manufacturer shipped spent solvents containing various hazardous wastes and hydrofluoric acid to site, and that hydrofluoric acid was contaminated with arsenic, established that purchaser of manufacturer was jointly and severally liable for response costs; (2) failure of purchaser to satisfy its burden of presenting evidence from which district court could determine amount of harm caused by each defendant mandated conclusion that purchaser was jointly and severally liable for response costs; (3) genuine issues of material fact existed, precluding summary judgment, on whether purchaser operated as alter ego of its parent corporation so as to...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Joiner v. Ryder System Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. Illinois.
Headnote: Corporation can be the agent of another corporation without being that corporation's alter ego.
Document Preview: Worker brought strict products liability and negligence action to recover for injuries sustained when he attempted to remove skids located at rear of automobile transport trailer.  Parent company of trailer's manufacturer moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Richard Mills, J., held that: (1) parent company did not exert improper control over subsidiaries so as to support argument that parent was alter ego of trailer manufacturer; (2) parent company did not hold itself out as manufacturer of trailer, for purposes of liability under apparent manufacturer doctrine; and (3) assuming parent company was aware prior to injuries in question that trailer was unsafe, parent did not have duty to order subsidiary to redesign trailer. Motion for summary judgment allowed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Mukhtar v. Castleton Service Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Indiana, Indianapolis Division.
Headnote: Courts generally treat two corporations as distinct legal entities under Indiana law, but may disregard that distinction and pierce corporate veil to prevent fraud or unfairness to third parties.
Document Preview: Doctor sued owner of clinic for allegedly violating Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA) by terminating their relationship.  Defendant moved for summary judgment on grounds that no employment relationship existed between parties.  The District Court, Hamilton, J., held that doctor was employee of clinic under ADEA. Summary judgment denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Manhattan Woods Golf Club, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Court may pierce corporate veil to hold one corporation liable for acts of another either upon showing of fraud or upon evidence that one corporation has been so dominated by the other, and its separate identity so disregarded, that it primarily transacted the dominator's business rather than its own and can be called the dominator's alter ego.
Document Preview: Corporations. corporate subsidiary's former officers and directors could not engage in reverse veil-piercing to hold subsidiary liable on their agreements with corporate parent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Murray v. Miner
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Law allows corporation to organize so as to isolate liabilities among separate entities; under doctrine of limited liability, corporate entity is liable for acts of separate, related entity only under extraordinary circumstances, commonly referred to as "piercing the corporate veil."
Document Preview: Former employees of defunct corporation brought suit against successor corporation's principal shareholders, seeking to hold them liable, under single employer doctrine, for breach of employment contracts.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, Robert P. Patterson, Jr., J., 876 F.Supp.  512, dismissed complaint for failure to state a claim, and plaintiffs appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Meskill, Circuit Judge, held that under New York law as predicted by the Court of Appeals, single employer doctrine did not apply to hold controlling shareholders of successor corporation liable for breach of employment contracts, where there was no employer-employee relationship between employees and successor at time of alleged wrong. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Holland v. High-Tech Collieries, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. West Virginia.
Headnote: Application of alter ego doctrine requires analysis of several factors, including common ownership, interrelation of operation, common management and centralized control of labor relations.
Document Preview: Trustees of 1992 Benefit Plan, which was established pursuant to National Coal Industry Retiree Health Benefit Act, sued mine operator and related corporations for unpaid premiums.  Operator and related corporations brought third-party complaint against mine owner, seeking to enforce contract which allegedly required owner to reimburse operator for retiree benefits.  Owner counterclaimed for monies advanced to operator to cover health care costs.  On motions for summary judgment by Plan and owner, the District Court, Keeley, J., held that: (1) Act did not violate due process clause; (2) Act did not violate takings clause; (3) beneficiaries of pension plan were properly assigned to operator; (4) operator, rather than owner, was employer of miners, for purposes of determining liability under Act; (5) related corporations were related persons jointly and severally liable to employees; (5) contract between...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Kasprzak v. American General Life & Acc. Ins. Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Texas, Beaumont Division.
Headnote: Corporate fiction is disregarded when, among other reasons, corporation is organized and operated as mere tool or business conduit of another corporation.
Document Preview: Insureds brought state-court action against life insurer and its corporate parent, alleging misrepresentation in sales of policies issued by insurer. Defendants removed. On insureds' motion to remand for lack of diversity, the District Court, Cobb, J., held that clear and convincing evidence showed that insureds fraudulently joined parent in effort to defeat diversity as jurisdictional basis for removal, and thus removal was proper, where there was no evidence to support disregarding corporate separateness of insurer and parent. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Chicago Dist. Council of Carpenters Pension Fund v. Cotter
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In determining whether successor corporation is alter ego of its predecessor, courts consider several factors: whether they have substantially identical management, business purpose, operation, equipment, customers, supervision, and ownership.
Document Preview: Fund trustees filed action to examine books of alleged sole proprietorship operated by former president of dissolved corporate employer to assess appropriate multiemployer benefit plan contributions.  Defendants filed motion seeking relief from default judgment allowing funds to examine defendants' books.  The District Court, Bucklo, J., held that: (1) ten-year statute of limitations for breach of written contracts under Illinois law applied to action; (2) district court had jurisdiction over action; (3) bankruptcy court's rejection of claim for contribution brought by funds did not bar action on res judicata grounds; (4) corporate employer never adequately rejected collective bargaining agreement in bankruptcy proceeding; and (5) audit was authorized to determine whether former president of dissolved corporation could be liable for contributions that corporation owed to plans. Motion granted in part and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Chicago Dist. Council of Carpenters Pension Fund v. Cotter
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Although courts may consider whether change was motivated by anti-union sentiment in determining whether successor corporation is alter ego of its predecessor, it is not necessary to find anti-union sentiment to conclude that successor is alter ego.
Document Preview: Fund trustees filed action to examine books of alleged sole proprietorship operated by former president of dissolved corporate employer to assess appropriate multiemployer benefit plan contributions.  Defendants filed motion seeking relief from default judgment allowing funds to examine defendants' books.  The District Court, Bucklo, J., held that: (1) ten-year statute of limitations for breach of written contracts under Illinois law applied to action; (2) district court had jurisdiction over action; (3) bankruptcy court's rejection of claim for contribution brought by funds did not bar action on res judicata grounds; (4) corporate employer never adequately rejected collective bargaining agreement in bankruptcy proceeding; and (5) audit was authorized to determine whether former president of dissolved corporation could be liable for contributions that corporation owed to plans. Motion granted in part and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Thomas Berkeley Consulting Engineer, Inc. v. Zerman
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Two.
Headnote: Test for piercing corporate veil is two pronged: first, corporation must be controlled and influenced by persons or by another corporation; and, second, evidence must establish that corporate cloak was used as subterfuge to defeat public convenience, to justify wrong, or to perpetuate fraud.
Document Preview: Veil Piercing. Genuine issue of material fact existed as to whether corporate veil should be pierced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Dale v. H.B. Smith Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: In order for court to disregard separate corporate entities, plaintiff must meet very high standard and court may pierce the corporate veil only when there is evidence of confused intermingling between corporate entities or where one corporation actively and directly participates in activities of second corporation, apparently exercising pervasive control.
Document Preview: Plaintiff sought to pierce corporate veil in breach of commercial lease action.  Defendants brought partial summary judgment motions. The District Court, Neiman, United States Magistrate Judge, held that: (1) evidence did not warrant disregarding separate corporate entities, and (2) summary judgment motion failed on procedural grounds. One motion granted, and one motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Dale v. H.B. Smith Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, disregarding separate corporate entities is the exception, not the rule, and is particularly appropriate where there is fraud and injurious consequences from such an intercorporate relationship.
Document Preview: Plaintiff sought to pierce corporate veil in breach of commercial lease action.  Defendants brought partial summary judgment motions. The District Court, Neiman, United States Magistrate Judge, held that: (1) evidence did not warrant disregarding separate corporate entities, and (2) summary judgment motion failed on procedural grounds. One motion granted, and one motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Dale v. H.B. Smith Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: There was no dispute authentic enough to justify or warrant court's use of unusual remedy of piercing corporate veil in absence of evidence that corporations were inextricably intertwined, that one controlled other, or that there was confused intermingling of non-business activity, assets, or management, where there was at most some limited common ownership between corporations through one man, and where there was no allegation or evidence of fraud.
Document Preview: Plaintiff sought to pierce corporate veil in breach of commercial lease action.  Defendants brought partial summary judgment motions. The District Court, Neiman, United States Magistrate Judge, held that: (1) evidence did not warrant disregarding separate corporate entities, and (2) summary judgment motion failed on procedural grounds. One motion granted, and one motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Grease Monkey Intern., Inc. v. Godat
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Four.
Headnote: Two separate corporations may be treated as one only where there is such dominion and control that controlled corporation has no separate mind, will or existence of its own and is but an alter ego for its principal; such dominion and control must be established by evidence and is not presumed.
Document Preview: REAL ESTATE - Specific Performance. Sales contract was incomplete and therefore not subject to specific performance.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Singh v. Therrien Management Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of New Hampshire.
Headnote: Although owners of corporation may take advantage of benefits of dividing business into separate corporate parts, principles of reciprocity require that courts also recognize separate identity of the enterprises when sued by injured employee.
Document Preview: Injured employee brought negligence action against corporation which was set up by his employer's president and his wife, and which employed supervisory workers at job site where injury occurred.  The Superior Court, Strafford County, Dickson, J., entered summary judgment for corporation.  Employee appealed.  The Supreme Court, Batchelder, J., held that: (1) suit was not barred under principle of coemployee immunity; (2) corporation was not acting as employer's agent, so as to require Workers' Compensation Law to be employee's exclusive remedy; and (3) assuming that corporation's workers were immune as borrowed servants of employer, their immunity could not inure to benefit of corporation. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Homelands of DeLeon Springs, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Jacksonville Division.
Headnote: Under Florida standard for disregarding corporate entity, not only must it be shown that corporations are alter egos of each other without independent existence, but also, that corporate form was used for improper, if not, fraudulent purpose.
Document Preview: Veil Piercing. Under Florida law, corporate veil could not be pierced to find debtor liable for tax debts of corporation that leased property from debtor and that was wholly owned by holding company set up by owner of debtor because fraud was not shown.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: King v. Eastman Kodak Co.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: "Alter ego" claim under Delaware law requires showing not only that dominant company controlled subservient one, but also that dominant company proximately caused plaintiffs harm through fraud or other misuse of its control.
Document Preview: Corporations. Parent was not liable for subsidiary's product.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re B.J. McAdams, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Under alter ego doctrine, legal fiction of separate corporate entity may be rejected in case of corporation that is controlled by another to extent that it has independent existence in form only, and is used as subterfuge to defeat public convenience, to justify wrong, or to perpetuate fraud.
Document Preview: Chapter 7 trustee filed adversary proceedings to determine nature, extent and priority of any liens asserted in proceeds from sale of jet and in certain personal property located on debtor's premises.  The United States Bankruptcy Court for the Eastern District of Arkansas found that creditor's liens were void, and creditor appealed.  The District Court, Elsijane Trimble Roy, J., dismissed appeals, and creditor appealed.  The Court of Appeals, 999 F.2d 1221, affirmed in part and reversed in part.  On remand, the bankruptcy court held that creditor's lien was null and void, and creditor appealed.  The District Court, Stephen M. Reasoner, Chief Judge, affirmed, and creditor appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Heaney, Senior Circuit Judge, held that: (1) proceeding did not constitute alter ego proceeding over which trustee would not have standing; (2) bankruptcy court had jurisdiction over proceeding, even though liens asserted...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: U.S. v. Schiefen
Court: United States District Court, D. South Dakota, Southern Division.
Headnote: In deciding whether assets of one entity may be reached to answer for the debts of another on "alter ego" theory under South Dakota law, court considers various factors, including whether debtor exerted extensive, if not absolute, control over assets of other entity, whether entity funds were used to pay debtor's personal expenses, whether personal property was transferred to entity for little or no consideration, whether debtor purchased property in name of entity for his personal use, whether assets of entity are insured in debtor's own name, and whether there is close family relationship between debtor and officers of entity, or whether other directors were merely figureheads who made no decisions.
Document Preview: Federal government brought action to foreclose on its tax liens and to foreclose on mortgage executed by tax protestor in connection with government loan.  On tax protestor's motion to dismiss government's action for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, and on government's motion to strike tax protestor's answer and for entry of summary judgment of foreclosure, the District Court, Piersol, J., held that: (1) district court could exercise subject matter jurisdiction over foreclosure action; (2) tax protestor failed to raise any genuine issue of material fact as to government's right to foreclose on mortgage and on federal tax liens; (3) transfers which tax protestor made for little or no consideration, at time substantially contemporaneous with federal tax liens, could be set aside as fraudulent conveyances; but (4) no Rule 11 sanctions would be imposed. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: U.S. v. Funds Held in Name or for Ben. of Wetterer
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: In order to determine whether corporation is dominated by individual or another corporation so as to warrant piercing of the corporate veil under New York law, trier of fact should consider the following factors: absence of corporate formalities; inadequate capitalization; whether funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; overlap in ownership; common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; amount of business discretion displayed by allegedly dominated company; whether corporations deal with each other at arms length; whether allegedly dominated corporation is treated as independent profit center; payment of debts and guarantees by parent for benefit of subsidiary; and whether subsidiary uses property of parent as if it were its own, but many of these factors are inapplicable when issue is dominion by an individual rather than another corporation.
Document Preview: Guatemalan not-for-profit corporation objected to report and recommendation of United States Magistrate Judge Chrein striking, on ground that corporation was alter ego of individual who was fugitive as to indictments in United States, corporation's claim to certain bank accounts held in its name or in the name of the individual, allegedly for its use and benefit, which were seized by United States. The District Court, Spatt, J., held that: (1) in the Second Circuit, district court can, in the exercise of its discretion and in the appropriate circumstances, apply the disentitlement doctrine in a civil forfeiture proceeding to the claim of a corporation alleged to be the alter ego of a fugitive; (2) under federal common law choice-of-law principles, New York and Texas were the jurisdictions whose laws and policies were implicated to the greatest extent; (3) under the laws of either New York or Texas, piercing the corporate veil was warranted on alter ego theory;...

Title: U.S. v. Funds Held in Name or for Ben. of Wetterer
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: New York law recognizes that corporate form may be disregarded upon showing of control by a dominating corporation that leads to wrong against third parties.

Title: U.S. v. Funds Held in Name or for Ben. of Wetterer
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Texas law, "alter ego" as basis for piercing corporate veil is defined as when corporation is organized and operated as mere tool or business conduit of another corporation or individual, and to show alter ego, total dealings of corporation and individual must be considered, including such factors as degree to which corporate formalities had been followed and corporate and individual property have been kept separately, amount of financial interest, ownership and control individual maintains over the corporation, and whether corporation has been used for personal purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: United Paperworkers Intern. Union, AFL-CIO, CLC v. Alden Corrugated Container Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, one corporation may be held liable for actions of another when there is act of indirect participation by representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of inter-corporate relationship, or when there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in common enterprise with substantial disregard for separate nature of corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about manner and capacity in which various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: Unions brought action against employers alleging violation of Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act (WARN) in connection with plant closing. The District Court, Robert B. Collings, United States Magistrate Judge, held that: (1) employer's layoff of 30 employees on one date and 24 additional employees within 90 days of first layoff was a mass layoff under WARN Act; (2) two corporations and a holding company were a single employer for purposes of WARN Act; and (3) District Court would not exercise its discretion to reduce amount of liability and penalty to be assessed against employers for failure to give notice of mass layoffs as required by WARN Act. Judgment in favor of plaintiffs.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: United Paperworkers Intern. Union, AFL-CIO, CLC v. Alden Corrugated Container Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Factors to consider when determining whether a corporation may be held liable for actions of another corporation under Massachusetts law include common ownership; pervasive control; confused intermingling of business activity, assets or management; thin capitalization; nonobservance of corporate formalities; absence of corporate records; no payment of dividends; insolvency at time of litigated transactions; siphoning away of corporate assets by dominant shareholders; non-functioning of officers and directors; use of corporation for transactions of dominant shareholders; and use of corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: Unions brought action against employers alleging violation of Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act (WARN) in connection with plant closing. The District Court, Robert B. Collings, United States Magistrate Judge, held that: (1) employer's layoff of 30 employees on one date and 24 additional employees within 90 days of first layoff was a mass layoff under WARN Act; (2) two corporations and a holding company were a single employer for purposes of WARN Act; and (3) District Court would not exercise its discretion to reduce amount of liability and penalty to be assessed against employers for failure to give notice of mass layoffs as required by WARN Act. Judgment in favor of plaintiffs.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Williams v. Wilson
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Texas, San Antonio Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, in determining whether corporate veil is to be disregarded, for an entity to be the alter ego of another, at least one of the entities must own stock in the other.
Document Preview: Purported third-party beneficiary sued magazine publisher, its affiliate, and others for breach of agreement to open and operate nightclubs.  Publisher and affiliate moved to dismiss beneficiary's petition and to dismiss cross-petitions.  Beneficiary and two defendants filed motions to remand.  The District Court, Orlando L. Garcia, J., held that: (1) publisher was not subject to specific or general jurisdiction; (2) affiliate was not subject to specific jurisdiction; and (3) remand of remaining state law claims was warranted. Motions to dismiss granted; motions to remand granted in part and denied in part. Affirmed, 95 F.3d 1149.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Americas Ins. Co. v. Engicon, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Galveston Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, alter ego doctrine is not employed to pierce corporate veil unless one of alter ego corporations owns stock in other corporations.
Document Preview: Liability insurer brought suit against its insured, corporation which insured allegedly indemnified, and others, seeking determination of its duty to defend and indemnify in underlying personal injury suit. On motions to dismiss for lack of jurisdiction and to transfer, the District Court, Kent, J., held that: (1) neither specific nor general personal jurisdiction existed over parent corporation of defendant subsidiary; (2) alter ego doctrine did not provide jurisdiction over parent corporation; and (3) transfer from Galveston Division to Houston Division of Southern District of Texas was appropriate in interests of justice and for convenience of parties and witnesses. Motions granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Leykis v. NYP Holdings, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Courts weigh several factors to determine whether person or entity is alter ego of corporation, including: absence of formalities; inadequate capitalization; whether funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal purposes; overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; common office space, address and telephone numbers; amount of business discretion displayed; whether related corporations deal with dominated corporation at arms length; whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers; payment or guarantee of debts of dominated corporation by other corporations and groups; and whether corporation in question had property that was used by other of corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: Former employees sued former employer and its owner for age discrimination under the Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA) and the New York State Human Rights Law (HRL).  On owner's motion to dismiss, and former employees' motion for leave to amend to cure any pleading deficiency, the District Court, Johnson, J., affirmed and adopted the report and recommendation of Azrack, United States Magistrate Judge, and held that: (1) owner could not be individually liable under the ADEA; (2) individuals may be named as defendants in ADEA actions in their representative or official capacities for purposes of respondeat superior liability; (3) former employees failed to sufficiently allege alter ego theory; and (4) former employees failed to allege any facts that would give rise to individual liability of owner under HRL; but (5) former employees were entitled to amend complaint to allege representative liability under ADEA and individual...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Keys Jeep Eagle, Inc. v. Chrysler Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil under Florida law, plaintiff must show that one corporation is "mere instrumentality" of the other, and that corporation is device or sham to mislead creditors or exists for fraudulent purposes.
Document Preview: Automobile dealership, its owner, and others brought action against automobile manufacturer and creditor that provided floor plan financing for dealership, alleging fraud, breach of fiduciary duty, violation of Automobile Dealer's Day in Court Act (ADDCA), and breach of contract.  Manufacturer and creditor filed motions for summary judgment.  The District Court, James Lawrence King, J., held that: (1) manufacturer could not be held liable for creditor's alleged wrongful acts under alter ego or agency theories; (2) Florida's economic loss doctrine precluded recovery against creditor under fraud and breach of fiduciary duty theories; (3) plaintiffs failed to establish that creditor breached contract; (4) plaintiffs did not establish that creditor was manufacturer's actual or apparent agent, and, thus, creditor could not be held liable under ADDCA, which provides cause of action against manufacturer for violation of duty of good faith. Motions...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: McCabe v. Henpil, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Texas, Beaumont Division.
Headnote: Alter ego is one basis for disregarding corporate fiction under Texas law, where corporation is organized and operated as mere tool or business conduit of another corporation.
Document Preview: Employee brought state court action against employer and employer's subsidiary, alleging tort claims related to employee's work-related accident. Suit was removed to federal court.  On plaintiff's motion to remand, the District Court, Schell, Chief Judge, held that: (1) negligence and strict liability claims were not subject to Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) preemption; (2) intentional infliction of emotional distress and mental anguish claim related to employer's occupational injury and disease benefits plan; (3) defendants did not establish that benefit plan fell outside of workers' compensation exception to ERISA preemption; but (4) subsidiary was fraudulently joined to destroy diversity, and diversity jurisdiction existed. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Communist Party v. 522 Valencia, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, First District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Under "alter ego" doctrine, where corporation is used by individual or individuals, or by another corporation, to perpetrate fraud, circumvent statute, or accomplish some other wrongful or inequitable purpose, court may disregard corporate entity and treat corporation's acts as if they were done by persons actually controlling the corporation.
Document Preview: Constructive Trust. Community Party was not entitled to constructive trust over assets of public benefit corporations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Communist Party v. 522 Valencia, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, First District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: To apply alter ego doctrine, there must be such unity of interest and ownership between corporation and individual or organization controlling it that their separate personalities no longer exist, and failure to disregard corporate entity would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Constructive Trust. Community Party was not entitled to constructive trust over assets of public benefit corporations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Dean Operations, Inc. v. One Seventy Associates
Court: Supreme Court of Kansas.
Headnote: Fiction of separate corporate identities of two corporations will not be extended to permit one of the corporations to evade its just obligations; to promote fraud, illegality or injustice; or to defend crime.
Document Preview: Parent corporation, which had purchased loan to partnership in which its subsidiary was managing partner, brought action to foreclose on loan. The Wyandotte District Court, Philip L. Sieve, J., granted partial summary judgment for other partner, finding that managing partner was alter ego of its parent.  The Court of Appeals granted parent's application for interlocutory appeal, and the Supreme Court granted parent's motion to transfer.  The Supreme Court, Lockett, J., held that parent was alter ego of subsidiary. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Gregg County Appraisal Dist. v. Laidlaw Waste Systems, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Tyler.
Headnote: Separate entity of corporations will be observed by courts even in instances where one may dominate or control the other or even treat it as mere department, instrumentality, or agency.
Document Preview: TAXES - Real Property. Evidence supported jury's determination that value of property was $587,220, rather than appraised value of $9,455,810.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Centeq Realty, Inc. v. Siegler
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: Supreme Court will disregard the corporate fiction under the alter ego theory when the corporation is organized and operated as mere tool or business conduit of another corporation.
Document Preview: TORTS - Premises Liability. Company had no legal duty to protect condominium resident from criminal acts of third party.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Coala, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Alabama, Northern Division.
Headnote: Under Alabama law, for separate corporate existence to be disregarded under "instrumentality" rule, control by stockholders must amount to total domination of subservient corporation, to extent that subservient corporation manifests no separate corporate interest of its own and functions solely to achieve purposes of dominant corporation.
Document Preview: Corporations. Chapter 7 debtor's employees failed to establish that debtor's shareholders were alter egos of corporations that leased equipment to debtor so as to subject equipment to debtor's creditors' claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Muroll Gesellschaft M.B.H. v. Tennessee Tape, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee, Middle Section, at Nashville.
Headnote: If separate corporations are designed or used as a means of defrauding creditors, their acts should be carefully scrutinized in determining whether corporate veil should be pierced.
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Fraudulent transaction between corporations owned by one shareholder justified piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Muroll Gesellschaft M.B.H. v. Tennessee Tape, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee, Middle Section, at Nashville.
Headnote: By suitable evidence, it may be established that separate corporations should be treated as a single entity.
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Fraudulent transaction between corporations owned by one shareholder justified piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Muroll Gesellschaft M.B.H. v. Tennessee Tape, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee, Middle Section, at Nashville.
Headnote: Where two corporations are both insolvent, it is often necessary to preserve their separate entities to do justice to their respective creditors.
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Fraudulent transaction between corporations owned by one shareholder justified piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Watkins v. Black & Decker (U.S.), Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Galveston Division.
Headnote: Alter ego exists, and corporate shell may be pierced under Texas law, where corporation is operated and organized as mere tool or business conduit of another corporation; making alter ego determination, court may look at total dealings of corporation, such as amount of financial interest, ownership, and control parent has over subsidiary.
Document Preview: Following accidental gun discharge, product liability action based on strict liability in negligence was brought against numerous corporations that were related as result of mergers.  Defendants moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Kent, J., held that: (1) sale of corporate division that manufactured guns did not absolve selling corporation from liability, and (2) genuine issue existed as to whether successor corporation could be held accountable for tort liability incurred by its fully owned subsidiary. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Pine Tree Associates v. Doctors' Associates, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Legal fiction of distinct corporate entity may be disregarded when corporation is so organized and controlled as to make it mere instrumentality or adjunct of another corporation.
Document Preview: Piercing Veil. Allegation of fraud not required in contract suit for piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Pine Tree Associates v. Doctors' Associates, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: If one corporation is wholly controlled by another, fact that controlling corporation is separate entity does not relieve it from liability; in that situation, controlled corporation is considered to be alter ego or business conduit of controlling corporation.
Document Preview: Piercing Veil. Allegation of fraud not required in contract suit for piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Markham v. Fay
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, piercing corporate veil may be warranted when there is active and direct participation by representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of intercorporate relationship, or when there is confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in common enterprise with substantial disregard of separate nature of corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about manner and capacity in which various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: Trustee in bankruptcy filed interpleader action with regard to proceeds from sale of nursing homes held in name of debtor and mortgaged by corporation and trusts, after United States asserted interest in proceeds as holder of judgment based upon responsible person liability against president of corporation and settlor of trusts for nursing homes' unpaid withholding taxes. Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Markham v. Fay
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, 12 factors which should be considered in deciding whether to penetrate corporate form are: common ownership; pervasive control; confused intermingling of business assets, or management; thin capitalization; nonobservance of corporate formalities; absence of corporate records; no payment of dividends; insolvency at time of litigated transaction; siphoning away of corporate assets by dominant shareholder; nonfunctioning of officers and directors; use of corporation for transactions of dominant shareholder; and use of corporation in promoting fraud.
Document Preview: Trustee in bankruptcy filed interpleader action with regard to proceeds from sale of nursing homes held in name of debtor and mortgaged by corporation and trusts, after United States asserted interest in proceeds as holder of judgment based upon responsible person liability against president of corporation and settlor of trusts for nursing homes' unpaid withholding taxes. Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Doney v. TRW, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Sixth District, California.
Headnote: Critical question in determining whether one corporation is alter ego of another is whether in particular case presented and for purposes of such case justice and equity can best be accomplished and fraud and unfairness defeated by disregard of distinct entity of corporate form.
Document Preview: Wrongful Death. Parent corporation was not liable for murders of subsidiary's employees, where subsidiary had secured payment of workers' compensation benefits.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Valley Mechanical Contractors, Inc. v. Gonzales
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi-Edinburg.
Headnote: Corporate fiction may be disregarded when fiction is used as means of perpetrating fraud, when corporation is organized and operated as mere tool or business conduit of another corporation, when corporate fiction is resorted to as means of evading existing legal obligation, when it is employed to achieve or perpetrate monopoly, when it is used to circumvent statute, and when it is relied upon as protection of crime or to justify wrong.
Document Preview: Veil Piercing. Corporation was mere alter ego of judgment debtor, whose bank accounts could be garnished.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Becherer v. Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Florida law, corporate veil may not be pierced unless it is shown not only that one business entity dominated or was alter ego of other, but that relationship was created or used in order to mislead or defraud creditors.
Document Preview: Investors brought action against brokers and others for securities violations and other claims, arising from investments made in hotel project.  After judgment was entered, 799 F.Supp. 755, some investors commenced state court litigation against brokers.  On motion for injunction and other motions, the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan, John Feikens, J., entered judgment disposing of claims, 809 F.Supp. 1259, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Kennedy, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) investors were not entitled to damages arising from early closing of transaction; (2) developer breached contract by leasing equipment for hotel which it was required to furnish; (3) trial court erred by piercing corporate veil, so as to allow recovery against officers and affiliated companies of developer; (4) remand would be required to determine whether developer had violated Land Sales Act prohibition against...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Pajaro Dunes Rental Agency, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: For corporate veil to be pierced under California law, there must be such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of the two corporations no longer exist and that, if acts are treated as those of subservient corporation alone, inequity will result.
Document Preview: FRAUDULENT TRANSFERS. chapter 11 debtor did not receive reasonably equivalent value for its obligation to lender on note, through disbursement of loan proceeds to its corporate parent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Pajaro Dunes Rental Agency, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, finding that corporations are alter egos of each other should be made only when adherence to fiction of separate existence of corporations would, under the particular circumstances, sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: FRAUDULENT TRANSFERS. chapter 11 debtor did not receive reasonably equivalent value for its obligation to lender on note, through disbursement of loan proceeds to its corporate parent.
