Title: Edward D. Gevers Heating & Air Conditioning Co. v. R. Webbe Corp.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division One.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, corporation must be controlled and influenced by persons or another corporation, evidence must establish that corporate cloak was used as subterfuge to defeat public convenience, to justify wrong, or to perpetrate fraud, and wrong must be proximate cause of injury to third persons who dealt with corporation.
Document Preview: Piercing Corporate Veil. Petition seeking to have sole officers, directors and shareholders of corporation held liable for debts of corporation sufficiently pleaded alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Desjardins v. Van Buren Community Hosp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Under Maine law, courts pierce corporate veil only if corporate form is used fraudulently or illegally, as where separate treatment of corporate entities would justify a wrong or defeat legislative policy or statutory aims.
Document Preview: Discharged employee who had previously obtained judgment against hospital sought to hold hospital district liable thereon, on theory that hospital district was judicially estopped from claiming that it was separate entity from hospital or that sufficient basis existed for piercing corporate veil in order to hold hospital district liable for hospital's debt.  The United States District Court for the District of Maine, Morton A. Brody, J., denied employee's request to hold hospital district legally responsible for hospital's debt, and employee appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Boudin, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) hospital district was not judicially estopped from claiming that it was separate entity from hospital, and (2) mere fact that trustees of hospital district automatically became directors of hospital, and that hospital district owned property and equipment used by hospital, did not provide sufficient basis for piercing corporate veil to hold hospital...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Crum & Forster, Inc. v. Monsanto Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Court may consider common employees, common offices, centralized accounting, payment by one corporation of wages of other corporation's employees, common business name, and services rendered by employees of one corporation on behalf of other corporation in determining whether corporations have been maintained as separate entities, for purpose of piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: Liability. Liability insurers wrongfully obtained financial interest in, and direct control of, tort action against insured chemical company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Crum & Forster, Inc. v. Monsanto Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce corporate veil, court should look beyond corporate forms to realities of relationship between corporations in order to determine whether their affairs are so commingled as to constitute one integrated business enterprise.
Document Preview: Liability. Liability insurers wrongfully obtained financial interest in, and direct control of, tort action against insured chemical company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Thompson v. Air Power, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Virginia.
Headnote: Nexus sufficient to provide equitable reason for disregarding separate corporate existences is generally established by showing control, interaction, or other similar involvement between corporations or their agents.
Document Preview: Subcontractor sued general contractor and property owner seeking to enforce mechanics' lien for labor and materials used in construction of sanitary facility for subdivision.  The Circuit Court, Prince William County, Richard B. Potter, J., found that beneficiary of land trust was necessary party, that subcontractor failed to join beneficiary within requisite time period, and that suit was thus barred by statute of limitations. Subcontractor appealed.  The Supreme Court, 244 Va. 534, 422 S.E.2d 768, reversed and remanded on the ground that the beneficiary of the land trust was not a necessary party.  On remand, the Circuit Court consolidated for subcontractors' suits, reinstated subcontractor's mechanics' lien and ruled that all four subcontractors' liens were valid and enforceable against property.  Property owner appealed.  The Supreme Court, Lacy, J., held that: (1) court had authority to reinstate previously released mechanics'...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Select Creations, Inc. v. Paliafito America, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: Circumstances which may be considered when deciding whether alter ego liability exists under California law include: identical equitable ownership in two entities; identification of equitable owners with dominion and control of two entities; use of same office of business location; employment of same employees and attorneys; use of corporation as mere shell, instrumentality, or conduit for single venture or business of individual or another corporation; concealment and misrepresentation of identity of responsible ownership, management, and financial interest; failure to maintain arms-length relationships among related entities; use of corporate entity to procure labor, services, or merchandise for another person or entity; and use of corporation as subterfuge for illegal transactions.
Document Preview: Following evidentiary hearing in proceedings to collect judgment entered based upon violation of Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO) by toy industry, the District Court, Warren, J., held that, inter alia: (1) transferees of interests of judgment debtors were joined as parties, and (2) federal receiver was empowered to collect assets anywhere in United States. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Indiana Waste Systems of Indiana, Inc. v. Indiana Dept. of State Revenue
Court: Tax Court of Indiana.
Headnote: Close corporate relationships, standing alone, do not break down walls of separate corporate identity. West's A.I.C. 6-2.5-5-3.
Document Preview: Exemption. Genuine issue of material fact precluded summary judgment in garbage hauling company's action seeking sales and use tax exemption.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Hystro Products, Inc. v. MNP Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: In Illinois, corporation's veil of limited liability may be pierced only if two requirements are met: (1) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual [or other corporation]no longer exist and (2) circumstances must be such that adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Seller brought action against corporate parent, seeking to hold parent responsible for payment for goods received by parent's subsidiary.  The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin, J.P. Stadtmueller, J., entered judgment in favor of seller, and parent appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Cudahy, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) under Illinois law, parent's veil of limited liability would be pierced, and (2) seller was not precluded from piercing corporate veil on grounds of waiver or estoppel. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Hystro Products, Inc. v. MNP Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Stock control and existence of common officers and directors are generally prerequisites to piercing of the corporate veil under Illinois law, although these factors alone will not suffice.
Document Preview: Seller brought action against corporate parent, seeking to hold parent responsible for payment for goods received by parent's subsidiary.  The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin, J.P. Stadtmueller, J., entered judgment in favor of seller, and parent appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Cudahy, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) under Illinois law, parent's veil of limited liability would be pierced, and (2) seller was not precluded from piercing corporate veil on grounds of waiver or estoppel. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Hystro Products, Inc. v. MNP Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: To determine whether there is sufficient unity of interest and ownership between two corporations so as to warrant piercing the corporate veil, Illinois focuses on four factors: (1) failure to maintain adequate corporate record or to comply with corporate formalities; (2) commingling of funds or assets; (3) undercapitalization; and (4) corporation's treating assets of another as its own.
Document Preview: Seller brought action against corporate parent, seeking to hold parent responsible for payment for goods received by parent's subsidiary.  The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin, J.P. Stadtmueller, J., entered judgment in favor of seller, and parent appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Cudahy, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) under Illinois law, parent's veil of limited liability would be pierced, and (2) seller was not precluded from piercing corporate veil on grounds of waiver or estoppel. Affirmed.

Title: Farley, Inc. v. Chiappetta
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining degree of control one entity holds over another for veil-piercing purposes include evidence of misrepresentation; commingling of funds, assets or identities; undercapitalization; failure to operate at arm's length; and failure to comply with corporate formalities.
Document Preview: CORPORATIONS. vice president of corporation owned by Chapter 11 debtor's principal was entitled to seek stock from debtor based on employment agreement between vice president and corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Jiffy Lube Intern., Inc. v. Jiffy Lube of Pennsylvania, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, party seeking to pierce the corporate veil on alter-ego theory must establish that controlling corporation wholly ignored separate status of controlled corporation and so dominated and controlled its affairs that its separate existence was mere sham, or that controlled corporation acted robot-like or puppet-like in mechanical response to controller's tugs on its strings or pressure on its buttons.
Document Preview: Automobile lubricating service center franchisor brought action against franchisee, alleging trademark infringement and unfair competition. Franchisee counterclaimed and brought third-party action against second franchisee and motor oil company, alleging, inter alia, fraudulent inducement to enter into franchisor-franchisee relationship, intentional interference with contractual relationship, conspiracy, and racketeering.  Plaintiffs and third-party defendants moved for summary judgment on counterclaim and third-party complaint.  The District Court, Van Antwerpen, J., held that: (1) under Maryland law, franchisee's release of franchisor in asset transfer agreement covered all of franchisee's claims against franchisor and second franchisee; (2) under Pennsylvania law, franchisee failed to show that company was liable for actions of franchisor on alter-ego theory on franchisee's claims for breach of contract, fraud, misrepresentation, and breach of...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Berger v. H.P. Hood, Inc.
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Middlesex.
Headnote: Corporations are to be regarded as separate entities absent compelling equitable reason to look beyond corporate form for purpose of fraud or wrong, or for remedying of injuries.

Title: In re Nahas
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Pennsylvania law permits corporate veil to be pierced once it is established that dominant shareholder or controlling corporation wholly ignored separate status of controlled corporation and so dominated and controlled its affairs that its separate existence was mere sham.

Title: Innkeepers' Telemanagement and Equipment Corp. v. Hummert Management Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, before separate corporate identity of one corporation will be disregarded in order to treat it as the alter ego of another, it must first be shown that corporation is so controlled and its affairs so conducted that it is a mere instrumentality of the other corporation, and it must further appear that observance of fiction of separate existence would, under the circumstances, sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Telecommunications services company brought suit against hotels and hotel management companies for their alleged breach of contract.  The District Court, Aspen, J., held that telecommunications company was collaterally estopped from denying that it had breached its contracts with hotels based on judgment previously entered against it by bankruptcy court at trial of bankrupt hotel's objection to company's claim. Partial summary judgment for defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Oregon RSA No. 6, Inc. v. Castle Rock Cellular of Oregon Ltd. Partnership
Court: United States District Court, D. Oregon.
Headnote: When one corporation is so organized and controlled and its affairs are so conducted as to make it mere instrumentality, conduit, or adjunct of another corporation, court may disregard fiction of distinct corporate existence in order to prevent fraud or injustice under Oregon law.
Document Preview: Limited partner brought action against another limited partner being sold, its parent corporations, and buyer to establish right of first refusal to purchase limited partner's interest.  Plaintiff moved for summary judgment. The District Court, Panner, J., held that: (1) sale of limited partner without offering right of first refusal to plaintiff violated covenant of good faith and fair dealing implied in limited partnership agreement, and (2) limited partner and its parent corporations could be treated as single entity so that parent corporation was subject to plaintiff's right to first refusal. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Ledford For and On Behalf of N.L.R.B. v. Mining Specialists, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. West Virginia.
Headnote: In general, alter ego doctrine operates to treat two nominally separate business entities as if they were a single continuous employer.
Document Preview: Regional Director of the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) filed a petition for temporary injunctive relief pending final disposition of unfair labor practice complaint brought against two mining companies.  The District Court, Copenhaver, J., held that there was a reasonable possibility that NLRB would ultimately enter an enforceable order; however, injunctive relief would not have been just and proper and, thus, would not be granted. Petition denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Board of Directors of Chestnut Grove Condominium Unit Owners' Ass'n v. Resolution Trust Corp.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under Virginia law, corporation has equitable interest in assets of alter ego.
Document Preview: STANDING. individual creditor lacked standing to pursue debtor's alter ego claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: May v. Club Med Sales, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: In order to recover from corporation under Pennsylvania mere instrumentality theory, plaintiff must prove: that one corporation controlled another corporation to such degree that controlled corporation is mere instrumentality; that controlling corporation is perpetrating fraud or wrong through controlled corporation, e.g., torts, violation of statute, or stripping subsidiary of its assets; and unjust loss or injury to claimant, such as insolvency of controlled corporation.
Document Preview: Resort guest who was injured when she fell from a horse brought action against corporation that sold vacation packages. On corporation's motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Robert F. Kelly, J., held that under Pennsylvania law, resort's owner and operator was not mere instrumentality of corporation. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: May v. Club Med Sales, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: To hold that one corporation is mere instrumentality or alter ego of another corporation, Pennsylvania law requires that plaintiff establish controlling corporation wholly ignored separate status of controlled corporation and so dominated affairs of controlled corporation that its separate existence was a sham.
Document Preview: Resort guest who was injured when she fell from a horse brought action against corporation that sold vacation packages. On corporation's motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Robert F. Kelly, J., held that under Pennsylvania law, resort's owner and operator was not mere instrumentality of corporation. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Application of CN Carriers, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Nebraska.
Headnote: Under instrumentality, or alter ego, doctrine, when corporation is so dominated by another corporation that subservient corporation becomes mere instrument and is indistinct from controlling corporation, corporate veil of dominated corporation will be disregarded if it will resolve an injustice to retain corporate veil.
Document Preview: Protestors appealed from order of Public Service Commission (PSC) which affirmed PSC's previous order granting application of wholly owned subsidiary of transportation cooperative to transfer common carrier operating rights of third party to wholly owned subsidiary.  The Court of Appeals, Wright, J., held that PSC acted arbitrarily and capriciously in granting application to transfer common carrier authority to wholly owned subsidiary of transportation cooperative that could not hold authority directly where wholly owned subsidiary was not truly separate and distinct from parent. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Hollingshead v. Burford Equipment Co.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Alabama, Northern Division.
Headnote: In order to prove that business organization is alter ego, plaintiffs must show that one organization completely controlled and dominated other in relation to transaction attacked.
Document Preview: Former employees brought action against employer and its parent corporation under Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA).  After determining that employer was liable under ERISA, the District Court, Ira DeMent, J., held that: (1) parent corporation exercised sufficient control over subsidiary and sufficiently misused that control to be held liable for subsidiary's ERISA obligation, and (2) individual shareholder who owned all voting shares of parent corporation sufficiently dominated parent's finances, policies and business practices to be held liable for subsidiary's ERISA obligations. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Laborers' Pension Trust Fund Detroit and Vicinity v. Lange
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: In determining if one company is alter ego of another company, question is whether two enterprises have substantially identical management, business, purpose, operation, equipment, customers, supervision, and ownership.
Document Preview: Unions brought action under Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) to enforce arbitration award granted under collective bargaining agreement. Cross motions for summary judgment were made.  The District Court, Gadola, J., held that: (1) owner of corporate employer was collaterally estopped from denying personal liability; (2) separately formed corporation was alter ego of corporate employer; and (3) unions were entitled to attorney fees and costs incurred in ERISA enforcement action. Arbitration award enforced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: O'Hazza v. Executive Credit Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Virginia.
Headnote: Initial undercapitalization of corporation may be indicator of whether corporation was created or operated as sham or as alter ego for another corporation or person.
Document Preview: Veil of corporation which installed sound equipment was pierced and personal liability for debts of corporation imposed upon shareholders by the Circuit Court, Fairfax County, Johanna L. Fitzpatrick, J. Shareholders appealed.  The Supreme Court, Lacy, J., held that: (1) fact that $10,000 was contributed in initial capital did not establish that corporation was undercapitalized; (2) subsequent loans by shareholders to corporation were not grounds for piercing corporate veil; (3) the fact that shareholders organized business to employ their son and received personal tax advantages was not basis for piercing corporate veil; and (4) shareholders did not breach fiduciary duties. Reversed and final judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Villar v. Crowley Maritime Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, there was no basis on which to disregard corporate fiction with respect to foreign corporation, incorporated in Saudi Arabia, which was owned, in part through another foreign company, by Delaware corporation licensed to do business in Texas, so that Delaware corporation's contacts with Texas could not be attributed foreign corporation or other company for purposes of establishing personal jurisdiction over them; Delaware corporation owned, indirectly, only 20% of foreign corporation, did not dominate either other company or foreign corporation, and was connected with only two of foreign corporation's eight directors, foreign corporation's other shareholders had veto power over its activities, foreign corporation had separate existence from shareholders and maintained corporate formalities, and there was no evidence of fraud, illegality, or injustice.
Document Preview: Survivors of seaman, who was Philippine citizen and who died while serving on ship of Panamanian registry in Saudi Arabia, brought wrongful death action in state court against Saudi Arabian employer, foreign corporation which owned 60% interest in employer, and domestic corporation which owned one-third interest in foreign corporation.  Corporations removed action to federal court.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas, Samuel B. Kent, J., 780 F.Supp. 1467, dismissed action, and survivors appealed.  The Court of Appeals, E. Grady Jolly, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) District Court could consider foreign corporations' motions to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction before survivors' remand motion; (2) foreign corporations were not alter egos of domestic corporation; (3) district court could dismiss action against domestic corporation on forum non conveniens grounds; (4) District Court could prohibit...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Kaeser & Blair, Inc. v. Willens
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, in determining whether corporation is so controlled by another to justify disregarding their separate entities, Illinois courts focus on four factors: failure to maintain adequate corporate formalities; commingling of funds or assets; undercapitalization; and one corporation treating assets of another corporation as its own; once unity of interest and ownership are established, plaintiff must show that circumstances are such that adhering to corporate fiction would constitute either sanctioning of fraud, i.e., intentional wrongdoing, or promotion of injustice, i.e., some wrong beyond inability to collect upon debt.
Document Preview: Corporation which purchased list of commissioned, independent sales agents from two other corporations that were subsequently dissolved sued son of owners of former corporations and his newly established corporation alleging breach of fiduciary duty and breach of contract as result of son's use of names on list to generate business for his new corporation.  Son and his corporation moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Aspen, J., held that: (1) genuine issue of material fact as to whether son usurped protected property interest from purchaser of list precluded summary judgment in favor of son on Illinois law breach of fiduciary duty claim; (2) genuine issue of material fact as to whether son's new corporation was continuation of dissolved corporations under different corporate name precluded summary judgment in favor of corporation on Illinois law breach of contract claim; and (3) court would defer ruling on issue of whether unity of...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Hess v. L.G. Balfour Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil, under Connecticut law using "identity test" plaintiff must demonstrate that there was such unity of interest and ownership that independence of corporations had in effect ceased or had never begun.
Document Preview: Former employee brought suit against employer and its parent corporation alleging breach of contract, failure to pay wages, unlawful deductions from wages, conversion, and constructive discharge.  Parent corporation moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Eginton, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) employee failed to demonstrate control or malice by parent required under Connecticut law to pierce corporate veil under instrumentality test; (2) employee failed to show that parent and subsidiary had same identity as required by Connecticut law to pierce corporate veil under identity test; and (3) parent did not dominate or interfere with subsidiary as needed under Connecticut law to impose liability on parent based on agency's principles. Granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Ciprotti v. United Inns, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Fact that corporations share corporate officers and mailing address is insufficient basis for piercing corporate veil or for finding that one corporation is a shell.
Document Preview: Service of Process. Corporate defendant was not effectively served.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Airflow Houston, Inc. v. Theriot
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: In determining whether to ignore separate existence of corporations, court must decide whether corporations have been maintained as separate entities, and in doing so, court may consider whether: entities shared employees, offices, or business name; one entity has paid wages of other's employees; one entity's employees have rendered services on behalf of other entity; there have been undocumented transfers of funds or unclear allocations of profits and losses between entities; and entities have had centralized accounting.
Document Preview: Separate Existence. Newly formed corporation was liable for liquidated corporations' debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: F.C. Imports, Inc. v. First Nat. Bank of Boston, N.A.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Under "instrumentality doctrine," corporation or bank may be held liable for debts of another corporation when it misuses that corporation by treating it as mere business conduit for purposes of dominant corporation or bank.
Document Preview: Wholesale supplier of appliances and owners of wholesale supplier brought action against bank seeking to hold bank liable for debts owed by retail seller to supplier for appliances supplier sold on credit to seller.  Bank brought motion for summary judgment.  The District Court, Pieras, J., held that: (1) bank could not be held liable to supplier for fraud, and (2) bank could not be held liable on theory that it had control over seller. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: F.C. Imports, Inc. v. First Nat. Bank of Boston, N.A.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: To be held liable under the "instrumentality doctrine," dominant corporation must have controlled subservient corporation and dominant corporation must have proximately caused plaintiffs' harm through misuse of its control.
Document Preview: Wholesale supplier of appliances and owners of wholesale supplier brought action against bank seeking to hold bank liable for debts owed by retail seller to supplier for appliances supplier sold on credit to seller.  Bank brought motion for summary judgment.  The District Court, Pieras, J., held that: (1) bank could not be held liable to supplier for fraud, and (2) bank could not be held liable on theory that it had control over seller. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: F.C. Imports, Inc. v. First Nat. Bank of Boston, N.A.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Creditor-debtor relationship does not per se constitute control under instrumentality doctrine.
Document Preview: Wholesale supplier of appliances and owners of wholesale supplier brought action against bank seeking to hold bank liable for debts owed by retail seller to supplier for appliances supplier sold on credit to seller.  Bank brought motion for summary judgment.  The District Court, Pieras, J., held that: (1) bank could not be held liable to supplier for fraud, and (2) bank could not be held liable on theory that it had control over seller. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: F.C. Imports, Inc. v. First Nat. Bank of Boston, N.A.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: For creditor corporation to be liable under instrumentality doctrine, strong showing is required that creditor assumed actual, participatory, total control of debtor; merely taking active part in management of debtor corporation does not automatically constitute control.
Document Preview: Wholesale supplier of appliances and owners of wholesale supplier brought action against bank seeking to hold bank liable for debts owed by retail seller to supplier for appliances supplier sold on credit to seller.  Bank brought motion for summary judgment.  The District Court, Pieras, J., held that: (1) bank could not be held liable to supplier for fraud, and (2) bank could not be held liable on theory that it had control over seller. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: F.C. Imports, Inc. v. First Nat. Bank of Boston, N.A.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Evidence that creditor's agent negotiates and consummates settlements of disputed claims or designates order in which debtor's creditors are to be paid is not evidence of control that is necessary to become liable for debtor's liabilities.
Document Preview: Wholesale supplier of appliances and owners of wholesale supplier brought action against bank seeking to hold bank liable for debts owed by retail seller to supplier for appliances supplier sold on credit to seller.  Bank brought motion for summary judgment.  The District Court, Pieras, J., held that: (1) bank could not be held liable to supplier for fraud, and (2) bank could not be held liable on theory that it had control over seller. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Hillsborough Holdings Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division.
Headnote: Corporate veil may be pierced under Florida law only when it is apparent that corporation was mere device, sham, or alter ego of another corporation or individual who owns controlling share of corporation in question.
Document Preview: DISCOVERY. additional discovery on issue of whether corporate veil could be pierced so as to hold parent of corporation liable to asbestos claimants was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: American Home Assur. Co. v. Sport Maska, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil is permitted only where there is confused intermingling between corporate entities or one corporation actively and directly participates in activities of second corporation, apparently exercising pervasive control; if there is evidence of fraud and injurious consequences from such an intercorporate relationship, court may disregard separate corporate entities.
Document Preview: Commercial liability insurer brought declaratory judgment action for determination of its obligations under policy issued to insureds in underlying products liability action.  Insureds moved to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction.  The District Court, Keeton, J., held that: (1) insureds were covered under Massachusetts long-arm statute as person contracting to insure risk located within Commonwealth at time of contracting; (2) grounds for establishing personal jurisdiction over insureds under Massachusetts long-arm statute were sufficient to meet the constitution's minimum contacts requirements; and (3) exercise of personal jurisdiction over insureds based on foreseeability that they would be required to assist and cooperate in defense comported with fair play and substantial justice. Denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Houston Cable TV, Inc. v. Inwood West Civic Ass'n, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Finding that cable television companies were alter egos of each other and judgment against one would be judgment against all made it unnecessary to enter judgment against individual entities in action brought by homeowners' associations seeking breach of contract damages and punitive damages.
Document Preview: CABLE TELEVISION - Right of Way. Evidence established that cable television companies breached right-of-way agreements with homeowners' associations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Detrick v. Midwest Pipe & Steel, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana, Third District.
Headnote: To prevent fraud or injustice, fiction of corporate entity may be disregarded where one corporation is so organized and controlled and its affairs are so conducted that it is mere instrumentality or conduit of another corporation.
Document Preview: Personal representative of estate of motorist who was killed in traffic collision with truck brought suit against truck driver, trucking firm and shipper.  The Circuit Court, Whitley County, Edward J. Meyers, J., entered summary judgment in favor of shipper.  Personal representative appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Staton, J., held that: (1) fact issues precluded summary judgment of issue of whether trucker was independent contractor or employee subject to shipper's control; (2) fact issues precluded summary judgment on issue of whether shipper was estopped from denying status as trucker's employer; (3) shipper could not be held vicariously liable as matter of law pursuant to ICC regulations for driver's negligence; (4) fact issue precluded summary judgment on claim that trucking firm existed as alter ego or mere instrumentality of shipper; and (5) shipper could not be held liable for negligence in failing to ascertain that...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Dave Kolb Grading, Inc. v. Lieberman Corp.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Two.
Headnote: To disregard existence of corporate entity, plaintiff must show complete dominion, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to transaction attacked so that corporate entity as to that transaction had at time no separate mind, will or existence; to pierce corporate veil, corporation must be controlled and influenced by persons or another corporation and corporate cloak must have been used as subterfuge to defeat public convenience, justify wrong or perpetrate fraud.
Document Preview: Contractors and subcontractors sought to recover from homeowners, trustees, and lending institution on liens in connection with subdivision construction project after contractor became insolvent.  The Circuit Court, St. Louis County, Robert L. Campbell, J., found for lien claimants, and appeal and cross appeal were taken.  The Court of Appeals, Crandall, J., held that: (1) profit and overhead could be included in the reasonable value of mechanics' liens; (2) lien claimants could be awarded prejudgment interest; and (3) subcontractors gave owners sufficient notice of mechanics' liens. Affirmed in part; remanded in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: N.L.R.B. v. O'Neill
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Court of Appeals considers four factors in determining whether entities are alter egos of one another: centralized control of labor operations, common management, interrelation of operations, and common ownership and financial control; no factor is controlling and all need not be present.
Document Preview: National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) petitioned for enforcement of two of its orders entered in connection with meat plant's closing, reopening and subsequent permanent closing. The Court of Appeals, D.W. Nelson, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) fraudulent concealment exception applied to toll running of limitations period applicable to unfair labor practice complaint until date unions received testimony of indicted company official that majority shareholder of original employer was heavily involved in new corporations operating plant and, thus, NLRB properly allowed reinstatement of previously dismissed charge; (2) NLRB's finding that corporations which took over operation of plant were alter egos of prior employer, so as to warrant treating them as single employer liable for unfair labor practices, was supported by evidence; and (3) piercing of corporate veil so as to hold majority shareholder liable for unfair labor practices was justified. Orders enforced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Superior Derrick Services, Inc. v. Anderson
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: In determining whether two corporations had been maintained as separate entities, court may consider common employees, common offices, centralized accounting, payment by one corporation of wages of other corporation's employees, common business name, services rendered by employees of one corporation on behalf of other corporation, undocumented transfers of funds between corporations, and unclear allocation of profits and losses between corporations.
Document Preview: Manufacturer brought action against buyers for balance due under purchase order to design and manufacture four masts for use in oil and gas industry.  The 295th District Court, Harris County, Frank O. White, J., entered judgment for manufacturer, and buyers appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Sears, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to support trial court's conclusion that masts were conforming goods; (2) evidence was sufficient to support trial court's finding that buyers accepted delivery of first mast at manufacturer's facility; (3) evidence did not support recovery under sworn account for fourth mast; (4) buyers operated as single business enterprise; and (5) trial court properly admitted videotape and photographs of masts during fabrication. Modified in part and affirmed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Swall v. Custom Automotive Services, Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: To satisfy two-pronged test for determining whether corporate veil should be pierced, first, corporation must be controlled and influenced by persons or by another corporation, and, second, evidence must establish that corporate cloak was used as subterfuge to defeat public convenience, to justify wrong, or to perpetrate fraud.
Document Preview: President and vice president of corporation were held personally liable for corporate debt to consignor in the Clay County Circuit Court, Frank D. Connett, Jr., J., and president and vice president appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Ulrich, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient for finding that president and vice president dominated and controlled corporation as required for piercing corporate veil, and (2) evidence supported findings that corporation was undercapitalized and that president and vice president stripped corporation's assets in reckless disregard of consignor's legal rights as required for piercing corporate veil. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: H.H. Robertson Co., Cupples Products Div. v. V.S. DiCarlo General Contractors, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Missouri law, two separate corporations are to be treated ordinarily as wholly distinct legal entities even where one corporation owns part or all of other corporation; however, when one corporation exercises complete dominion and control over another and such control has been used to accomplish fraud or injustice or some unlawful purpose, separate form of corporate structures will be disregarded and corporate veil may be pierced.
Document Preview: Judgment creditor filed motion for creditor's bill in equity to enforce judgment against corporations related to judgment debtor.  The District Court, Gunn, J., held that judgment creditor was entitled to pierce corporate veil and hold related corporations liable on judgment on basis that judgment was subterfuge and alter ego of related corporations. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: United Elec., Radio and Mach. Workers of America v. 163 Pleasant Street Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts "alter ego" doctrine, corporate disregard is allowed, even absent finding of fraud, if there is confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in common enterprise with substantial disregard of separate nature of corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about manner in which various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: Union sued employer and employer's foreign parent alleging that employer's planned cessation of health care payments after its closing would violate Massachusetts common law, Labor Management Relations Act (LMRA), and Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA).  The United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts, A. David Mazzone, J., ordered parent corporation to pay health care premiums, and parent corporation appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Selya, Circuit Judge, held that there was insufficient evidence to find that Scottish parent corporation purposefully availed itself of privilege of conducting activities in Massachusetts, and, thus, court lacked jurisdiction over Scottish parent of Delaware employer. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Century Hotels v. U.S.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: One of two ways for corporation to be held liable for debts of another entity is when it misuses corporation by treating it, and by using it, as a mere business conduit for purposes of controlling entity.
Document Preview: Debtor in possession, a corporation, instituted adversary proceeding as turnover action to regain funds seized by Internal Revenue Service (IRS) levy for payment of taxes of officer of corporation.  The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana, Morey L. Sear, J., found that the IRS was entitled to funds on theory of alter ego liability and that corporation's bankruptcy estate was not entitled to funds.  Debtor appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Brown, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) district court applied appropriate legal standard to alter ego issue; (2) reverse piercing of corporate veil issue has not been decided in Louisiana; (3) district court's finding that corporation was alter ego of taxpayer was not clearly erroneous; and (4) district court's failure to consider question of bankruptcy estate's interest in property to which IRS had alter ego rights or to make determination of kind, nature, and value of...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Sea-Land Services, Inc. v. Pepper Source
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, factors applied in determining whether corporation is so controlled by another to justify disregarding their separate entities and piercing corporate veil are failure to maintain adequate corporate records or to comply with corporate formalities, commingling of funds or assets, undercapitalization, and one corporation treating the assets of another corporation as its own.
Document Preview: Ocean carrier filed federal diversity action against owner of dissolved business and other corporations he owned, seeking money owed on shipment of goods.  The United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, Eastern Division, James F. Holderman, Jr., J., entered default judgment in carrier's favor.  On appeal, the Court of Appeals, Bauer, Chief Judge, held that: (1) unity of interest and ownership prong of test under Illinois law for piercing corporate veil was satisfied, but (2) remand was warranted for additional evidence and argument on issue of whether adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence would promote injustice beyond carrier's inability to satisfy judgment. Reversed and remanded with instructions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Torco Oil Co. v. Innovative Thermal Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, party seeking to pierce corporate veil must show first that there has been abuse of the corporate form such that one corporation has made a "mere instrumentality" of the other as evidenced by such conduct as failure to maintain adequate corporate records or to comply with corporate formalities, commingling of funds or assets, undercapitalization, and one corporation treating the assets of another corporation as its own and that adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Following jury verdict for buyer in suit for breach of contract to sell natural gas, seller and two other corporations controlled by one of seller's principals moved for judgment notwithstanding verdict or new trial. The District Court, Posner, Circuit Judge, sitting by designation, held that: (1) jury could find that seller breached contract, based on testimony of buyer's representative that seller's agent had no complaint about standby feature in letter of credit tendered to him, and (2) under Illinois law, evidence of intent to defraud justified piercing of seller's corporate veil to reach assets of other corporations. Motions denied; final judgment for plaintiff.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Coastal Shutters and Insulation, Inc. v. Derr
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: "Alter ego" applies when there is such unity or blurring of identity between two corporations or corporation and individual that separateness of single corporation has ceased and holding only corporation liable would cause injustice.
Document Preview: In suit against corporation and its president to collect on note and extensions thereof, the 56th District Court, Galveston County, H.G. Dalehite, J., rendered judgment in holder's favor.  On appeal, the Court of Appeals, Junell, J., held that: (1) corporation ratified original preincorporation note by signing and obligating itself in extensions and by accepting benefits of $25,000 loan evidenced by note and thus could be held liable on even though it did not sign original note; (2) corporate fiction could be disregarded and corporation's president held liable for corporate debt on theory of alter ego; and (3) holder's attorney fees were properly limited to ten percent of balance due on note, as stipulated therein. Affirmed. Murphy, J., concurred in part and dissented in part and filed opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: U.S. v. MPM Contractors, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Under Kansas law, circumstances justify disregard of corporate entity if separation of two entities has not been maintained and injustice would occur to third parties if separate entity were recognized; corporate entity can also be disregarded when it is used as cloak or cover for fraud or illegality, or if necessary to achieve equity.
Document Preview: United States sought preliminary injunction against asbestos removal companies and their principal to prohibit company and principal from disturbing status quo and moving any assets beyond jurisdiction of court pending action for violations of Clean Air Act.  The District Court, Earl E. O'Connor, Chief Judge, held that asbestos removal corporations and their principal would be enjoined from disturbing status quo or moving any assets beyond court's jurisdiction until final judgment was entered in action for civil penalties under Clean Air Act given substantial likelihood that Government would prevail on its successsor-in-liability claim and under alter ego doctrine. Injunction issued.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: U.S. v. MPM Contractors, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Under Kansas law, where relationship between two corporations is so intimate and assets of two are so mingled that recognition of their distinct entity would result in injustice, courts will look through legal fiction of separate entity and treat them as one corporation.
Document Preview: United States sought preliminary injunction against asbestos removal companies and their principal to prohibit company and principal from disturbing status quo and moving any assets beyond jurisdiction of court pending action for violations of Clean Air Act.  The District Court, Earl E. O'Connor, Chief Judge, held that asbestos removal corporations and their principal would be enjoined from disturbing status quo or moving any assets beyond court's jurisdiction until final judgment was entered in action for civil penalties under Clean Air Act given substantial likelihood that Government would prevail on its successsor-in-liability claim and under alter ego doctrine. Injunction issued.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: U.S. v. MPM Contractors, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Under Kansas law, following factors warrant consideration in determining whether two corporations should be treated as separate entities or same: undercapitalization of one-person corporation; failure to observe corporate formalities; nonpayment of dividends; siphoning of corporate funds by dominant stockholder; nonfunctioning of other officers or directors; absence of corporate records; use of corporation as facade for operations of dominant stockholder or stockholders; and use of corporate entity in promoting injustice or fraud.
Document Preview: United States sought preliminary injunction against asbestos removal companies and their principal to prohibit company and principal from disturbing status quo and moving any assets beyond jurisdiction of court pending action for violations of Clean Air Act.  The District Court, Earl E. O'Connor, Chief Judge, held that asbestos removal corporations and their principal would be enjoined from disturbing status quo or moving any assets beyond court's jurisdiction until final judgment was entered in action for civil penalties under Clean Air Act given substantial likelihood that Government would prevail on its successsor-in-liability claim and under alter ego doctrine. Injunction issued.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Green v. Champion Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Legal fiction of distinct corporate entity may be disregarded when corporation is so organized and controlled as to make it merely instrumentality or adjunct of another corporation.
Document Preview: Liquidation proceedings were commenced against an insolvent insurance company and, after appointment of a special liquidator ad hoc, the special liquidator sought an injunction to prevent transfer of assets of affiliated companies.  The Nineteenth Judicial District Court, Parish of East Baton Rouge, Joseph F. Keogh and Douglas Moreau, JJ., decided to treat the insurance company and related entities as a single business enterprise and ordered on accounting, issued a permanent injunction and granted declaratory relief.  Appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeal, Lottinger, J., held that: (1) once the Commissioner of Insurance voluntarily recused himself, the trial court had authority to select a liquidator; (2) the insurance company and related entities were a single business enterprise for liquidation purposes; and (3) the trial court was not required to stay the liquidation proceedings until completion of pending criminal charges...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Green v. Champion Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: If one corporation is merely alter ego or business conduit of another, courts may disregard separate corporate identities.

Title: Green v. Champion Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in deciding whether separate corporations are to be treated as single business entity are similar to factors used in deciding whether it is appropriate to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Logal v. Inland Steel Industries, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, First Division.
Headnote: Generally, before court will pierce corporate veil, it must be shown that one corporation so controls affairs of another that other is mere instrumentality or dummy of former and that, under the circumstances, observance of fiction of separate corporate existences would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Shareholder of parent corporation, employee of subsidiary corporation, sought to inspect corporate records concerning closing of plant.  The Circuit Court, Cook County, Albert Green, J., dismissed petition.  Shareholder appealed. The Appellate Court, Buckley, J., held that: (1) proposed examination was not for proper purpose, and (2) subsidiary was not alter ego of parent corporation. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: U.S. v. Fidelity Capital Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: Entry on corporate books was sufficient formality, under Georgia law, for intercorporate loan.
Document Preview: As receiver of firm designated a Small Business Investment Company (SBIC) under Small Business Investment Act, Small Business Administration (SBA) began nonjudicial proceedings to foreclose mortgage which company held on parcel of real estate by exercising power of sale contained in mortgage.  Mortgage company which claimed that it owned property moved for leave to intervene in receivership action and to declare investment company's mortgage, which had not been satisfied of record, null and void.  The United States District Court for the Northern District of Georgia, No. C862033A, granted mortgage company leave to intervene and declaratory relief it sought.  SBA appealed.  The Court of Appeals, 888 F.2d 1344, vacated and remanded with directions.  On remand, the District Court, Richard C. Freeman, J., made supplemental findings of fact.  The Court of Appeals, Tjoflat, Chief Judge, held that facts as found by district court were...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: U.S. v. Fidelity Capital Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, court may disregard corporate form if one corporation has bled or depleted assets of another for its own benefit.
Document Preview: As receiver of firm designated a Small Business Investment Company (SBIC) under Small Business Investment Act, Small Business Administration (SBA) began nonjudicial proceedings to foreclose mortgage which company held on parcel of real estate by exercising power of sale contained in mortgage.
