The Court of Appeals, Tjoflat, Chief Judge, held that facts as found by district court were...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Woodstock Associates I, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Factors to consider in determining whether to pierce corporate veil, under Illinois law, include whether corporations have maintained adequate corporate records and complied with corporate formalities, whether corporations have commingled funds or assets, whether one of the corporations was undercapitalized, and whether one corporation treated the other's assets as its own.
Document Preview: Debtor nursing home operators objected to creditor's claims. On cross motions for summary judgment, the Bankruptcy Court, John H. Squires, J., held that: (1) creditor did not have perfected security interest in debtors' medicaid reimbursements; (2) creditor's postpetition contributions were not entitled to administrative priority status; and (3) issue of material fact as to whether operators' Chapter 11 plan was proposed in good faith precluded summary judgment for creditor. Debtors' motion granted in part and denied in part; creditor's motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Twin City Shipyard, Inc. v. U.S.
Court: United States Claims Court.
Headnote: Separate and distinct corporate entities are not held liable for one another's obligations; however, where it is clear that formal corporate arrangements are mere sham and have no valid business purpose, but rather, are aimed at avoiding consequences of efficacious transaction, corporate fiction is disregarded.
Document Preview: Shipyard and its purported assignee sued for payment allegedly wrongfully withheld by United States under contract with Panama Canal Commission for construction and delivery of tugboat.  All parties moved for summary judgment.  United States moved to dismiss complaint as to purported assignee.  The Claims Court, Reginald W. Gibson, J., held that: (1) purported assignee lacked requisite privity of contract to sue United States under Tucker Act; (2) even assuming that purported assignee was in fact assignee of contract, assignee could only maintain action to recover funds wrongfully paid out to third party; and (3) genuine issue of material fact as to whether parent corporation was acting as mere instrumentality or alter ego of shipyard in agreeing to pay subcontractors prior to final payment from Government thereby justifying piercing of corporate veil and treating shipyard as promissor and obligor under agreement to pay subcontractors...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Twin City Shipyard, Inc. v. U.S.
Court: United States Claims Court.
Headnote: Court should hold one corporation liable for obligations of another only where: one corporation completely dominates the other; such domination is used to commit fraud or injustice, that is, to avoid obligation at issue; and such domination causes unjust loss.
Document Preview: Shipyard and its purported assignee sued for payment allegedly wrongfully withheld by United States under contract with Panama Canal Commission for construction and delivery of tugboat.  All parties moved for summary judgment.  United States moved to dismiss complaint as to purported assignee.  The Claims Court, Reginald W. Gibson, J., held that: (1) purported assignee lacked requisite privity of contract to sue United States under Tucker Act; (2) even assuming that purported assignee was in fact assignee of contract, assignee could only maintain action to recover funds wrongfully paid out to third party; and (3) genuine issue of material fact as to whether parent corporation was acting as mere instrumentality or alter ego of shipyard in agreeing to pay subcontractors prior to final payment from Government thereby justifying piercing of corporate veil and treating shipyard as promissor and obligor under agreement to pay subcontractors...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Twin City Shipyard, Inc. v. U.S.
Court: United States Claims Court.
Headnote: Court must take many factors into consideration in order to determine whether one corporation has dominated another to such extent that other has lost its independent existence justifying disregard of corporate fiction.
Document Preview: Shipyard and its purported assignee sued for payment allegedly wrongfully withheld by United States under contract with Panama Canal Commission for construction and delivery of tugboat.  All parties moved for summary judgment.  United States moved to dismiss complaint as to purported assignee.  The Claims Court, Reginald W. Gibson, J., held that: (1) purported assignee lacked requisite privity of contract to sue United States under Tucker Act; (2) even assuming that purported assignee was in fact assignee of contract, assignee could only maintain action to recover funds wrongfully paid out to third party; and (3) genuine issue of material fact as to whether parent corporation was acting as mere instrumentality or alter ego of shipyard in agreeing to pay subcontractors prior to final payment from Government thereby justifying piercing of corporate veil and treating shipyard as promissor and obligor under agreement to pay subcontractors...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Trailways, Inc. v. Clark
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi-Edinburg.
Headnote: Corporate fiction is disregarded when, among other reasons, corporation is organized and operated as mere tool or business conduit of another corporation.
Document Preview: In wrongful death action against United States and Mexican bus lines arising out of Mexican bus accident, the 138th District Court, Cameron County, Robert Garza, J., entered judgment for plaintiffs.  On appeal, the Court of Appeals, 756 S.W.2d 786,reversed and remanded, and plaintiffs brought error.  The Supreme Court, 774 S.W.2d 644, reversed and remanded.  On remand, the Court of Appeals, Kennedy, J., held that: (1) supervisor for Mexican federal police was qualified to testify as expert on speed of bus and its contribution to cause of accident; (2) there was some evidence to support finding that bus driver exceeded rate of speed at which person using high degree of care would have driven; (3) Texas had the most significant contacts, for choice of law purposes; and (4) United States bus line was not liable for actions of its subsidiary. Affirmed in part and reversed and rendered in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Phillips Petroleum Securities Litigation
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, separate corporate existence will not be set aside merely on showing of common management or whole ownership, but only in interest of justice, when such matters as fraud, contravention of law or contract, public wrong, or equitable considerations among members of corporation require it.
Document Preview: Shareholders brought action challenging target corporation's settlement with tender offeror.  The District Court, 697 F.Supp. 1344, granted summary judgment in favor of target corporation, its board of directors, and offeror, and shareholders appealed.  The Court of Appeals, 881 F.2d 1236, affirmed in part, vacated in part and remanded.  On remand, the District Court, Murray M. Schwartz, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) material question of fact, regarding materiality of tender offeror's representation that it would not sell stock back to target corporation unless other shareholders were given opportunity to sell stock back on same terms, precluded entry of summary judgment for tender offeror on Rule 10b5 claims; (2) material question of fact, whether tender offeror's corporate parent had created tender offeror for purpose of participating in takeover attempt and whether parent had so dominated actions of tender offeror to reduce them...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Culbreth v. Amosa (Pty) Ltd.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Assuming that Pennsylvania would permit recovery on alter ego theory upon showing of injustice, as opposed to fraud and deceit in manipulation of controlled corporation, Pennsylvania, like New Jersey, would not allow recovery unless party seeking to pierce corporate veil on alter ego theory established that controlling corporation wholly ignored separate status of controlled corporation and so dominated and controlled its affairs that separate existence was mere sham.
Document Preview: Plaintiff brought action to recover damages for injuries suffered as result of asbestos exposure against, inter alia, corporations which owned majority of voting stock of British corporation whose Illinois subsidiary marketed asbestos.  The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, Edmund V. Ludwig, J., granted summary judgment for the corporations on all claims, cross claims, and third-party claims, and plaintiff appealed.  The Court of Appeals held that asbestos plaintiff had not established pervasive domination of British parent corporation that would permit finding British corporation to be defendant corporations' alter ego, under Pennsylvania law, so as to support piercing of corporate veil to impose liability. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Hornsby v. Hornsby's Stores, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law separate corporations are deemed to have separate corporate identities; although there are some exceptions to rule, they are not favored and are stringently applied.
Document Preview: Commercial lessor brought suit for breach of lease agreement against defaulting lessee, and related corporations to whom lessee's corporate assets had been transferred.  On cross motions for summary judgment, and joint motion to dismiss filed by related corporations, the District Court, Aspen, J., held that: (1) lessor was not entitled to liquidated damages in the form of accelerated rent payments; (2) genuine issue of fact existed as to whether certain repairs were cognizable as damages under lease agreement, precluding summary judgment on that issue; and (3) under Illinois law, lessor failed to state a claim against corporations related to lessee, under theories of fraudulent conveyance or alter ego. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Derbyshire v. United Builders Supplies, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: To activate cut-through of "piercing the corporate veil," there must be abuse of corporate form; sole ownership of corporation by one person or another corporation is not factor, and neither is fact that sole owner uses and controls it to promote his ends.
Document Preview: Landlord sued corporations and individual corporate official to recover under a lease agreement and for damages to the leased premises.  The Muscogee State Court, Johnson, J., entered judgment on a jury verdict for landlord, and defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Beasley, J., held that: (1) the court erred in entering judgment without fulfilling its responsibility to decide the jurisdictional question raised by defendant's motion to dismiss; (2) it was proper to pierce the corporate veil to hold the individual defendant and the nonsignatory corporations liable under the lease; and (3) landlord could not recover attorney fees. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded with direction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Archem, Inc. v. Simo
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana, First District.
Headnote: Corporation's filing consolidated tax return is one factor favoring piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: Manufacturer sued salesman regarding independent distributorship agreement alleging misrepresentation, unjust enrichment, and breach of contract.  Salesman counterclaimed alleging breach of contract, abuse of process, and corrupt business influence.  The Bartholomew Circuit Court, Suzanne F. Trautman, J., entered judgment for salesman on his breach of contract and abuse of process claims.  Manufacturer appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Robertson, J., held that: (1) financial documents of manufacturer's parent corporation were admissible in assessing punitive damages against manufacturer; (2) trial court erred in admitting video taped deposition of salesman's witness when manufacturer's attorney was unable to attend deposition; (3) award of punitive damages against manufacturer was not excessive; and (4) evidence supported salesman's breach of contract and abuse of process claims. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: South Side Nat. Bank in St. Louis v. Winfield Financial Services Corp.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Two.
Headnote: Test for piercing corporate veil is two pronged: first, corporation must be controlled and influenced by persons or by another corporation, and second, evidence must establish that corporate cloak was used as a subterfuge to defeat public convenience to justify a wrong, or to perpetrate a fraud.
Document Preview: Bank filed fraudulent conveyance action against corporate president, transferor corporation and transferee corporation.  The Circuit Court, St. Charles County, Donald E. Dalton, J., entered judgment for defendants, and bank appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Crandall, J., held that transfers of real estate properties evidenced badges of fraud and were fraudulent conveyances. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Cabalceta v. Standard Fruit Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: Even if defendant corporation could be considered as alter ego of another, it could not be held liable under Florida law for any wrongs of the other corporation which took place prior to defendant corporation's incorporation.
Document Preview: Appeals were taken from orders of the United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida, No. 87457CIVCCA, C. Clyde Atkins, J., 667 F.Supp. 833, which denied motion to remand and dismissed products liability actions.  The Court of Appeals, Fitzpatrick, District Judge, sitting by designation, held that: (1) domestic corporation which did not have its principal place of business in the United States, District of Columbia, or Puerto Rico would not be considered an alien for purposes of determining diversity, but (2) district court should have applied Costa Rican law to determine the merits of plaintiff's claims against one defendant when determining whether that defendant's joinder had been fraudulent. Affirmed in part and reversed and remanded in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Frazier v. Bryan Memorial Hosp. Authority
Court: Supreme Court of Oklahoma.
Headnote: If one corporation is but instrumentality or agent of other, corporate distinctions must be disregarded and two separate entities must be treated as one.
Document Preview: Appeal was taken from orders of the District Court, Bryan County, Joe C. Taylor, J., entered in wrongful death action.  The Supreme Court, Opala, V.C.J., held that: (1) order dismissing action against hospital for failure to state claim upon which relief could be granted due to absence of statutorily required notice of claim was a nonappealable interlocutory order, and (2) fact issue as to whether hospital management corporation's wholly owned subsidiary was instrumentality or agent of corporation precluded summary judgment. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Pan Eastern Exploration Co. v. Hufo Oils
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate veil may be pierced under Texas law, where corporation is organized and operated as mere tool or business conduit of other corporation, where corporate form is used to avoid legal limitations on natural persons or corporations, or where form is used as sham to perpetrate fraud, inequity or injustice.
Document Preview: Natural gas company and its wholly owned subsidiary filed suit against oil producers and other defendants based on defendants' alleged conversion of natural gas belonging to plaintiffs.  The United States District Court for the Western District of Texas, Lucius Desha Bunton, III, Chief Judge, entered judgment on jury verdict which rejected all of parties' claims, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Gee, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) finding that managers of gas company and its wholly owned affiliate had consented to independent oil producer's alleged conversion of affiliate's gas, by signing agreement to purchase oil producer's casinghead gas even though they suspected that producer had obtained gas by high-level perforation of gas formations to which affiliate held rights, was sufficiently supported by evidence, and (2) consent continued, at very latest, until plaintiffs filed suit against producer. Affirmed in part, reversed in part and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Pan Eastern Exploration Co. v. Hufo Oils
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, mere fact that corporations shared interlocking directorates and officers would not permit court to pierce corporate veil, on ground that corporations were mere "alter egos" of each other, where all of corporate formalities were maintained.
Document Preview: Natural gas company and its wholly owned subsidiary filed suit against oil producers and other defendants based on defendants' alleged conversion of natural gas belonging to plaintiffs.  The United States District Court for the Western District of Texas, Lucius Desha Bunton, III, Chief Judge, entered judgment on jury verdict which rejected all of parties' claims, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Gee, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) finding that managers of gas company and its wholly owned affiliate had consented to independent oil producer's alleged conversion of affiliate's gas, by signing agreement to purchase oil producer's casinghead gas even though they suspected that producer had obtained gas by high-level perforation of gas formations to which affiliate held rights, was sufficiently supported by evidence, and (2) consent continued, at very latest, until plaintiffs filed suit against producer. Affirmed in part, reversed in part and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Rivermeadows, Inc. v. Zwaanshoek Holding and Financiering, B.V.
Court: Supreme Court of Wyoming.
Headnote: Where parties are aware of corporate status and knowingly enter into transactions with no fraud being evidenced, there is no rationale or policy which requires that corporate entity be disregarded, even if corporations are in alter ego relationship.
Document Preview: Lender brought action against developer on promissory note, against purchaser on property which had been mortgaged as collateral for the developer's note, and against vendor as guarantor of note.  Vendor and developer raised affirmative defenses and filed a cross claim against the purchaser.  The District Court, Teton County, Robert B. Ranck, J., entered judgment in favor of lender and purchaser.  Appeal was taken.  The Supreme Court, Macy, J., held that: (1) evidence that the lender and the purchaser may have been in an alter ego relationship did not mandate disregarding their separate corporate entities where the vendor and the developer dealt with them as separate entities; (2) the trial court did not abuse its discretion in refusing to stay the action in favor of pending litigation in California; (3) the purchaser's and the lender's parent corporations were not indispensable parties to the litigation; and (4) the trial...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Western Washington Laborers-Employers Health & Sec. Trust Fund v. Harold Jordan Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 1.
Headnote: Under doctrine of corporate disregard, in order to find that two corporate entities should be treated as one, it must appear that one so dominates other as to make other mere tool and that their funds and property interests are commingled.
Document Preview: Trust sought to recover judgment it had obtained against defunct corporation against its sister corporation on theories of fraudulent conveyance, corporate disregard, and successor corporation liability.  The Superior Court, Snohomish County, Robert C. Bibb, J., granted summary judgment in corporation's favor on fraudulent conveyance claim, and entered judgment in its favor on remaining claims after trial.  Trust appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Webster, J., held that: (1) fraudulent conveyance claim was barred by limitations; (2) sister corporation and sole shareholder of both corporations were not liable to trusts on theory of corporate disregard; and (3) sister corporation had no liability on theory it was mere continuation of defunct judgment debtor corporation under successor corporation theories. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Western Washington Laborers-Employers Health & Sec. Trust Fund v. Harold Jordan Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 1.
Headnote: One corporation's grant of credit to another, without more, is not grounds for applying doctrine of corporate disregard, notwithstanding fact that one person dominates both corporations, as long as domination was exerted upon each as separate concern.
Document Preview: Trust sought to recover judgment it had obtained against defunct corporation against its sister corporation on theories of fraudulent conveyance, corporate disregard, and successor corporation liability.  The Superior Court, Snohomish County, Robert C. Bibb, J., granted summary judgment in corporation's favor on fraudulent conveyance claim, and entered judgment in its favor on remaining claims after trial.  Trust appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Webster, J., held that: (1) fraudulent conveyance claim was barred by limitations; (2) sister corporation and sole shareholder of both corporations were not liable to trusts on theory of corporate disregard; and (3) sister corporation had no liability on theory it was mere continuation of defunct judgment debtor corporation under successor corporation theories. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Amason v. Whitehead
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Because cardinal rule of corporate law is that corporation possesses legal existence separate and apart from that of officers and shareholders, mere operation of corporate business does not render one personally liable for corporate acts; sole ownership of corporation by one person or another corporation is not a factor and neither is fact that sole owner uses and controls corporation to promote his ends.
Document Preview: Subcontractor brought action against corporate contractor and sole or principal shareholder to recover sums allegedly due for performing various masonry cleaning services.  The sole or principal shareholder and corporate contractor filed counterclaim for subcontractor's alleged failure to perform services in workmanlike manner.  The Gwinnett Superior Court, Henderson, J., entered verdict against sole or principal shareholder and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Beasley, J., held that evidence was insufficient to warrant piercing the corporate veil to hold sole or principal shareholder liable. Reversed with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Hideca Petroleum Corp. v. Tampimex Oil Intern., Ltd.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Doctrine of alter ego is separate and distinct theory and is not to be confused with other reasons for disregarding corporate fiction; alter ego theory is applicable where corporation is organized and operated as mere tool or business conduit of another corporation.
Document Preview: Action was brought for breach of contract arising out of aborted international crude oil transaction.  The 234th District Court, Harris County, Ruby Sondock, J., entered judgment for seller of crude oil and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Levy, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to support finding that domestic crude oil company was individually liable on contract because it was acting for undisclosed or partially disclosed principal, and substituted its own responsibility for, or pledged its own responsibility in addition to, that of its principal; (2) evidence was sufficient to support finding that domestic oil company was alter ego of oil company operating in international markets; and (3) evidence was sufficient to support finding that domestic oil company was liable for damages for negligent misrepresentation. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Hideca Petroleum Corp. v. Tampimex Oil Intern., Ltd.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Alter ego may be established by evidence showing blend of identities, or blurring of lines of distinction, both formal and substantive, between two corporations or between an individual and a corporation, and in determining alter ego factors such as identity of shareholders, directors, officers, and employees, failure to distinguish an ordinary business between two entities, and failure to observe proper formalities, are important.
Document Preview: Action was brought for breach of contract arising out of aborted international crude oil transaction.  The 234th District Court, Harris County, Ruby Sondock, J., entered judgment for seller of crude oil and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Levy, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to support finding that domestic crude oil company was individually liable on contract because it was acting for undisclosed or partially disclosed principal, and substituted its own responsibility for, or pledged its own responsibility in addition to, that of its principal; (2) evidence was sufficient to support finding that domestic oil company was alter ego of oil company operating in international markets; and (3) evidence was sufficient to support finding that domestic oil company was liable for damages for negligent misrepresentation. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Hideca Petroleum Corp. v. Tampimex Oil Intern., Ltd.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Alter ego is found when there is such unity between corporation and individual, or between corporation and corporation, that separateness between two has ceased, and holding only corporation or just one of corporations liable would result in injustice.
Document Preview: Action was brought for breach of contract arising out of aborted international crude oil transaction.  The 234th District Court, Harris County, Ruby Sondock, J., entered judgment for seller of crude oil and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Levy, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to support finding that domestic crude oil company was individually liable on contract because it was acting for undisclosed or partially disclosed principal, and substituted its own responsibility for, or pledged its own responsibility in addition to, that of its principal; (2) evidence was sufficient to support finding that domestic oil company was alter ego of oil company operating in international markets; and (3) evidence was sufficient to support finding that domestic oil company was liable for damages for negligent misrepresentation. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Anderson v. Jasper Federal Sav. and Loan Ass'n
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Beaumont.
Headnote: Determination that second corporation is alter ego of first corporation merely furnishes means to reach second corporation or individual upon cause of action that otherwise would have existed only against first corporation.
Document Preview: General partner brought action against limited partner, lender and lender's successor, alleging that by requiring general partner to form partnership in order to obtain construction loan and then, through partnership, refusing to sell property, thereby preventing repayment on loan, defendants were guilty of usury.  The 258th District Court, Polk County, Joe Ned Dean, J., entered take nothing judgment for general partner, and general partner appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Dies, C.J., held that: (1) finding that lender, lender's successor and limited partner had unreasonably prevented general partner from performing his part of partnership's obligation to repay balance of note did not excuse general partner from performing his part of obligation, regardless of whether limited partner was lender's alter ego; (2) general partner sustained no damages by virtue of being prevented from repaying loan; and (3) overruling of motion in limine was not...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Porter v. Beloit Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Mississippi, Western Division.
Headnote: Under Mississippi law, one entity's ownership of all stock in another is not determinative of whether corporate fiction may be disregarded.
Document Preview: Wholly-owned subsidiary of decedent's employer moved for summary judgment that subsidiary was entitled to exclusivity protection of Mississippi's workers' compensation law in wrongful death action arising out of accident wherein platform installed by subsidiary above paper machine gave way, causing death of decedent when he fell into paper machine. The District Court, Barbour, J., held that wholly owned subsidiary was not the same as decedent's employer under Mississippi law so as to be entitled to invoke protection of exclusivity provision of workers' compensation law. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Cahaba Veneer, Inc. v. Vickery Auto Supply
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Alabama.
Headnote: One corporation will be liable for debts of a second, separate corporation on alter ego theory, only where first corporation dominated second to such extent that second corporation became mere instrumentality of the first, provided that complaining party also proved that dominant corporation proximately causes injury by misusing its control over subservient corporation.
Document Preview: Creditors brought suit against first corporation alleging its liability for debts of second corporation on theory of alter ego or apparent authority.  The Circuit Court, Henry County, Billy J. Sheffield, J., found in favor of creditors.  First corporation appealed.  The Court of Civil Appeals, Bradley, P.J., held that: (1) corporation was not liable on alter ego theory; (2) corporation was liable to one creditor on apparent authority theory; and (3) corporation was not liable to other creditors on apparent authority theory. Affirmed in part; reversed in part and remanded with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Terre Du Lac Ass'n, Inc. v. Terre Du Lac, Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Three.
Headnote: Ordinarily, two separate corporations are to be regarded as wholly distinct legal entities, even though the stock of one is owned partly or entirely by the other.
Document Preview: Homeowners' association brought action against subdivision developer, and other corporate defendants and individuals, including financier of development, seeking specific enforcement of alleged promises concerning roads, common areas and amenities, damages for breach of contract and declaratory relief.  The Circuit Court, Cape Girardeau County, A.J. Seier, J., granted motion to dismiss and association appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Crandall, J., held that: (1) dismissal of prior federal court action was not res judicata as to state court claims; (2) association was proper party to bring action to enforce purchase contracts between its members and developer; (3) association failed to state claim against financier; and (4) allegation that controlling corporation was alter ego of other defendant corporations was sufficient to withstand motion to dismiss. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Terre Du Lac Ass'n, Inc. v. Terre Du Lac, Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Three.
Headnote: Mere fact of ownership and control of one corporation by another does not of itself authorize piercing the corporate veil, and the question is whether the corporations are being manipulated through their interrelationship to cause illegality, fraud, or injustice.
Document Preview: Homeowners' association brought action against subdivision developer, and other corporate defendants and individuals, including financier of development, seeking specific enforcement of alleged promises concerning roads, common areas and amenities, damages for breach of contract and declaratory relief.  The Circuit Court, Cape Girardeau County, A.J. Seier, J., granted motion to dismiss and association appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Crandall, J., held that: (1) dismissal of prior federal court action was not res judicata as to state court claims; (2) association was proper party to bring action to enforce purchase contracts between its members and developer; (3) association failed to state claim against financier; and (4) allegation that controlling corporation was alter ego of other defendant corporations was sufficient to withstand motion to dismiss. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Terre Du Lac Ass'n, Inc. v. Terre Du Lac, Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Three.
Headnote: Test for piercing the corporate veil is two-pronged: corporation must be controlled and influenced by persons or another corporation, and, second, evidence must establish that corporate cloak was used as subterfuge to defeat public convenience, to justify wrong or to perpetrate fraud.
Document Preview: Homeowners' association brought action against subdivision developer, and other corporate defendants and individuals, including financier of development, seeking specific enforcement of alleged promises concerning roads, common areas and amenities, damages for breach of contract and declaratory relief.  The Circuit Court, Cape Girardeau County, A.J. Seier, J., granted motion to dismiss and association appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Crandall, J., held that: (1) dismissal of prior federal court action was not res judicata as to state court claims; (2) association was proper party to bring action to enforce purchase contracts between its members and developer; (3) association failed to state claim against financier; and (4) allegation that controlling corporation was alter ego of other defendant corporations was sufficient to withstand motion to dismiss. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Banegas v. United Brands Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Carolina, Charleston Division.
Headnote: Ownership by one corporation of stock in another corporation, either directly or through subsidiary, is simply not sufficient legal basis, in and of itself, to disregard corporate entities.
Document Preview: Seaman brought action under Jones Act for damages for personal injury sustained while employed as merchant seaman.  The District Court, Hawkins, J., held that: (1) the seaman could not maintain Jones Act action against New Jersey corporation, and (2) district court did not have jurisdiction over action brought by Honduran seaman employed to serve upon vessel owned pro hac vice by Honduran corporation. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Banegas v. United Brands Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Carolina, Charleston Division.
Headnote: In order to warrant disregard of separateness of corporate entities, actual domination, rather than simply opportunity to exercise control, must be shown.
Document Preview: Seaman brought action under Jones Act for damages for personal injury sustained while employed as merchant seaman.  The District Court, Hawkins, J., held that: (1) the seaman could not maintain Jones Act action against New Jersey corporation, and (2) district court did not have jurisdiction over action brought by Honduran seaman employed to serve upon vessel owned pro hac vice by Honduran corporation. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Duff v. Southern Ry. Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Where one corporation controls and dominates another corporation to extent that second corporation becomes a mere instrumentality of first, the dominant corporation becomes liable for those debts or torts of subservient corporation attributable to an abuse of that control.
Document Preview: Employee of alleged instrumentality of railroad brought action under Federal Employers' Liability Act to recover for injuries allegedly sustained during course of employment.  The Circuit Court, Jefferson County, C. W. Callaway, J., granted railroad's motion for summary judgment, and employee appealed. The Supreme Court, Shores, J., held that question whether employer was an instrumentality of railroad so as to make injured individual an employee of railroad for purposes of Federal Employers Liability Act because railroad owned all of employer's stock and paid salaries of its workers and because employer did over 99 percent of its business with railroad and had a director who was an officer of railroad was a question of fact precluding summary judgment. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Sumner Realty Co. v. Willcott
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Fifth District.
Headnote: Findings that shareholders of first corporation owned all stock in second corporation, that some officers of first corporation were also officers of second corporation, and that second corporation rented office space from first corporation and used same warehouse for storage were insufficient to justify piercing corporate veil absent evidence that one corporation was dummy or sham for the other and that observance of separate existence would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Lessor of offset duplicator press filed complaint for unpaid rent and writ of replevin to recover press or judgment for purchase price of press, and attorney's fees.  Lessee counterclaimed for compensatory and punitive damages and attorney's fees.  The Circuit Court, Madison County, Clayton R. Williams, J., dismissed lessor's complaint and found for lessee on counterclaim, awarding him compensatory and punitive damages, and attorney's fees.  Lessor appealed.  The Appellate Court, Harrison, J., held that: (1) remand was required for application of Missouri law under lease's choice of law provision where counterclaim award was based exclusively on Illinois usury law, and (2) identity of shareholders and some corporate officers, as well as rental of office space and warehouse storage, were insufficient factors to justify piercing corporate veil. Reversed in part, and vacated and remanded in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Collet v. American Nat. Stores, Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Two.
Headnote: Control by dominant corporation is insufficient, standing alone, to pierce corporate veil and impose liability upon dominant corporation; control exercised by dominant corporation must have been used in improper manner which proximately caused injury to creditor of subserviant corporation.
Document Preview: Action was brought against tenant corporation and its former parent for breach of lease.  The Circuit Court, St. Louis County, Richard F. Provaznik, J., held for landlord and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Crist, J., held that: (1) landlord did not accept tenant's attempted surrender of lease; (2) former parent corporation remained liable, though subsidiary had been sold prior to its liquidation, in that sale was not arm's length transaction and parent continued to treat subsidiary's assets as its own; (3) parent corporation was liable for debt of former subsidiary in that subsidiary was undercapitalized and stripped of its assets by parent upon liquidation; (4) parent corporation was liable for debt of former subsidiary in that its actions rendered subsidiary corporation insolvent and thus proximately caused injury to subsidiary's creditors; (5) finding that parent corporation was liable was proper, though second...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: 3-D Elec. Co., Inc. v. Barnett Const. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Commonality of officers, evidence that corporations officed in same building, and showing that corporations were related in some ways was not enough to establish alter ego relationship between corporations so as to attribute to one corporation activities of second corporation in Texas, where two corporations filed separate tax returns, kept separate books and records, did not subcontract work between them, and one was not subsidiary of other.
Document Preview: Texas electrical contractor brought breach of contract action against Tennessee general contractor based on construction work done on motel in Colorado.  The Fourteenth Judicial District Court, Dallas County, John McClellan Marshall, J., sustained Tennessee general contractor's special appearance and dismissed suit for lack of jurisdiction, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Maloney, J., held that: (1) commonality of officers of two general contractors, evidence that they officed in same building, and showing that general contractors were related in some way was not enough to establish degree of control necessary for one general contractor's activities in Texas to be attributable to defendant general contractor; (2) mere fact that same individual owned stock in both general contractors was not enough to hold two corporations acted as one; and (3) defendant general contractor did not have minimum contacts needed to assert personal...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Municipal Bldg. Authority of Iron County v. Lowder
Court: Supreme Court of Utah.
Headnote: For one corporate entity to be alter ego of another, there must be such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation no longer exists and observance of corporate form must sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or cause inequitable result to follow.
Document Preview: County and its municipal building authority brought action against county officials, seeking declaratory relief and writ of mandamus to compel county officials to carry out their alleged duties in connection with county's plan for financing construction of new jail facility.  The District Court, Iron County, George E. Ballif, J., upheld actions of county, and the county officials appealed.  The Supreme Court, Zimmerman, J., held that: (1) debt of municipal housing authority for which county was not responsible was not subject to debt restrictions of Constitution; (2) county did not violate constitutional article providing that legislature shall not authorize any county to lend credit to any private individual or corporate enterprise; and (3) municipal building authority was not a special commission within purview of constitutional article denying legislature power to delegate to special commission power to perform municipal functions; and...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Hearn v. Petra Intern. Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 4.
Headnote: Separate existence of a corporate entity is recognized, except in cases when the corporate veil is pierced, whether stock is owned by natural individuals, other corporations, or by one corporation.
Document Preview: Injured oil worker brought action against corporation which wholly owned the corporation which employed him, alleging that the injury was result of actions of the parent corporation.  The parent corporation moved for summary judgment on grounds that action was barred by exclusive remedy provision of workers' compensation law.  The District Court, Payne County, Ray Lee Wall, J., entered summary judgment, and worker appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Brightmire, P.J., held that: (1) action against parent corporation was not barred by the exclusive remedy provision, but (2) issue of fact as to whether injuries were as a result of acts of parent corporation or another subsidiary precluded summary judgment. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Boafo v. Hospital Corp. of America
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: One reason that law establishes separate corporate identity is so that a corporation can hold itself independently apart and insulate it from existence of another related corporation even while it uses related corporation or controls it to promote its own end, and separate identity is not disregarded unless it serves to promote injustice or protect fraud, for that would defeat purpose of law.
Document Preview: Patient who allegedly suffered severe and unremedied injury while being administered anesthesia at hospital operated by subsidiary brought action against parent corporation.  The Superior Court, Fulton County, Etheridge, J., granted parent corporation's motion for summary judgment, and patient appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Birdsong, P.J., held that subsidiary was not a shell for parent corporation in operating hospital, but did fully and, for the most part, autonomously operate and manage hospital, and thus, patient was not entitled to pierce corporate veil of parent corporation, even though two corporations shared some officers and had jointly purchased hospital property from bankruptcy receivership. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Institutional Laundry, Inc. v. Utah State Tax Com'n
Court: Supreme Court of Utah.
Headnote: Although in appropriate cases equity may look through corporate shell to corporation's alter ego to prevent fraud or wrongdoing, general rule is that separate corporations are separate legal entities bound by obligations as well as benefits.
Document Preview: Subsidiary corporation brought action challenging sales tax assessment for laundry services provided by it to parent corporation.  The Third District Court, Salt Lake County, Timothy R. Hanson, J., upheld sales tax assessment, and subsidiary appealed.  The Supreme Court held that subsidiary, with separate corporate existence, was liable for sales tax in regard to laundry services provided for parent corporation on nonprofit basis. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Zisblatt v. Zisblatt
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Fort Worth.
Headnote: Burden of proof necessary to pierce corporate veil may be satisfied and corporate fiction may be disregarded where it is used as means for perpetrating fraud, where corporation is organized and operated as mere tool or business conduit of another corporation, where resort is made to corporate fiction in order to avoid existing legal obligation, where corporate form is used to achieve or perpetrate monopoly, where corporate structure is used as a vehicle for circumventing statute, or where fiction is invoked in order to protect crime or justify wrong.
Document Preview: Husband petitioned for divorce and wife cross petitioned against husband for divorce and filed third-party action against corporation owned by husband at time parties were married.  The 324th District Court, Tarrant County, Brian A. Carper, J., granted the petition for divorce, denied wife's third-party action, and divided the property.  Wife appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Joe Spurlock II, J., held that: (1) corporation was husband's alter ego at time parties were married and through time of parties' divorce; (2) all assets which came into corporation during time of parties' marriage, were in fact part of community estate and subject to division upon divorce with only exception of assets which came into corporation pursuant to 1976 merger of husband's other companies into corporation; and (3) trial court's division of marital property was manifestly unjust where trial court's conclusion that corporation was not husband's alter ego...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Vucci v. Meyers Bros. Parking System, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Rhode Island.
Headnote: Separateness of two corporations affiliated through common stock ownership must be respected unless the totality of circumstances surrounding their relationship indicates that one of the corporations is so organized and controlled, and its affairs are so conducted, as to make it merely instrumentality, agency, conduit, or adjunct of the other.
Document Preview: Customer of parking lot brought action against several defendants for personal injuries sustained when guardrail in parking lot collapsed, allegedly due to improper repair of damage caused when insured motorist had collided with it. The Superior Court, Providence County, Almeida, J., entered final judgment for customer against insurer and parking lot owner, and insurer appealed.  The Supreme Court, Shea, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to carry case to the jury on issue of insurer's liability; (2) evidence about claims adjustor's employer's apparent authority to act on insurer's behalf was admissible; (3) allowing questions and requests that assumed corporate identity shared by insurer and claims adjustor's employer was not abuse of discretion; (4) admission of expert testimony on the issue of customer's future earning capacity was not error; (5) domination by one corporation of the other corporation's finances, policies...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Vucci v. Meyers Bros. Parking System, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Rhode Island.
Headnote: In determining whether to disregard corporate entities of corporations which are affiliated through common stock ownership, domination by one corporation of the other corporation's finances, policies, and practices should be considered, under the totality of circumstances.
Document Preview: Customer of parking lot brought action against several defendants for personal injuries sustained when guardrail in parking lot collapsed, allegedly due to improper repair of damage caused when insured motorist had collided with it. The Superior Court, Providence County, Almeida, J., entered final judgment for customer against insurer and parking lot owner, and insurer appealed.  The Supreme Court, Shea, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to carry case to the jury on issue of insurer's liability; (2) evidence about claims adjustor's employer's apparent authority to act on insurer's behalf was admissible; (3) allowing questions and requests that assumed corporate identity shared by insurer and claims adjustor's employer was not abuse of discretion; (4) admission of expert testimony on the issue of customer's future earning capacity was not error; (5) domination by one corporation of the other corporation's finances, policies...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Roy E. Thomas Const. Co. v. Arbs
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Fort Worth.
Headnote: The corporate fiction will be disregarded when it is used as a means for perpetrating fraud, when the corporation is organized and operated as the mere tool or business conduit of another corporation, where resort is made to the corporate fiction in order to avoid an existing legal obligation, when the corporate form is used to achieve or perpetuate monopoly, when the corporate structure is used as a vehicle for circumventing a statute or when the fiction is invoked in order to protect crime or justify wrong.
Document Preview: Purchasers of home brought deceptive trade practices action against corporate construction company and shareholder for breach of warranty to construct house in good and workmanlike manner.  The 141st District Court, Tarrant County, James E. Wright, J., entered judgment in favor of purchasers, and builders appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Joe Spurlock, II, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to support finding that defendant construction company breached warranty to construct house in good and workmanlike manner; (2) evidence supported jury's finding of cost to repair cracked foundation, bricks and mortar; (3) trial court did not err in awarding treble damages; (4) trial court did not err in awarding attorney fees to purchasers; and (5) there was no evidence to support jury's finding that corporate construction company had become alter ego of shareholder. Affirmed in part and reversed and reformed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Glenn v. Wagner
Court: Supreme Court of North Carolina.
Headnote: For purpose of disregarding corporate entity of affiliated corporations, domination of finances, policy and business practices is sufficient where affiliated corporation is dominated by another to extent that dominated corporation has no separate mind, will or identity of its own.
Document Preview: Sublessees of hotel-apartment complex brought action against manager and corporate lessor, alleging, inter alia, that defendant had trespassed by locking sublessees out of their apartments.  The District Court, Forsyth County, Gary B. Tash, J., entered judgment on jury verdict in favor of sublessees, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, 67 N.C.App. 563, 313 S.E.2d 832, granted new trial.  Sublessees appealed.  The Supreme Court, Branch, C.J., held that: (1) relationship between corporate lessor and corporate owner was that of affiliated corporations; (2) domination sufficient to pierce corporate veil was not required to be limited to particular transaction attacked; (3) dominant shareholder exercised such control that he would be deemed to have had notice of transaction at issue; and (4) jury instruction respecting instrumentality rule was adequate. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Glenn v. Wagner
Court: Supreme Court of North Carolina.
Headnote: For purpose of disregarding corporate entity of affiliated corporations, analysis of domination need not be narrowly limited to control over particular transaction attacked where affiliated corporation is without separate and distinct corporate identity and is operated as mere shell, created to perform function for dominant corporation or common shareholders.
Document Preview: Sublessees of hotel-apartment complex brought action against manager and corporate lessor, alleging, inter alia, that defendant had trespassed by locking sublessees out of their apartments.  The District Court, Forsyth County, Gary B. Tash, J., entered judgment on jury verdict in favor of sublessees, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, 67 N.C.App. 563, 313 S.E.2d 832, granted new trial.  Sublessees appealed.  The Supreme Court, Branch, C.J., held that: (1) relationship between corporate lessor and corporate owner was that of affiliated corporations; (2) domination sufficient to pierce corporate veil was not required to be limited to particular transaction attacked; (3) dominant shareholder exercised such control that he would be deemed to have had notice of transaction at issue; and (4) jury instruction respecting instrumentality rule was adequate. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Glenn v. Wagner
Court: Supreme Court of North Carolina.
Headnote: When issue of intercorporate liability is addressed, factors which may be considered inherent in instrumentality rule include nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of debtor corporation, siphoning of funds by dominant shareholder, nonfunctioning of other officers or directors and absence of corporate records, in addition to factors of inadequate capitalization, noncompliance with corporate formalities, complete domination and control, and excessive fragmentation.
Document Preview: Sublessees of hotel-apartment complex brought action against manager and corporate lessor, alleging, inter alia, that defendant had trespassed by locking sublessees out of their apartments.  The District Court, Forsyth County, Gary B. Tash, J., entered judgment on jury verdict in favor of sublessees, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, 67 N.C.App. 563, 313 S.E.2d 832, granted new trial.  Sublessees appealed.  The Supreme Court, Branch, C.J., held that: (1) relationship between corporate lessor and corporate owner was that of affiliated corporations; (2) domination sufficient to pierce corporate veil was not required to be limited to particular transaction attacked; (3) dominant shareholder exercised such control that he would be deemed to have had notice of transaction at issue; and (4) jury instruction respecting instrumentality rule was adequate. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Glenn v. Wagner
Court: Supreme Court of North Carolina.
Headnote: Focus of instrumentality rule is upon reality, not form, upon operation of corporation and upon defendant's relationship to such operation; it is not presence or absence of particular factor that is determinative, but it is combination of factors which, taken together with element of injustice or abuse of corporate privilege, suggest that corporate entity attacked had "no separate mind, will or existence of its own," and was therefore "mere instrumentality or tool" of dominant corporation.
Document Preview: Sublessees of hotel-apartment complex brought action against manager and corporate lessor, alleging, inter alia, that defendant had trespassed by locking sublessees out of their apartments.  The District Court, Forsyth County, Gary B. Tash, J., entered judgment on jury verdict in favor of sublessees, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, 67 N.C.App. 563, 313 S.E.2d 832, granted new trial.  Sublessees appealed.  The Supreme Court, Branch, C.J., held that: (1) relationship between corporate lessor and corporate owner was that of affiliated corporations; (2) domination sufficient to pierce corporate veil was not required to be limited to particular transaction attacked; (3) dominant shareholder exercised such control that he would be deemed to have had notice of transaction at issue; and (4) jury instruction respecting instrumentality rule was adequate. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Glenn v. Wagner
Court: Supreme Court of North Carolina.
Headnote: Where there is evidence of common corporate ownership and actual working control as in case of affiliated corporations, taken together with other factors suggesting domination of finances, policy or business practice, including but not limited to undercapitalization, disregard of corporate formalities and insolvency, jury instruction on instrumentality rule as enunciated in case law is adequate.
Document Preview: Sublessees of hotel-apartment complex brought action against manager and corporate lessor, alleging, inter alia, that defendant had trespassed by locking sublessees out of their apartments.  The District Court, Forsyth County, Gary B. Tash, J., entered judgment on jury verdict in favor of sublessees, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, 67 N.C.App. 563, 313 S.E.2d 832, granted new trial.  Sublessees appealed.  The Supreme Court, Branch, C.J., held that: (1) relationship between corporate lessor and corporate owner was that of affiliated corporations; (2) domination sufficient to pierce corporate veil was not required to be limited to particular transaction attacked; (3) dominant shareholder exercised such control that he would be deemed to have had notice of transaction at issue; and (4) jury instruction respecting instrumentality rule was adequate. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Entech Systems Corp. v. Gaffney
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Factors indicating mingling of corporate identities include lack of corporate formalities, undercapitalization, and failure to keep separate accounting records.
Document Preview: Distributor of water treatment device brought breach of contract and negligent representation action against corporate manufacturer, its sole shareholder and second corporation allegedly controlled by that shareholder.  The Civil District Court, Parish of Orleans, Joseph V. Dirosa, J., entered summary judgment for shareholder and second corporation, and distributor appealed. The Court of Appeal, Williams, J., held that affidavit by certified public accountant indicating undercapitalization of manufacturer, commingling of funds between two corporations, and disregard of corporate identities raised genuine issue of fact as to integrity of manufacturer's corporate identity, precluding summary judgment. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Oriental Commercial and Shipping Co., Ltd. v. Rosseel, N.V.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To apply alter ego doctrine to justify disregard of corporate entity, court must determine that there is such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of the corporations no longer exist and that failure to disregard corporate form would result in fraud or injustice, though stringent showing is required before court will pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: Party to dispute arising out of alleged breach of international oil purchase agreement moved to compel arbitration, pursuant to the Convention on the Recognition of Foreign Arbitral Awards and the United States Arbitration Act.  The District Court, Leisure, J., held that: (1) by sending telex containing terms of the contract, including a provision for arbitration in New York City, seller evidenced its intention to arbitrate disputes arising under that contract, and the arbitration clause was valid; (2) dispute concerning fundamental aspect of the contract, namely, alleged nonperformance by a party and resulting damages, was clearly within scope of the arbitration clause; and (3) further factual development was necessary before the court could determine whether a corporation which, though not a formal party to the contract, was related to corporate party, should itself be made a party to the arbitration proceeding under alter ego doctrine. Motion stayed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Van Dorn Co. v. Future Chemical and Oil Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: A corporate entity will be disregarded and veil of limited liability pierced when there is such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and individual or other corporation no longer exist, and circumstances are such that adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Vendor brought action for breach of contract against two corporations dominated by same individual and against individual to recover for various labels and cans ordered by one of the two corporations.  The United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, Hubert L. Will, J., entered judgment against both corporations jointly and severally in amount of $57,498.62.  An appeal and cross appeal were taken.  The Court of Appeals, Fairchild, Senior Circuit Judge, held that: (1) under Illinois law, evidence, including facts that, of two corporations dominated by same individual, corporation which ordered cans and labels from vendor had no assets, while corporation which actually used cans and labels had substantial assets, that individual operated both corporations very loosely as suited his convenience, and that corporations were completely intermingled, warranted piercing corporate veil to extent of disregarding separate corporate identities...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Van Dorn Co. v. Future Chemical and Oil Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, separate corporate identities will be disregarded only if condition claimed to be unjust to creditors is a result of abuses of corporate form.
Document Preview: Vendor brought action for breach of contract against two corporations dominated by same individual and against individual to recover for various labels and cans ordered by one of the two corporations. Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Matrix-Churchill v. Springsteen
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Control required under instrumentality doctrine for piercing corporate veil amounts to total domination of subservient corporation to extent that subservient corporation manifests no separate corporate interests of its own and functions solely to achieve purposes of dominant corporation.
Document Preview: Products liability action was brought for injuries allegedly sustained by plaintiff while working at press brake manufactured by a corporation. Successor corporate defendant cross-claimed against corporation which had purchased the corporation's operation consisting of the manufacture and sale of press brakes seeking declaratory judgment as to which of the defendant corporations would be liable to plaintiff should he prevail.  The Circuit Court, Jackson County, W. L. Campbell, J., held the successor corporation liable, and plaintiff and successor corporation appealed.  The Supreme Court, Beatty, J., held that: (1) successor corporation was not liable to plaintiff; and (2) trial court erred in not considering issue of estoppel against purchaser corporation. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Symons Corp. v. Tartan-Lavers Delray Beach, Inc.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: Corporate veil may not be pierced unless it is shown not only that one business entity dominated or was the alter ego of the other, but that the relationship was created or used in order to mislead or defraud creditors.
Document Preview: Claimant brought action against owner on mechanic's lien.  The Circuit Court, Palm Beach County, Robert S. Hewitt, J., entered judgment for claimant.  It appealed the denial of attorney fees and owner cross-appealed.  The District Court of Appeal, Smith, Charles E., Associate Judge, held that: (1) claimant's proof was sufficient to show good-faith substantial compliance in mailing notice to owner, where name listed in notice was similar to name of owner, evidence supported an inference that the notice was received by owner, and owner failed to show prejudice, and (2) claimant was entitled to recover reasonable attorney fees, but with recovery limited to $100 maximum against owner's cash deposit and an unsecured judgment for balance of attorney fees and costs. Remanded. Hurley, J., filed dissenting opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Extra Energy Coal Co. v. Diamond Energy and Resources, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana, Third District.
Headnote: Under doctrine of piercing the corporate veil, fiction of corporate entity may be disregarded where one corporation is so organized and controlled and its affairs so conducted that it is a mere instrumentality or adjunct of another corporation.
Document Preview: Judgment creditor brought action to pierce corporate veil of corporation and hold second corporation and its officers and directors liable.  The Circuit Court, Lake County, Lorenzo Arredondo J., entered judgment in favor of judgment debtor and other defendants, and an appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Hoffman, J., held that where corporations sharing nearly identical directors, officers, and shareholders were incorporated at different times for separate and distinct purposes, had separate offices, telephone numbers, stationery and business cards, were identified separately, along with two other tenants, on business sign outside building in which their offices were located, and had own bank accounts and corporate general ledgers for recording of receipts and expenditures, judgment creditor's decision to do business with first corporation, for which there was no financial information, was a poor decision which did not raise circumstances to level of unfairness,...
