Title: Lucas v. Texas Industries, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: Blending of activities alone cannot suffice to treat two corporations as one.
Document Preview: Plaintiff brought action to recover damages for personal injuries allegedly sustained on construction site when concrete beam which was being lifted from truck fell on plaintiff's leg.  Defendants included subcontractor and parent of subsidiary who fabricated the beam.  The 190th District Court, Harris County, Wyatt H. Heard, J., rendered judgment against defendants jointly and severally for $2,000,000, and they appealed.  The Court of Appeals, 634 S.W.2d 748 reversed the judgment against subcontractor and affirmed the judgment as modified.  Plaintiff appealed.  The Supreme Court, Campbell, J., held that: (1) evidence introduced by plaintiff was insufficient to pierce corporate veil to hold parent liable for alleged negligence of subsidiary in construction of concrete beam, and (2) from testimony of president of subcontractor, jury was entitled to conclude that advising that only one and a quarter-inch lifting equipment was necessary at job...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Southern Elec. Supply Co. v. Raleigh County Nat. Bank.
Court: Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia.
Headnote: Where both corporations controlled by single individual served separate purpose although businesses were related, neither corporation was undercapitalized, none of funds of either corporation were commingled, and neither corporation controlled the other, neither corporation was alter ego of other.
Document Preview: Corporation which saw its deposit transferred by bank and used as setoff for matured indebtedness of second corporation controlled by same individual brought action against bank for conversion of funds.  The Circuit Court, Raleigh County, Thomas Canterbury, J., entered judgment in favor of bank, and an appeal was taken.  The Supreme Court of Appeals, Harshbarger, J., held that bank had no explicit or implicit authority to transfer funds from corporation's account to second corporation's account and then set off those funds against second corporation's matured indebtedness. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Ioviero v. Ciga Hotels, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Courts will only pierce corporation veil and hold two corporations to constitute a single legal unit where one is so related to, or organized, or controlled by, the other as to be its instrumentality or alter ego.
Document Preview: Plaintiffs brought suit alleging that infant plaintiff sustained injury to her hand when she slipped and fell while exiting dining room at Italian hotel, and seeking to hold New York corporation vicariously liable. The Supreme Court, Richmond County, Rubin, J., denied the motion, and corporation appealed.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that: (1) New York corporation which was merely employed by Italian corporation which owned hotel as its independent sales representative in United States and Canada could not be sued by plaintiffs, notwithstanding similarity in New York corporation's first corporate name and name of Italian corporation, since contract documents established existence of two separate and distinct corporate entities, and (2) postponing a decision on motion in order to allow plaintiff to discover if New York...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Glenn v. Wagner
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Corporate entity may be disregarded if corporation is totally dominated by individual shareholder, and operated as his alter ego, whether sole or dominant shareholder is individual or another corporation.
Document Preview: Sublessees of hotel-apartment complex initiated action against individual who managed complex and corporate lessor alleging defendants had trespassed upon plaintiffs' premises by padlocking them out of their apartments, breached implied covenants of quiet enjoyment, and had wrongfully converted their personal property by removing and/or disposing of it.  Plaintiffs sought recovery against lessor on theory that corporate lessee was operated as mere instrumentality of lessor to shield it from liability, and that corporate entity of lessee should be disregarded to allow plaintiffs to recover directly from lessor for their damages.  The District Court, Forsyth County, Gary B. Tash, J., entered judgment on jury verdict in favor of plaintiffs, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Johnson, J., held that: (1) trial court erred in charging jury that corporate entity may be disregarded if corporation is totally dominated by individual shareholder;...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: NCR Credit Corp. v. Underground Camera, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, party requesting court to disregard corporate form must allege facts suggesting that representatives of one corporation exercise some type of pervasive control over activities of another corporation or that there is confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in common enterprise with substantial disregard of separate nature of the corporate entities, and, secondly, party must show that piercing of the corporate veil is necessary to defeat fraud or wrong or to prevent gross inequity.
Document Preview: In a suit for money allegedly due and unpaid on a computer sales contract, and on various motions, the District Court, Caffrey, Chief Judge, held that: (1) point charging that defendants conspired to defraud plaintiff to its great harm and detriment was insufficient to inform opposing party of nature of the conspiracy charged; (2) case was not appropriate one in which to apply equitable doctrine of corporate disregard; (3) court having declined to treat parent manufacturer and financing subsidiary corporation as same entity, it was found that subsidiary did not waive parent's right to arbitrate by filing suit in federal court, and where outcome of arbitration might dispose of some or all claims outstanding, proceedings in the court between plaintiff buyer and financing subsidiary would also be stayed pending outcome of arbitration; and (4) description of pending case in news weekly was unlikely to interfere with any litigant's right to fair...

Title: DeMartino v. Monroe Little League, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Fraud need not be shown in order to disregard the corporate entity where one corporation is used as an adjunct to another corporation.
Document Preview: Property owners who had obtained injunction which imposed time and place restrictions on little league baseball activities by a corporation which was organized for such activity moved to hold in contempt the original defendant corporation and another little league baseball corporation which was subsequently formed, for violating terms of the injunction. Headnote: One corporation may be disregarded when the two corporations are identical or indistinguishable in fact.

Title: Church of Scientology of California v. Blackman
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: Total domination of one corporation by another, if established by competent evidence, will justify piercing a corporate veil.
Document Preview: Psychiatrist brought defamation action against an incorporated committee organized for the protection of patients' rights, the Church of Scientology of California, and against a minister of the Church of Scientology of Florida and a member of the committee, arising from demonstration outside hospital in which psychiatrist worked condemning his use of electro-convulsive therapy.  The Circuit Court, Broward County, William Clayton Johnson, J., entered judgment for psychiatrist, and the California church timely appealed.  The District Court of Appeal, Hurley, J., held that psychiatrist failed to adduce competent evidence from which jury could reasonably conclude that the California church dominated the committee; thus, trial court committed reversible error in piercing the corporate veil and holding the California church liable for defamatory remarks made by the committee when it picketed hospital where plaintiff worked. Reversed and remanded. Downey, J.,...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Landry v. St. Charles Inn, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Absent evidence of failure to keep separate accounting records, or failure to observe corporate formalities, or undercapitalization or insolvency, or of control by one corporation of the affairs of another, there is no justification for piercing the corporate veil. LSA-C.C. art. 435.
Document Preview: Hotel guest brought action against innkeeper and owner of hotel parking lot in which she was assaulted and robbed.  The Civil District Court, Parish of Orleans, Revius O. Ortique, J., awarded plaintiff $20,000, and defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeal, Augustine, J., held that: (1) hotel premises included hotel parking lot on which hotel guest was assaulted and robbed; (2) innkeeper's failure to provide security in hotel parking lot was a breach of its special duty to guest who was robbed on such lot, in view of repeated instances of assault that had taken place within the previous year in or around such parking lot; (3) landowner which leased parking lot to innkeeper owed no duty to protect guest of innkeeper from assault by third persons; thus, landowner was not liable for injury sustained by innkeeper's guest; (4) guest was not entitled to pierce the corporate veil of innkeeper to hold its four stockholders and their...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Hoffman v. United Telecommunications, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Fact that one corporation may own all stock of another and may further select from its own directors and officers majority of all directors of other corporation, or fact that parent finances subsidiary, is not sufficient, standing alone, to warrant disregard of corporations as separate entities; however, where from all facts and circumstances it is apparent that relationship between parent and its subsidiary is so intimate, parent's control over subsidiary so dominating, and business and assets of two so mingled, that recognition of distinct entity would result in injustice to third-parties, courts will look through legal fiction of separate entity and treat them as justice requires.
Document Preview: Employment discrimination action was filed against plaintiff's former employer, its holding company parent corporation, and 38 other subsidiaries of parent which were located throughout country, and subsidiaries filed motion to dismiss.  The District Court, Saffels, J., held that: (1) prima facie case that constitutional and statutory requirements for assumption of personal jurisdiction over subsidiaries were satisfied; (2) parent corporation exerted such dominion and control over subsidiaries that they were not in reality separate and distinct corporate entities, but one and same under alter ego analysis, so that service of process on chief executive officer of parent was appropriate service on subsidiaries; and (3) venue was proper in district of Kansas. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Hoffman v. United Telecommunications, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Establishing injustice requirement for demonstrating corporation is but alter ego of another does not require showing that commingling of corporations was for purpose of causing injustice or that two or more corporations acted in concert in bringing about particular harm alleged by plaintiff; furthermore, injustice shown need not amount to fraud.
Document Preview: Employment discrimination action was filed against plaintiff's former employer, its holding company parent corporation, and 38 other subsidiaries of parent which were located throughout country, and subsidiaries filed motion to dismiss.  The District Court, Saffels, J., held that: (1) prima facie case that constitutional and statutory requirements for assumption of personal jurisdiction over subsidiaries were satisfied; (2) parent corporation exerted such dominion and control over subsidiaries that they were not in reality separate and distinct corporate entities, but one and same under alter ego analysis, so that service of process on chief executive officer of parent was appropriate service on subsidiaries; and (3) venue was proper in district of Kansas. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: State, Dept. of Revenue v. Alaska Pulp America, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Alaska.
Headnote: Generally, courts refuse to look through corporate veil and consider separate corporations a single unit even when intercorporation transactions are mere bookkeeping entries.
Document Preview: Appeal was taken from decision of Department of Revenue hearing officer assessing Business License Act taxes on seven domestic corporations wholly owned by foreign corporation for tax years 1971 through 1974.  The Superior Court, First Judicial District, Sitka, Duane Craske, J., held that statute of limitations barred all assessments for tax years 1971 through 1974, but, on reconsideration, decided that notice of proposed assessment for 1974 gross receipts, which was sent by Department in 1978 to three of the corporations, tolled the statute, and therefore concluded that those assessments were not barred.  Department and taxpayers appealed.  The Supreme Court, Rabinowitz, J., held that: (1) three-year statute of limitations for assessment of Business License Act taxes did not bar assessment of such taxes for 1971 through 1974; (2) subsidiary corporations were separately taxable under the Business License Act; (3) terms manufactured...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: North Pacific S.S. Co. v. Pyramid Ventures Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Where controlling parties with disregard for independent corporate interest of shipping company and in effort to render it judgment-proof while maintaining its business and losing none of its assets, shifted operations among it and other companies as if they were one, corporate veil of such company would be pierced to reach dominant corporation.
Document Preview: Judgment creditor sought to pierce corporate veil to find others liable for corporate debt.  The District Court, Cassibry, J., held that: (1) in view of controlling parties' shifting of operations among companies as if they were one, interest of justice required piercing of corporate veil to reach dominant corporation; (2) requisite degree of commingling of individual and corporate assets did not exist so as to hold controlling individual personally responsible, and (3) shareholder's redemption of stock constituted partial liquidation and was, under Louisiana law, unlawful distribution of assets. Order accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Sisk v. General Builders Corp. of Fort Lauderdale, Inc.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: Two ostensibly separate corporations will be treated as one when it is established that one totally dominates the other to extent that the subservient corporation manifests no separate corporate interests of its own and functions solely to achieve purposes of the dominant corporation.
Document Preview: Personal representative of fatally injured worker filed suit against two sister corporations, one a general contractor of record while the other was the owner of record.  Summary final judgment of the Circuit Court, Broward County, Barbara Bridge, J., found that the general contractor of record was immune from suit.  An appeal was taken by the personal representative.  The District Court of Appeal, Hurley, J., held that the personal representative by submitting documents and depositions to support his contention of total domination of the general contractor of record and the owner of record by the corporate parent of both raised genuine issue of material fact concerning corporate status of the defendant subsidiary and availability of immunity. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Dania Jai-Alai Palace, Inc. v. Sykes
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: A highly relevant factor in evaluating the application of the instrumentality rule is whether there is proof that the subservient corporation was being used to further purposes of the dominant corporation to the extent that the subservient corporation in reality had no separate, independent existence of its own.
Document Preview: Action was instituted to recover against three corporations for injuries sustained by plaintiff when crushed between two automobiles in parking lot.  The Circuit Court, Broward County, James F. Minnet, J., entered judgment on verdict for plaintiff, and defendants appealed.  The District Court of Appeal, Hurley, J., held that: (1) parking attendant employed by second corporation was negligent when, though trying to apply brakes on plaintiff's vehicle, he hit accelerator and caused plaintiff, then in front of vehicle, to be propelled forward and crushed between cars; (2) whether plaintiff was contributorily negligent, however, was a question which should have been submitted to jury instead of being determined on motion for directed verdict; (3) first corporation could be held liable for negligence of parking attendant employed by second corporation where both corporations held themselves out as a single enterprise; and (4) whether third...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Central Cooling & Supply Co. v. Director of Revenue, State of Mo.
Court: Supreme Court of Missouri, Division No. 2.
Headnote: Where one corporation is so controlled and its affairs so conducted as to transform it into adjunct or alter ego of another corporation, so that question arises whether to retain or disregard corporate fiction, test is whether arrangement between two corporations is being employed for proper purpose; if purpose served by arrangement is fair and lawful, then legal forms and relationships are to be observed and case determined upon basis of separate and individual corporate existence.
Document Preview: Corporation sought reversal of decision of Administrative Hearing Commission which affirmed director's assessment of sales and use tax against corporation on transfer of goods between it and its parent.  The Supreme Court, Higgins, J., held that no basis existed for ignoring separate corporate existence to permit subsidiary to avoid tax liability. Welliver, P. J., dissented and filed opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Central Cooling & Supply Co. v. Director of Revenue, State of Mo.
Court: Supreme Court of Missouri, Division No. 2.
Headnote: Ownership of capital stock in one corporation by another does not itself create identity of corporate interest as between the two.
Document Preview: Corporation sought reversal of decision of Administrative Hearing Commission which affirmed director's assessment of sales and use tax against corporation on transfer of goods between it and its parent.  The Supreme Court, Higgins, J., held that no basis existed for ignoring separate corporate existence to permit subsidiary to avoid tax liability. Welliver, P. J., dissented and filed opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Vantage View, Inc. v. Bali East Development Corp.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: Courts will look through the screen of corporate entity to individuals who compose it in cases in which the corporation is mere device or sham to accomplish some ulterior purpose, or is mere instrumentality or agent of another corporation or individual owning all or most of its stock, or where purpose is to evade some statute or to accomplish some fraud or illegal purpose, or where corporation is employed by stockholders for fraudulent or misleading purposes, is organized or used to mislead creditors or to perpetuate a fraud upon them, or to evade existing personal liability.
Document Preview: Condominium association brought action to recover against developers for breach of implied warranty, negligence and strict liability arising out of construction defects and deficiencies.  The Circuit Court, Broward County, Robert C. Abel, Jr., J., dismissed association's second amended complaint with prejudice, and association appealed.  The District Court of Appeal, Glickstein, J., held that: (1) complaint stated cause of action for breach of implied warranty; (2) complaint stated cause of action for negligence in designing, constructing, supervising, inspecting and approving the condominium building and improvements; and (3) complaint, in which it was alleged that defendant parent corporation established defendant subsidiary as a mere instrumentality and a sham and did so to mislead creditors and to avoid liability, stated cause of action against parent for acts of subsidiary. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re D.H. Overmyer Telecasting Co., Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Individual's control over various corporations was so pervasive that the unity of interest between himself and those corporations made it inequitable to treat the corporations as separate legal entities; individual was liable for obligations of each of the corporations and each corporation was liable for the obligations of the individual and each of the other corporations.
Document Preview: One Chapter 11 debtor brought action against second Chapter 11 debtor for relief from the stay. Intervenors filed action against the creditor. Creditor and defendant debtor filed counterclaims against plaintiffs. The Bankruptcy Court, John F. Ray, Jr., J., held that: (1) transfers of defendant debtor's assets for the benefit of person who controlled debtor and other corporations had been fraudulent; (2) certain action taken by defendant debtor at direction of the person who controlled it had been for the purpose of hindering and delaying creditor; (3) creditor was entitled to recover attorney fees incurred in furtherance of its ultimate goal of collecting the overdue indebtedness, including amounts expended in other reorganization proceedings involving other corporations controlled by the individual; and (4) counsel would be held liable for attorney fees. Order accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: DeJong v. Stern
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Where individual defendant operated three corporate defendants interchangeably as if they were one, evidence did not demand a verdict in favor of any one corporate defendant, despite contention that there was no evidence that two of the corporations ever had any dealings with plaintiff.
Document Preview: Suit was brought alleging breach of contract, and defendant filed counterclaim and third-party complaint alleging breach of contract and negligence.  The Superior Court, Chatham County, Dunbar Harrison, J., directed verdict in favor of plaintiff and third-party defendant on counterclaim and third-party action, and denied motion for new trial following verdict in favor of plaintiff, and defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Pope, J., held that: (1) defendants failed to show any actual damages on counterclaim and third-party action; (2) defendants were not entitled to have jury determine issue of nominal damages to reduce proved claim of plaintiff; and (3) where individual defendant operated three corporate defendants interchangeably as if they were one, evidence did not demand a verdict in favor of any one corporate defendant, despite contention that there was no evidence that two of them ever had any dealings with plaintiff. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Meisel v. M & N Modern Hydraulic Press Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Washington, En Banc.
Headnote: Separate corporate entities should not be disregarded solely because one cannot meet its obligations.
Document Preview: Plaintiff appealed order of the Superior Court, King County, Stephen M. Reilly, J., granting summary judgment to defendant corporation on plaintiff's product liability claim. The Supreme Court, Utter, J., held that: (1) defendant was not successor corporation of corporation which manufactured trim press which injured plaintiff, as required under plaintiff's successor liability theory, and (2) separate identities of corporate defendant and corporation which manufactured trim press would not be disregarded. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Schmid v. Roehm GmbH
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Under alter ego theory "injustice" required to pierce corporate veil must result from activities from two corporations holding themselves out to third parties as one entity; after representing themselves to public as one, law will not allow them to hide behind two separate corporate structures to escape consequences of their acts which have resulted in damage to third party.
Document Preview: Action was brought to recover damages for injuries sustained allegedly as a result of defective safety devices on gun. Plaintiff moved to strike defenses of defendants, one defendant moved for summary judgment and another defendant moved to dismiss and plaintiff cross moved for summary judgment. The District Court, O'Connor, Chief Judge, held that: (1) corporation was not liable to plaintiff as corporation was not in chain of distribution and was, in fact, not in existence at time gun was manufactured and imported into United States and was not alter ego of manufacturer, and (2) where plaintiff failed to serve process on defendant within 90 days as provided by Kansas law, action was barred by two-year statute of limitations. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: International City Bank and Trust Co. v. Morgan Walton Properties, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporations are treated as separate legal entities notwithstanding fact that they have common shareholders and officers, or that one corporation owns stock in the other.
Document Preview: Makers appealed from judgments entered by the United States District Court for the Northern District of Florida, Winston E. Arnow, Chief Judge, in mortgage foreclosure proceedings. The Court of Appeals held that: (1) notes payable on demand or two years after date were payable on demand and, in absence of demand, two years after execution; (2) formal demand was not necessary prior to commencing suit; (3) evidence was sufficient to support determination that there was no issue of material fact regarding existence of seven-year joint venture or financing contract; and (4) denial of makers' motion for new trial, which was premised upon allegedly prejudicial statements made by bank's counsel in closing argument, was not abuse of discretion. Affirmed. See also 612 F.2d 227;404 So.2d 1059.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: New Sheridan Hotel & Bar, Ltd. v. Commercial Leasing Corp., Inc.
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. I.
Headnote: Before one corporation may be held liable for acts of another corporation, there must be such a close relationship between the two companies that one is, in essence, an instrumentality of the other; factors which enter into this determination include, inter alia, stock ownership of one corporation by the other, management decisions by one corporation for the other, and amount of business which one company has apart from its business with the other.
Document Preview: Lessee of telephone system brought action against lessor to rescind the lease agreement, and lessor counterclaimed to accelerate payments required under the lease and to recover attorney fees. The District Court, San Miguel County, Jerry Lincoln, J., entered judgment for lessor on both the complaint and counterclaim, and lessee appealed. The Court of Appeals, Coyte, J., held that: (1) lessor was not responsible for any representations or warranties made by installer, from whom it had purchased the system, to lessee; (2) trial court did not err in accelerating payments due under terms of lease when lessee failed to make required payments; and (3) since no objection was timely made, lessee had no basis to complain as to amount of attorney fees awarded to lessor. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Kwick Set Components, Inc. v. Davidson Industries, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Elements essential for liability under "instrumentality doctrine" are, first, that dominant corporation must have controlled subservient corporation and, second, that dominant corporation must have proximately caused plaintiff harm through misuse of such control.
Document Preview: Company brought action against allegedly subservient corporation doing business as allegedly dominant corporation and against such corporations' president for failure to pay debt on open account. The Circuit Court, Russell County, Paul Jack Miller, Jr., J., dismissed corporate president as party defendant and entered judgment against corporations, and dominant corporation appealed. The Supreme Court, Beatty, J., held that: (1) in view of evidence that both allegedly dominant and subservient corporations had same president and board of directors and that dominant corporation purchased goods through name of defunct subservient corporation and used such goods to perform contracts, combined with apparent scheme of dominant corporation to avoid payment of subservient corporation's debts while benefiting from use of goods causing debt, evidence permitted finding that subservient corporation had become mere instrumentality of dominant corporation and that justice required court to look...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Kwick Set Components, Inc. v. Davidson Industries, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Control required under the "instrumentality" rule to impose liability upon dominant corporation which controls subservient corporation amounts to total domination of subservient corporation, to extent that subservient corporation manifests no separate corporate interests of its own and functions solely to achieve purposes of dominant corporation.
Document Preview: Company brought action against allegedly subservient corporation doing business as allegedly dominant corporation and against such corporations' president for failure to pay debt on open account. The Circuit Court, Russell County, Paul Jack Miller, Jr., J., dismissed corporate president as party defendant and entered judgment against corporations, and dominant corporation appealed. The Supreme Court, Beatty, J., held that: (1) in view of evidence that both allegedly dominant and subservient corporations had same president and board of directors and that dominant corporation purchased goods through name of defunct subservient corporation and used such goods to perform contracts, combined with apparent scheme of dominant corporation to avoid payment of subservient corporation's debts while benefiting from use of goods causing debt, evidence permitted finding that subservient corporation had become mere instrumentality of dominant corporation and that justice required court to look...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Cray v. Kennedy
Court: Supreme Court of Kansas.
Headnote: In considering relationship between corporate entities, each case must be decided upon its own special facts.
Document Preview: Applicant appealed from denial of alcoholic beverage distributor's license by Director of Alcoholic Beverage Control and Alcoholic Beverage Control Board of Review. The Shawnee District Court, James M. MacNish, Jr., J., reversed and ordered Director to grant license, and Director appealed. The Supreme Court, Prager, J., held that: (1) equipment company, in which applicant's spouse allegedly owned interest as beneficiary of trust having as its sole asset stock of equipment company, was not a subsidiary or affiliate of alcoholic beverage manufacturer, to which company leased equipment, and thus applicant was not disqualified for possession of license on such basis; (2) applicant's spouse, as contingent, nonvested beneficiary of discretionary trust, terms of which specified that he was to receive certain shares of stock in equipment company at age 30, had no present, legally enforceable rights in that trust which might give him direct or indirect interest...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: U.S. Barite Corp. v. M.V. Haris
Court: United States District Court, S. D. New York.
Headnote: Superficial indicia such as common offices and telephone numbers between corporate entities is not enough to show that one corporation is an alter ego of another; more important are such factors as degree of overlap of personnel, amount of business discretion displayed by alleged puppet corporation, and whether two entities deal with each other at arms length.
Document Preview: Shipper, a subsidiary of corporation which entered a charter party with shipowner whereby any dispute arising between charterer and shipowner would be submitted to arbitration, brought action against shipowner to recover damages for alleged destruction of cargo of oil drilling lubricant which it shipped aboard shipowner's vessel. On motion to compel arbitration, the District Court, Kevin Thomas Duffy, J., held that: (1) shipper was not required to submit to arbitration issue regarding alleged destruction of a cargo of oil drilling lubricant, even though charter party required that any dispute arising between charterer and shipowner would be submitted to arbitration, in view of fact that shipper was a separate corporate entity and not a party to charter; (2) arbitration clause of charter party was not incorporated by reference into bill of lading so as to cause shipper to be subject to arbitration clause; and (3) shipper's choice of forum in which to bring action would...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: St. Paul Fire and Marine Ins. Co. v. Vest Transp. Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: It is impermissible for stockholders to avail themselves of corporate structures of separate corporations when their interests are served but to discontinue them when it becomes no longer advantageous.
Document Preview: Issuer of excess protection and indemnity marine insurance sought declaration that expense of removal of sunken wreck of insured barge did not fall within scope of coverage, in which counterclaim and cross claims were filed. The United States District Court for the Northern District of Mississippi, William C. Keady, Chief Judge, rendered judgment of no liability, and appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals affirmed on decision of the District Court holding that where owner of barge which sank in navigable waters was not negligent and it was stipulated that sinking was caused solely by negligence of towing vessel, the barge owner could not be held personally liable to the United States for cost of removing the barge and, hence, there was no coverage under protection and indemnity fleet marine policies which insured tug and barge and which provided that each vessel was deemed a separate insurance and that coverage extended to liability which owner of the vessel named herein...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Main Bank of Chicago v. Baker
Court: Supreme Court of Illinois.
Headnote: Stock ownership in one corporation by another does not, alone, create identity of interest between the two or create relation of principal and agent, representative, or alter ego between the two.
Document Preview: Corporate obligee sued obligors on a note and obligors counterclaimed against a subsidiary of the obligee and against the obligee itself seeking recovery on the lease with the subsidiary. The Circuit Court, Cook County, Walter J. Kowalski, J., rendered judgments on directed verdicts for the obligee and obligors appealed. The Appellate Court, 88 Ill.App.3d 28, 43 Ill.Dec. 681, 410 N.E.2d 681, affirmed in part and reversed in part. Obligors appealed. The Supreme Court, Underwood, J., held that: (1) parol evidence was inadmissible to establish an oral agreement to make payment on the note contingent on the subsidiary's obligations under the lease; (2) the corporate veil could not be pierced so as to hold obligee liable on the lease; (3) a jury question existed as to the amount due under the lease; and (4) the obligee was entitled to recover from obligors the portion of the attorney fees attributable to recovering on the note itself, but not that portion attributable to the balance...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Main Bank of Chicago v. Baker
Court: Supreme Court of Illinois.
Headnote: Generally, before separate corporate identity of corporation will be disregarded and treated as alter ego of another corporation, it must be shown that it is so controlled and its affairs so conducted that it is mere instrumentality of another and it must further appear that observance of fiction of separate existence would, under the circumstances, sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Corporate obligee sued obligors on a note and obligors counterclaimed against a subsidiary of the obligee and against the obligee itself seeking recovery on the lease with the subsidiary. The Circuit Court, Cook County, Walter J. Kowalski, J., rendered judgments on directed verdicts for the obligee and obligors appealed. The Appellate Court, 88 Ill.App.3d 28, 43 Ill.Dec. 681, 410 N.E.2d 681, affirmed in part and reversed in part. Obligors appealed. The Supreme Court, Underwood, J., held that: (1) parol evidence was inadmissible to establish an oral agreement to make payment on the note contingent on the subsidiary's obligations under the lease; (2) the corporate veil could not be pierced so as to hold obligee liable on the lease; (3) a jury question existed as to the amount due under the lease; and (4) the obligee was entitled to recover from obligors the portion of the attorney fees attributable to recovering on the note itself, but not that portion attributable to the balance...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: General Finance Corp. v. Skinner
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana, First District.
Headnote: Indiana courts refuse to recognize corporations as separate entities where facts establish several corporations are acting as same entity.
Document Preview: In action against finance corporation for recovery of benefits under credit disability insurance on loan balance, the Superior Court, Vigo County, Charles K. McCrory, J., awarded default judgment in favor of insured, and finance corporation appealed denial of its amended motion for relief from judgment, alleging insufficient service of process. The Court of Appeals, Neal, P. J., held that since subsidiary corporation did not conduct its own business as independent entity, but was maintained as instrument of finance corporation, service of process on registered agent of subsidiary was sufficiently served notice of action. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Talen's Landing, Inc. v. M/V Venture, II
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit. Unit A
Headnote: Admiralty courts can pierce the corporate veil of corporation in order to reach the "alter egos" of the corporate defendant directly involved, and this is especially true where the near identity of two corporations should be disregarded in order to prevent manifest injustice to third parties, or where the separate identity of two corporations should be disregarded where one corporation becomes the conduit of another.
Document Preview: Owner of boat store brought action against vessel owner and others to recover for fuel and other services provided vessel. The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana, Edward J. Boyle, Sr., J., entered judgment for plaintiff, and defendants appealed. The Court of Appeals, Brown, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) trial court properly admitted testimony explaining that meter tickets from plaintiff's store were based on tenths of a gallon liability, and there was no error factually or legally with trial court's conclusion that the tickets and invoices together constituted a contract between the parties, and (2) evidence that individual defendant totally dominated both corporate defendants, confused corporate records and finances, and failed to follow usual corporate formality supported trial court's action in piercing the corporate veil. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Baker v. Raymond Intern., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit. Unit A
Headnote: To justify extraordinary step of holding dominant shareholder corporation liable for debts of controlled corporation, jury must find that the control amounts to total domination of the subservient corporation to the extent that the subservient corporation manifests no separate corporate interests of its own and functions solely to achieve purposes of the dominant corporation.
Document Preview: Seaman brought action against barge owner to recover for injuries sustained while working on barge. The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana, Morey L. Sear, J., Judge, awarded seaman compensatory damages, and barge owner appealed. The Court of Appeals, Alvin B. Rubin, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) seaman failed to establish barge owner's liability under borrowed servant doctrine; (2) charge did not provide jury with an adequate understanding of factors to be considered in reaching finding holding barge owner liable as seaman's actual Jones Act employer; (3) fact that seaman's nominal employer had complete possession and control of the barge did not absolve barge owner of liability; (4) even if there had been a bareboat charter to the nominal employer, it would not have absolved barge owner of liability for the barge's unseaworthiness; and (5) new trial was granted on issue of seaman's right to maintenance, cure and wages to end of the voyage. Affirmed...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Vallone v. Vallone
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Generally, corporate form will be disregarded where: the corporation is used as a means for perpetrating a fraud; the corporation is organized and operating as a mere "tool" or "business conduit" of another corporation; resort is made to the corporate fiction in order to avoid an existing legal obligation; corporation form is used to achieve or perpetrate a monopoly; corporate structure is used as a vehicle for circumventing a statute; or the fiction is invoked in order to protect crime or justify a wrong.
Document Preview: Former wife appealed from that portion of divorce judgment rendered by the District Court, Harris County, Sam S. Emison, Jr., J., which divided the marital estate. The Court of Civil Appeals, Warren, J., held that: (1) former wife's acceptance of at least some of the benefits of the divorce judgment did not estop her from pursuing the appeal; (2) trial court's finding that transfer of restaurant assets to former husband from his father was a gift was not against great weight and preponderance of the evidence; (3) finding that 47% of stock of the incorporated restaurant was separate property of former husband was not against great weight and preponderance of the evidence; (4) trial court's awarding of virtually all of the parties' income-producing property to former husband and in giving former wife a money judgment was not unfair; (5) trial court did not take into consideration large increment to former husband's separate property by reason of community labor and as a result...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: South Side Bank v. T.S.B. Corp.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Fifth Division.
Headnote: Ownership of capital stock in one corporation by another does not, itself, create an identity of corporate interest between the two companies, nor render the stockholding company the owner of the property of the other nor create the relationship of principal and agent, representative, or alter ego between the two.
Document Preview: Shareholder in a corporation sought a writ of mandamus to compel the corporation to produce for inspection certain corporate records of its subsidiary. The Circuit Court, Cook County, Richard L. Curry, J., dismissed the complaint as insufficient in law, and the shareholder appealed. The Appellate Court, Lorenz, J., held that the shareholder's complaint failed to state a cause of action, where it alleged only that the principal business and substantial and major asset of the corporation was ownership of in excess of 90 percent of the stock of the subsidiary and it did not allege that the subsidiary was a mere alter ego of the corporation or that some fraud had occurred. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Royal Exchange Assur. of America, Inc. v. SS President Adams
Court: United States District Court, W. D. Washington.
Headnote: Where there is near identity between corporations, their separate existences can be disregarded in order to prevent injustice to third party.
Document Preview: Shipper and its insurer brought suit to recover for cargo damage. On carrier's motion to dismiss complaint, to amend pretrial order and to continue trial limited to subject of whether on-deck storage amounted to deviation, the District Court, Beeks, J., held that: (1) treating shipper's insurer and carrier's insurer as one because of their near identity, such insurer, which had paid shipper on cargo damage policy, could not subrogate against carrier whose stevedoring operations it insured under unrelated liability policy for damage allegedly caused to cargo in carrier's capacity as carrier; and (2) shipper's acquiescence in storing arrangement whereby portion of cargo would be stowed on deck created agreement that portion of cargo be carried on deck, and therefore, there was no deviation from contract of carriage as would deprive carrier of its defenses given by Carriage of Goods by Sea Act. Ordered Accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Walker v. Dominick's Finer Foods, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: Legal fiction of distinct corporate existence will be disregarded when necessary to circumvent fraud or where the corporation is so organized and its affairs so conducted as to make it merely an instrument of another corporation.
Document Preview: Personal injury action was brought in which plaintiff claimed he was injured as result of willful and wanton assault and battery committed by employee of defendant. The Circuit Court, Clark County, David Cerda, J., entered judgment on general verdict for plaintiff after vacating judgment entered on answer to special provocation interrogatory in favor of defendant, and defendant appealed. The Appellate Court, Rizzi, J., held that: (1) special interrogatory as to whether plaintiff was guilty of any provocation which was proximate cause of the injury was improper since it did not relate to an ultimate issue in that provocation is not a justification for or a complete defense to an assault and battery action; (2) the special interrogatory was also a nullity since the given definition of provocation could have improperly included mere words; (3) trial court properly refused defendant's tendered instruction with respect to plaintiff's alleged duty to be free from contributory willful...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Walker v. Dominick's Finer Foods, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: A corporation is an entity separate and distinct from its stockholders and from other corporations with which it may be connected; mere ownership of corporate stock in one corporation by another does not create an identity of corporate interest between the two corporations, nor render the stockholding corporation the owner of property of the other, nor create relationship of principal and agent, representative or alter ego between two corporations, nor does identity of officers of two corporations establish identity of corporations.
Document Preview: Personal injury action was brought in which plaintiff claimed he was injured as result of willful and wanton assault and battery committed by employee of defendant. The Circuit Court, Clark County, David Cerda, J., entered judgment on general verdict for plaintiff after vacating judgment entered on answer to special provocation interrogatory in favor of defendant, and defendant appealed. The Appellate Court, Rizzi, J., held that: (1) special interrogatory as to whether plaintiff was guilty of any provocation which was proximate cause of the injury was improper since it did not relate to an ultimate issue in that provocation is not a justification for or a complete defense to an assault and battery action; (2) the special interrogatory was also a nullity since the given definition of provocation could have improperly included mere words; (3) trial court properly refused defendant's tendered instruction with respect to plaintiff's alleged duty to be free from contributory willful...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Flemmer v. Ming
Court: Supreme Court of Montana.
Headnote: A finding of fraud was warranted so as to justify piercing the corporate veil on ground that the corporate defendants were the alter ego of the individual defendant and were without separate identities in that all three of the corporate defendants were closely held family corporations, the officers, stockholders and members of the boards of directors consisted in each case of the same people, registered offices of all the corporations were located in defendant's personal residence, and all three corporate defendants were engaged in the same enterprise.
Document Preview: An action at law was instituted for breach of contract as well as on a claim in equity for fraud. The District Court of the Nineteenth Judicial District, County of Lincoln, Robert M. Holter, J., denied defendants' motion for summary judgment and, thereafter, entered judgment on verdict in favor of plaintiff, and defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Shea, J., held that: (1) claim that corporate defendants were not contractual parties to note was not a basis for establishing their nonliability so as to require dismissal as to them where plaintiff's lawsuit was based not only on an action at law for breach of contract, but also on a claim in equity for trial, and plaintiff alleged, in substance, that defendants acted in concert to perpetuate a fraud, and (2) a finding of fraud was warranted so as to justify piercing the corporate veil on ground that the corporate defendants were the alter ego of the individual defendant and were without separate identities in that...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Starr Farms, Inc. v. Southwestern Elec. Power Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Arkansas.
Headnote: Separate corporate entities will be disregarded only when privilege of transacting business in corporate form has been illegally abused to injury of third person.
Document Preview: Landowners brought actions seeking to enjoin power company from trespassing upon their lands and to recover damages for past trespasses. The Chancery Court, Washington County, John Lineberger, C., in consolidated actions dismissed complaints for want of equity, and landowners appealed. The Supreme Court, George Rose Smith, J., held that power company, a foreign corporation, was entitled to use its wholly owned subsidiary, a domestic corporation, to condemn right-of-way so that power company itself could construct its transmission lines upon property of landowners. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Adams v. Associates Corp. of North America
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Ordinarily, several corporations retain their distinct identities notwithstanding fact that they have stockholders and officers in common or that one corporation owns stock in the other.
Document Preview: Parent corporation appealed from a judgment of the 15th Judicial District Court, Lafayette Parish, Lucien C. Bertrand, Jr., J., which required it to pay termination benefits to a former employee of a wholly owned subsidiary's wholly owned subsidiary. The Court of Appeal, Guidry, J., held that employee of wholly owned subsidiary of wholly owned subsidiary of parent corporation, which administered all personnel policies and programs for the several corporations and which sold employee's employer, would be treated as an employee of parent corporation and was therefore entitled to termination pay under provision of parent's human resources policy authorizing termination pay for reduction in staff. Affirmed. Swift, J., filed dissenting opinion and voted to grant a rehearing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Adams v. Associates Corp. of North America
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Court will look beyond mere technical separate entity of corporations where one corporation, by stock control of another, interlocking directors, and having same general executive officers, operates the other corporation as a mere agency or instrumentality of the dominant corporation in furtherance of business of dominant corporation and as part of one system and in such a case, if subservient corporation incurs an obligation growing out of its operations under such relationship and enforcement of that obligation is only available and effective against dominant corporation, court will ignore fiction of separate, corporate legal existence of the two corporations and hold the dominant corporation.
Document Preview: Parent corporation appealed from a judgment of the 15th Judicial District Court, Lafayette Parish, Lucien C. Bertrand, Jr., J., which required it to pay termination benefits to a former employee of a wholly owned subsidiary's wholly owned subsidiary. The Court of Appeal, Guidry, J., held that employee of wholly owned subsidiary of wholly owned subsidiary of parent corporation, which administered all personnel policies and programs for the several corporations and which sold employee's employer, would be treated as an employee of parent corporation and was therefore entitled to termination pay under provision of parent's human resources policy authorizing termination pay for reduction in staff. Affirmed. Swift, J., filed dissenting opinion and voted to grant a rehearing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Picture Lake Campground, Inc. v. Holiday Inns, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E. D. Virginia, Richmond Division.
Headnote: Where officers and directors of corporation determined that two corporations were necessary, one to own and lease certain property and one to manage and operate a recreational campground on the property, the officers and directors of the two corporations were thereafter bound by the disadvantages as well as the advantages of separate incorporation and it was irrelevant whether the initial decision was made for liability or tax purposes.
Document Preview: Virginia corporation that was a franchisee in a recreational vehicle campground system and its sister corporation that owned the land on which the campground was operated brought suit against franchisor to obtain damages. On motions to dismiss, the District Court, Warriner, J., held that: (1) the complaint did not state a claim for relief with respect to the alleged breach of a commitment agreement; (2) since the sister corporation that owned the property was not a party to or in privity with the license agreement between franchisor and franchisee, the corporation was dismissed from count alleging breach of the license agreement; (3) the corporation that owned the property was not entitled to sue for tortious injury to business or property based on allegations that its business and property interests were intertwined with and dependent on the success of the franchise recreational vehicle campground system; (4) there was no cause of action under the Virginia statute which makes it...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Milgo Electronic Corp. v. United Business Communications, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Proof of fraud is not a necessary element in finding an alter ego relationship between corporations.
Document Preview: Appeal was taken from a judgment of the United States District Court for the District of Kansas, George Templar, J., which found that defendants had infringed plaintiff's patent. The Court of Appeals held that: (1) United States Patent No. 3,524,023 which disclosed and claimed a high-speed data modem system intended to operate over ordinary unconditioned switched telephone lines was valid; (2) United States Patent Nos. 3,590,381 and 3,643,023, which were follow-on patents that improved detection techniques by relating data representing phase angles in a squared intermediate frequency at center sampling times to digital counts in a high-speed binary counter, were also valid; (3) defendants infringed plaintiff's patents; (4) the District Court's conclusion that the defendant Maryland corporation was the mere instrumentality, alter ego or agency of the defendant Kansas corporation was not clearly erroneous; (5) the trial court properly awarded damages for lost profits; (6) the...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: City of Paterson v. Fargo Realty Inc.
Court: District Court of New Jersey, Passaic County.
Headnote: In analyzing whether notice given to one corporate entity is sufficient as to another corporate entity, court must pierce multiplicity of formalities and relationships to determine whether particular corporate form is shield behind which injustice is sought to be done by those who control the corporation.
Document Preview: A city brought suit to obtain a personal judgment against two corporations for the entire cost of demolition of a fire-damaged building. On cross motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Saunders, J. S. C. (temporarily assigned), held that: (1) where owner did not abate nuisance after notice from city, city was not precluded from total indemnification for cost of abating nuisance, through value of property before and after demolition was less than amount of demolition lien and assessment, and collection of full assessment did not deprive owner of due process and (2) where notice to abate nuisance was served upon one corporation and premises were deeded by such corporation to another on same day notice was served, and relationship between such two close corporations compelled court to conclude that both had notice and neither did anything whatsoever once it had received such knowledge, failure to abate nuisance was mutual, and liability of corporations would likewise be...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Textile Industries Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S. D. Florida.
Headnote: Under Florida law, separate identities of two or more corporations will be disregarded on showing that one corporation is a "mere instrumentality" of the other and that the corporation is a device or sham to mislead creditors or exists for fraudulent purposes.
Document Preview: Trustee in Chapter 11 proceeding filed complaint to determine validity, priority and extent of various liens on debtor's property. The Bankruptcy Court, Thomas C. Britton, J., held that: (1) trustee failed to establish that corporation, which was engaged in the same line of business as the debtor at the same location and which utilized some of the same employees and was owned and controlled by the same principal, was the debtor's alter ego and that six knitting machines sold to the corporation while the proceedings were pending were therefore debtor's property, and (2) there was no evidence supporting claimed landlord's lien with respect to such property. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Norton v. Integral Corp.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: Generally, separate entity of corporations will be observed by the courts, even in instances where one may dominate or control the other, or may even treat it as a mere department, instrumentality, or agency of the other.
Document Preview: Former employee appealed from action of 155th District Court, Fayette County, Paul Huser, J., which issued a temporary injunction prohibiting him from violating terms of noncompetition covenant entered into with his former employer. The Court of Civil Appeals, O'Quinn, J., held that where corporate employer, which was engaged in the manufacturing and the sale of irrigation cable as well as other products and which obtained contractual agreement from employee not to compete in sales of competitive equipment for three years after termination of employment, underwent structural changes whereby another corporation controlled by majority shareholder of corporate employer was created and designated to take over all sales of irrigation cable, employee could not be enjoined from selling irrigation cable after termination of his employment but could be enjoined from engaging in those business activities in which corporate employer remained involved. Affirmed as modified.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Wolf v. Little John Corp. of Liberia
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Generally, corporate form will be disregarded where corporation is used as means for perpetuating fraud, where the corporation is organized and operating as mere "tool" or "business conduit" of another corporation, where resort is made to corporate fiction in order to avoid existing legal obligation, where the corporate form is used to achieve or perpetuate monopoly, where corporate structure is used as vehicle for circumventing statute, or where the fiction is invoked in order to protect crime or justify wrong.
Document Preview: Holder brought suit on promissory note against corporate maker and shareholders-officers for whom corporation was alleged alter ego. The District Court, Harris County, Richard Millard, J., entered judgment on jury verdict, and holder appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Wallace, J., held that: (1) where person who signed note was president of both corporations with same name, he and his two sisters were only directors of both corporations, resolution of the board of directors of one of the corporations authorized such person to execute note, the note was executed by all three directors, holder acknowledged reading such resolution, such person was authorized to sign the note as president of one of the similarly named corporations, and thus holder could not recover from such person on basis that there existed two principals with identical names and the note did not indicate one intended to be named so as to be equivalent to naming no principal and rendering person...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Roylex, Inc. v. Langson Bros. Const. Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Generally, corporate form will be disregarded if it is used as means for perpetrating fraud, if corporation is organized and operated as mere tool or business conduit of another corporation, if resort is made to corporate fiction to avoid existing legal obligation, if corporate form is used to achieve or perpetuate monopoly, if corporate structure is used as vehicle for circumventing a statute, or if the fiction is invoked to protect crime or justify wrong.
Document Preview: Concrete subcontractor sued general contractor to recover for amounts allegedly due under contract for work done on townhouse project. The District Court, Harris County, Wm. N. Blanton, Jr., J., entered judgment for plaintiff and it appealed and on crosspoint defendants asserted that plaintiff's cause of action was barred by limitations. The Court of Civil Appeals, Peden, J., held that: (1) although there was some confusion as to whether progress payments made to plaintiff were credited to correct account, where the only questionable bookkeeping entry did adversely affect defendant which was furnished means of ascertaining with reasonable certainty extent of its liability, the plaintiff was entitled to prejudgment interest on amount awarded; (2) forfeiture of defendant corporation's corporate charter did not make shareholders or officers personally liable on the contract which had been entered into almost three years earlier and on which work had been completed before the charter...

Title: Board of Transp. v. Martin
Court: Supreme Court of North Carolina.
Headnote: "Corporation" is an entity distinct from shareholders which own it whether the owner of the corporation is another corporation, single individual or group of individuals.
Document Preview: Board of Transportation brought action to have defendants' land condemned for highway purposes. Pilston Godwin, J., entered order predicated on findings that the two adjacent parcels constituted a unit for purposes of determining damages and that corporation and trustee were proper parties defendant to the action, and, Board appealed. On petition for discretionary review, the Supreme Court, Britt, J., held that: (1) ownership of such parcels by individual defendants and corporation did not involve a unity of ownership so as to permit parcels to be treated as unified tract for purpose of assessing condemnation damages; (2) even if ownership of parcels by those parties involved unity of ownership, parcels could not...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Federal Ins. Co. v. Maritime Shipping Agencies, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Second Division.
Headnote: A corporation may be alter ego of another corporation and where this occurs distinct corporate entity will be disregarded and two corporations will be treated as one.
Document Preview: Judgment creditor sought to obtain satisfaction of judgment against corporate judgment debtor in supplementary proceeding against related corporation and owners of corporations. The Circuit Court, Cook County, Richard Samuels, J., granted judgment creditor's motion for summary judgment, finding a unity of interest and ownership among defendants and that related corporation and owners were alter egos of judgment debtor. On appeal, the Appellate Court, Downing, J., held that: (1) defendants were not denied their right to a trial on petition for turnover order by entry of summary judgment; (2) trial court did not err in striking portions of affidavit of owner filed in support of response to judgment creditor's motion for summary judgment; (3) related corporation and owners were alter egos of judgment debtor and were liable for its obligations, and (4) judgment creditor was entitled to recover reasonable costs and attorney fees incurred in defending frivolous appeal. Affirmed and...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Skouras v. Admiralty Enterprises, Inc.
Court: Court of Chancery of Delaware,New Castle County.
Headnote: Mere control and even total ownership of one corporation by another is not sufficient to warrant the disregard of a separate corporate entity.
Document Preview: Stockholder sought order granting him the right to inspect certain books and records of closely held family corporation as well as books of corporation's affiliates. The Court of Chancery, in and for New Castle County, Marvel, Chancellor, held that: (1) technical defect in stockholder's demand could not be permitted to defeat his claim, and (2) where stockholder's primary purpose in obtaining inspection was not to compel a buy-out of his holdings but was to rally support to his battle against what he believed to be corporate acts detrimental to corporation and consequently to himself as minority stockholder of such corporation, he would be granted right to inspect books and records. Order to be entered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Rea v. An-Son Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W. D. Oklahoma.
Headnote: Generally, fact that corporation owns all or majority of stock of another corporation does not destroy identity of latter as distinct legal entity.
Document Preview: Texas citizen, who was injured while working aboard a drilling tender vessel in Venezuela, brought suits against an American parent corporation and a subsidiary, which had their principal places of business in Oklahoma, and against Venezuelan subsidiary which moved for dismissal. The District Court, Thompson, J., held that, for purposes of determining its personal jurisdiction over Venezuelan subsidiary, record disclosed that both of the other corporations had exercised sufficient control over Venezuelan corporation to enable court to disregard separate identities of each and to find that their acts might be imputed to Venezuelan corporation to give court jurisdiction under Oklahoma long-arm statute over that corporation which could be said to be doing business in Oklahoma. Motions to dismiss denied.

Court: United States District Court, W.D. Kentucky, Louisville Division.
Headnote: Fact that none of the three defendant corporations paid any compensation to their directors was properly considered in disregarding the corporate shield.

Title: Fuls v. Shastina Properties, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, corporation is treated as being alter ego of another corporation only if there is such unity of interest and ownership that individuality of corporation and owner or owners of its stock has ceased.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Urbanational Developers, Inc. v. Shamrock Engineering, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana, Third District.
Headnote: Fiction of corporate entity may be disregarded where one corporation is so organized and controlled and its affairs are so conducted as to make it a mere instrumentality or conduit of another corporation.
