Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Bendix Home Systems, Inc. v. Hurston Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Florida rule requiring that, before separate identities of two or more corporations will be disregarded, showing must be made that one corporation was "mere instrumentality" of other and that instrument corporation was used to mislead creditor for fraudulent purposes is not materially different from requirements of New York rule under which person seeking to set aside corporate identity must show that individual corporation sought to be held liable completely "dominated" other corporation and used that domination to commit unjust act or wrong.

Scott, J., entered judgment for plaintiff on the principal claim and against the plaintiff on the counterclaim, and appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals held that: (1) under Florida law, the separate identities of two or more corporations will be disregarded only on a showing that one corporation is the mere instrumentality of the other and that the corporation is a device or sham to mislead creditors or exists for fraudulent purposes, and (2) where the plaintiff failed to show that the parent corporation exercised an...

Title: Farkar Co. v. R. A. Hanson DISC., Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S. D. New York.
Headnote: Under Washington law, a court will ignore nominal, corporate separation when there is such a commingling of property rights or interests as to render it apparent that corporations are intended to function as one, and, further, to regard them as separate would aid the consummation of a fraud or wrong upon others.
Document Preview: Buyer of excavation equipment filed petition to compel arbitration of dispute arising under contract for sale of excavation equipment, and sellers moved to dismiss. The District Court, Lasker, J., held that: (1) provision in purchase agreement to the effect that sellers would in no event be liable for consequential damages did not remove buyer's claim for consequential damages from subject matter jurisdiction of arbitrators; (2) district court would not direct arbitrators to make specific findings concerning clause in purchase agreement to the effect that sellers would in no event be liable for consequential damages, and (3) where wholly owned subsidiary which signed agreement to sell excavating equipment was alter ego of parent corporation, subsidiary's officers and directors were identical to those of parent, subsidiary had no employees, parent's personnel performed all of subsidiary's functions, and subsidiary had no inventory, buyer under purchase...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re County Green Ltd. Partnership
Court: United States District Court, W. D. Virginia, Charlottesville Division.
Headnote: Corporate entity will be disregarded when it is so organized and its affairs so conducted as to make it a mere instrumentality or adjunct of another corporation, person, or business enterprise and there has been a fraud on creditors.
Document Preview: On appeal of mechanic's lienors from a judgment of the bankruptcy court holding invalid the liens on certain property owned by the bankrupt debtor, the District Court, Turk, Chief Judge, held that the bankruptcy court's findings that development corporation, the general contractor for debtor's apartment construction project, was not the alter ego of the debtor and that the claimed mechanic's lienors did not furnish labor and materials to the owner were clearly erroneous, since an examination of the manner in which the affairs of the development corporation were conducted made it apparent that it had no separate existence of its own and was in all respects a mere fiction and the alter ego of the debtor; e. g., its policies were not directed to its own interests but to those of the debtor and the debtor's general partners, it was undercapitalized, and it failed to keep reliable records. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Centurian Corp. v. Fiberchem, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Utah.
Headnote: Essential to defense of alter ego is that corporations of similar names were so used as to confuse or deceive, that there is basic unfairness, something akin to fraud or injustice, which placed person dealing with corporations at disadvantage or worked injustice.
Document Preview: Action was brought against corporate seller for return of sum advanced by corporate buyer under contract to purchase materials to be used in manufacture of boats. The Third District Court, Salt Lake County, Stewart M. Hanson, Sr., J., entered judgment in favor of buyer and seller appealed. The Supreme Court, Crockett, J., held that evidence supported order rejecting defense of alter ego asserted to justify seller's refusal to deliver materials or return buyer's advance payment on theory that the money could properly be applied to debt previously owed to seller by another corporation with similar name and same original incorporators and shareholders as buyer. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Matter of Bowen Transports, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Doctrine of piercing the corporate veil will be invoked only when there is control by one corporation to such degree that the other has become its mere instrumentality, when fraud or wrong has been committed by the one corporation through the other, and when unjust loss or injury to the claimant results.
Document Preview: Creditor appealed from order of the District Court for the Eastern District of Illinois, James L. Foreman, J., which sustained objection of debtor to claim filed by the creditor. The Court of Appeals, Harlington Wood, Jr., Circuit Judge, held that state court proceedings had not resulted in a lien in favor of the creditor on certain amounts being paid to the debtor; that the debtor was not the maker of eight notes which were basis for the judgment against a related corporation; that there was no basis for application of doctrine of piercing the corporate veil so as to permit creditor to recover from debtor amounts which were owed to it from related corporation which had also been involved in bankruptcy proceedings. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Key v. Robert M. Duke Ins. Agency
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: When articles of incorporation are filed pursuant to statute, new corporation is created even though new corporation may be identical to previously created corporation in many respects.
Document Preview: Automobile passengers brought action against driver and owner of automobile in which they were riding and uninsured driver of other automobile charging negligence and against insurers charging negligence in the failure to have uninsured motorist coverage in effect on automobile at time of accident. The matter of uninsured motorist coverage was severed by the trial court. The Circuit Court, Elmore County, Joe Macon, J., held that there was no duty to provide uninsured motorist coverage, and appeal was taken. On motion to dismiss the appeal, the Supreme Court, Bloodworth, J., held that where trial court expressly granted severance on question of uninsured motorist coverage, judgment rendered as to such coverage was independent of original action and appealable; and that although uninsured motorist coverage was rejected by named corporate insured which was created in 1966 and which was composed of one county, where new corporation which was similar in many respects but composed of...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Port Chester Elec. Const. Co. v. Atlas
Court: Court of Appeals of New York.
Headnote: Mere fact that one person was controlling principal of more than one corporation was insufficient to justify disregarding corporate form, and where such person himself carefully respected separate identities of the corporations, and each corporation was pursuing its separate corporate business, rather than purely personal business of shareholder, corporate veils were not to be pierced.
Document Preview: A subcontractor brought action to recover the amount of its judgment against a contractor from the corporate landower, the controlling principal of the landowner and several other corporations controlled by the same principal. The Supreme Court, Trial Term, Westchester County, George M. Fanelli, J., pierced the corporate veil of the various corporate defendants and granted relief to the subcontractor as a third-party beneficiary. The Appellate Division affirmed, 47 A.D.2d 849, 368 N.Y.S.2d 814. Appeal was taken by permission. The Court of Appeals, Jasen, J., held that the lower courts had placed reliance upon improper theories, but that relief could be granted through converting the plenary action into a special proceeding. The general contractor's right to reimbursement from the property owner, for the amount of a judgment against the property owner, could be enforced by the subcontractor, and, in similar fashion, the subcontractor could enforce any other cause of action that the...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Cornwell v. Williams Bros. Lumber Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia, Division No. 3.
Headnote: In absence of any evidence to contrary, corporations which were located in same building but on different floors leased separately from landlord and which maintained separate banking accounts, separate equipment, separate records and separate insurance and which filed separate tax returns and employed separate personnel on separate payrolls were separate corporations though two out of eight directors were common to the corporations and three of eight shareholders were common to both. Code, § 81A-156(b).
Document Preview: In an action arising out of an automobile collision, defendants moved for summary judgment and the motion was granted by the Fulton County Superior Court, John S. Langford, Jr. J. Plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeals, Deen, P.J., held that in absence of any evidence to the contrary, corporations which were located in the same building but on different floors leased separately from the landlord and which maintained separate banking accounts, separate equipment, separate records and separate insurance and which filed separate tax returns and employed separate personnel on separate payrolls were separate corporations though two out of eight directors were common to the corporations and three of eight shareholders were common to both. Judgments affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: International Union, United Auto., Aerospace and Agr. Implement Workers of America (UAW) v. Cardwell Mfg. Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Ordinarily, several corporations retain their distinct identities notwithstanding that they have stockholders and officers in common or that one corporation owns stock in others, creating subsidiary or affiliated corporations, but concept or fiction of distinct identity will not be recognized where one corporation is so organized and controlled and its business conducted in such a manner as to make it a mere agency, instrumentality, agent or alter ego of other corporation.
Document Preview: International and local unions and bargaining unit employees brought action against employer and its parent corporation following failure of employer to meet its pension plan obligations under agreements with unions. The District Court, Theis, J., held that corporate veil would be pierced and parent as well as subsidiary employer would be held liable for the pension fund obligations where subsidiary employer was a mere agent, instrumentality and alter ego of parent, parent's directors, officers and employees, acting within the scope of their employment and authority, intentionally interfered with known contractual rights of unions and directly caused violations of contracts within meaning of the Labor Management Relations Act, and where, in causing such violation, officers and employees of parent and subsidiary acted in concert in manner constituting civil conspiracy; and that where, inter alia, considered conduct of the two corporations was carried on in bad faith and for...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Omaha Pollution Control Corp. v. Carver-Greenfield Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Nebraska.
Headnote: Under the "instrumentality" or "alter ego" doctrines, when a corporation is so dominated by another corporation that the subservient corporation becomes a mere instrument, and is really indistinct from the controlling corporation, the corporate veil of the dominated corporation will be disregarded if it would result in injustice to retain the corporate veil.
Document Preview: City and its pollution control corporation brought action against contractor seller of sewage treatment plant which was designed to remove certain packinghouse waste from the city sewer system so as to permit the sewage to be handled by city's already extant sewage treatment plant and which was also designed to convert the materials removed from the system into marketable products and against a related corporation for breach of warranties with respect to the construction and sale of the treatment plant. The District Court, Van Sickle, J., held that the contractor seller impliedly warranted the merchantability and fitness for particular purpose of the plant; that the warranties were breached; that the city could recover for the breaches as a third-party beneficiary of the implied warranties; that the contractor seller was entitled to recover on its counterclaim for amounts not paid for work pursuant to change orders and was also entitled to recover insurance loss proceeds resulting...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Fisher Controls Co., Inc. v. Com.
Court: Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Corporation, whose assets were absorbed on date of its legal expiration into separate corporation and, simultaneously therewith, were transferred to newly formed corporation, and newly formed corporation were not single continuing corporate entity but rather were two distinct corporate taxpayers; subsequent appearance of first corporation's assets after its legal expiration within corporate framework of newly formed corporation was simply result of transplant and could not give continued vitality to first corporation's legal existence. 72 P.S. § 3420a et seq.
Document Preview: Plaintiff corporation filed de novo administrative agency appeals under 1104 Fiscal Code from adverse decision of the Board of Finance and Revenue. The Commonwealth Court, Nos. 594 and 840 C.D.1972, Bowman, President Judge, held that corporation, whose assets were absorbed on date of its legal expiration into separate corporation and, simultaneously therewith, were transferred to newly formed corporation, and newly formed corporation were not single continuing corporate entity but rather were distinct separate taxpayers; that statute imposing 12% Corporate net income tax was applicable to both calendar year taxpayers and fiscal year taxpayers; and that applicability of statute was in no way diminished despite fact plaintiffs' respective calendar and fiscal periods were abbreviated. Appeals dismissed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Waff Bros, Inc. v. Bank of North Carolina, N.A.
Court: Supreme Court of North Carolina.
Headnote: Where two corporations owned by one individual are so operated that they are mere instrumentalities or alter egos of the sole or dominant shareholder and a shield for his activities in violation of the declared public policy or statute of the state, or for the purpose of fraud, the corporate entities will be disregarded and the corporations and the shareholder treated as one and the same person.
Document Preview: Holder of judgment lien on tract of land brought action to restrain execution sale of the land under another judgment lien, to have such other judgment lien declared extinguished, or in the alternative, to require foreclosing bank to exhaust other security before proceeding with foreclosure. The Superior Court, Pasquotank County, Russell J. Lanier, J., denied preliminary injunction and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeals, 25 N.C.App. 517, 214 S.E.2d 261, affirmed and certiorari was granted. The Supreme Court, Lake, J., held that showing that execution sale of property would not produce adequate sums to pay any appreciable portion of plaintiff's judgment claim with interest was a sufficient showing of reasonable apprehension of irreparable harm; that if debtor corporation and corporation to which debtor conveyed the land were so controlled by the sole stockholder as to make transferee the mere alter ego of transferor, transfer of judgment to transferee had the same effect as...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Republic Petroleum Corp. v. U.S.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: In determining whether corporations owned by individual taxpayer were separate taxable entities, the court must ascertain whether the taxpayer's corporations "carried on business."
Document Preview: In consolidated actions, taxpayer and his wife and corporation sought refund of income taxes for the years 1959-1966. The District Court, Heebe, Chief Judge, held, inter alia, that certain of refund claims were not barred by the statute of limitations; that the individual taxpayer was not entitled to treat the sale of certain mineral leases to the corporation which he controlled as an installment sale; that certain of taxpayer's corporations did sufficient business to be recognized as separate taxable entities; that the amounts paid by corporation in settlement of litigation did not constitute income to the individual taxpayer and that the corporation was not entitled to deduct as a business deduction an amount which it paid to the individual to reimburse him for all expenditures he might have made in connection with certain litigation. Judgment in accordance with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Westcott Const. Corp. v. Cumberland Const. Co., Inc.
Court: Appeals Court of Massachusetts, Norfolk.
Headnote: That two corporations occupy common premises is not, standing alone, sufficient to merge them into one or to make either the agent of the other.
Document Preview: Bill was brought for declaratory relief in which corporate general bidder sought to establish propriety of bid submitted by it to joint board of water commissioners of two towns. The Superior Court, Norfolk County, Griffin, J., decreed the bid to be valid, and another bidder appealed. The Appeals Court, Armstrong, J., held that the general bid was not invalid on theory that corporate general bidder and corporate subbidder were essentially the same entity so that general bidder was therefore prohibited by statute from listing any other subbidder in general bid. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Westcott Const. Corp. v. Cumberland Const. Co., Inc.
Court: Appeals Court of Massachusetts, Norfolk.
Headnote: Fact of common ownership and control of two corporations and that they occupy same premises is of importance in determining whether they are merged into one or either is the agent of the other only where they combine in such a way as to permit conclusion that agency or similar relationship exists between the entities.
Document Preview: Bill was brought for declaratory relief in which corporate general bidder sought to establish propriety of bid submitted by it to joint board of water commissioners of two towns. The Superior Court, Norfolk County, Griffin, J., decreed the bid to be valid, and another bidder appealed. The Appeals Court, Armstrong, J., held that the general bid was not invalid on theory that corporate general bidder and corporate subbidder were essentially the same entity so that general bidder was therefore prohibited by statute from listing any other subbidder in general bid. Title: Siboney Corp. v. Dresser Industries, Inc.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: If association between companies was merely a device to defraud creditors, fiction of separate entities will be disregarded.
Document Preview: Seller brought suit against corporate buyer and buyer's former parent corporation to recover for merchandise sold and delivered on account to buyer. The District Court, Harris County, W. Ervin James, J., entered judgment in seller's favor and parent corporation appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Evans, J., held that where seller had had no prior dealings with buyer, a wholly owned subsidiary, which previously had been division of parent corporation, and there was no indication that, at time seller furnished merchandise to buyer, it was misled as to buyer's incorporated status, parent was not liable to seller for the merchandise on basis of failure of parent to give statutory notice of incorporation of buyer and that, even though someone in seller's offices prepared invoice showing that corporate buyer was a division of parent and that information generally came from the buyer, in absence of showing that parent had authorized or knowingly permitted anyone at buyer to represent...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: U.S. v. State Tax Commission of State of Miss.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate fiction is not to be disregarded because of mutuality of corporate names, stockholders and officers, under Mississippi law.
Document Preview: The United States brought suit on behalf of Mississippi Band of Choctaw Indians to enjoin the Mississippi State Tax Commission from assessing, collecting, and attempting to collect sales taxes from a construction company which was formed at request of tribal council. The United States District Court for the Southern District of Mississippi, at Jackson, William Harold Cox, J., entered judgment granting a permanent injunction, and the Commission and the sheriff of Neshoba County appealed. The Court of Appeals, Coleman, Circuit Judge, held that the construction company was an entity separate and distinct from the Mississippi Band of Choctaw Indians, the group named as beneficiary of the exemption in Mississippi's sales tax statutes, that the United States was attempting to lend its name to a suit on behalf of a private corporation and was not the real party in interest, and that tribal character of Choctaw Indians in Mississippi came to an end when the United States Senate ratified...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Ampex Corp. v. Office Electronics, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Fourth Division.
Headnote: One corporation may be treated as the alter ego of another if there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the individuality of one corporation has ceased, and if the observance of the fiction of separate existence would under the circumstances sanction a fraud by promoting injustice.
Document Preview: Plaintiff corporation brought suit against electronics corporation and marketing corporation created by the electronics corporation to recover value of magnetic tapes sold by plaintiff to both defendants. The Circuit Court, Cook County, Wilbert F. Crowley, J., entered judgment on the verdict in favor of the plaintiff and against both defendants. The electronics corporation appealed. The Appellate Court, Dieringer, J., held that where two out of three directors of the marketing corporation were officers of the electronics corporation, the electronics corporation owned 51% Of the stock in the marketing corporation, the electronics corporation capitalized the marketing corporation, and received merchandise, along with monthly statements and invoices from the plaintiff, principle of piercing the corporate veil was properly invoked, and that court properly instructed the jury and properly refused to submit special interrogatories which did not relate to an ultimate issue of fact....

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Quarles v. Fuqua Industries, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: One company's exercise over a second corporation of a controlling influence through stock ownership does not make the second corporation an agent of the first.
Document Preview: Class action was brought against a nonresident corporation and others to recover compensatory and punitive damages for fraudulently inducing plaintiffs to enter into training course contracts and enroll in vocational training schools. The United States District Court for the District of Kansas, George Templar, J., sustained nonresident corporation's motion to quash and dismiss, and appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals, Hill, Circuit Judge, held that district court had no jurisdiction over nonresident corporation, notwithstanding alter ego and agency theories relied upon by plaintiffs. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Soderberg Advertising, Inc. v. Kent-Moore Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 1.
Headnote: Even if, in order to disregard corporate entities, the dominant corporation must control and use the other as a mere tool and even if there must also be a confusion of identities such as to work a fraud upon third parties, doctrine of disregarding corporate entities was properly applied as to two corporations, one of which had an option to purchase the other, and which had all the power of a shareholder plus powers of life and death over the optionor corporation through fiscal control and the power to appoint directors.
Document Preview: Advertising agency which had done work for one corporation brought action against that corporation and second corporation, which at one time had an option to purchase the first corporation. The Superior Court, King County, Frank D. Howard, J., entered judgment in favor of advertising agency and optionee corporation appealed. The Court of Appeals, Horowitz, J., held that evidence sustained finding that advertising agency had been led to believe that optionee corporation would be responsible for debts of the optionor corporation; that doctrine of disregarding the corporate entity was properly applied; and that statute of frauds provisions relating to agreements to answer for the debts of another were inapplicable. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Brown Bros. Equipment Co. v. State
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan, Division No. 2.
Headnote: The fiction of a separate corporate entity as to each corporation will not be extended where to do so would not serve the ends of justice.
Document Preview: Suit to recover for breach by State of agreement to settle or lessen damages to plaintiff's business resulting from condemnation of underlying land. The Court of Claims, William John Beer, Circuit Judge for Oakland County, entered judgment in favor of plaintiff, and the State appealed. The Court of Appeals, Bashara, P.J., held that findings as to existence of agreement and its subsequent breach by State were not clearly erroneous, and that an award for loss of future profits was proper, but that relocation costs representing damages incurred in reliance on promise to perform were not recoverable where plaintiff did not lack knowledge of breach and did not attempt to minimize its damages in face of such knowledge. Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: U.S. v. Wood
Court: United States Customs Court, Third Division, Appellate Term.
Headnote: A corporation does not become an agent of another corporation merely because a majority of the voting shares is held by the other.

The...

Title: U.S. v. Wood
Court: United States Customs Court, Third Division, Appellate Term.
Headnote: If a corporation holds stock of another not for the purpose of participating in the affairs of the other corporation, in the normal and usual manner, but for the purpose of control, so that the subsidiary corporation is used as a mere instrumentality or department of the stockholding company, the subsidiary will be considered an agent or alter ego of the stockholding company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Krivo Indus. Supply Co. v. National Distillers & Chemical Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: If dominant corporation misuses subservient corporation's corporate form by using it for dominant corporation's own purposes, the courts will look through the forms to the realities of the relation between the corporations as if the corporate agency did not exist and will deal with them as justice of case may require.
Document Preview: Actions by ten creditors of reorganized corporate debtor against its major creditor on ground that defendant had dominated debtor corporation to extent that it became mere instrumentality of the defendant. The United States District Court for the Northern District of Alabama, Sam C. Pointer, Jr., J., directed verdict in favor of defendant and plaintiffs appealed. The Court of Appeals, Roney, Circuit Judge, held that fact that defendant as major creditor was vested with capacity to assert great pressure and influence on debtor did not constitute sufficient control to make defendant liable for sums debtor owed to plaintiffs and that, in absence of showing actual operative total control, defendant was not liable. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Krivo Indus. Supply Co. v. National Distillers & Chemical Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Two elements are essential for liability of dominant corporation for acts or omissions of subservient corporation under the "instrumentality" doctrine: first, the dominant corporation must have controlled the subservient corporation, and second, the dominant corporation must have proximately caused plaintiff harm through misuse of that control.

Affirmed.

Title: Krivo Indus. Supply Co. v. National Distillers & Chemical Corp.

Headnote: For purposes of predicating liability of allegedly dominant corporation for acts or omissions of allegedly subservient corporation on basis of "instrumentality" theory, a creditor-debtor relationship between dominant corporation and subservient corporation does not per se constitute control necessary to establish liability.

Headnote: Generally, mere loan of money by one corporation to another does not automatically make the lender liable for acts and omissions of the borrower.

Title: Krivo Indus. Supply Co. v. National Distillers & Chemical Corp.

Headnote: If lending corporation becomes so involved with debtor corporation that it is in fact actively managing the debtor's affairs, then quantum of control necessary to support liability of lending corporation for acts and omissions of debtor under the "instrumentality" theory may be achieved.

Title: Krivo Indus. Supply Co. v. National Distillers & Chemical Corp.

Headnote: To predicate liability of allegedly dominant corporation for acts or omissions of allegedly subservient corporation on basis of a creditor-debtor relationship between them, there must be strong showing that creditor assumed actual, participatory, total control of debtor; its merely taking an active part in management of debtor corporation does not automatically constitute such control.
