Title: Krivo Indus. Supply Co. v. National Distillers & Chemical Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Control required for liability of dominant corporation under the "instrumentality" rule amounts to total domination of subservient corporation, to extent that it manifests no separate corporate interest of its own and functions solely to achieve purposes of dominant corporation.
Document Preview: Actions by ten creditors of reorganized corporate debtor against its major creditor on ground that defendant had dominated debtor corporation to extent that it became mere instrumentality of the defendant. The United States District Court for the Northern District of Alabama, Sam C. Pointer, Jr., J., directed verdict in favor of defendant and plaintiffs appealed. The Court of Appeals, Roney, Circuit Judge, held that fact that defendant as major creditor was vested with capacity to assert great pressure and influence on debtor did not constitute sufficient control to make defendant liable for sums debtor owed to plaintiffs and that, in absence of showing actual operative total control, defendant was not liable. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Krivo Indus. Supply Co. v. National Distillers & Chemical Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: To predicate liability of allegedly dominant corporation for acts or omissions of allegedly subservient corporation under the "instrumentality" theory, there must be fraud or injustice proximately resulting from misuse of control of subservient corporation by dominant corporation, but actual fraud is not necessary predicate for disregarding the corporate form and courts may decline to recognize corporate existence whenever recognition of corporate form would extend principle of incorporation beyond its legitimate purposes and would produce injustices or inequitable consequences.
Document Preview: Actions by ten creditors of reorganized corporate debtor against its major creditor on ground that defendant had dominated debtor corporation to extent that it became mere instrumentality of the defendant. The United States District Court for the Northern District of Alabama, Sam C. Pointer, Jr., J., directed verdict in favor of defendant and plaintiffs appealed. The Court of Appeals, Roney, Circuit Judge, held that fact that defendant as major creditor was vested with capacity to assert great pressure and influence on debtor did not constitute sufficient control to make defendant liable for sums debtor owed to plaintiffs and that, in absence of showing actual operative total control, defendant was not liable. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Krivo Indus. Supply Co. v. National Distillers & Chemical Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: In cases in which liability of allegedly dominant corporation for acts or omissions of allegedly subservient corporation is based on theory that subservient corporation was instrumentality of dominant corporation, which had actual, operative, total control of subservient corporation, court must take broad approach to question of control, examining all evidence to ascertain if allegedly subservient corporation in fact had no separate corporate purposes or existence.
Document Preview: Actions by ten creditors of reorganized corporate debtor against its major creditor on ground that defendant had dominated debtor corporation to extent that it became mere instrumentality of the defendant. The United States District Court for the Northern District of Alabama, Sam C. Pointer, Jr., J., directed verdict in favor of defendant and plaintiffs appealed. The Court of Appeals, Roney, Circuit Judge, held that fact that defendant as major creditor was vested with capacity to assert great pressure and influence on debtor did not constitute sufficient control to make defendant liable for sums debtor owed to plaintiffs and that, in absence of showing actual operative total control, defendant was not liable. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Krivo Indus. Supply Co. v. National Distillers & Chemical Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: When one corporation controls and dominates another corporation to extent that second corporation becomes mere instrumentality of the first, the dominant corporation becomes liable for subservient corporation's debts attributable to abuse of that control.
Document Preview: Actions by ten creditors of reorganized corporate debtor against its major creditor on ground that defendant had dominated debtor corporation to extent that it became mere instrumentality of the defendant. The United States District Court for the Northern District of Alabama, Sam C. Pointer, Jr., J., directed verdict in favor of defendant and plaintiffs appealed. The Court of Appeals, Roney, Circuit Judge, held that fact that defendant as major creditor was vested with capacity to assert great pressure and influence on debtor did not constitute sufficient control to make defendant liable for sums debtor owed to plaintiffs and that, in absence of showing actual operative total control, defendant was not liable. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Krivo Indus. Supply Co. v. National Distillers & Chemical Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporation may be held liable for debts of another corporation when it misuses that corporation by treating it, and by using it, as a mere business conduit for purposes of the dominant corporation and in such case the debts of the subservient corporation are in reality the obligations of the dominant corporation.
Document Preview: Actions by ten creditors of reorganized corporate debtor against its major creditor on ground that defendant had dominated debtor corporation to extent that it became mere instrumentality of the defendant. The United States District Court for the Northern District of Alabama, Sam C. Pointer, Jr., J., directed verdict in favor of defendant and plaintiffs appealed. The Court of Appeals, Roney, Circuit Judge, held that fact that defendant as major creditor was vested with capacity to assert great pressure and influence on debtor did not constitute sufficient control to make defendant liable for sums debtor owed to plaintiffs and that, in absence of showing actual operative total control, defendant was not liable. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Hernando Bank v. Bryant Elec. Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N. D. Mississippi, Delta Division.
Headnote: The courts will ignore separate corporate entities in order to defeat a fraud, wrong, or injustice, at least where the rights of third persons are concerned.
Document Preview: Action by bank, which had obtained state court judgment against Mississippi corporation, against North Carolina corporation seeking to recover on numerous theories. The District Court, Orma R. Smith, J., held, inter alia, that evidence was insufficient to support bank's theory that proceeds of water association project in which Mississippi corporation had engaged were fraudulently transferred or conveyed to North Carolina corporation in violation of any legal right which the bank held in the fund. Judgment accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Bay Sound Transp. Co. v. U.S.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Separate corporate existence of entities will be ignored when to do so furthers ends of justice, and a corporation which exercises actual control over another and operates the latter as a mere instrumentality or tool is liable for the torts and obligations of the corporation thus controlled.
Document Preview: Income tax refund actions. On remand, 410 F.2d 505, the District Court, Hannay, J., held that evidence failed to establish that evasion or avoidance of federal income taxes, by securing benefit of multiple surtax exemptions, was not the principal purpose motivating separate incorporation of 20 barges and vessels acquired by shipping fleet, with one individual being major stockholder and chief executive officer of all but two of such corporations, with two partnerships and corporations using same office address, with one individual personally soliciting all business and directing services to be performed, with records governing all transactions being maintained by partnerships and intercorporate affairs handled as accounts payable and accounts receivable and only evidence that tax evasion or avoidance was not principal motive being unsupported statements of stockholders and others. Order accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Service Afloat, Inc. v. U. S.
Court: United States Customs Court.
Headnote: A corporation may be an alter ego or business conduit of another and its separate corporate existence will not be recognized where it is so organized and controlled and its business is conducted in such manner as to make it merely an agency or instrumentality of other corporation.
Document Preview: Appeal for reappraisement. The Customs Court, Maletz, J., held that evidence would not sustain plaintiffs' contention that corporation was selected purchaser of boat from its manufacturer-exporter and established, to contrary, that corporation was sales agent of manufacturer-exporter. Order accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Pilot Title Ins. Co. v. Northwestern Bank
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: When corporation is so dominated by another corporation that subservient corporation becomes mere instrument and is indistinct from controlling corporation, corporate veil of dominated corporation will be disregarded if to retain such veil results in injustice.
Document Preview: Action by issuer of mortgagee title policy for injunctive relief, or in alternative, relief pursuant to Declaratory Judgment Act. The Superior Court, Mecklenburg County, Pilston Godwin, J., ordered injunctive relief and certain defendants appealed. The Court of Appeals, Graham, J., held that where corporation, to which was donated bookkeeping credit received by borrower for major portion of loan represented by demand note given to bank was at all times under control of bank, and bank caused corporation to use such credit to purchase certain assets from bank corporation was alter ego of bank, and thus bank had sustained no loss with respect to portion of loan allocated for assets and issuer of mortgagee title policy to bank on tract of land, which was subject to deed of trust given by borrower to bank as security for demand note, and to which borrower did not have title, was not liable under such policy for sum allocated for assets. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Pilot Title Ins. Co. v. Northwestern Bank
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Stock ownership alone is not determining factor for purpose of deciding whether corporation is so dominated by another corporation that corporate veil should be disregarded, but rather there must be control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to transaction attacked so that corporate entity as to such transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own.
Document Preview: Action by issuer of mortgagee title policy for injunctive relief, or in alternative, relief pursuant to Declaratory Judgment Act. The Superior Court, Mecklenburg County, Pilston Godwin, J., ordered injunctive relief and certain defendants appealed. The Court of Appeals, Graham, J., held that where corporation, to which was donated bookkeeping credit received by borrower for major portion of loan represented by demand note given to bank was at all times under control of bank, and bank caused corporation to use such credit to purchase certain assets from bank corporation was alter ego of bank, and thus bank had sustained no loss with respect to portion of loan allocated for assets and issuer of mortgagee title policy to bank on tract of land, which was subject to deed of trust given by borrower to bank as security for demand note, and to which borrower did not have title, was not liable under such policy for sum allocated for assets. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Roman Catholic Archbishop v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, First District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Among factors to be considered in applying doctrine of "alter ego" are comingling of funds and other assets of two entities, holding out by one entity that it is liable for debts of the other, identical equitable ownership in two entities, use of same offices and employees, and use of one as mere shell or conduit for affairs of the other.
Document Preview: Mandamus proceeding to compel the Superior Court of Alameda County to enter summary judgment in favor of petitioner, a corporation sole, in suit against petitioner to recover amount deposited with European monastery of same religious faith for purchase of dog which was not delivered and to recover additional amount expended for similar dog. The Court of Appeal, David, J., held that uncontroverted affidavit that corporation sole had no dealings with European monastery negated any possibility that corporation so controlled and dominated the monastery as to be liable for its actions under alter ego doctrine; thus, plaintiff was not entitled to recover. Peremptory writ issued.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: St. Petersburg Sheraton Corp. v. Stuart
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Second District.
Headnote: Ownership by one corporation of all stock of another corporation does not destroy the identity of the latter as a distinct legal entity, nor does fact that stockholders or officers of two corporations are same persons operate to destroy legal identity of either corporation.
Document Preview: Action for burns received by guest at restaurant in hotel during preparation of cherries jubilee brought against corporate owner of hotel and corporation allegedly chargeable with its liabilities. The Circuit Court, Pinellas County, Robert E. Beach, J., entered judgment for compensatory and punitive damages and defendants appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Pierce, Acting Chief Judge, held that chef at restaurant in one defendant's hotel was not grossly negligent in preparing cherries jubilee at banquet when he poured flambe on cherries at time he did not see any fire in pan and plaintiff is not entitled to punitive damages for burns received when the flambe was ignited causing flame to shoot out and strike plaintiff. The Court also held that where the other defendant or a subsidiary was to receive all of stock of hotel corporation, the parent of corporate owner of restaurant, in exchange for defendant's stock, a wholly owned subsidiary of defendant was organized and by bill...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Shirley v. Drackett Products Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan, Division No. 3.
Headnote: Where a corporation is so organized and so controlled as to make it a mere instrumentality or an agent of another corporation, its separate existence as a distinct corporate entity will be ignored and the two corporations will be regarded in legal contemplation as one unit.
Document Preview: Products liability case in which plaintiff claimed that upon using toilet bowl cleaner she suffered respiratory injuries from the inhalation of fumes. The Circuit Court, Isabella County, Robert H. Campbell, J., entered judgment for plaintiff and defendant appealed. The Court of Appeals, Brown, J., held that evidence that toilet bowl cleaner when used would react with iron oxide and produce harmful gases supported finding that the toilet bowl cleaner was the cause of plaintiff's respiratory condition. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Sundaco, Inc. v. State
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Eastland.
Headnote: Courts will look through form to substance of relations between corporations and will disregard fiction of corporate identity if it is used to circumvent statute or as mere tool or business conduit.
Document Preview: Action by city against corporations alleging violation of statute prohibiting person from selling or compelling his employees to sell certain items on consecutive days of Saturday and Sunday. The 42nd District Court, Taylor County, Raleigh Brown, J., entered judgment adverse to defendants which appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Collings, J., held that evidence sustained findings that contract whereby defendant owners who operated their stores Monday through Saturday allegedly leased stores on Sundays under arrangement whereby defendant lessee bought all of owner's merchandise with option to return it after every Sunday and almost all of employees of owners worked for lessee was a subterfuge to evade statute prohibiting person from selling or compelling his employees to sell certain merchandise on consecutive Saturday and Sunday. Affirmed. See also, Tex.Civ.App., 445 S.W.2d 606.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: In re Panama Airways, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: One corporation can hold the assets of another without being the other's alter ego.
Document Preview: Petition by creditor for review of bankruptcy proceedings. The United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida at Miami, Emett C. Choate, J., denied the petition for review and the creditor appealed. The Court of Appeals, Dyer, Circuit Judge, held that evidence supported finding of referee and of district court that assets of principal were the assets of its bankrupt-agent. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Hubbard v. Capital Southwest Corp.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas. Waco.
Headnote: Fact that one corporation owns all or a majority of stock of another corporation does not destroy identity of latter as a distinct legal entity.
Document Preview: Stockholders' derivative action, in which plaintiffs sought judgment against organizing corporation and joint officers and directors for intercorporate indebtedness. The 68th District Court, Dallas County, Owen Giles, J., entered summary judgment in favor of defendants and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Wilson, J., held that where history of organizing and incorporated corporations evidenced constant effort by organizer and its officers to salvage incorporatee and predecessor from insolvency, stockholders of incorporatee were fully informed of steps taken, including intercorporate loans, and actively participated or maintained silence without dissent and inequity or disruption of purpose of legal entity was not otherwise shown, corporate entity would not be disregarded and organizing corporation and joint officers and directors held liable for intercorporate indebtedness, notwithstanding that incorporatee may have been alter ego of organizing corporation....

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Superintendent of Ins. of State of N. Y. v. Bankers Life & Cas. Co.
Court: United States District Court S.D. New York.
Headnote: Corporation cannot maintain its status as separate or existing entity without having another entity or individual serving capacity of proprietor or owner.
Document Preview: Proceedings on motion to dismiss action brought under provisions of Securities Acts. The District Court, Herlands, J., held that where it was never intended that corporation would take title to shares, fact that corporation was source of funds for purchase of its own shares was insufficient to establish corporation as purchaser of shares and corporation lacked standing to assert cause of action for violation of securities laws with respect to purchase and sale of shares, and that complaint in action against defendants who allegedly participated in transactions whereby corporation's portfolio of government securities was used to enable individual to acquire corporation's stock alleged no more than common-law action for misappropriation of corporate funds by fiduciary, embezzlement or fraudulent conveyance, or distribution of illegal dividend none of which, in absence of diversity of citizenship, could be maintained in federal court. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Blackwell Printing Co. v. Blackwell-Wielandy Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Missouri, Division No. 1.
Headnote: Corporation is ordinarily an entity, separate and apart from its stockholders, and mere ownership of all stock of one corporation by another, and identity of officers of one with officers of another, are not alone sufficient to create identity of corporate interests between the two companies or to create the relation of principal and agent or to create a representative or fiduciary relation between the two; rather, there must be such dominion and control that the controlled corporation has, so to speak, no separate mind, will or existence of its own.
Document Preview: Assignee of realty purchaser brought action claiming that defendant, which had been a tenant of building on the realty, wrongfully removed a ventilating system, two conveyor systems, and two wash basins. The Circuit Court of the City of St. Louis, Michael F. Godfrey, J., set aside verdict for plaintiff and granted tenant a new trial. On plaintiff's appeal, the Supreme Court, Houser, Commissioner, held, inter alia, that every legitimate inference to be drawn from the evidence of plaintiff led to conclusion that landlord-vendor, which conveyed the realty to plaintiff's assignor, never owned or claimed to own conveyor systems in building on the realty; on the contrary, the undisputed facts of record established that the conveyor systems, which were installed by tenant, constituted trade fixtures which the tenant, upon surrender of its lease, had right to lawfully remove. Affirmed in part, reversed in part and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Houston Oil Field Material Co. v. Stuard
Court: United States Court of Appeals Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Where there is near identity between two corporations, their separate existences can be disregarded in order to prevent injustice to third party.
Document Preview: Action by former employer of first corporation to recover for loss allegedly sustained as result of denial of exercise of stock option. The United States District Court for the Southern District of Mississippi, William Harold Cox, J., rendered judgment for the former employee and the corporation appealed. The Court of Appeals, Thornberry, Circuit Judge, held that charge that if jury believed that lease arrangement between first corporation and second corporation was for purpose of convenience and policy in carrying on first corporation's business and that plaintiff's job remained the same as before and there was no understanding between him and first corporation that his duties or compensation under his original contract of employment would be affected, then jury should find that plaintiff was still employee of first corporation rather than second corporation which was wholly owned by first corporation when plaintiff attempted to exercise stock option conditioned on...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: GAF Corp. v. Hanimex Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Even though certain forms of corporate separateness were observed, the facts taken in the aggregate reveal a mere cloak for the actual agency relationship.
Document Preview: Action against Australian holding corporation and Illinois corporation for patent infringement. On Australian corporation's motion to dismiss, the District Court, Robson, J., held that where all important negotiations and decisions of Illinois corporation were handled by president who was also chief executive officer of Australian corporation with the same name as Illinois corporation which controlled holding company which held all shares in Illinois corporation, and all but one of illinois corporation's directors were directors and/or officers of Australian corporation, and all meetings were held in Australia and Australian corporation controlled and financed defense of patent infringement suit, service of process on secretary of Illinois corporation was sufficient to confer jurisdiction over Australian corporation, and requisites for venue in patent case were met. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Christiansen v. Mechanical Contractors Bid Depository
Court: United States Court of Appeals Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Where judgment creditor of corporation engaged in bid service to contractors took all of such corporation's assets and immediately executive manager of such corporation and two contractors formed a nonprofit corporation offering similar service, but there was no transfer of assets, the new corporation was not a mere successor and alter ego of the old corporation and was not liable for old corporation's judgment debt under Utah law.
Document Preview: Action by judgment creditor of corporation for injunction against withdrawal of deposited bank funds by judgment debtor's alleged successor. The United States District Court for the District of Utah, Central Division, A. Sherman Christensen, J., denied a permanent injunction and dissolved a temporary restraining order, and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeals, Hickey, Circuit Judge, held that where judgment creditor of corporation engaged in bid service to contractors took all of such corporation's assets and immediately executive manager of such corporation and two contractors formed a nonprofit corporation offering similar service, but there was no transfer of assets, the new corporation was not a mere successor and alter ego of the old corporation and was not liable for old corporation's judgment debt. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Phelps v. Missouri-Kansas-Texas R. Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Missouri, Division No. 1.
Headnote: If any intercorporate affiliation is devised for or is being used to accomplish an improper or unlawful purpose, equity has authority to reach beyond them to impose liability or grant proper relief, but, if purpose is lawful and fair and equitable to those with whom it is intended to deal, legal forms and relationships should be observed.
Document Preview: Truck driver brought action under Federal Employers' Liability Act for personal injuries. The Circuit Court of Jackson County, Charles Shangler, J., entered judgment on verdict for driver, and railroad appealed. The Supreme Court, Higgins, C., held that in absence of evidence that corporation furnishing substitute rail freight service by highway for railroad was not a going, solvent corporation or that purposes of both corporation and railroad were anything but proper, the corporate entity of corporation could not be disregarded, and truck driver was not an employee of railroad, which owned all stock of corporation furnishing substitute rail freight service by highway, for purpose of liability under Federal Employer's Liability Act. Judgment reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: National Homes Corp. v. Lester Industries, Inc.
Court: United States District Court W.D. Virginia, Danville Division.
Headnote: The corporate veil should not be pierced so as to benefit party which has established or maintained existence of separate corporate structure for its own benefit.
Document Preview: Suit for injunction. The District Court, Walter E. Hoffman, Chief Judge, held that where smaller corporate manufacturer of prefabricated housing units became wholly-owned subsidiary of larger corporate manufacturer of such units, and smaller manufacturer's president became member of larger manufacturer's board of directors and agreed to continue in employment of smaller manufacturer and covenanted not to compete with larger manufacturer anywhere in United States after termination of employment within ten-year period, larger manufacturer suffered such irreparable injury by president's engaging in prefabricated housing business after termination of employment as to be entitled to injunctive relief as to areas in which such competition occurred. Injunctive relief granted. Affirmed in part and reversed in part 4 Cir., 404 F.2d 225.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Brown v. Margrande Compania Naviera, S. A.
Court: United States District Court E.D. Virginia, Norfolk Division.
Headnote: Courts should invoke instrumentality rule only with mature consideration and with caution; and one of tests is exercise of control by one corporation over other, not mere opportunity to exercise control.
Document Preview: Action against parent corporation and its subsidiaries for salvage services in towing and saving tanker chartered by one subsidiary and carrying other subsidiary's cargo. Upon parent corporation's motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Kellam, J., held that instrumentality rule would not be invoked to make parent corporation liable, even though corporations had interlocking directors and officers, and though subsidiaries were wholly owned by parent corporation, where there was no injustice, fraud, or wrong, public convenience was not affected, and no illicit act was committed. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Brown v. Margrande Compania Naviera, S. A.
Court: United States District Court E.D. Virginia, Norfolk Division.
Headnote: More than identity of officers and stock ownership in corporate setup must exist before corporate fiction will be disregarded; it must appear that corporation was organized for a fraudulent purpose or that some injury has resulted from the transaction, something of fraud, illegality, or wrongdoing or something giving moving party cause for complaint.
Document Preview: Action against parent corporation and its subsidiaries for salvage services in towing and saving tanker chartered by one subsidiary and carrying other subsidiary's cargo. Upon parent corporation's motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Kellam, J., held that instrumentality rule would not be invoked to make parent corporation liable, even though corporations had interlocking directors and officers, and though subsidiaries were wholly owned by parent corporation, where there was no injustice, fraud, or wrong, public convenience was not affected, and no illicit act was committed. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Brown v. Margrande Compania Naviera, S. A.
Court: United States District Court E.D. Virginia, Norfolk Division.
Headnote: Separate corporate entity will be observed by the courts even though one corporation may dominate or control another or treat it as a mere department, instrumentality, or agency, and separate legal identities will be disregarded only when one is used to defeat public convenience, justify wrongs, or protect fraud or crime of other.
Document Preview: Action against parent corporation and its subsidiaries for salvage services in towing and saving tanker chartered by one subsidiary and carrying other subsidiary's cargo. Upon parent corporation's motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Kellam, J., held that instrumentality rule would not be invoked to make parent corporation liable, even though corporations had interlocking directors and officers, and though subsidiaries were wholly owned by parent corporation, where there was no injustice, fraud, or wrong, public convenience was not affected, and no illicit act was committed. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: My Bread Baking Co. v. Cumberland Farms, Inc.
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Bristol.
Headnote: A corporation or other person controlling a corporation and directing or participating actively in its operations may become subject to civil or criminal liability on principles of agency or of causation; this may sometimes occur where corporations are formed, or availed of, to carry out objectives and purposes of corporations or persons controlling them.
Document Preview: Conversion actions tried in Superior Court before Mitchell, J. One defendant excepted to judge's refusal to direct a verdict for it. The Supreme Judicial Court, Cutter, J., held that separate corporate entities were disregarded, and principal family-owned corporation which sold its milk and dairy products to retail dairy stores operated by satellite family-owned corporations was liable for conversions of plaintiff's bakery racks on termination of arrangement for sale of plaintiff's bakery products in stores, where principal corporation's sales manager was responsible for order that stores not return racks, principal corporation and satellite corporations were operated from same headquarters as closely coordinated single enterprise in which sales manager was dominant figure, and manager dealt ambiguously with plaintiff. Exceptions overruled.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: My Bread Baking Co. v. Cumberland Farms, Inc.
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Bristol.
Headnote: Although common stock ownership of corporations and common management alone will not make one corporation liable for acts of another, liability may be imposed upon one or more of group of closely identified corporations (a) when there is active and direct participation by representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequences of intercorporate relationship, or (b) when there is confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in common enterprise with substantial disregard of separate nature of corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about manner and capacity in which various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: Conversion actions tried in Superior Court before Mitchell, J. One defendant excepted to judge's refusal to direct a verdict for it. The Supreme Judicial Court, Cutter, J., held that separate corporate entities were disregarded, and principal family-owned corporation which sold its milk and dairy products to retail dairy stores operated by satellite family-owned corporations was liable for conversions of plaintiff's bakery racks on termination of arrangement for sale of plaintiff's bakery products in stores, where principal corporation's sales manager was responsible for order that stores not return racks, principal corporation and satellite corporations were operated from same headquarters as closely coordinated single enterprise in which sales manager was dominant figure, and manager dealt ambiguously with plaintiff. Exceptions overruled.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Blackwell Indus. Foundation, Inc. v. Texstar Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Ownership of stock in one corporation by another does not of itself destroy the corporate entity.
Document Preview: Action against corporation on a contract. The United States District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma, Chandler, J., rendered judgment in favor of defendant, and plaintiff appealed. The Court of Appeals, Seth, Circuit Judge, held that fact that defendant corporation and second corporation operated in common facility, that some personnel were used in common, and that some common services were provided both did not establish a merger or consolidation within contract wherein defendant, majority stockholder in the second corporation, agreed to pay plaintiff $20,000 for plaintiff's stock in said second corporation in the event of such a merger or consolidation. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Zaist v. Olson
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Courts will disregard fiction of separate legal entity when corporation is mere instrumentality or agent of another corporation or individual owning all or most of its stock.
Document Preview: Action was brought against individual defendant, first corporate defendant and second corporate defendant for services and materials furnished by plaintiffs in clearing and grading land. The Superior Court in New London County, Thim, J., after reference to Thomas E. Troland State Referee, entered judgment in favor of the plaintiffs on the referee's report against the individual defendant and the second corporate defendant, and all defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Alcorn, J., held that where individual defendant caused creation of both first corporate defendant and second corporate defendant and thereafter completely dominated and controlled them, and all work and material furnished to first corporate defendant by plaintiffs in clearing and grading went into land which, after being juggled about, came to rest in individual defendant or second corporate defendant, and first corporate defendant was used for benefit of individual defendant and second corporate defendant,...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Overstreet v. Southern Ry. Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate fiction should not be disregarded because of identity of corporate names, stockholders and officers and fact of ownership of stock in one corporation by another.
Document Preview: Action against railroad arising out of crossing accident. The United States District Court for the Southern District of Mississippi, William Harold Cox, J., overruled plaintiff's motion to set aside and vacate summary judgment for defendant, and plaintiff appraled. The Court of Appeals, Ainsworth, Circuit Judge, held that under circumstances, separate identities of two railroad corporations would not be disregarded, although first railroad owned all stock in second railroad, where second railroad owned and actively operated its own business, and first railroad would not be held liable for alleged negligence of second railroad in crossing accident. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Walkovszky v. Carlton
Court: Court of Appeals of New York.
Headnote: Although either the circumstance that a corporation is a fragment of a larger corporate combine which actually conducts a business, or that a corporation is a dummy for its individual stockholders who in reality are carrying on a business in their own personal capacities for purely personal rather than corporate ends would justify treating the corporation as an agent and piercing the corporate veil to reach the principal, in the first circumstance only a larger corporate entity could be held financially responsible, while in the other circumstance the stockholders would be personally liable.
Document Preview: Action against corporation in name of which a taxicab was registered, driver of the taxicab, nine other corporations in whose names other taxicabs were registered, two additional corporations, and three individuals for injuries sustained by plaintiff when struck by the taxicab. The Supreme Court, Edward G. Baker, J., granted motion of an individual defendant who was claimed to be a stockholder of ten corporations, including corporation in name of which taxicab was registered, to dismiss the complaint as to him for failure to state a cause of action, and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, 24 A.D.2d 582, 262 N.Y.S.2d 334, reversed and denied the motion and individual defendant appealed by leave of the Appellate Division on a certified question. The Court of Appeals, Fuld, J., held that complaint containing allegations that individual defendant organized, managed, dominated and controlled a fragmented corporate entity and that fleet ownership of taxicabs had...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Tiernan v. Sheldon
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: Courts will look through the screen of corporate entity to the individuals who compose it in cases in which the corporation was a mere device or sham to accomplish some ulterior purpose, or was a mere instrumentality or agent of another corporation or individual owning all or most of its stock, or where purpose was to evade some statute or to accomplish some fraud or illegal purpose, or where corporation was employed by the stockholders for fraudulent or misleading purposes, was organized or used to mislead creditors or to perpetuate a fraud upon them, or to evade existing personal liability.
Document Preview: Action by lessor against lessee and others to set aside assignment of lease and for damages. The Circuit Court, Palm Beach County, R. O. Morrow, J., entered summary decree for defendants, and plaintiff appealed. The District Court of Appeal, 147 So.2d 167, reversed and remanded. The Circuit Court, Palm Beach County, R. O. Morrow, J., entered decree which in part held defendants personally liable for rent, interest and taxes subsequent to assignment of lease, and an appeal was taken. The District Court of Appeal, John S. Rawls, Associate Judge, held, inter alia, that assignment by lessee to corporation duly and properly formed by lessee was fraud upon no one and relieved lessee of any future liability for rent, interest and taxes, where lease was duly and properly assigned in accordance with contract, parties agreed that upon assignment transferor should be thenceforth released from any liability, lessor did not reserve unto herself any vestige of control as to an assignment and...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Kueckelhan v. Federal Old Line Ins. Co. (Mut.)
Court: Supreme Court of Washington, En Banc.
Headnote: Legal fiction of corporate existence may be disregarded where corporation is so organized and controlled, and its affairs are so conducted, as to make it merely instrumentality or adjunct of other corporation.
Document Preview: Proceeding by insurance commissioner for rehabilitation of mutual insurer. The Superior Court, King County, George H. Revelle, J., appointed commissioner as rehabilitator, and insurer appealed. The Supreme Court, Hamilton, J., held that the insurance code provisions in question were constitutional and that under circumstances, court did not err in directing rehabilitation, on ground that mutual insurer's operations were hazardous, in view of excessive concentration of investments in single project, dubious security of mortgage guarantees, insufficient return for mortgage property, practice of periodically increasing face amount of mortgages to effect amounts of unpaid interest, deferment of interest payments, and failure to consider mortgages in default, despite insurer's solvency in ordinary business sense and despite its good record of payment. Affirmed and remanded. Hunter, J., dissented in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Savage v. Royal Properties, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Arizona.
Headnote: The fiction of corporate entity must be disregarded where one corporation is so organized and controlled, and its affairs so conducted that it is, in fact, a mere instrumentality or adjunct of another corporation.
Document Preview: Director of corporation sought to enjoin sale of certain of subsidiary's assets, which director had an option to purchase. His petition for preliminary injunction was denied by the Superior Court of Maricopa County, No. 173495, Donald Daughton, J., and he appealed. The Court of Appeals, Robert O. Roylston, Superior Court Judge, held that director of parent corporation, who had approved transfer of certain assets to subsidiary was estopped from maintaining that the corporation and the subsidiary should be treated as a single entity and thus when subsidiary decided to sell the assets the option the director had to purchase the assets if the parent had decided to sell them could not be exercised. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Associates Development Corp. v. Air Control Products, Inc.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: Generally, separate corporate entities will be observed even though one corporation may dominate or control another or may treat it as a mere dependent.
Document Preview: Seller's action on sworn account for goods and merchandise sold by it to buyer corporation which was sued together with individual and another defendant corporation. The 53rd District Court, Travis County, Herman Jones, J., entered a judgment against buyer corporation only and seller corporation appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Hughes, J., held that where seller in making sales transacted business only with manager of corporate buyer and billed corporate buyer for all goods without any suggestion as to personal liability of individual defendant or liability of another defendant corporation, owned by individual defendant who also owned buyer, until long after bills were incurred, corporate buyer alone was liable. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Associates Development Corp. v. Air Control Products, Inc.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: Courts will disregard separate legal identities of corporations only when one is used to defeat public convenience, justify wrongs, or to protect fraud or crime of other.
Document Preview: Seller's action on sworn account for goods and merchandise sold by it to buyer corporation which was sued together with individual and another defendant corporation. The 53rd District Court, Travis County, Herman Jones, J., entered a judgment against buyer corporation only and seller corporation appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Hughes, J., held that where seller in making sales transacted business only with manager of corporate buyer and billed corporate buyer for all goods without any suggestion as to personal liability of individual defendant or liability of another defendant corporation, owned by individual defendant who also owned buyer, until long after bills were incurred, corporate buyer alone was liable. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Republic-Transcon Industries, Inc. v. Templeton
Court: Supreme Court of Mississippi.
Headnote: Evidence that defendant corporation owned all stock in second corporation did not make agents and employees of second corporation agents and employees of defendant.
Document Preview: Defendant foreign corporation appealed from a default judgment rendered against it in the Circuit Court, Oktibbeha County, John D. Greene, Jr., J. The Supreme Court, Inzer, J., held that question of whether foreign corporation or individual is doing business in state must be determined from facts in each case, and where proof failed to show that defendant was doing business in state, court should have sustained its motion to dismiss. Reversed and rendered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Fire Ass'n of Philadelphia v. Vantine Paint & Glass Co. of Bismarck
Court: Supreme Court of North Dakota.
Headnote: Where affairs, assets and equipment of corporations are intermingled and confused, the corporations conduct a single business insofar as persons who contract with them are concerned.
Document Preview: Actions by various property owners and their fire insurers against named individual who allegedly started the fire, a partnership and various corporations to recover for the fire damage on the theory that the separate businesses did not have a separate corporate existence but were used and existed for the sole purpose of permitting the incorporators to transact individual businesses under a multiple corporate guise. The District Court, Morton County, C. F. Kelsch, J., entered summary judgment for defendants except as to named individual who allegedly started the fire and his employer and the plaintiffs appealed. The Supreme Court, Schneller, District Judge, held that there was no showing that the business conduct of the four corporations had been so intermingled and confused that the four corporations conducted a single business insofar as the public was concerned, that there was not the slightest intimation that anything was unfair or fraudulent in the conduct of the defendant...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: J. I. Case Credit Corp. v. Stark
Court: Supreme Court of Washington, Department 1.
Headnote: For court to declare two corporations to be identical in responsibility, there must be such a commingling of property rights or interests as to render it apparent that they are intended to function as one, and the situation must be such that to regard them as separate would aid the consummation of a fraud or wrong upon others.
Document Preview: Action by credit corporation on note and for foreclosure of chattel mortgage against buyers of combine. The Superior Court, Whitman County, Thomas G. Jordan, J., granted judgment for plaintiff, and defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Rummel, J., held that use of combine for harvest season of one year and part of a second, which amounted to two months or less of total operation, before buyers returned it to retailer claiming that it was irrepairable did not constitute more than reasonable time to assert if combine could be made to function properly and did not amount to waiver of right to rescind the sale, and that buyers were entitled to rescission. Remanded with directions to join manufacturer and retailer and to enter judgment in accordance with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: National Bond Finance Co. v. General Motors Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Missouri, Western Division.
Headnote: The so-called "instrumentality" or "alter ego" rule states that when a corporation is so dominated by another corporation that the subservient corporation becomes a mere instrument and is really indistinct from controlling corporation, then the corporate veil of dominated corporation will be disregarded, if to retain it results in injustice.
Document Preview: Action for actual and punitive damages growing out of transactions between plaintiff and an automobile dealer doing business in Illinois involving the purchase of conditional sales contracts for sale of motor vehicles. The District Court, Duncan, J., held, inter alia, that evidence regarding relationship between finance company which purchased automobile conditional sales contracts, the automobile manufacturer and automobile dealer did not justify piercing of corporate veil of dealer and holding the manufacturer liable for actions and conduct of dealer's president and of dealer so as to render manufacturer liable to company for losses sustained. Judgment for defendant in accordance with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Haynes v. Champagne Tile Corp.
Court: United States District Court E.D. Louisiana, Baton Rouge Division.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, corporate veil is pierced to hold one corporation liable for debts of another when theory of separate entity leads to an absurdity or persons involved in corporation seek to use legal fiction to obtain immunity from consequences of their fraud or illegal actions.
Document Preview: Suit brought pursuant to Fair Labor Standards Act for back wages. The District Court, West, J., held that where corporate employer of plaintiff was incapable of handling business, but new corporation organized to obtain new work did not take place or supplant employer and it did not acquire employer's officers or employees, new corporation was not alter ego of employer and plaintiff who terminated employment four months before new corporation was organized was not entitled to recover from new corporation but was entitled to recover from employer. Claim against new corporation dismissed and judgment entered against employing corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Haynes v. Champagne Tile Corp.
Court: United States District Court E.D. Louisiana, Baton Rouge Division.
Headnote: One corporation may be said to be alter ego of another when it is principal for another or when it is dominant corporation of two.
Document Preview: Suit brought pursuant to Fair Labor Standards Act for back wages. The District Court, West, J., held that where corporate employer of plaintiff was incapable of handling business, but new corporation organized to obtain new work did not take place or supplant employer and it did not acquire employer's officers or employees, new corporation was not alter ego of employer and plaintiff who terminated employment four months before new corporation was organized was not entitled to recover from new corporation but was entitled to recover from employer. Claim against new corporation dismissed and judgment entered against employing corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: David Moore Development Co. v. Higgins Industries, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Captive corporation cannot be used as screen behind which one may hide his true interest in transaction.
Document Preview: House contractor's suit against tile manufacturer for indemnification for expenditures made by contractor in replacing defective tile. The Civil District Court for the Parish of Orleans, Division D, No. 406-119, Rene A. Viosca, J., entered judgment for the contractor and the manufacturer appealed. The Court of Appeal, Regan, J., held that house contractor who purchased corporation's floor tile from corporation's sales representative, who handled sales, made demonstrations, and effected adjustments for dissatisfied customers, was entitled to assume that sales representative possessed authority to make written guarantees on behalf of corporation to pay for replacement of defective tile. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Technograph Printed Circuits, Limited v. Epsco, Inc.
Court: United States District Court E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Normally, separate corporations will not be regarded as single entity so as to hold one responsible for acts or obligations of other, even where one has practical control over the other through stock ownership.
Document Preview: Patent infringement action in which one of the defendant corporations moved to quash return of service and dismiss action against it for improper venue. The District Court, Luongo, J., held that subsidiary corporation which established place of business in district in which patent infringement action was brought against it and which had committed alleged acts of patent infringement in district, was not, under the circumstances, alter ego of its parent corporation and service on officer of subsidiary was not service on parent corporation as to which venue was improperly laid. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Technograph Printed Circuits, Limited v. Epsco, Inc.
Court: United States District Court E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Corporation may become so involved and intertwined in or so control activities of another as to compel disregard of technical separate existence and hold the one legally accountable for what the other does.
Document Preview: Patent infringement action in which one of the defendant corporations moved to quash return of service and dismiss action against it for improper venue. The District Court, Luongo, J., held that subsidiary corporation which established place of business in district in which patent infringement action was brought against it and which had committed alleged acts of patent infringement in district, was not, under the circumstances, alter ego of its parent corporation and service on officer of subsidiary was not service on parent corporation as to which venue was improperly laid. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Architectural Bldg. Products, Inc. v. Cupples Products Corp.
Court: United States District Court E.D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: Control of one corporation by virtue of stock ownership or incidental to overlapping directorates does not warrant disregard of individual corporate entities.
Document Preview: Action for damages for wrongful termination of representation contract. On motion of one defendant corporation for summary judgment, the District Court, Grubb, J., held that in absence of any showing that defendant corporation, which had acquired all capital stock of other defendant corporation in exchange for common stock of acquiring corporation under reorganization agreement, had evinced an intent to assume liabilities of other corporation whose stock it had acquired, acquiring corporation could not be sued by other corporation's distributor for alleged wrongful termination of representation contract. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Farber v. Cross-Westchester Realty Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Westchester County, New York.
Headnote: When corporation is so dominated and controlled by another that it is no more than agency or instrumentality, dominant corporation will not be permitted to escape liability for wrongful act committed by dummy corporation.
Document Preview: Proceeding against two corporations, in which first corporation moved to dismiss complaint and the second corporation moved to make complaint more definite and certain, or, in alternative, to strike certain paragraphs thereof. The Supreme Court, John J. Dillon, J., held that complaint sufficiently alleged cause of action against corporation predicated on theory that corporation maintained such domination and control over affairs of other corporate defendant as to merge their identities. Motions denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: McLaughlin v. L. Bloom Sons Co.
Court: District Court of Appeal, First District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Corporate entity may be disregarded where it is so organized and controlled and its affairs are so conducted as to make it an instrumentality, agency, conduit or adjunct of another corporation.
Document Preview: Union's action for declaratory judgment that the new defendant corporation was the alter ego of the old defendant corporation for the purposes of collective bargaining agreement. The Superior Court, County of Santa Clara Robert F. Peckham, J., entered a judgment for the union and the defendants appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Agee, J., held that it was not an abuse of discretion to apply the alter ego doctrine to the new corporation which was controlled by the same individuals as the old corporation that had signed a collective bargaining agreement. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Mull v. Colt Co.
Court: United States District Court S. D. New York.
Headnote: Where corporations are organized, controlled and utilized so as to make them merely instrumentalities, agencies or conduits of another corporation, the corporate entity would be disregarded.
Document Preview: Action against stockholders in taxicab companies, taxicab companies, manufacturer of taxicab, and automobile dealer for injuries sustained by plaintiff when struck by taxicab. On motions to dismiss the complaint, the District Court, Edelstein, J., held that complaint, which alleged that 100 corporations each owning two taxicabs and carrying the minimum amount of insurance required by state law were formed in violation of police department regulations to enable stockholders and the corporations to defraud fraud the public and that the corporations had inadequate capitalization, stated sufficient grounds to pierce the corporate veil and stated a claim against individual stockholders and the corporations holding the cabs, which were garaged, maintained and operated centrally. Motions denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Randolph Foods, Inc. v. McLaughlin
Court: Supreme Court of Iowa.
Headnote: While in general, a corporation is a separate legal entity, nevertheless when one corporation so dominates another as to make that other a simple instrumentality or adjunct to it, courts will look beyond the legal fiction of distinct corporate existence as the interests of justice require.
Document Preview: Action by corporation against assistant general manager of corporation for breach of contract and action by president of corporation against the assistant general manager for unpaid rent under a lease of house to the assistant general manager, who filed a cross-petition raising issues requiring an accounting, which were transferred to the equity branch and tried first. From orders and a judgment of the Guthrie District Court, George H. Sackett, J., upon the accounting, the corporation and the president appealed and the assistant general manager cross-appealed. The Supreme Court, Thompson, J., held that assistant general manager was entitled to an accounting for salary claimed to be due and it was error for trial court to set aside judgments entered in his favor in the accounting proceeding, and court should have entered judgment in accordance with its findings and made the judgment not subject to execution until the other issues were subsequently determined and possible offsets...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1051 In general >
Title: Houston-American Life Ins. Co. v. Tate
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Waco.
Headnote: Fiction of corporate entity will be disregarded: where fiction is used as means of perpetrating fraud; where corporation is organized and operated as mere tool or business conduit of another corporation; where corporate fiction is resorted to as means of evading an existing legal obligation; where corporate fiction is employed to achieve or perpetrate monopoly; where corporate fiction is used to circumvent statute; and where corporate fiction is relied upon as protection of crime or to justify wrong.
Document Preview: Action by husband and wife against finance company, life insurance company, and their common holding company for damages on account of wrongful conduct in seeking to enforce usurious contract. Wife as executrix was substituted for husband upon suggestion of his death. The 44th District Court, Dallas County, Sam B. Hall, J., rendered judgment for plaintiff, and defendants appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Tirey, J., held that the husband's cause of action for exemplary damages survived, and that the judgment was proper except that exemplary damages awarded were excessive. Judgment reformed in conformity with remittitur and affirmed.
